fields.headline: Pull-down menus
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor looks at on the net
fields.body:
Flavour Cookery Holidays
'Can my husband come too?" is one of the questions that tends to be asked by cooks travelling to Provence and Lazio for the Flavour Cookery Holidays. Fear not: there are plenty of activities for men who are not interested in cooking. A local cook leads the Italian classes in the morning and participants can watch the evening meal being prepared; in France, two professional chefs hold courses at a former olive oil mill. Prices start at £699, excluding flights.

Le Baou d'Infer
Le Baou d'Infer is also in Provence, and the classes of six are led by the former director of Le Manoir aux Quat' Saisons' cookery school, Alex Mackay. Courses are only held in June and July and start from £1,185 for a week. Traipsing around local markets is shunned in favour of cooking and relaxing by the swimming-pool and under the mulberry trees.

Cordon Bleu in Paris
If you are looking for lessons in more formal French cooking, Cordon Bleu in Paris is probably the best site to visit. Four-day courses are available in bread-making, viennoiserie and regional cooking; if you have four weeks to spare, the introductions to patisserie and French cuisine (stocks, meat preparation and knife technique) are also open to the public.

Shaw Guides
France and Italy are still the most popular places to learn new cookery skills, and it can be difficult to find holiday courses elsewhere; the best directory is probably Shaw Guides, which is searchable by country.

Prue Leith's School of Food and Wine
Prue Leith's School of Food and Wine in Kensington also has a few specialist summer courses on such topics as Easy Dinner Parties and Fish. These start from £395 for a week.

www.bordeaux.com
If your approach to food and wine is rather more Bacchic - or if these fees seem a lot - you could tour a particular region and rely on free dégustations and improvised meals. The useful site at www.bordeaux.com is an excellent guide to touring the region and it's usually easy to make an appointment at the châteaux - even the celebrated Château d'Yquem.

French Connections
French Connections has a directory of around 600 holiday properties that you can e-mail directly to make a reservation.

There's still time to celebrate the Hunter Valley harvest festival
Hunter Valley harvest festival (held in March and April) in Australia. About 60 miles north of Sydney, it has more than 80 wineries to visit.

webTitle: The train-spotter's guide to England's one-hit wonders

fields.headline: The train-spotter's guide to England's one-hit wonders
fields.standfirst: Jim Whites takes a look at the weider, weirder world of sport
fields.trailText: A new football encyclopaedia is tackling the issue of Football Philosophy.
fields.body:
It sometimes takes a statistics enthusiast to spot the wood among the trees. Hugh Tisdale, one of the brains behind the Philosophy Football empire, has recently turned his attention away from designing T-shirts extolling the cryptic wisdom of everyone from Bill Shankly to Karl Marx, to slip on a much less sartorial item: an anorak.

He has produced what he calls a "graphic history" of Aston Villa. And in case you were wondering whether his tome might include the truth about that alleged incident involving John Gregory, his guitar and Stan Collymore, that's not graphic as in salacious. The book is lavishly illustrated and lovingly detailed, with page after page of statistics presented in more than palatable form. Graphic, in short.

"I suppose we're trying to bring data alive," he says of his project, which already encompasses a graphic history of Chelsea and will soon take in Arsenal, Celtic and Everton. Plus England. And this is where Tisdale has happened across a continuity problem which has plagued English football.

"I've plotted out all the information for the England book," he says. "The problem is we can't present it like a club book because so many players have played so few games for England."

Tisdale has discovered that more than a third of the 1200 men who have proudly worn three lions on their shirt did so for only one international. Typical of the modern game, that. So when was the period that encompassed the most one-hit wonders? During the dithering of the Don Revie era? Or when Graham "I used to be indecisive but now I'm not so sure" Taylor was at the helm?

"Actually," says Tisdale. "It was during the 1920s."

Aston Villa 2000: The Graphic History (Sportsdays, £14.99).

fields.headline: Sheringham smouldering for success
fields.standfirst: Old feud will not distract United's strikers against Leeds tomorrow
fields.trailText: Daniel Taylor speaks to Teddy Sheringham, the striker Manchester United fans will never forget. Remember why?
fields.body:
It is the end of training at Manchester United, and the boisterous mood at their Carrington retreat defies the trials and tribulations ahead at Leeds tomorrow.

Gary Neville saunters into the foyer and demands to know why there is nothing decent on television these days. Next through is Mark Bosnich to look at the newspapers. Someone has taken the Sun and he is not happy. Nicky Butt and Phil Neville share a joke. Everyone seems relaxed. Then the two exceptions to the rule enter and the bonhomie evaporates.

Teddy Sheringham is coming down the staircase as Andy Cole slouches past, through the double doors and outside to his top-of-the-range BMW. For a moment their eyes meet, but just as quickly they look away. Nothing is said, there is no nod goodbye. Just silence.

Like a recalcitrant third-former, Cole has refused to speak to his team-mate since a dressing-room squabble about who was responsible for giving away a goal against Bolton during their first season as colleagues in 1998. Tomorrow, when they are both likely to start this key top-of-the-table Premiership clash, their dispute will have to be forgotten as it is every match day, but for now the friction is palpable.

Raising the subject with Sheringham provokes a tense response. He shifts uneasily, suspicion clouding his eyes. He says he does not want to become embroiled in a slanging match. "If he wants to keep talking about it he can do." Has he known anything like it before? A shake of the head, an uncomfortable smile.

Besides, Sheringham has more pressing concerns. The time is looming when he must choose either to accept a new contract or cash in with a lucrative Bosman transfer for guaranteed first-team football elsewhere. He has been grappling with the decision for months but is no closer to a definitive answer.

"I change from week to week. At the moment I'm starting games so I have a really good feeling about everything. It's contentment coming in to work and feeling that you are achieving something.

"If I was playing week-in week-out, I would have no hesitation about signing. But that's not always the case. Sometimes I look at it and think this is the greatest club in the world, so 20 minutes here and there is not so bad.

"But I have to weigh that up against the job satisfaction of playing regular football somewhere else, because you have to be selfish and I'm never happy with being substitute."

Either way, he cannot lose. He is guaranteed either a handsome pay packet at Old Trafford or a fat signing-on fee with new employers. Yet finance is not the over-riding factor for a man whose range of automobiles acts as evidence that he has hardly been short of a shilling since starting out at Millwall (on £110 a week) 17 years ago.

"London is another swaying factor. I think you are most happy when you are playing where you come from, and there's the fact that my son is down there. He's 11 now and I would like to see more of him. It's very hard up here because of the amount of games. You find yourself always on call and once the Champions League starts again, we will be in on Sundays as well.

"Money is not everything and I'm not a fan of the Bosman rule. It's crazy how the game has gone in the last five years. You read about people on free transfers getting £60,000 or £70,000 per week. Players' wages are astronomical as they are and the money should stay in football. Paying people £20,000 a week is far too much."

Should United win at Elland Road, it would not be presumptuous to assume that another championship winners' medal will soon be added to last season's haul of Premiership, FA Cup and European Cup for a man once baited by choruses of: "Oh Teddy, Teddy, he went to Man United and he won f . . . all".

After last weekend's histrionics, the match has taken on potentially x-rated proportions. Lancaster Gate will be watching, and Sir Alex Ferguson has reiterated that he will not tolerate his players intimidating referees.

"He has spoken to us about the situation and made it clear he doesn't want it happening again," said Sheringham. "I think there are times when you don't realise quite how bad something looks until you see it afterwards and it's like: 'Whoah!' But when you are caught up in the heat of the moment, it's easy sometimes to find yourself contesting decisions.

"It's no different anywhere else but there is always more focus on us. OK, so one of our players was sent off in our last game [Roy Keane at Newcastle] but at the same time there were two brawls going on across the country and all the headlines were about what we were up to again. It would not happen with any other club but I suppose it's part and parcel of being here.

"I can understand all the fuss and I think the FA are right to clamp down on all these different incidents. The more money that is put into the game, the more pressure there is and the referees are right in the middle of it as well. The FA should come down as hard as they need to."

When the dust settles the likelihood is that United's striker-cum-substitute will leave the club at the end of the season. Peter Schmeichel, he confides, has spoken to him about the virtues of Sporting Lisbon and his curriculum vitae has been emailed to every club in Europe.

One thing is for sure, his Old Trafford ties will not be severed easily. At 33, Sheringham still smoulders with ambition. After United, however, the only way tends to be down.

fields.headline: Second chance for eager Bolton
fields.trailText: Jon Brodkin gives a preview of all the matches in two minutes.
fields.body:
Bolton Wanderers have been halted one step from Wembley already this season, by Tranmere in the Worthington Cup. This afternoon they hope to make amends when Charlton visit in the FA Cup quarter-final.

"It's not often you get the chance to go to Wembley but we've two opportunities," said their manager Sam Allardyce. "We missed the first one and we want to make sure we don't miss the second one, so that's an added spur."

The task is no easy one. Charlton came from two goals down to defeat Coventry in the previous round and took a club-record ninth straight league win in midweek.

The only disappointment for Allardyce is that the tie is not considered glamorous enough to televise. "A top-of-the-First-Division side who've won 11 games on the trot against a side which just missed out on a place at Wembley in the Worthington Cup final would have been an attraction," he said.

Bolton's superstitious players believe luck is on their side after they refused to touch the FA Cup when the sponsor AXA brought the trophy to their training ground. Allardyce is not so sure: "I chose not to touch the Worthington Cup and it didn't do me any good."

The game guarantees the presence of at least one First Division side in the semi-finals. Tranmere hope to make it two by beating Newcastle at home tomorrow.

They already have the Worthington Cup final against Leicester to look forward to next weekend and have so far seen off Coventry, West Ham, Sunderland and Middlesbrough in cup combat. But their manager John Aldridge recognises that containing Alan Shearer and Duncan Ferguson is the toughest task of the lot.

"They are on fire, there's no doubt about that," he said. "Last week they were turning over Manchester United and now it's our turn to try to stop them. As a partnership they are red hot and seem to be getting better and better. We have stopped a few top strikers so far in this cup run but this is the sternest test for us."

A stern test awaits Gillingham at Stamford Bridge tomorrow, while Everton take on Aston Villa at Goodison Park. David Unsworth, who won the FA Cup with Everton in 1995, said: "Taking Everton to Wembley would be a big step in the right direction to making this club great again."

Lou Macari has launched legal proceedings against Stoke nearly three years after resigning. He has made a claim for wrongful dismissal but Stoke said: "The club is vigorously defending Mr Macari's claims and is bringing a counter-claim against him in respect of his failure to repay substantial loans made to him while at the club."

Leeds's Harry Kewell is set to make his first appearance for Australia in nine months after being named in the squad to play a friendly in Hungary next week. But first he must recover from an ankle injury which makes him doubtful for tomorrow's game against Manchester United.

fields.headline: Paterson plots another Highland miracle
fields.standfirst: Caley Thistle seek Scottish Cup scalp to follow up their defeat of Celtic
fields.trailText: Steve Paterson Inverness Caledonian Thistle's manager is ready to go ballistic again - you know...
fields.body:
Steve Paterson would not go as far as saying that the fatal accident in which he was involved changed his life. But he does admit it had a profound effect.

The manager of Inverness Caledonian Thistle, the former Highland League club which provided the greatest upset in Scottish football history by beating Celtic 3-1 at Parkhead in the Scottish Cup fourth round, was a passenger in a taxi involved in a head-on crash 13 years ago.

"I suffered injuries down my left side," Paterson explains. "Sadly, the driver of my car was killed. It made me realise that you should not take life for granted. I would like to think the experience made me a better person."

Although able to play again, the former Manchester United striker-cum-centre-back knew he was a shadow of his former self and turned his thoughts to management. Now Caley Thistle's victory over the fifth-best supported club in the world has sent his stock soaring.

Paterson's team were 18-1 rank outsiders when they beat Celtic last week but bookmakers learn quickly and Caley Thistle are just 9-4 to beat Aberdeen in tomorrow night's fourth-round home tie at Caledonian Stadium.

Scrutiny of the 41-year-old Paterson's track record shows he has a measure of that special knack possessed by Sir Alex Ferguson and others like Sir Alf Ramsey, Bob Paisley, Bill Shankly, Brian Clough, Sir Matt Busby and Jock Stein.

In his first year as player-manager, Paterson brought the glory days back to Elgin City by guiding them to the Highland League title. But a short-sighted approach cost them dearly: "I was on £40 a week and my 'reward' was a £10 increase," he says. "It was an insult, so I told them where to go." Elgin's fortunes promptly took a nosedive.

Paterson moved to Huntly, a small farming town and generally regarded as lightweights, but he nevertheless took them to two successive Highland championships.

He joined Caley Thistle in 1995, steered them to third place in the Third Division and the quarter-finals of the Scottish Cup, where they lost 3-0 to Rangers. They clinched the title the following year and have since been promoted to the First Division - their achievements proving the end for three opposing managers along the way.

Victory over Celtic, of course, resulted in John Barnes's swift removal, but earlier wins against Dunfermline and Morton were quickly followed by the departures of their respective managers, Dick Campbell and Billy Stark.

"I feel bad when that happens," Paterson admits, "but that's the nature of the game. The rewards can be great but there is a fine line between success and failure."

While Sir Alex has cited Stein and Busby as big influences on his career, Paterson says he learned a lot from Tommy Docherty. "He signed me as a 16-year-old for Manchester United [Paterson made 12 first-team appearances in all] and eight years later I joined him in Australia with Sydney Olympic.

"Tommy is a larger-than-life character but there can be no denying that his knowledge of the game is tremendous. Martin Buchan, a legend at Old Trafford, told me Docherty was the finest manager he had worked under. He had his flaws, but I'd like to think that some of his ability as a manager rubbed off on me."

Paterson has every reason to hold his head high. He has assembled a team at a cost of approximately £80,000 - less than a month's wages paid to some of the vanquished Celtic players. "I'm particularly proud that nine of the 14 players in that game came from the Highland League," he says.

He has two part-timers - his 40-year-old goalkeeper Jim Calder, who works as a builder, and the striker Martin Bavidge, a student at Aberdeen Univerisity. "Martin is on £60 a week but I'm reviewing his contract. Jim gets £35 but is happy with his lot," he says.

Tomorrow's game, which will be screened on Sky, will be the first time any of his team will have experienced being on live television. "Our ground can only hold 6,200 but there'll be a great atmosphere," Paterson says. "You couldn't have scripted it better - beating Celtic then getting a home tie against Aberdeen, the closest Premier League side to Inverness."

And as for tomorrow's opponents, from recently having the worst record in Europe, Aberdeen now find themselves in the League Cup final, a step away from a quarter-final in the Scottish Cup and thus the only side that can land the treble. Some help would be required from Rangers and Celtic, but football can be a funny game. Just ask any of the 40,000 spectators at Parkhead 11 days ago.

"I'm particularly proud that nine of the 14 players in that game came from the Highland League," he says. He has two part-timers - his 40-year-old goalkeeper Jim Calder, who works as a builder, and the striker Martin Bavidge, a student at Aberdeen Univerisity. "Martin is on £60 a week but I'm reviewing his contract. Jim gets £35 but is happy with his lot," he says. Tomorrow's game, which will be screened on Sky, will be the first time any of his team will have experienced being on live television. "Our ground can only hold 6,200 but there'll be a great atmosphere," Paterson says. "You couldn't have scripted it better - beating Celtic then getting a home tie against Aberdeen, the closest Premier League side to Inverness." And as for tomorrow's opponents, from recently having the worst record in Europe, Aberdeen now find themselves in the League Cup final, a step away from a quarter-final in the Scottish Cup and thus the only side that can land the treble. webTitle: In the name of Geordie, stay

fields.headline: In the name of Geordie, stay
fields.standfirst: Bobby Robson, 67 yesterday, is to go on showing that there is still a good Toon in the old conductor
fields.trailText: Frank Keating on Bobby Robson the suave, debonair, swanky 67-year-old who's taken Newcastle, his lifelong darling, by storm. Oh, by the way they take on Tranmere for the small matter of an FA Cup quarter final tomorrow at Prenton Park.
fields.body:
I wonder if Bobby Robson remembered to ring room service and order himself a glass of champagne after settling his charges in bed at their Warrington hotel last night. The spry and engaging pensioner would have had plenty of reasons to toast himself - even if yesterday had not been his 67th birthday, and even if Newcastle had not marked the date by announcing a 12-month extension to his contract.

Whatever happens in tomorrow's FA Cup quarter-final against Tranmere Rovers, the patriarch Robson's almost biblical resurrection of Newcastle United is one of the most touching stories of this Premiership season. Revival of a corpse is one thing but the colourful dash with which Robson's black-and-whites have been reinvigorated warms the cockles of English football's army of unbiased cognoscenti. Newcastle's ravishing 3-0 defeat of Manchester United alone released a flock of pigeons into the slumberous cattery and recharged the whole championship race.

The added piquancy is that the white-haired prophet is a true north-easterner, a Tooner through and through. His miner father introduced the boy to Newcastle's legendary post-war teams: "Invariably we'd be first in the queue at noon, and I worshipped Albert [Stubbins] and Joe [Harvey], Len [Shackleton] and, of course, Wor Jack [Milburn]."

A half-century ago, on his 17th birthday, young Robson left the Durham pit village of Langley Park to seek fame and fortune in London and beyond. He found both those things and more. He played for England, then managed the national side at two World Cups - when different rubs of the green might have seen England reach the final on both occasions.

Though he was still admired as a masterclass coach in Spain, Portugal and the Netherlands, there remained a classic and ancient football colony that held the fondest place in this wanderer's heart, an inborn allegiance that uplifted his soul for fully 50 years. No prodigal's return to his native north-eastern fields can have been more timely and auspicious than the one Robson finally made last autumn.

Newcastle's red-hot hotbed was no place for the cool Dutchman Ruud Gullit, whose turbulent tenure came to a messy end in September with Newcastle prostrate in the Premiership with one single and laughable point from six matches. Without a farthing to buy a player, and with the club in hock to a stadium refurbishment as costly as it is grand, Robson has in 19 matches amassed 30 points - "each one a separate little miracle," said the local Journal last week - and already almost brought a mid-table serenity. Plus, of course, Newcastle kick off tomorrow only two matches away from Wembley.

The warning shot

An altogether separate miracle is Robson's bonny health. Having been cruelly denied by Diego Maradona's wicked "Hand of God" in 1986, and denied again four years later in that fevered World Cup semi-final shootout with Germany, Robson sought, and achieved, triumphs abroad. Then, five years ago while at Porto, he was diagnosed with cancer in his face. The operations were painful, and so was the treatment.

"Life-threatening? Oh, sure, twice," he says, matter of fact. Within a year he was managing Barcelona. He now looks as perkily fit as a flea. "I'm 66, going on 46. Do you think I'd have taken on Newcastle if I wasn't 110%?"

On a sparkling blue-bright winter's morning at United's swish Chester-le-Street training ground, Robson is first in, hale, grinning and brimming with relish for the day. "Man U last Saturday, Tranmere on Sunday: these are the most crucial days since I've been here," he enthuses. Then, on time and almost in convoy, in come the stream of players' limousines or four-wheel drives, each seemingly more sleek and expensive than the next. Some have chauffeurs. It is more like a motor-show parade than a football centre. Forty-two years ago, Robson celebrated his first cap for England by scraping together a £50 deposit for his first car, a £200 secondhand Morris Minor.

Some balletic "light training", choreographed by a businesslike Robson, is followed by lunch in the clubhouse. That spritely little talent and new talk of the Toon, Kieron Dyer, approaches his manager familiarly.

"Boss, d'you mind if I skip lunch? I've a photo commitment with England in Leeds this afternoon."

"Yes I do mind," Robson says firmly. "You know lunch is between one and two, so you change and go and join your team-mates for it. Ring the people in Leeds and tell them Newcastle United comes first today, and having lunch together is part of the day's training. Then you can easily get down to Leeds."

"Yes, boss. Sorry, boss."

"Wherever I've managed [Fulham, Ipswich, England, PSV Eindhoven, Porto, Barcelona]," Robson explains, "my two watchwords have been order and discipline. I may be found wanting in other areas but those are my tenets. I arrive here and, for whatever reason, everything was slipshod, disordered, laissez-faire, and half the players didn't want to play with the other half.

"So I banned mobile phones. I said English must be the common language; it had been like a Tower of Babel. I insisted the whole team have lunch together.

"Players would drift into lunch, or not, in ones and twos. Others stuck in little cliques, talking their own language. There was a complete lack of comradeship. Now we all sit together, eat together, talk together. Nobody misses. And I must say, as a team-building exercise, the banter and range of conversation has been a joy to behold. And you can see this mutual regard manifesting itself under the most intense pressure on the field of play."

He nods fondly towards top-of-the-table Alan Shearer, England's revitalised ace and a younger Geordie who came back to familiar fields.

"See, the natural leader, the strong personality. I tried to buy Alan for Barcelona when he was a world all-time great in 1996. Blackburn said 'no way' and Ray Harford told me not to mention to a soul I'd bid. 'Fair enough,' I said and I never did. Then a fortnight later Blackburn sold him to Newcastle. Was I furious? They'd have adored Alan in Barcelona. I had to buy Ronaldo instead for $20m.

Shearer revivified

"Alan didn't have the best of relationships with Ruud. They just couldn't gel. A tragedy: they both needed each other. The truth was, however, that Alan's game really had fallen away. I sat him down. Long, intense chats. We talked about his technique, his ambitions. I told him bluntly he'd stopped doing the things which had made him a genuine great. We agreed on a reappraisal, a complete overhaul.

"Some people told me that Newcastle were expecting Alan to do too much. I told them - and him - that he was doing too little, not doing half enough. I told him his whole movement had stopped, that he was just wearily working the parameters of the 18-yard line, going through the motions. Ruud had bought big Duncan [Ferguson] just for Alan, but whisperers said it was as a threat to Alan."

The pepperpots and coffee cups are slid around the table. "See how Alan's responded. It's sensational. He's coming in now from here - or here - or here. He's winging in from all angles, yet he's still in all the close-quartered places where it hurts.

"Look at his movement now, just a half-turn and he's away and clear. His running angles are terrific again, the crucial diagonals or, sometimes, the unstoppable straight line. He is hungry again, greedy for it." Shearer, of course, scored two and had one assist in Saturday's trouncing of Manchester United.

Robson has always had the knack of giving encouragement to the great goalscorers. I first watched him play for West Brom in the 50s, England's athletic non-stop wing-half fetching and carrying for Ronnie Allen and Derek Kevan (one season the three of them shared 77 goals). At ulham in the early 60s he was the stylish head waiter to Johnny Haynes's maitre d'.

I was on the Slough Observer and came to Craven Cottage to write a story on a local kid trialist. Nervously I knocked on the dressing-room door to ask if a first-team player would be photographed shaking hands with our boy. Haynes ignored me, so did Jim Langley, George Cohen and even young Rodney Marsh. But Robson came out, posed for the pic, then spent half an hour encouraging the youngster. That was Robson, enthusiast, romantic, good egg, emotional... plus, of course, order and discipline.

Going home

Ruthless, too, when necessary. This week he put 13 of the vast Newcastle squad he inherited on the transfer list. He had done the same sort of thing 31 winters ago when he went to manage Ipswich and at once had a famous dressing-room fist-fight with two tempestuous old-soldier Celts, Bill Baxter and Tommy Carroll. They might have blacked his eyes - but they never played for Ipswich again. Nor did those who had cheered them on.

So Robson was free to fashion at Portman Road one of the most successful European sides of the 70s. Which set him up for England - and those two notable World Cups in which he stuffed such Sun headlines as "Plonker!" and "In the name of Allah go!" back down the headline-writer's gullet.

"I've been lucky, haven't I? I played with Matthews and Finney, Haynes and Greaves. I managed Lineker and Robson and Gascoigne and Romario and Ronaldo... and Shearer.

"And I came home to England last May to plan my retirement, to put my feet up, watch a bit of cricket. June, July, August... then football starts again, and the hankerings begin, the pangs.

"I'd never experienced the passion, the pace, the international flavours of the Premiership. When Ruud was obviously on the way out here, I admit I 'let it be known' I was free. Only because it was Newcastle, mind, my very roots, my club, and my club was in a perilous position.

"After that I was worried to death I wouldn't get it. Couldn't sleep for worry. But they took the plunge on me for this season.

"I'm content in temporary furnished digs a couple of miles from where I was brought up. And now the chairman has drawn up a new contract. That's a pretty exciting 67th-birthday present, isn't it? That'll do me for my birthday."

The taxi driver takes me the 10 miles to Durham station. "Been seeing our Bobby?" he says. "I'm a good friend of his brother."

On a sudden whim, he switches off the meter at the right fork to Langley Park: "It's only a couple of miles extra. I'll show you where our Bobby used to live." And so he does. A tiny two-up ex-NCB cottage damply clamped in the very middle of a squashed, bleak, doll's house terrace.

"Bob's coming home has worked wonders already," says the taxi driver. "You see, it's always been the case. Only a Geordie can really understand what football means to Geordies."

Bobby Robson is supporting the Portman Group's "I'll be Des" campaign, which encourages fans to designate a non-drinking driver whenever they go out to watch a match.

fields.headline: Hearts flutter over bonnier Clyde
fields.trailText: Scottish FA Cup preview. Ian Archer ponders the imponderable: there may be no Premier League clubs involved in the competition by tomorrow night.
fields.body:
The Scottish Cup today gives a group of unlikely and unfashionable clubs the chance to prove that they are more than merely members of the chorus line of a production that tends to star the same double act.

Astonishingly, there could be no Premier League teams involved in the competition by tomorrow night. That may be a fanciful suggestion but many of the bigger clubs will be feeling vulnerable this weekend.

The defeats of Celtic and Kilmarnock in the last round might just galvanise the more humble brethren. As it is, two out of Berwick Rangers, Falkirk, Partick Thistle and Livingstone will end up just one match away from the semi-finals.

Clyde also have a chance since Hearts will not be keen to visit Broadwood, a ground set alone in fields outside of the new town of Cumbernauld.

The runaway Second Division leaders moved out of their own ramshackle Shawfield, a greyhound track, nearly a decade ago but almost went bust in 1998. Their response was radical; rather than offering a home to ageing players on the way out, they reinvented themselves.

They appointed Ronnie MacDonald as manager, a man with no experience in senior football. They have only one full-time player and instead have brought on a young team with a sense of evangelism that might impress even Sir Alex Ferguson. Their efforts have been rewarded with an improving league place and a £30,000 cheque from the SFA's Gold Award for youth development. They have 200 kids involved and a waiting list half as long.

"They are only allowed to wear Clyde and Scotland jerseys," says MacDonald.

Attendances are up to 1,200, a planning application for a grandstand that will make Broadwood compatible with SPL rules has been lodged and today they meet the 1998 Cup winners.

Morton will face Rangers at Love Street, home of their Renfrewshire rivals St Mirren, in front of an 8,000 crowd after legal challenges to take the tie to Hampden Park - their own Cappilow ground is unsuitable - ended in failure. They should be dispatched but a Dundee United's trip to Alloa looks like an accident waiting to happen.

webTitle: Ferguson puts police on best behaviour

fields.headline: Ferguson puts police on best behaviour
fields.trailText: Alex Ferguson, football's No1 managerial wind-up merchant, has done it again. He's now called on police to protect his players against the "dangerous hostility at Leeds".
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson has taken the unusual step of reminding the police about their responsibilities in an attempt to ensure the safety of his Manchester United players at Leeds tomorrow.

Ferguson believes the hype surrounding the top-of-the-table encounter could lead to a repeat of incidents in previous years when his players and staff have been subjected to intimidation.

"There is a hostility [at Leeds] that borders on the dangerous," he said. "Why the police don't do something about it, I don't know."

Ferguson emphasised at a meeting at the club's Carrington training complex yesterday that he would not tolerate any behaviour from his players that might inflame matters.

"In this particular game dissent is always a concern and I have addressed the situation, as I always do before trips to Leeds. You just have to look at the statistics to see we are the cleanest team in the country this season, but we need to iron out some of the dissent."

webTitle: England play the field at Oakwell

fields.headline: England play the field at Oakwell
fields.standfirst: Record crowd for Portugal's visit reflects rising status of English game
fields.trailText: Come on you gals:a record 5,000 people are expected to watch England's women take on Portugal at Barnsley tomorrow in a European Championship qualifier.
fields.body:
Joe Royle will probably send his apologies but at least 5,000 others are set to brave the cold, turn a blind eye to the numerous televisual offerings and head for Barnsley tomorrow to watch England's female footballers take on their Portuguese counterparts.

It is fitting that a week which saw the Manchester City manager rebuked for airing some less than complimentary views on women's role in the game should end with the long-awaited return of women's international football. And in front of a record crowd, no less.

England are currently second in qualifying group two for the fifth European championship, having won their only match so far 3-0 in Switzerland. The game against Portugal, who are bottom of the table without a point or a goal, is seen as the prelude to next month's potentially decisive clash with much-fancied Norway, the group leaders.

But the Portugal fixture has certainly captured the imagination in south Yorkshire. Coinciding nicely with the return to our screens of Fay Weldon's drama series Playing The Field, the record crowd is a further reminder of the game's burgeoning status, with 34,000 female footballers now registered in England.

"We're the second biggest participation sport in Britain among females now," said the Football Association's Katherine Knight. "We've overtaken hockey and there's only netball to beat now. And we've got them in our sights.

"It looks like it's going to be a record crowd of over 5,000, which would be amazing considering all the football that's on television on Sunday. We had 4,917 for a match against Germany at Millwall last year but we're set to have even more on Sunday.

"It's our first competitive home match for nearly a year, we've even had Kevin Keegan to one of our training sessions this week, and we've got people from all the girls' and women's teams all over the country coming."

They may be coming from all parts of England but a sizeable proportion of those present will be rooting for the prolific Doncaster Belles forward Karen Walker, the local girl made good.

Walker, a lifelong Barnsley fan, has longed for the day she would play in a front of a home crowd at her beloved Oakwell.

"I really can't believe I'm actually going to be playing for England at Oakwell," said the 30-year-old striker. "I've got nearly 50 caps but this is going to be the biggest by far. My family all watch Barnsley every week and I still go whenever I can, even though I live in Hull now."

The form book suggests that the visitors will hardly spoil Walker's big day. But three points remains the priority.

And in front of a record crowd, no less. England are currently second in qualifying group two for the fifth European championship, having won their only match so far 3-0 in Switzerland. fields.headline: Dibbs, yobs and boob jobs (allegedly)
fields.trailText: Tuesday
fields.body:
Tuesday

With no game this weekend we is on a week's R&R at the El Dorado resort hotel, Morecambe, resting limbs exhausted by the continual round of legging it from reporters. Not to mention relaxing the muscles in the accelerator foot what have been strained by gunning the engine to get away from the prying lens of the paparazzi.

I is in me bed recovering after a night of unwind when the mobe rings. "All right, Rodders," I says when I've finally extricated it from under the tangle of limbs and clothing on the floor of me room what turns out to be Vic, Bob and several members of the Morecambe and district ladies rugby league team. "What now?"

"It's not Rodders, Dazz," says this voice. "It's Tristan from BBC Hereford and Worcester. I'm doing a feature on footballers behaving badly and wondered if I might have your comments on last night's incident."

"Listen, mate, I never saw the incident. Where I was stood in the bar, there was absolutely no sign of any problem and any suggestion that, as the result of forfeits in a drinking game, Mick Watts leapt on to a table top wearing only the landlady's Wonderbra while one of the Bosnians gargled the Serb national anthem with his head immersed in a bucket of creme de menthe are entirely media speculation."

"Oh, right," says Tristan. "Actually, Dazz, I was talking about Gazza breaking his arm smacking an opponent."

"Gazza?" I says. "When will he ever grow up?"

Wednesday

Spent most of last night helping Morecambe police with their inquiries. Only too glad to be of assistance, after Hermann and Darko got surrounded on the prom by a bunch of local lads what couldn't stop sniggering at their new Prada puffa jackets and Valentino ankle boots.

"As you'll appreciate, this is a very serious matter," says one of the dibble. "At midnight last night two of the Greens squad were seen running in a northerly direction along the prom pursued by a pack of youths brandishing baseball bats, and in the chase one of said players was seen to raise what appeared to be a two-fingered salute. You will realise that we take such provocative behaviour very seriously and are obliged to investigate thoroughly."

Phew, thank God for the dibbs, I think, as Hermann and Darko is led off. If it wasn't for their vigilance the yobs of Britain might be unable to go about the business of abusing footballers without fear of being subjected to a v-sign in response.

After the dibbs has taken a DNA sample from us all (Wattsy already pants-filling in case they pass his on to the Child Support Agency) there's a training session on the beach to brush up on our dissent skills, followed by a stroll to the Greens' MegaStore on the prom and a work-out of the right wrist signing a stockpile of last year's duvet covers. And the media reckons we have it easy.

Me signing duties is interrupted by Rodney belling. "If you can drag yourself away from the fleshpots of Morecambe's Latin quarter tonight," he says, "there's a long 'un to be had appearing on Ron Atkinson's new hard-hitting chat show on Central. The subject: whatever happened to loyalty in football?"

"Sod that, Rodds," I says. "What you doing about me new contract? Tell Mr Bleedin' So-called Chairman that if his club hasn't got the ambition to keep the likes of Darren Tackle, then Darren Tackle will be instructing his agent to find him a club what has."

"Yeah, yeah, yeah," says Rodney. "I told him that six months ago."

"And? What did he say?"

"Oh, is that the time?" says Rodds. "Must dash, got a call on me other line. Speakcha."

"Don't avoid the question," I says. "What did he say?"

"I've just told you, boy. That is what he said."

Thursday

Have you seen the pictures in the paper? Posh Spice on the catwalk, skin-tight trollies, charlies on red alert, looking like she's got a pair of corks stuck up her jumper? Wattsy has already opened a book on whether she's had a breast-enhancement surgery, and yours truly's been given the job of ringing Becks to get furthers and betters.

"Boob job?" Becks says when I finally track him down to the Manchester branch of Nicole Farhi, where he's stocking up on Brooklyn's designer nappies. "No, she's got a good job. She's in a pop group."

webTitle: Benfica must pay Thomas his due

fields.headline: Benfica must pay Thomas his due
fields.trailText: Michael Thomas' misery at Benfica lifted a little yesterday when Fifa ordered the Portuguese club to pay him almost £750,000 in wages and signing-on fees.
fields.body:
Michael Thomas' misery at Benfica lifted a little yesterday when Fifa ordered the Portuguese club to pay him almost £750,000 in wages and signing-on fees.

The former Arsenal and Liverpool midfielder has not been paid since he was dropped early in the season. Thomas took his case to Fifa, whose players' status committee ruled he is owed £728,331, including 15% interest. Benfica have 20 days to appeal to Fifa's executive committee and are thought to be in dire financial straights.

But Thomas' agent, Michael Kennedy, was upbeat: "Michael's glad the decision's been made and looks forward to the receipt of his money."

Benfica's response sounded positive, though their insistence last night that they had not been notified of the ruling surprised Fifa. World football's governing body said the decision was conveyed to the national federation, as is standard, yesterday morning.

"Until we get official notification we are not prepared to comment," Benfica said. "However in principle we will respect the decision."

Thomas has been a virtual outcast since he was discarded by Benfica's coach Jupp Heynckes and demoted to the B squad. He has trained regularly and did make a couple of appearances for the B team, but for three months he has cut a lonely figure.

Unpaid, unwanted but unwilling to leave without his money, Thomas lost patience this month and accused the club of racism. Benfica's claim that he would be thrown out unless he retracted his comments proved an idle threat.

According to sources close to the club, the treatment meted out to the 32 year old is a standard tactic when a top Portuguese team want rid of a player. "They simply wanted him to go," said Jose Manuel Delgado, journalist for the sports paper Record and a former Benfica player. "But it was an awful way to behave."

How easy it will be for Benfica to pay Thomas remains to be seen. The decision could hardly come at a worse time for the club, whose directors are engaged in a battle for control.

Benfica also have basketball, cycling and ice hockey teams, all of whom are said to have had financial problems of late.

The cycling team came within a whisker of being relegated to the Third Division after the club failed to pay the annual deposit to the UCI, cycling's governing body. At the last minute a private backer came to the rescue.

Meanwhile Thomas, whose contract ends in June, will continue training and wait for his money. After that a move home could be on the cards. "Some people have expressed interest in him," Kennedy said, "but it's too early to say."

 The Football Association has written to Chelsea asking to see video footage from a closed-circuit television camera in the tunnel in which players and staff from Chelsea and Wimbledon clashed last weekend. The FA hopes the tape will shed light on what occurred, although police describe the camera's view as "limited".

webTitle: England escape from another fine mess

fields.headline: England escape from another fine mess
fields.standfirst: Hussain's men show talent for farce in a nail-biting win over Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: We have had epic storms in recent weeks and enough rain to sink Noah and his ark but somehow England contrived to make even heavier weather of it yesterday when they beat Zimbabwe by a single wicket to go 2-0 up in the four-match series.
fields.body:
We have had epic storms in recent weeks and enough rain to sink Noah and his ark but somehow England contrived to make even heavier weather of it yesterday when they beat Zimbabwe by a single wicket to go 2-0 up in the four-match series.

Set a very modest 132 to win this 48-over match they were swaggering along at 120 for five when suddenly they lost four wickets for five runs in the space of four overs.

In the miserable lexicon of England batting collapses there have been worse than this. But in the miserable context of almost throwing away a match that already seemed won there has been little to beat this latest episode. With seven runs still required the unlikely pair of Darren Gough and Alan Mullally were asked to see England safe home.

First Gough leg-glanced a stray Gary Brent delivery to the fine-leg boundary to bring the target down to three. Then, after the pair had survived an over of left-arm spin from Dirk Viljoen, Mullally edged Brent wide of the slips to the third-man boundary.

The captain Nasser Hussain said afterwards: "Every time I come to Bulawayo I seem to be sat in the stands chewing off my fingernails. We can't collapse like that on a pretty good wicket. There is not much point in me banging heads together but the lads do know the score. The important thing is we won the game and are 2-0 up."

The result might have been different had the home captain Andy Flower kept one of his best bowlers back for the death. But Heath Streak, Henry Olonga and his brother Grant Flower, with his teasing left-arm spin, had all been bowled out as Zimbabwe desperately looked for another breach earlier in the innings.

England did not get off to a good start. Nick Knight was given caught behind off Streak in the first over. In his next over Streak had Hussain lbw, pushing forward to only the sixth delivery he faced.

As long as Graeme Hick remained, though, England still looked comfortable. But he was third out with the score on 30 in the 11th over, top-edging a pull for the wicketkeeper-captain to take a simple catch.

This brought together the young batsmen Darren Maddy and Vikram Solanki, both with much to prove. Puzzlingly, though with a required run-rate of just over two an over they were impatient to dominate the bowlers.

In the over that saw his demise, Maddy looked most uncomfortable. First he swatted Brent over extra cover and stood there admiring his shot, expecting it to go for four. It failed to make it, and Solanki had completed one run before Maddy even started to move.

Maddy then escaped an attempted stumping, top-edged a hook and was finally caught at deep backward square leg when he pulled a leg-stump long hop. In entertainment terms, not bad for a single over.

Solanki's head was equally hot and he was caught sweeping Grant Flower to short fine leg for 24. This is a flair player with plenty of strokes but sometimes he plays too many of them when the situation calls for a little restraint.

None of this seemed to matter when Craig White and Mark Ealham formed a happy alliance. White had been outstanding earlier with the ball, returning the third-best figures by an England bowler in a one-day international of 10-1-21-5. Now he batted with composure, and with the more violent Ealham added 47 in 15 overs.

The overs never mattered, of course, but the wickets did. And they mattered even more when, at 120, White drove Olonga to point. Then we had the familiar panic. Two overs later Chris Read flicked to midwicket and at once Ealham, who had hit two fours and a six in his 32, was lbw to Brent; 125 for eight. In the next over, without addition, Andrew Caddick was bowled by Viljoen and it was left to the last pair to ease England home with 22 balls to spare.

The conditions only partially explained a disappointing day for batsmen. Yes, it was cloudy, the outfield was slow and the damp pitch offered seam movement. But par for this surface was about 200.

Zimbabwe, having been put in by Hussain, looked like scoring at least that when Neil Johnson made his usual confident start, taking six off the first over and eventually hitting four fours in a 44-ball 30.

White, bowling with accuracy, economy and some pace, took five wickets in succession and when Zimbabwe slipped to 102 for eight it looked easy for England. But nothing is easy for England's batsmen these days.

 Pakistan are to release Shoaib Akhtar to Nottinghamshire on May 26 at the end of their three-Test Caribbean tour. The so-called Rawalpindi Express's bowling action was effectively cleared by the International Cricket Council recently.

webTitle: Aussies still ignoring their best opener

fields.headline: Aussies still ignoring their best opener
fields.trailText: This week, the Australian one-day team set off for New Zealand on the latest leg of their all-conquering summer. And once again they have left the country's best opening batsman behind. Presumptuous though it may seem to criticise the team selection of a nation that has just won seven Tests in a row, it doesn't mean there's no room for improvement.
fields.body:
This week, the Australian one-day team set off for New Zealand on the latest leg of their all-conquering summer. And once again they have left the country's best opening batsman behind. Presumptuous though it may seem to criticise the team selection of a nation that has just won seven Tests in a row, it doesn't mean there's no room for improvement.

In an otherwise exemplary batting line-up, the opening partnership has failed, relatively speaking, to deliver the goods on several occasions. Nearly all the runs it has produced have come from Michael Slater, while Greg Blewett continues to look edgy and uncomfortable against the new ball. He was the only one of Australia's top seven not to help himself to a century against the rather ineffective bowling attacks of Pakistan and India during the recent series; he did manage two scores in the 80s, but then so did Shane Warne, batting at No.8. It might be time for a change at the top of the order, and although various names have been touted, nobody seems to have mentioned the obvious choice - Jamie Cox of Tasmania.

Consider the evidence. First, Cox consistently scores lots of runs - his record of 10,445 first-class runs at 44.44 is easily comparable to Slater's and Blewett's. Secondly, he's in form - in his last two matches he has scored a quickfire 101 against Western Australia and a whopping 245 against New South Wales. But the important thing about Cox is not just the number of runs he scores, but the way in which he does it. He's been virtually carrying the entire Tasmanian order for a couple of years now: the once-prolific David Boon was definitely winding down towards the end of his career, Dene Hills hasn't been nearly as reliable as usual, Ricky Ponting is hardly ever available, and Michael Di Venuto is only just starting to come into his own as a supporting act. If Cox can produce that many runs under that sort of pressure, who can say how he would perform surrounded by players of a higher standard?

Leaving him out of the New Zealand tour is foolish, and if he continues next season for Somerset where he left off last year it would be absolutely criminal to omit him from next year's Ashes squad. England's apparent policy of 'pick 'em and drop 'em' has been - quite rightly - criticised. But one chance is better than none, as Cox and others like him would probably testify. And the way he's been playing, one chance would probably be enough.

Catherine Hanley, 27, teaches at Sheffield University, and is halfway through a PhD on medieval French literature and history. She comes from Australia, and supports Tasmania and Somerset, though she insists she was a Somerset fan before Cox took over the captaincy there last summer.

England's apparent policy of 'pick 'em and drop 'em' has been - quite rightly - criticised. But one chance is better than none, as Cox and others like him would probably testify. And the way he's been playing, one chance would probably be enough. Catherine Hanley, 27, teaches at Sheffield University, and is halfway through a PhD on medieval French literature and history. She comes from Australia, and supports Tasmania and Somerset, though she insists she was a Somerset fan before Cox took over the captaincy there last summer.

webTitle: Warne flares up after teenager catches him smoking

fields.headline: Warne flares up after teenager catches him smoking
fields.trailText: Shane Warne is said to have snapped after a 15-year-old boy photographed him smoking a cigarette during Australia's opening match of their New Zealand tour.
fields.body:
Shane Warne is said to have snapped after a 15-year-old boy photographed him smoking a cigarette during Australia's opening match of their New Zealand tour.

Wellington television news yesterday reported that police were called in at the city's WestpacTrust Stadium on Thursday to intervene in a dispute between Warne and the teenager and his father.

Australia's vice-captain, who took part in a very public sponsored bid to give up smoking last year, had been told by the youth that he could have the film after more pictures of the action had been taken. When rain cut the match short, Warne again demanded the film and, it is alleged, grabbed the youth's bag and swore at him. A security guard then called in the police.

"Mr Warne was upset by the fact that he was photographed smoking," said Inspector Greg Gilpin, and had "probably over-reacted". The youth, he added, "was certainly agitated and upset by what had occurred."

The leg-spinner must be a little touchy on the subject of smoking after being photographed with a cigar ette on Australia's tour of the West Indies last year.

Warne had been paid A$200,000 (£80,000) for quitting for four months by a nicotine chewing gum maker but the snap showed he was still the same Shane.

fields.headline: Rescuing the wrecks
fields.standfirst: Why are empty homes allowed to rot when there is a national housing shortage? Elizabeth Langton looks at the problem and some of the solutions
fields.trailText: Why are empty homes allowed to rot when there is a national housing shortage? Elizabeth Langton looks at the problem and some of the solutions
fields.body:
The government is facing a national housing shortage and widespread homelessness, yet the number of homes standing empty has shot up, official figures revealed this week. More than 750,000 properties were left empty in England last year - a rise of 11,500 on the previous year and the first since 1993.

The news comes as ministers are urging planners and housebuilders to put every inch of land in urban areas to good use before building on greenfield sites. Abandoned properties are a magnet for petty crime, vandalism and drug dealing and with their steel or boarded up doors and windows make for depressing eyesores. Living next door to an empty home can also knock 10% off the value of your own property, say experts.

The Empty Homes Agency, a charity campaigning to bring empty properties back into use, says the sharpest rise in abandoned properties was in the private sector where more than a third had been empty for a year or more.

But, says Ashley Horsey, the charity's chief executive, there are almost as many reasons behind the abandonment as there are properties. "Maybe it belongs to grandad who's moved into hospital or long-term care. The family might not live in the area or have forgotten about it.

"Many people are scared of becoming landlords. Too often people have said to us they would rather keep the property vacant than risk having a bad tenant." Owners might not have the money for extensive repairs or be unaware of grants. And with prices shooting through the roof in some parts of the country, owners are biding their time before they sell.

Although 53% of empty homes are in the north and midlands, the rest are in south, east and west of the country. "There are 112,000 empty homes in London alone," says Mr Horsey, "And there is no shortage of people who want to live in the capital."

Councils can take action against owners whose buildings become dangerous structures or an environmental health hazard because of fly-tipping. The ultimate sanction is a compulsory purchase order but, says Mr Horsey: "An empty property strategy should be as much about encouraging the owners of empty properties to do something with them as it is about sanctions."

The Empty Homes Agency says major changes are needed to bring large swathes of housing stock back into service. About 150 councils have yet to introduce an empty property strategy; Mr Horsey says this should be a statutory duty.

In Slough, the council, Ealing Family Housing Association and a regeneration agency pooled resources to breathe new life into empty properties. The housing association bought and refurbished 45 properties in the town centre which were then let to people on the council's housing list. A derelict space around a Blockbuster Video in the high street was turned into eight flats. In Warwick, the district council appointed an empty property officer to set about "knocking heads together and push private sector landlords to bring empty homes back into use", says spokesman Derek Dyas. But he became a victim of his own success: as the number of empty properties dwindled there wasn't enough of a problem to justify a dedicated officer.

Where empty properties do pop up, the council is taking an innovative approach. Some owners want to bring empty properties back into use but can't afford the repairs. In its current state the property may not be worth enough to secure a loan. The Nationwide building society has agreed to lend money for repairs if the local authority underwrites the loan.

"The building society lends on how much it would be worth when all repairs are done. For example, a home worth £50,000 derelict may be worth £100,000 when repaired. The building society would lend on £100,000. We have an approved list of contractors so it is a relatively safe bet for the council," says Mr Dyas. Soon, a large, double-fronted regency building in Leamington Spa will be brought back to life thanks to the scheme.

The Empty Homes Agency says the government must end perverse incentives to keep homes empty by letting local authorities charge full council tax on properties that owners are making no effort to bring back into use: at present empty homes are charged half the normal rate.

Mr Horsey wants to end the discrepancy where VAT is zero rated on new homes but charged at 17.5% for refurbishing existing homes and to harmonise the rate at 5% for both.

The agency is calling upon the public to report abandoned properties to the local authority. London residents can call the Empty Homes Hotline 0870-901-6303 where staff can ensure that councils are aware of the property and its state.

Those interested in rescuing an old wreck can trace its owner for just £4 via the Land Registry which holds details of who owns property in England and Wales.

The government must act now to reverse the rise in empty properties, says Mr Horsey. With seven empty properties for every homeless person in England alone, there's no excuse to let what could be good homes rot.

webTitle: Michael Collins: Sleeping bag | Bovril | A relic of St Therese

fields.headline: Michael Collins never travels without...
fields.trailText: Sleeping bag | Bovril | A relic of St Therese
fields.body:
A necessity: In the Antarctic, Arctic and high into the Himalayas, I've found the necessity is a sleeping bag rated to at least -40F.

A luxury: A jar of Bovril. For a quick fix when you're cold and exhausted, a scalding cup of Bovril tastes like a feast.

A good-luck charm: I always take a relic of St Therese, a small bone fragment in a glass case. I was given it for being a member of a winning Catholic Football League team when I was young. They didn't give medals, only saintly parts as prizes. The bishop who blessed it said the person wearing it would never die of unnatural causes. At the age of nine, that made sense. Well, I'm still alive, so who knows.

If only: To be honest, in the extreme sports arena, the harder the conditions the better. It's all about surviving extreme temperatures, days without food and rest, distance travelled, near-death experience, etc. That said, there is one thing I would like to see invented: a better seasickness medication. There is nothing so humiliating and terrifying as being trapped at sea, curled in the fetal position, believing your boat is about to capsize.

 Michael Collins is a novelist and extreme sports enthusiast. His latest novel, The Keepers of the Truth, is published by Phoenix House at £9.99.

fields.headline: Heart of the Matterhorn
fields.standfirst: Climbers have come here for 150 years, but skiing is a recent development.  Nicky Holford discovers an unspoilt valley
fields.trailText: Climbers have come here for 150 years, but skiing is a recent development. Nicky Holford discovers an unspoilt valley
fields.body:
Once a month, on the night of the full moon, locals and visitors find their way to the small Swiss village of Grimentz in the Val d'Anniviers to see the "vue panoramique" by moonlight.

After the traditional fondue supper at the restaurant at the top of the gondola, you are launched into your skis and thrust on to a button lift going at full speed. Two more lifts take you to the top, from where you look out on to some of the world's most famous mountains circling the twinkling lights in the distant valley. Then you ski down the 1,200m descent by moonlight back to Grimentz and a welcoming vin chaud.

For beginners and intermediates, the Val d'Anniviers are five separate ski areas with gentle slopes and a variety of terrain and scenery. For adventurous skiers, the off piste is paradise with long descents and easy returns to civilisation by an efficient free bus service. If you are prepared to put skins on your skis, an hour's touring leads to unlimited skiing.

And if skiing is something you prefer to leave to others, you can join the locals for a spot of ice-fishing or follow the footsteps of the great Victorian climber Edward Whymper who first stayed here in 1859.

The valley is still beautiful and unspoilt. Five mountains over 4,000m, including the Matterhorn, make up the "Imperial Crown" and provide spectacular views. No British tour operators, with the exception of the independent-travel specialist Inntravel, have yet penetrated the French-speaking valley. While mass tourism is no doubt on the way, it is a joy to visit small Alpine villages that have remained largely unchanged for well over 400 years.

The small heart of Grimentz is a collection of ancient wooden dwellings with uneven walls and roofs bowing from the weight of snow and passage of time. The narrow, winding streets are barely wide enough for two people to walk side by side.

In a country where most inhabitants speak three languages fluently, we were surprised by the lack of English speakers. But the Anniviards are very hos pitable and never in a hurry.

Once, while skiing from Zinal on a beautiful route to Grimentz, we were invited by the director of the lift company to his " mayen ", a summer cattle shed across the pastures and through the trees. His had been in the family for generations.

There was a pot-bellied fire in a simple room with wood walls and floor, and a communal sleeping room. Fendant , the local white wine, flowed, cheese and bread were passed around. Eventually, we trekked back to our skis, through knee-high snow and set off in the dark down a winding cart-track. The route through the forest and along a trickling stream took us straight to our hotel where chamois steaks awaited us.

The practicals

The Switzerland Travel Centre (020 7734 1921) can book flights, rail tickets, car hire, accomodation and package holidays. Inntravel (01653 9629002) offers seven nights' half board in St Luc inc flights.

webTitle: 'Think of Cecil B DeMille shooting a ballet as a Biblical epic'

fields.headline: 'Think of Cecil B DeMille shooting a ballet as a Biblical epic'
fields.standfirst: Alex Bellos at the world's biggest fancy dress party
fields.trailText: Alex Bellos at the world's biggest fancy dress party.
fields.body:
The outfit was marvellously camp. It wasn't just the tight red swimming trunks peeking out from behind the red patterned loin-cloth that made me feel particularly outrageous. Nor was it the bracelets with their dangling red streamers, the wooden shoulder frame from which draped fake white fur, the two feathered wings, nor even the Roman centurion's hat made from plastic sea-shells. The extravagance was in the visual overload; the mix of the contemporary, the historical and the fantastical. Who was I supposed to be? An Amazonian indian god, Genghis Khan's gay younger brother or the flamboyant missing member of Village People?

In fact, I was a figure inspired by the life of Anita Garibaldi, a Brazilian version of Joan of Arc - a local girl who married and fought alongside the 19th-century Italian freedom-fighter Giuseppe Garibaldi when he was in South America. Anita Garibaldi was something of a tough cookie - some would say flat and speckled with raisins - spending her honeymoon in armed naval conflict.

Garibaldi has been mythologised as a warrior-heroine. As such, she is the perfect subject for mystical interpretation, hinting on wider themes such as religion, femininity and nationalism. When seen through the eyes of Joãsinho Trinta, who designed the costumes, she could have been anything from a witch to a queen, a transvestite pop star or a jungle animal. Even though Garibaldi was the theme of Trinta's parade in 1999, the costumes said more about him than her.

Trinta is also something of a myth in Brazilian culture. A tiny man, whose resemblence to a ventriloquist's puppet is accentuated by a paralysed arm, he's the one who many - himself especially - believe made the carnival parade the luxurious visual and cultural tour- de-force that it is today. Trinta is Brazil's most famous carnavalesco , the name given to the creative directors of each of the samba schools whose parades light up the Sambadrome through the carnival's steamy nights. Trinta was the first to camp up the performances, to make them a symbol of excess and extravagance. At first, commentators thought this an affront to the poverty of most of the people taking part, but it was the poor who adored it most of all.

Sitting on the pavement in full regalia at 2am, awaiting my turn to dance down the Sambadrome's narrow arena, I pondered the irony that tourists like myself and rich Brazilians now paid high prices for appearing as lavishly attired as people who earn about £50 a month.

The analogy that is always used to describe how the carnival parade works is football. This is a doubly good explanation considering that football is about the only other thing most people know about Brazil. There are 14 main samba schools, and they function like football clubs - they have team colours, fanatical supporters and a home ground - the carnavalescos are the managers, and the carnival is like the league - an annual competition to see who is best. Every year, each school chooses a different theme and a different song to go with it.

But the football analogy fails to capture the dimensions, organisational complications and artistic resonances of the event. I'd say think of Cecil B DeMille shooting a ballet as a Biblical epic - seven times a night, once for each of the seven samba schools who parade during the two principle nights. Each school's parade consists of around 4,000 people in about 40 different types of costume, with about seven enormous floats pushed along by teams (it's hard not to think of Biblical slaves or Roman galleons), choreographed dancers and a rhythm section of about 500 drummers.

As well as the swelter of the humid climate, the atmosphere is prickled with the heat of excitement and competition. There is a constant pressure that everything is under scrutiny: the quality of the drumming, the way the carnavalesco has developed the theme, the tune of the samba being sung. The unregulated exuberance is, in fact, strictly regulated. If you dilly-dally down the Sambadrome, you are penalised. Everyone - even the foreigners who turn up - can lose the day for the team.

To really enjoy the experience, it's best to come prepared. In my case, this was making sure my swimming trunks were bright red (to fit in with the rest of the costume) and learning the words to the samba (as you are expected to sing while you parade). I only knew I would be parading 24 hours before, so this meant getting a taped copy of the song and learning it by rote.

The Sambadrome is a kilometre-long stretch of walkway with stands on either side. It was designed by Oscar Niemayer, the architect who created the concrete minimalist city of Brasilia. Backstage, so to speak, is central Rio's main avenue, where all the floats and the paraders wait for their turns. Here, it really does look like the set of an epic film. Tens of thousands of people in costume walking around, drinking beer, eating hotdogs as thousands of those who couldn't get tickets for the Sambadrome mingle and look on.

I was to parade surrounded by about 40 other similarly attired people. As the zero hour approached, a member of the samba school who was in charge of our section came and gave us a pep talk. All we had to do was sing, dance and look happy. Easy. Well, not quite. At about 4am, the samba school I was with, Viradouro, moved into place at the beginning of the Sambadrome. We stood up, got in line and then heard our drummers kick off. As we started parading, Viradouro helpers lined the side of the avenue and, like the bike fans who giddy-up cyclists on the Tour de France, they yelled orders: "Smile! Smile! Be Happy." I don't think I've ever looked so terrified.

For about an hour, it was a total high. You can feel the sense of pride and happiness of both the paraders and the crowds by the looks on people's faces, by the interaction between the audience and the spectacle. On the tops of the floats are Brazilian celebrities and models. It's like a showcase of their own hopes and desires. Critics say that the carnival has sold out to tourists. I did not sense that at all. I felt it was an uncompromising celebration of Brazilianness.

This did not exclude me from the party. Like many other parts of Brazilian life, the carnival fosters a communnal inclusivity you do not get in Europe. Brazil is not a country where people like to be different - perhaps because racially and socially, there is no country so diverse. People like to share, to be as one - and being a foreigner does not forbid you from feeling part of this.

The carnival experience is not over when you walk out the Sambadrome, though. The climax is the judging a few days later, which is as drawn out and as melodramatic as the Eurovision Song Contest. Broadcast live on television from a stage on the Sambadrome - with cameras also positioned at every competing samba school, the city is glued to the screen.

For such a popular occasion, much of the judging is steadfastly highbrow. (Give or take a few kickbacks between the mafia bosses who bankroll many of the schools). Experts in music, dance and art, historians and journalists are among those who do the scoring. The Brazilian equivalent of Terry Wogan comperes and milks every last drop of tension. The result marks the end of carnival, and the closing images are of hundreds of people swarming to the winning samba school to celebrate.

Last year, unfortunately, the winner was not Viradouro, despite being one of the favourites. However, I feel fairly confident that my novice parading skills played no part in our downfall. We wuz robbed.

Don't just stand and watch

Carnival 2000 takes place from Saturday March 4 to Tuesday March 7. All the samba schools have chosen themes related to the 500th anniversary of the first Europeans landing in Brazil.

On the two main nights, Sunday and Monday, 14 samba schools parade, each made up of about 4,000 people - which makes 56,000 dressed in ridiculous outfits, or the largest fancy dress party in the world. There is always space for some tourists.

Within each school's parade, there are several different sections with separate costumes, each called an "ala". Some will be just for members of the community where the school is based, but others will be open to anyone who is willing to pay. In fact, the latter subsidise the former by charging middle-class Brazilians and foreigners quite large fees for the costumes, whereas local people get theirs free.

You can pay anything from £50 for a simple costume from one of the less glamorous schools, to more than £100 for one from the top schools.

Travel agencies sometimes arrange a costume as part of a package. But once you are in Rio, you can do it yourself. Ask your hotel receptionist to call the alas who are selling outfits. Once you've got your costume, you learn the words to the school's song and turn up in time on the day.

This year, the process has been made simpler thanks to the internet, where some of the big schools have their own websites. The most detailed is by the Salgueiro samba school, which has a list of almost all the costumes from all 44 of its alas. Previously, each school's costumes were a closely-guarded secret.

You can chose to be Napoleon, an Indian spice merchant, a botanical garden, or even "Beneficent England" - dressed in red stockings, with a Union Jack coming out your back and a globe on your head. Next to each picture is a contact number.

Other good sites are Viradouro, and Beija-Flor. The Independent League of Samba Schools also has useful links.

The practicals

Bales Worldwide (01306 732718) offers seven nights at the Luxor Regente Hotel (room only), Copacabana, for £14445pp based on two sharing and including BA return flights, transfers and a grandstand seat at the carnival parade. Eight nights at the Caesar Park Hotel (deluxe room), Ipanema, with BA Club class flights, transfers and a special chair at the Carnival parade, costs £3695. STA (0870 1606070) has return fares to Rio for £288 plus £27 tax. The fare is open to all and valid from London, Manchester, Edinburgh and Birmingham for departures until March 31.
