A tiny man, whose resemblence to a ventriloquist's puppet is accentuated by a paralysed arm, he's the one who many - himself especially - believe made the carnival parade the luxurious visual and cultural tour- de-force that it is today. Trinta is Brazil's most famous carnavalesco , the name given to the creative directors of each of the samba schools whose parades light up the Sambadrome through the carnival's steamy nights. Trinta was the first to camp up the performances, to make them a symbol of excess and extravagance. At first, commentators thought this an affront to the poverty of most of the people taking part, but it was the poor who adored it most of all. Sitting on the pavement in full regalia at 2am, awaiting my turn to dance down the Sambadrome's narrow arena, I pondered the irony that tourists like myself and rich Brazilians now paid high prices for appearing as lavishly attired as people who earn about £50 a month. The analogy that is always used to describe how the carnival parade works is football. This is a doubly good explanation considering that football is about the only other thing most people know about Brazil. There are 14 main samba schools, and they function like football clubs - they have team colours, fanatical supporters and a home ground - the carnavalescos are the managers, and the carnival is like the league - an annual competition to see who is best. Every year, each school chooses a different theme and a different song to go with it. But the football analogy fails to capture the dimensions, organisational complications and artistic resonances of the event. I'd say think of Cecil B DeMille shooting a ballet as a Biblical epic - seven times a night, once for each of the seven samba schools who parade during the two principle nights. Each school's parade consists of around 4,000 people in about 40 different types of costume, with about seven enormous floats pushed along by teams (it's hard not to think of Biblical slaves or Roman galleons), choreographed dancers and a rhythm section of about 500 drummers. As well as the swelter of the humid climate, the atmosphere is prickled with the heat of excitement and competition. There is a constant pressure that everything is under scrutiny: the quality of the drumming, the way the carnavalesco has developed the theme, the tune of the samba being sung. The unregulated exuberance is, in fact, strictly regulated. If you dilly-dally down the Sambadrome, you are penalised. Everyone - even the foreigners who turn up - can lose the day for the team. To really enjoy the experience, it's best to come prepared. In my case, this was making sure my swimming trunks were bright red (to fit in with the rest of the costume) and learning the words to the samba (as you are expected to sing while you parade). I only knew I would be parading 24 hours before, so this meant getting a taped copy of the song and learning it by rote. The Sambadrome is a kilometre-long stretch of walkway with stands on either side. It was designed by Oscar Niemayer, the architect who created the concrete minimalist city of Brasilia. Backstage, so to speak, is central Rio's main avenue, where all the floats and the paraders wait for their turns. Here, it really does look like the set of an epic film. Tens of thousands of people in costume walking around, drinking beer, eating hotdogs as thousands of those who couldn't get tickets for the Sambadrome mingle and look on. I was to parade surrounded by about 40 other similarly attired people. As the zero hour approached, a member of the samba school who was in charge of our section came and gave us a pep talk. All we had to do was sing, dance and look happy. Easy. Well, not quite. At about 4am, the samba school I was with, Viradouro, moved into place at the beginning of the Sambadrome. We stood up, got in line and then heard our drummers kick off. As we started parading, Viradouro helpers lined the side of the avenue and, like the bike fans who giddy-up cyclists on the Tour de France, they yelled orders: "Smile! Smile! Be Happy." I don't think I've ever looked so terrified. For about an hour, it was a total high. You can feel the sense of pride and happiness of both the paraders and the crowds by the looks on people's faces, by the interaction between the audience and the spectacle. On the tops of the floats are Brazilian celebrities and models. It's like a showcase of their own hopes and desires. Critics say that the carnival has sold out to tourists. I did not sense that at all. I felt it was an uncompromising celebration of Brazilianness. This did not exclude me from the party. Like many other parts of Brazilian life, the carnival fosters a communnal inclusivity you do not get in Europe. Brazil is not a country where people like to be different - perhaps because racially and socially, there is no country so diverse. People like to share, to be as one - and being a foreigner does not forbid you from feeling part of this. The carnival experience is not over when you walk out the Sambadrome, though. The climax is the judging a few days later, which is as drawn out and as melodramatic as the Eurovision Song Contest. Broadcast live on television from a stage on the Sambadrome - with cameras also positioned at every competing samba school, the city is glued to the screen. For such a popular occasion, much of the judging is steadfastly highbrow. (Give or take a few kickbacks between the mafia bosses who bankroll many of the schools). Experts in music, dance and art, historians and journalists are among those who do the scoring. The Brazilian equivalent of Terry Wogan comperes and milks every last drop of tension. The result marks the end of carnival, and the closing images are of hundreds of people swarming to the winning samba school to celebrate. Last year, unfortunately, the winner was not Viradouro, despite being one of the favourites. However, I feel fairly confident that my novice parading skills played no part in our downfall. We wuz robbed. Don't just stand and watch Carnival 2000 takes place from Saturday March 4 to Tuesday March 7. All the samba schools have chosen themes related to the 500th anniversary of the first Europeans landing in Brazil. On the two main nights, Sunday and Monday, 14 samba schools parade, each made up of about 4,000 people - which makes 56,000 dressed in ridiculous outfits, or the largest fancy dress party in the world. There is always space for some tourists. Within each school's parade, there are several different sections with separate costumes, each called an "ala". Some will be just for members of the community where the school is based, but others will be open to anyone who is willing to pay. In fact, the latter subsidise the former by charging middle-class Brazilians and foreigners quite large fees for the costumes, whereas local people get theirs free. You can pay anything from £50 for a simple costume from one of the less glamorous schools, to more than £100 for one from the top schools. Travel agencies sometimes arrange a costume as part of a package. But once you are in Rio, you can do it yourself. Ask your hotel receptionist to call the alas who are selling outfits. Once you've got your costume, you learn the words to the school's song and turn up in time on the day. This year, the process has been made simpler thanks to the internet, where some of the big schools have their own websites. The most detailed is by the Salgueiro samba school, which has a list of almost all the costumes from all 44 of its alas. Previously, each school's costumes were a closely-guarded secret. You can chose to be Napoleon, an Indian spice merchant, a botanical garden, or even "Beneficent England" - dressed in red stockings, with a Union Jack coming out your back and a globe on your head. Next to each picture is a contact number. Other good sites are Viradouro, and Beija-Flor. The Independent League of Samba Schools also has useful links. The practicals Bales Worldwide (01306 732718) offers seven nights at the Luxor Regente Hotel (room only), Copacabana, for £14445pp based on two sharing and including BA return flights, transfers and a grandstand seat at the carnival parade. Eight nights at the Caesar Park Hotel (deluxe room), Ipanema, with BA Club class flights, transfers and a special chair at the Carnival parade, costs £3695. STA (0870 1606070) has return fares to Rio for £288 plus £27 tax. The fare is open to all and valid from London, Manchester, Edinburgh and Birmingham for departures until March 31.

webTitle: I lost my heart in... Calcutta

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Calcutta
fields.standfirst: Joe Roberts
fields.trailText: Joe Roberts.
fields.body:
I was first attracted to Calcutta by the crumbling grandeur. I expected the place to be difficult, with terrible bureaucracy and endless frustration, but we settled in quickly. We found somewhere to live within 10 days, were accepted right away into the neighbourhood and stayed for five months.

Calcutta is a huge city, but not particularly threatening. Things that would cripple a place like New York are dealt with as part of ordinary life: everyone keeps going even when the city floods. People seem to be looking out for each other, which you don't get in western cities.

There are squares that remind me of Italian piazzas, fascinating temples and sweet shops like Viennese cafés where people meet and talk. The most British areas are the least appealing.

Some tourists are disappointed if they don't go to visit the slums, but is easy to get a distorted picture. If you go to Calcutta with an open mind, it is a remarkable place not a disaster zone.

 Abdul's Taxi to Kalighat, A Celebration of Calcutta, by Joe Roberts is published by Profile Books at £15.99

webTitle: Stephen Cook visits W.R. Hearst's grandiose castle

fields.headline: Fool's paradise
fields.standfirst: William Randolph Hearst looted the art treasures of the world to create his fantasy kingdom only to be immortalised, much to his fury, as Citizen Kane.  Stephen Cook fails to find Rosebud
fields.trailText: William Randolph Hearst looted the art treasures of the world to create his fantasy kingdom only to be immortalised, much to his fury, as Citizen Kane. Stephen Cook fails to find Rosebud.
fields.body:
"He was disappointed with the world, so he built his own - an absolute monarchy" Mr Leland in Citizen Kane (1941)

It must have been a mixed blessing for the beautiful people of the 1930s to be invited for the weekend to San Simeon, William Randolph Hearst's grandiose castle on the Californian coast. You couldn't say no, for a start, because Hearst was big in Hollywood as well as newspapers and could break the career of anyone who crossed him.

Then there were all the restrictions: you couldn't bring your own maid, you weren't allowed as much as a cup of coffee in the guest rooms, and if you wanted to sleep with your boyfriend or girlfriend, forget it: Hearst co-habited with his mistress, the actress Marion Davies, but wouldn't let other unmarried couples share a room.

And so it went on. The pre-dinner drinks, according to David Niven, "flowed like glue". Anyone who managed to get drunk - Errol Flynn and Dorothy Parker were two lucky ones - would return to their rooms to find their bags packed and a car waiting to take them to the station.

"Life in this Hearstian empire," wrote the socialite Gloria Vanderbilt, "is lived according to the disciplinary measures laid down by its dictator."

There were a few dissidents, such as the guest who, when asked one morning if he wanted to ride, motor, shoot, golf, swim or play tennis, replied firmly: "Not if I can help it."

And it seems that when Hearst retired to his library to telegram instructions to his newspapers deep into the night, the more spirited guests would sneak off to the steamy, gold-tiled indoor pool for boozy parties.

Hearst indulged his every whim, and the eminent San Francisco architect Julia Morgan patiently went along with it all, year after year. The swimming pool was rebuilt three times, the foundations of the main house were moved at huge expense to make room for a bowling alley that was never built.

Davies and some of the women guests often did jigsaw puzzles in the Assembly Room after dinner, and on one occasion a skilled carpenter and painter were brought in to make a perfect replacement for a tiny lost piece. "Afterwards, nine chances out of 10, it was shoved in the wastepapaper basket," the carpenter commented later.

Nowadays, the hordes of mass tourism have taken the place of the beautiful people at Hearst Castle, but a whiff of the old man's authoritarianism lingers on. As you move across glittering terraces and through dim interiors, you're tailed by a dark man in mirrored sunglasses: just checking you're not lifting the marble statue of Galatea or tucking a prize rug under your arm.

The worst touch on our visit came when we went to a movie called Building the Dream, a sycophantic account of how Hearst came to create this great monument to extravagance and vanity. The flunkey with the task of switching it on declined to do so until the audience, like a kindergarten chorus, had said good morning to him in the approved manner: not if I can help it.

You learn, as you troop from room to room, that the 14th- and 15th-century Gothic ceilings came mainly from Spain, that the huge 400-year-old stone fireplace in the Assembly Room was made in Burgundy, that the four tapestries on the wall were woven from wool and silk in Flanders, that the 600-year-old choir stalls came from a Spanish monastery, that there are 155 Greek vases in the Gothic library.

The jumble becomes most absurd when you reach the coffee room and the adjoining billiard hall, where there are 1,700-year-old Roman mosaics close to a 15th- century Spanish ceiling, a 16th-century tapestry of a stag hunt from northern France, and the 1930s billiard tables. The loot of the world arrived here by the shipload. Often it was never unpacked, let alone looked at.

But one thing you won't find mentioned in the official guidebooks is the Orson Welles film, Citizen Kane, in which a super-rich newspaper magnate fails to achieve his political ambitions and tries to console himself by building a huge castle.

There was never any doubt that the character of Kane started with Hearst, who had twice failed to become mayor of New York and win the Democratic presidential nomination. The great man instructed his columnists to attack Welles and used his influence in Hollywood to try to block the film's distribution. It was, he claimed, "Communist inspired".

Welles issued a statement denying he was a Communist, praising the American political system and adding: "It is not necessarily unpatriotic to disagree with Mr Hearst."

But there were probably more differences than similarities between the fictional Charles Foster Kane and the real life William Randolph Hearst. In particular, the central device of the film - that Kane's psychological scar comes from his deprivation in early childhood of his beloved snowsled Rosebud - seems to have had very little to do with Hearst, who had never been deprived of anything. (The story that Rosebud was Hearst's pet name for Marion Davies's clitoris is widely regarded as a red herring.)

Film writer David Thomson argues in his book Rosebud that Kane's complicated, self-destructive character is closer to Welles himself than Hearst: "Some other resemblance developed behind the showy but superficial kinship of Kane and Hearst. In emotion and energy, Kane was based on Welles. No one who knew or has written about Hearst has ever reported such complex depths, such an air of the damned."

But the message that gives the film so much of its impact - the ultimate emptiness of power, wealth and ambition, and the limitations of the American dream - seems to hover in the air around Hearst Castle. The place is a triumph of money, willpower and acquisition, but all the time a little voice whispers: what on earth is it all for?

There are many beautiful things at the castle. The site is stunningly beautiful, 2,000ft above the Pacific on what Hearst liked to call La Cuesta Encantada, the Enchanted Hill. (The website refers to it as La Cuesta Encantada.) But as the tour bus takes you back down the winding road to the shoreline, through the grounds once inhabited by the 300 animals of his private zoo, it is hard to find any meaning in it all.

The practicals

Hearst San Simeon State Historical Monument, San Simeon, California 93452, US, 805927 2020. You must book in advance on 805 4444445, ,international reservations =916 414 8400. Adults $14, children 6-12 $8. Evening tour $25 adults, $13 children. Accomodation nearby in Morro Bay and San Luis Obispo. BA (0345 222111), Virgin Atlantic (01293 747747) and United (0845 8444777) have daily flights from London to San Francisco and Los Angeles from £215 to £525 return. Trailfinder (020 7938 3444) puts together tailor-made trips with car hire and hotels.

fields.headline: Join the swarm
fields.trailText: Bee on board or miss out?
fields.body:
Bee on board or miss out?

On buzz, the newest airline of the millennium, which has just taken off.

Who are the proud parents?

KLM uk.

The sky's the limit?

Milan, Berlin and Paris are the most popular honeypots, with Dusseldorf, Frankfurt, Lyons and Vienna not far behind and others to follow on March 27.

More major players?

Second division but still vital to the game: Helsinki, Marseilles, Hamburg and Bordeaux.

Not quite my holiday choices.

Fear not. New routes to Toulouse on March 26, and Jerez and Montpelier on April 1 give better access to beaches.

No booking until then?

You can book now to all destinations, by phone (0870 240 7070) or over the internet (www.buzzaway.com).

If I've time for a litany of fares, restrictions, etc . . .

It's surprisingly simple. Done deal or Open deal.

Done? Someone else has paid?

You wish. But this is the cheaper of the two fare types, a return fare with restrictions and four pricing tiers.

Has Paris been Done to death?

No, there's plenty of space. Return Done deals to Charles de Gaulle airport cost £60, £80, £100 and £120.

So I wouldn't buzz into some secondary airport miles from town?

No, directly into the primary airport, whatever your destination.

For cheap, read inflexible?

As always. Whereas Open dealers can cancel up to two hours prior to departure, and a credit will be held for up to six months.

Are Open deals also reduced to tiers?

Yes, there are three one-way prices, with £10 between each. Single to Paris costs £99-119.

Where can I buy tickets?

You don't. Travel is ticketless and bookings are confirmed by letter or fax.

The pay-as-you-go approach?

Which means you can add extras like lounge access and fastracking through security as and when you need it along the way.

How about eating as you go?

buzz provides snacks and full meals, both at the boarding gate and in flight. From £3.50 for a sandwich to £7 for a full meal.

fields.headline: Square bash
fields.standfirst: It may be on its uppers in terms of tourist numbers, but that doesn't stop the Slovenians from hitting the high notes at their annual music festival.  Peter Moszynski  reports
fields.trailText: It may be on its uppers in terms of tourist numbers, but that doesn't stop the Slovenians from hitting the high notes at their annual music festival. Peter Moszynski reports.
fields.body:
The sound of steel drums drifts over French Revolution Square, where locals sip cold drinks under café awnings, a welcome relief from the hot afternoon sun. Within the walls of the old monastery, crowds of children dance to West Indian melodies. However, this is not some former French colony in the Caribbean, but Ljubljana, capital of the former Yugoslav Republic of Slovenia, and the musicians are British, a bunch of north London schoolkids called the Dollis Deep Pans.

And this is not some war-torn Balkan city, but the hub of what prides itself on being the most stable and prosperous country in eastern Europe.

The British Council - the UK's international organisation for educational and cultural relations - brought the steel band over to participate in the Druga Godba ("the other music") international music festival.

If you ever needed a reason to visit Ljubjana in early June, this is a perfect excuse. Not only is it one of the most vibrant festivals anywhere in Europe, it also takes place in a stunning setting, the Krizanker Summer Theatre.

The complex is in the ruins of an old Teutonic monastery, rebuilt by Slovenia's most famous architect Joze Plecnik, whose eclectic neo-classicism allowed him to express his religious beliefs without too much disapproval from the Communist government. The open-air auditorium has a retractable roof, and one of its structural elements is the remains of the old city wall, from the Roman settlement of Emona.

At last year's Druga Godba, the 15th, music from Europe and the Balkans mixed with Vietnamese, African, South American and Caribbean. Twenty-four groups played over nine days, and soloists included Senegalese singer Baaba Maal, Mali's Rokia Troare, Angola's Waldemar Bastos and Britain's DJ Vitu's Asian Equation, back by popular demand after a sell-out show the previous year.

Ljubljana is easily accessible and on a human scale, like a smaller version of Prague or Budapest, but without the commercialism and compromises to mass tourism.

Slovenia has been badly affected by a downturn in tourism since the break-up of Yugoslavia. In 1989, the Postojna caves in Slovenia's Karst region had more than a million visitors. Two years later, it was only 40,000, and the Kosovo crisis made matters worse, even though Slovenia was not directly involved in the conflict.

It claims to be the most heavily wooded country in Europe, with more than half its area covered in forests. And it is possibly the only place in the world where forest cover is increasing, as hill farming is no longer economic and pastureland is being reclaimed by trees.

The country's compact size -roughly that of Wales -means that almost everywhere can be reached within a few hours. And these places are worth reaching. In winter, Triglav National Park, in the Julian Alps, boasts some fine ski centres, but by June the snow has receded to the peaks and the rivers reach their fullest. This is the time to head for the town of Bovec, centre of "Adrenaline valley", for white-water rafting and canoeing.

Piran is a beautiful Venetian town on the short stretch of coast. Kobarid - Caporetto in Hemingway's A Farewell to Arms - is set in the stunning Soca valley. Lake Bled, with its island church and clifftop castle, shouldn't be missed, but much less visited and even more beautiful are the nearby Lake Bohinj and Lake Cerknica, whose annual disappearance puzzled scholars for centuries.

 This year's Druga Godba international festival of alternative and ethno music will be held from June 3-10.

The practicals

Slovenjia Pursuits (01767 631144) has tailor-made holidays to Slovenia. A two-night trip to Ljubljana, including flights from Heathrow, private transfers and B&B accomodation in a 4star centrally located hotel, costs £255 per person. Other two-night breaks include farmhouse and country holidays from about £265 for self-catering and &#'163;289 B&B inc flights

fields.headline: The light that failed
fields.standfirst: A new exhibition at the Design Museum in London celebrates the work of the Bauhaus school, who believed that standardised buildings based on scientific principles could be beautiful and transform people's lives.  Mark Hudson goes to Dessau, where it all began, to see what remains of the dream
fields.trailText: A new exhibition at the Design Museum in London celebrates the work of the Bauhaus school, who believed that standardised buildings based on scientific principles could be beautiful and transform people's lives. Mark Hudson goes to Dessau, where it all began, to see what remains of the dream
fields.body:
The sweeping glass walls - the first of their kind, ancestors of the steel and glass towers of Chicago, Manhattan and London - glowed in the evening light. There, lurking amid Dessau's still suburban avenues, was one of the 20th century's classic utopias, where Walter Gropius aspired to fuse architecture, sculpture and painting into "a crystal symbol of a new faith that is to come".

The place seemed deserted, but the door opened easily. Upstairs were three sets of double doors - the circular chrome finger plates, illustrated in hundreds of books, still in place. One opened noisily into a packed lecture theatre. As I squeezed blushing into the only empty seat, I noticed it was a variant on Marcel Breuer's steel-framed "Wassily" chair - that 20th-century icon, now ubiquitous in the stylish interiors of the West.

Founded 81 years ago, the Bauhaus was the most influential art and design school of the 20th century, where the giants Walter Gropius, Mies van der Rohe, Wassily Kandinsky and Paul Klee all taught. Their ideas still pervade everything from table-lamp design to performance art.

The Nazis shut the Bauhaus in 1933. After decades of suppression, bombing and neglect, would there would be much left to see? But there I was, amid rows of fresh-faced East German youth, listening to a short, bearded architect, who was holding forth with a masterful fluency, not one word of which I could understand. It was as though, in the parallel reality of the GDR, the Bauhaus had just kept on going as Dessau's local tech.

In fact, the students belong to the local university, which still rents half the building. The war-shattered Bauhaus accommodated various rag-tag institutions, including a cottage hospital and a driving school before restoration in the 1970s. It only returned to the status of educational institution last autumn, with a small intake of international postgraduates. But the standing of the Bauhaus is higher than ever. Modernism - rebranded for our own times as "minimalism" - is in. Gropius's building, one of the key works of the whole movement, is now a Unesco World Heritage site.

And you can stay in the original student accommodation, the Atelier wing with its jutting cantilevered balconies. The showers are communal, the decor utilitarian, but it's cheap, comfortable enough, and I had the building practically to myself. More to the point, you're sleeping in the Bauhaus, as close as you could be to the "Spirit of the Modern".

In Dessau, a whole range of monuments testify to the time - not so long ago - when artists, designers and architects really believed they could create a New Man: that if people were given a better, more rationally determined environment, they would behave in a better and more rational way. The fact that you're seeing these things against the battered reality of the former GDR makes the lost hopes and shattered dreams all the more poignant.

The Bauhaus phenomenon was of course, fraught with contradictions. Born into an illustrious Prussian family, Gropius was at once a great idealist and a gifted natural impresario and manipulator. Inspired by American grain silos and ocean liners - forms evolved not by "designers", but through the exigencies of function - he promoted collaborative creativity. Yet two of his most significant appointments, Klee and Kandinsky, were supremely individualistic painters preoccupied with the transcendental and the non-rational. And what did Oskar Schlemmer's surreal Triadic Ballets, the Bauhaus's most famous stage performances, have to do with "scientific" functionalism?

And far from being clinical, the Bauhaus building has an aura of peculiar secular sanc tity, somewhat enhanced by the fact that it's in a less than perfect state of repair.

You're constantly looking through acres of window on to vast counterbalancing friezes of glass. Light vibrates through the harmoniously-proportioned white spaces, the burnished black floors reflecting clouds and sky.

Modern architecture, you recall, was always supposed to be beautiful and uplifting. You could feel it would be worth flattening any number of Palladian villas to live in a world like this. So what went wrong?

A few hundred yards away, set among pine trees, are the houses that Gropius designed for the school's top teachers. They're not exactly poky, but you feel a few extra feet wouldn't go amiss. It's as though everything's been squeezed to a democratic minimum to compensate for the grotesque inequities of the past. The fixtures and fittings, such as the cylindrical steel door handles, are the same as those throughout the Bauhaus. Forget "choice" - that clarion call of contemporary mediocrity. Standardisation was the ideal: everyone would have the most beautiful and functional door handle.

For his Törten housing estate in suburban Dessau, Gropius set up experimental living spaces, where experts analysed exactly how much space the inhabitants would need to perform household tasks, such as cooking, with the minimum amount of movement.

Generally described as "bleakly industrial", Dessau is actually a very green city, a place of allotments and wooded parks, of undulating cobbled avenues widened by cycle lanes and wildly overgrown verges. But the centre is pretty grim, its churches and gothic town hall hidden among vast graffiti-spattered housing estates. Passing the array of brutally enormous blocks, you wonder if this was the inevitable legacy of Bauhaus utopianism. Or is it simply that there have been mediocre architects in every period?

Aat the end of Franzstrasse, Törten's cubic, partially- prefabricated units are immediately recognisable, though what has happened to them is at once sad and somehow heartening.

An information board shows the street as it looked on completion: the houses sitting mathematically equidistant on the bare earth like an assembly line of fridges.

The idea that this sterile, quasi-industrial uniformity had represented a new Platonic ideal was oddly shocking. Then, a slight tilt of the head revealed the same view today: straight lines eased from alignment; fake mahogany doors added; rococo mail boxes; hard white replaced by cream, plum and that greyish crumbling ochre you see everywhere in the former GDR. Trees overhung the waist-high verges, and many gardens were so thick with roses and silver firs that the houses were invisible. But there's no graffiti or broken glass here. These houses are cared for. Their owners have destandardised them into cottages.

The attendant, a big, middle-aged woman, explained that Herr Gropius had set up a show house to demonstrate that slimline Bauhaus products were not only more suitable to these houses than bulky traditional furniture, but cheaper. "He said people couldn't bring their own furniture!" she said with indignation. "But they wouldn't stand for it!"

She was supposed to be giving me the official Bauhaus version but, having lived on the estate for 30 years, she kept slipping back to the residents' view. There was, she said, not a single window on the estate that hadn't been moved. "They were too high. People couldn't see out!" And from the first, nobody could cope with the tiny "scientifically-designed" kitchens.

It could be argued that the influence of the Bauhaus has been more lasting than that of the Nazi and Stalinist ideologies that crushed it. It wasn't itself free of the totalitarian impulses that characterised its period. But as I ate dinner that night at the Kornhaus, Carl Fieger's 1928 riverside restaurant, I watched the sun sinking into the Elbe beyond the curving sweep of the windows, and I felt as though I were looking back on the Bauhaus down a long tunnel of darkness, as a shining moment of hope and integrity.

fields.headline: Tales from the tabs
fields.trailText: Junior Baiano to Arsenal? Teddy Sheringham to West Ham? All the latest tittle-tattle in one place for your leisure and pleasure.
fields.body:
WENGER GOES FOR BAIANO

Arsenal have opened talks via a French agent to bring Brazil's 29-year-old, £3m-rated hardman Junior Baiano to Highbury from Vasco da Gama.

SHERI SIGNS FOR HAMMERS - FOR £2.5m

Teddy Sheringham has agreed to join West Ham from Man Utd this summer. He'll leave Old Trafford for a £2.5m signing on fee, plus £1m-a-year in wages.

AND THE REST...

Arsenal and Chelsea could get an answer from PSV about Ruud van Nistelrooy this week - PSV have invited official offers, and will listen to any £20m+ deal which allows the striker to remain in Holland until the end of the season; Gianluca Vialli has denied preparing a big money move for Barcelona ace Guardiola; Bradford have released Isaiah Rankin for a second month's loan at Birmingham ; Leeds are watching former Everton midfielder Olivier Dacourt; Manchester United have denied that a deal for Russian star Alexei Smertin is close; Middlesbrough's move for Parma's Giampiero Maini should go through this week; Newcastle's Paul Robinson has withdrawn his transfer request after Bobby Robson convinced him he 'has a future' at St James'; Peter Reid is set to up his £3m offer for Everton's Don Hutchison: Reid wants the hardman midfielder to reverse Sunderland's slump; Charlton prodigy Scott Parker is set to leave The Valley on loan; Norwich have denied that Craig Bellamy is about to be sold; West Brom will offer Cambridge Fabian De Freitas in part-exchange for Trevor Benjamin; Everton are set to sign Sheffield Wednesday's Niclas Alexandersson - Walter Smith will use the cash from selling John Collins and Mitch Ward to finance a deal; Leeds' reserve Mark Jackson is ready to join Bristol Rovers ; Espen Bardsen wants a loan move from Spurs ; Arsenal's Nigel Winterburn could leave Highbury despite being offered a new deal; and George Boateng has revealed how the divinity prevented him from being more seriously injured by Gazza's elbow: 'Before every game I pray to God,' says George. 'I have been protected by angels.'

fields.headline: Ski briefs
fields.trailText: • Club Med (01455 852202) is to open a new village in Colorado's Crested Butte. The French operator has bought the Marriott Resort at the foot of the ski runs, about three miles from the former mining town, where the main street's original 19th-century buildings have been converted into shops and restaurants. The property will be renovated in time for next season and will offer the usual all-inclusive formula - packages including lift passes, meals, nightly entertainment, ski and snowboarding lessons, and activities for children between four and 12.
fields.body:
 Club Med (01455 852202) is to open a new village in Colorado's Crested Butte. The French operator has bought the Marriott Resort at the foot of the ski runs, about three miles from the former mining town, where the main street's original 19th-century buildings have been converted into shops and restaurants. The property will be renovated in time for next season and will offer the usual all-inclusive formula - packages including lift passes, meals, nightly entertainment, ski and snowboarding lessons, and activities for children between four and 12.

 Watch for bargain holidays in late March. Travel agents say a late Easter has left tour operators with something of a trough in bookings. Thomas Cook Ski Direct (0870 7520044), for example, is already offering discounted Neilson deals, including a week's half-board at a four-star hotel in Andorra's Soldeu, with flights from Gatwick or Manchester on March 19. With £20 off the brochure price from the operator and a further 10% from the agent, that brings it down to £382.50. Thomas Cook is also offering a week's self-catering with Airtours in Flaine, leaving Gatwick on March 18, for £225.50, based on two sharing. It will provide free insurance on holidays costing £349 or more. Specialist agent Snow Line (01858 828000) has deals including self-catering packages in Belle Plagne for £245, based on four sharing; half-board breaks for £219 at Encamp in Andorra; and chalet holidays at £279 in Bardonecchia (Italy) and £309 in the French resort of Valmorel.

 Winter Park, known as Denver's local hill, has plans to build a gondola lift to link its slopes with the town centre. At present, skiers have to catch shuttle buses to and from the main lift base area. But it could be up to five years before the project comes to fruition. Besides finance - it will cost an estimated £12.5 million - the proposal will need approval from private landowners and public bodies, not least of which is the US Forest Service.

 The Swiss resort of Crans-Montana, which has a source of thermal water, is to get a major new spa complex. Scheduled to open in 2002, and promising spectacular views over the Rhone Valley, it will have an outdoor and two indoor pools - one for children - saunas, slides, waterfalls, a hammam and a health and beauty clinic.

 A new complex of restaurants, shops and hotels is to be built at Whistler, in British Columbia. Owner Intrawest has been given planning permission to revitalise the Whistler Creek area, at the base of the Creekside gondola lift. The three-year project will include the construction of three condominium hotels.

 The latest astonishing transatlantic bargain comes from Thomson (0870 6061470), which is offering a week in the Colorado resort of Breckenridge for £299, accommodation only with British Airways flights non- stop from Gatwick to Denver. Departures are on Thursdays and Sundays from February 24 to the end of the season. Full-board packages start at £369.

At present, skiers have to catch shuttle buses to and from the main lift base area. But it could be up to five years before the project comes to fruition. Besides finance - it will cost an estimated £12.5 million - the proposal will need approval from private landowners and public bodies, not least of which is the US Forest Service.  The Swiss resort of Crans-Montana, which has a source of thermal water, is to get a major new spa complex. Scheduled to open in 2002, and promising spectacular views over the Rhone Valley, it will have an outdoor and two indoor pools - one for children - saunas, slides, waterfalls, a hammam and a health and beauty clinic.  A new complex of restaurants, shops and hotels is to be built at Whistler, in British Columbia. Owner Intrawest has been given planning permission to revitalise the Whistler Creek area, at the base of the Creekside gondola lift. The three-year project will include the construction of three condominium hotels.  The latest astonishing transatlantic bargain comes from Thomson (0870 6061470), which is offering a week in the Colorado resort of Breckenridge for £299, accommodation only with British Airways flights non- stop from Gatwick to Denver. Departures are on Thursdays and Sundays from February 24 to the end of the season. Full-board packages start at £369.

fields.headline: Down in the valley
fields.trailText: Grimentz
fields.body:
Grimentz

The most central ski area with several modern hotels at one end of the valley and the old village at the other. The village became a winter sports resort in 1968. The skiing is mostly intermediate and beginner with some easy beginner slopes from top to bottom.

Zinal

This small, simple village did not become a ski resort until 1967, although it has long been popular with climbers for 150 years - Edward Whymper (now buried in Zermatt) climbed here. The skiing is mostly red runs, not ideal for beginners. Zinal has the most challenging skiing with several off-piste routes to Grimentz, although you cannot return to Zinal on skis from Grimentz. We skied one long and solitary route which took us to the bus stop at Mottec and back to Zinal. There are spectacular views of the "Imperial Crown", the five 4,000m peaks of the Weisshorn, Zinalrothorn, Obergabelhorn, Matterhorn and Dent-Blanche.

Vercorin

A beautiful spot with lovely views and wide pistes, excellent for beginners or cruisers. It's the lowest resort (top 2,347m, bottom 1,300m) with stunning runs through the trees to the village.

St Luc/Chandolin

These two resorts, 20 minutes away from Grimentz by car, are now linked by chairlift. A free ski bus operates between the resorts, and the Anniviers Valley has introduced a single ski pass for the entire region. The five ski areas have 46 lifts and 220km of pistes. We barely saw another skier here, and it is a large area consisting mostly of red and blue runs. Food on the mountain costs much less than at a large resort.

fields.headline: Late bookings
fields.trailText: Orange sun
fields.body:
Orange sun

Leave the grey skies behind for the Spanish sun. Two nights' B&B in Seville with return scheduled flights from Gatwick cost £259 per person until March 31 with Crystal Cities (0870 8880022).

Silk roadster

Take the Golden Road to Samarkand. A 10-day trip through Uzbekistan has been discounted by £150 per person and leaves from Heathrow on April 21. The journey starts in Tashkent and takes in Khiva, the Kizilikum desert and Bukhara. The new price of £1,695 includes return flights, transfers, full-board accommodation and sightseeing. Bales Worldwide (01306 732700).

Warmer Malta

Go for some winter sun in Gozo. Malta has temperatures of around 70F at this time of year. Leave on February 26 and seven nights' self-catering based on four people sharing, costs £349 per person including return scheduled flights from Gatwick, ferry transfer and car hire. Simply Winter Sun (020-8541 2277).

Arab steps

You can Salsa, you can Tango, now learn Arabic dancing. Visit Granada and dance in the streets during La Fiesta de Cruces de Mayo - a celebration of birth. The holiday costs £450 and includes return flights, seven nights' bed and breakfast, 10 hours' Arabic dance tuition and an English- speaking guide. Departs April 29 with Dance Holidays (01206 577000).

Parisian spree

Take Eurostar to Paris and three nights' B&B at a two-star hotel costs £164, including a sightseeing tour of the city, a cruise along the Seine and a 10% discount at Galeries Lafayette. See Escape Routes

Caribbean sands

Jet off to Jamaica and a week at the four-star Beaches Inn hotel costs £899 per person until the end of March. The price includes return flights from Heathrow, transfers and all-inclusive accommodation. Tropical Journeys Caribbean (0171-388 9292).

Beyond Bruges

Take a free day trip to Lille or Brussels when you book a two-night mid-week stay in Bruges before March 31. The holiday costs £185 per person for return Eurostar travel and B&B accommodation. Eurostar Holidays Direct (0870 1676767).

Canal party

See the Venice carnival. Stay two nights at the four-star Hotel Principe and join Italy's biggest street party. Return scheduled flights and two nights' B&B cost £345 per person, any time between February 24 and March 7 (£290 at a three-star hotel). Magic Cities (020-8563 8959).

fields.headline: Medina date
fields.standfirst: Sensual and sub-tropical, it offers everything Britain can't in the middle of winter.  Steven Poole  abandons himself to the exotic fruits and heady wafts of the souks
fields.trailText: Sensual and sub-tropical, it offers everything Britain can't in the middle of winter. Steven Poole abandons himself to the exotic fruits and heady wafts of the souks
fields.body:
A night in Tunisia, sang Ella Fitzgerald, is "a tale/Too exotic to be told". Perhaps the composer of that tune, Dizzy Gillespie, had spent the night in question tuning his zither - all 72 strings of it, making the phrase a wry Tunisian euphemism for sensual indulgence. The "desert sand" of the song, beloved also of Star Wars fans (Luke Skywalker's home planet, Tatooine, is a real southern Tunisian place name) is worlds away from the lush sub-tropical greenery of the capital in the north. Yet if it's not quite camel-trekking in the starlit Sahara, a weekend in Tunis still makes for a warmly exotic winter retreat.

At the centre of the city is the medina, the walled old town founded 13 centuries ago and now designated a Unesco World Heritage site. You can spend most of a day exploring its warren of low, arched stone passageways. Shops selling carpets, leather, silverware, khaftans and jewellery are festooned with twinkling fairy lights; strings of scarves and multi-coloured beads hang from rods spanning the width of the alleys. Tunisians everywhere are engaged in the long game of barter: a prospective buyer feigns outrage with an amicable bark and begins to walk away; the stallholder calls confidently that he'll be back. Down another passageway, a grinning old man displays racks of traditional headwear, shashia and fez, and - a commercially necessary modern barbarism, it seems - baseball caps made from the same purple-dyed wool.

Some of the shops here are still laid out as old medina houses: one delightfully eclectic antique emporium, CD Dar, offers swords in an urn, old cameras and flintlock rifles, a squeezebox or an organ. From its roof terrace, you can peer out over the top of the medina: a skyline decorated with glazed green rooftiles and a forest of slender spires and domes. Below, the frenetic activity of the souks is invisible under the undulating stone roofs, whose interlocking curves begin to resemble patterns in the dunes.

It's worth deliberately wandering off the busiest shop-and-café routes: some alleys are peacefully deserted, and sunlight bludgeons through gaps in the roofs to wash the stone in captivating shades of russet and gold. Dart down one such and you come across the Musée des Arts, a lovingly-preserved 19th-century bourgeois household with chandeliers, gilded furniture and exquisitely-tiled walls, laid out in the old way around a central courtyard. To aid historical visualisation, each room hosts a tableau of waxwork dummies dressed in their finest robes and jewels.

There is no point trying to plan a route through the medina: although attractions such as the museum are helpfully signposted around the central Zitouna Mosque, it's not the sort of place where you'd purposefully march from A to B and cross off the sights. You might be led off course by the promise of a prickly pear or by the heady intermingled wafts of sizzling food and perfumeries (the prophet Mohammed, it is said, disdained wealth and power, but confessed two weaknesses: women and scent). And, at regular intervals, the chatter of commerce and idle gossip in Arabic, French and English, mixed with the polite shouts of men trying to wheel enormous, glistening fish past you on the dark, slippery cobbles, is joined by transistorised minarets, and the crowds begin to move with more purpose as the faithful heed the call to prayer.

Lunch should be savoured opposite the main entrance of the central mosque, at the ridiculously cheap Restaurant Mahdaoui, which serves delicious fried tuna with egg in tomato sauce, or lamb couscous. Later, out of the medina and on to the street as sunset approaches, the main Avenue Habib Bourguiba, thronged with tourists, street performers and promenading Tunisians, fills with a symphonic cheeping. Thousands of starlings flock here every day at this hour, swooping hungrily among the olive trees, passing ecstatically high-pitched judgment on the quality of the fruit. The terrace of Hotel Africa - at four stories, once the tallest building in Tunis - will happily furnish beer while you watch them wheeling through the warm evening air.

'To Carthage then I came . . ." Even the venerable medina is a brash architectural upstart next to the remains of the citadel here that once ruled as much of the Mediterranean as anyone thought important enough to subjugate.

What's left of the ancient city of Carthage perches in Ozymandian grandeur atop a hill to the east of modern Tunis. This is where, according to legend, Dido arrived on the run from Tyre nearly three millennia ago: the local king told her she could have as much land as could be covered by an ox-hide. Resourcefully, she cut the skin into thin strips and stretched it all around the top of the hill.

Proud Carthage, of course, was eventually sacked by the vandals of Rome, and the replacement Roman city, in a kind of historical poetic justice, was later kicked down by the Vandals themselves. For centuries afterwards, its remains were looted for building material, and gradually overtaken by agricultural use. Now, from the top of Mount Byrsa (which translates as ox-hide), you can inspect the poignantly-deserted grid layout of a Punic village, with some mosaic floors still intact, and gaze across at the twin ports through which all the sea's wealth passed.

There are still some massive stone catapult balls strewn around the acropolis, silently mourning their failure to protect the city. Behind you, the Museum of Carthage is filled with fascinating artefacts from the Punic, Roman and Byzantine eras, and behind that is the enormous, near-decadent 19th-century French basilica.

Just down the hill are the spectacular ruins of the Antonine thermal baths, among whose maze of dank vaults it is easy to lose yourself in reveries of imperial watersports. A single main column of the frigidarium , or cold pool, spears 45ft up into the cobalt sky: the original building is thought to have been twice as high as that.

If you have the time, it's also certainly worth the four-hour round trip south of Tunis to the extraordinary site of Dougga, an entire Roman town complete with vertiginous mountain-top amphitheatre, a capitol, a temple to Celeste and a mausoleum whose bilingual inscription, now in the British Museum, was vital in the first efforts to decode the Punic language.

All this stamping around, of course, eventually brings on a yearning to put one's feet up in a café and suck on an enormous bong. That, it seems, is what the darling village of Sidi Bou Said was built for, piled up delicately on a rosy-clay cliffside just north of Byrsa. Palm trees fondly wave their inedible golden dates and the narrow, steep streets are lined with buildings that are all washed dazzling white, with sky-blue woodwork - not by accident but by law, an aesthetic edict that curiously manages to avoid the twee. From this sky-village, you can watch the fishermen on the beach below spread their multi-coloured nets, undulating like giant jellyfish, and look across the bay to the twin-horned mountain that has hurried generations of Tunisian artists to the canvas.

But winding down on your last afternoon in Tunis, you'll probably leave the watercolour set at home. Wander up instead to the Café El Alia and try a shisha , or water-pipe, with your coffee. Songbirds in cages philosophise melodically about the idea of freedom, and ornate bronze lanterns swing gently from the rafters.

No one seems to be in a hurry in Tunis - and why should they be? Ancient history is scattered in plain view over the soil: no clearer illustration could be wished for of the fact that everything is in flux, that a single human lifespan is so brief as to win forgiveness for the incorrigible daydreamer. You think again of Ella's song - "The cares of the day seem to vanish" - and decide that, yes, it fits here just as well.

Five of the best

Places to eat

1 Mahdaoui (Rue Jamaa ez Zitouna): Delicious and very cheap traditional Tunisian food, popular with civil servants.

2 Dar Bel Hadj (17 Rue des Tamis): Stunning old courtyard townhouse serving exquisite food with live music.

3 Au Bon Vieux Temps (56 Rue Hedi Zarrouk, Sidi Bou Said): Fabulous sea view from this airy Sidi Bou Said eaterie.

4 Café Sidi Meht (Medina): Ideal place to rest your legs during a day wandering the souks.

5 Café El Alia (Sidi Bou Said): Gorgeously relaxing hill-top retreat in the village of the sky.

Cultural sites

1 Bardo Museum (Bardo): Exquisite mosaics from Punic, Roman and Byzantine periods.

2 Musée des Arts (Rue Sidi Qacem): A fully-restored 19th-century bourgeois Tunisian townhouse, peopled with dummies.

3 Centre des Musiques Arabes et Méditerranéennes (Sidi Bou Said): Fascinating collection of stringed and wind instruments in the old Baron's home.

4 Museum of Carthage (Mount Byrsa): Sculpture, tools and paintings from the ancient city.

5 Sadika (Zone Touristique Gammarth): Watch glassblowers at the forge and browse the displays of traditional glassware and jewellery.

The practicals

Steven Poole was a guest of Wigmore Holidays (020 7836 4999). A four night stay in the 5 star Hotel Abou Nawas Gamarth coists from £439 and includes return flights, transfers and B&B. A two-night stay costs from £364.

fields.headline: Oceans of space
fields.standfirst: Clippers used to sail the Indian Ocean laden with tea and spices. Nowadays, they deliver the romance of the open seas.  Leslie Thomas  embarks on an epic adventure
fields.trailText: Clippers used to sail the Indian Ocean laden with tea and spices. Nowadays, they deliver the romance of the open seas. Leslie Thomas embarks on an epic adventure
fields.body:
It was Saturday night in the Indian Ocean. The sails were full of the south-west trades, there were moonbeams on the masts and stars in the sky; the sea was thick and dark, the wind warm. From below came the sound of the bagpipes.

Not only the sound of the bagpipes, but the bagpipes played by a German sea captain who lives in Scotland and sports a kilt. He loves the sea and ship so much, he was sailing as a passenger.

We were miles from anywhere, doing about six knots. The ocean stretched far beyond the bowsprit. Our next landfall, after navigating the passage between Nicobar and the Andamans, would be the uninhabited Similan Islands. There were worse places to be.

The Star Flyer - 2,200 tonnes, 350ft from figure head to stern - was on the longest passage made these days by a ship under sail. She began her 35-day voyage in Athens, called in at Alexandria, went through Suez to Aden and Oman and then set out across the Arabian Sea, the first stretch of the Indian Ocean. I joined her at the iron-ore port of Vasco da Gama in India for the second sea crossing to Thailand.

She is a strong, beautiful and romantic ship, built on clipper lines, but she lay, unromantically, among grimy ore carriers, with red dust flying from the loading hoppers on the quay. The German skipper, Captain Gerhardt Lickfelt, regarded the peppery coating on his deck and sniffed. He wanted to get going.

We sailed due south, along the hilly coast. At her swiftest, the Star Flyer carves the ocean at 13 knots, all her masts crammed with sail, and with the wavering givaway of a pennant of smoke issuing from the rear mast. It doubles as a slim funnel for the auxiliary diesel engine. You can lie on the sun-bleached deck and, if you have nothing better to do, which may well be the case, you can name the sails (36,000 square feet of them): the top gallants, the jigger, the mizzen fisherman and the rest. Ropes and blocks and belaying pins make enticing patterns in the ocean sun. The bar is circular, half of the curve outside, half inside. You can drink whatever the weather.

We called at Cochin, tying up at Wilmington Island, among the lagoons - an island made by the British from the silt dredged from a new harbour and handily finished in time for Indian independence. Then we made our way past Cape Comorin, the most southerly point of India, with its giant, white church, down to Colombo and eventually went out into the open ocean.

The trades took us by the hand and led us on. The bow nosed hungrily at the easy waves. Settling in at sea, knowing that the next landfall was six days away, was wonderful. The cabins were on the small side, the bathrooms like Houdini cabinets, but done out in teak and brass. There was a television that showed videos, but it was never turned on. News came via a daily sheet, which was placed in the library, but few people bothered. Now was the time for talking.

We heard tales of the ship's crossing of the Arabian Sea, the first indent of the Indian Ocean, on the stretch before I joined. The 150 passengers, and 72 crew had come across fishermen in boats, tiny, each one hardly bigger than a man, and days from land, who did a quick deal for a 100lb silvery marlin they had caught. The ship had stopped so everyone could swim in the ocean.

fields.headline: Marching to a different beat
fields.standfirst: Carolyne Ellis looks at other music festivals in Europe
fields.trailText: Carolyne Ellis looks at other music festivals in Europe.
fields.body:
Bulgaria

The Festival of Roses is celebrated with folk songs and dances at Kazanl and Karlovo on the first Sunday in June. During the first week of June, the Golden Orpheus International Pop Song Festival is held at Sunny Beach. July sees the International Chamber Music Festival at Plovdiv, while the New Year Music Festival is held in Sofia's Palace of Culture. Bulgarian Tourist Board: 020-7584 9433 ext 21.

Croatia

Zagreb rolls to Spring Time Jazz Fever from March 21 to April 4 and International Days of Jazz in mid-October. In July, it hosts its Summer Festival showcasing classical works by Croatian composers. July and August also see Dubrovnik's Summer Festival, again featuring the country's classical music stars, and a festival of acapella vocal music in Omis. Croatian Tourist Board

Czech Republic

The Prazske jaro (Prague Spring) International Music Festival takes place in April and May, the Mozart Festival and the Dvorak Autumn Music Festival in September and a New Music festival in October. Brno hosts the annual International Jazz Festival. The Frederic Chopin Music Festival takes place in Marianske Lazne in August. Czech Tourist Pages

Finland

The Pori Jazz Festival in July is the more trendy, but the Savonlinna Opera Festival, held at the medieval Olavinnlinna Castle, is the more famous. Finnish Tourist Board

Hungary

Hungary's major celebration is the Budapest Spring Festival (March), a two-week local and international cultural extravaganza. Hungarian tourist office

Latvia

The Baltika Annual International Folklore Festival, which has taken place in each Baltic capital in turn since 1987, is due in Riga this year. It is a week-long affair of music, dance, exhibitions and parades usually held in mid-July. The International Festival of Organ Music is held in the capital in June; the Opera Music Festival in Sigulda; and the Festival of Ancient Music at Bauska Castle in July. Latvian Tourist Board

Lithuania

The most emotive cultural event is the National Song Festival, held every five years (in Vilnius this year). More than 100,000 people are expected to sing along with several hundred choirs from the Baltic region. April's International Jazz Festival attracts top international musicians to Kaunas. July sees a week-long Summer Music Festival of street theatre, dancing, masked parades and craft fairs in the Old Town of Vilnius. Lithuanian Tourist Board

Poland

For classical events, check out Lancut's Old Music Festival in May, Warsaw's Mozart Festival in June and July and Wroclaw's Wratislavia Cantans oratorio and cantata festival in September. The Warsaw Autumn International Festival takes place in September, featuring contemporary music; the Warsaw Summer Jazz Days festival in June; and the Jazz Jamboree festival (again in Warsaw) in late October. Polish National Tourist Office

Romania

The three-day Bucharest carnival takes place in June. July sees Brasov's Golden Stag international pop music festival and the International Chamber Music Festival concerts in Brasov and Bran. In September, there's Sibiu's Cibinium music festival followed by Cluj-Napoca's Musical Autumn in October. Romanian Tourism Promotion Office

Ukraine

In Lviv, the National Virtuoso fills the month of May with musical and theatrical performances focusing on national themes. Embassy of Ukraine

fields.headline: Cite unseen
fields.standfirst: The Readers' Editor on... quotes from an unnamed source
fields.trailText: The Readers' Editor on... quotes from an unnamed source
fields.body:
This week I have been looking at a complaint about a story that we ran across the top of our front page on February 11. It was headed "Sponsors confused by dome boss hype" and concerned the sacking of the dome's chief executive, Ms Jennie Page, and her replacement by Pierre-Yves Gerbeau. Among the questions raised in the piece were: Had Mr Gerbeau's appointment been "over-hyped"? Had he been presented as the "saviour" of Disneyland Paris, where he has been employed? Had his qualifications been exaggerated? Would the dome sponsors have agreed to the dismissal of his predecessor if they had known more about Mr Gerbeau?

One of the people to raise these questions was identified as "a senior source at one of the main sponsors". His quoted remarks concluded, "It's a massive cock-up. Nice one Bob." This was a reference to Bob Ayling who is both the chairman of the dome board and the chairman of British Airways. (In our report Mr Ayling denied that there had been any exaggeration of Mr Gerbeau's qualifications and said the information given to the public relations company handling the announcement and disseminated by it had fairly described "the calibre and character" of Mr Gerbeau.)

The complaint, lodged by the director of communications at British Airways, questioned the source and authenticity of the quote that referred to Mr Ayling, but its main point was "that pejorative blind quotes are journalistically unethical".

The letter went on, "The New York Times Manual of Style and Usage requires that when derogatory remarks about a person or institution are being reported the source must be named. If the information... is important (scarcely plausible in this case) but 'cannot be fully attributed' then it must be paraphrased 'after thorough discussions between writer and editor'. As the New York Times argues that 'the vivid language of direct quotation confers an unfair advantage on a speaker' it should not be given to people hiding behind the newspaper when attacking others.

"It is about time the Guardian adopted an ethical position in its reporting of such matters."

The writer had, perhaps, recently read an interesting piece on this subject by Simon Jenkins in the Times (details below) prompted by reports, all based on anonymous sources, touching the health and competence of Mo Mowlam. Jenkins praised rules of the kind operated by the New York Times, and said that without such rules "the carnival of unnamed sources leads on to a grim mountain of innuendo, located somewhere between fact, fiction and vendetta..."

I broadly agree with all that. However, let us have a closer look at the complaint that I am asked to consider. The reporter who obtained the quote had every intention of attributing it to the person from whom it came and who had telephoned him to offer his comments. The reporter has told me in confidence who made the remarks and I am satisfied that they came from someone of sufficient authority for them to be relevant. The reporter was perfectly frank about the nature and source of the comments when he spoke to others in the course of gathering material for the story.

As the deadline for the page approached, several things happened. The paper had a number of telephone calls seeking to prevent the publication of the remarks. One of the calls threatened legal action if the remarks were connected with the organisation on whose behalf we were prepared to say they were made.

Then the reporter had a call from the person who had volunteered the remarks asking that neither he nor the organisation be identified. During the course of this conversation he said to the reporter, "They'll crucify me."

At this point the matter was referred to the senior editor in charge that evening - the deputy editor (news) - and to the editor of the paper. It was their decision to accede to the request of the person quoted and to preserve his anonymity. He was called back and told that neither he nor his organisation would be named but the paper would go ahead with the quote.

In the circumstances it seems to me that publication of the remarks, the general thrust of which, the reporter says, reflected comments from another dome sponsor which were not included in his piece, was perfectly justified.

Was it necessary, though, to include the words, "It's a massive cock-up. Nice one Bob"? I think it probably was. They are the words which vividly express the spirit in which the remarks were made, remarks which, I believe, were fairly reported. I shall return, not to this, but to the general subject next week.

 The New York Times Manual of Style and Usage by Allan M Siegal and William G. Connolly is published in the US by Times Books (a division of Random House). Simon Jenkins's column, Top source, low ethics, appeared in The Times (in London) February 2. Readers may contact the office of the Guardian Readers' Editor by telephoning 0171 239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. Surface mail to Readers' Editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Fax 0171 239 9897.
Email: reader@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Thames links
fields.standfirst: Continuing our series of celebrity walks, Conservative candidate for London mayor  Steven Norris legs it over the capital's bridges
fields.trailText: Continuing our series of celebrity walks, Conservative candidate for London mayor Steven Norris legs it over the capital's bridges.
fields.body:
Steven Norris readily admits that he's better at talking than walking and doesn't get out in the fresh air often enough: "What do they say? A bad ride is better than a good walk." But once a year. he turns out in his trainers, £11 miles of pavement, and is surprised how much he enjoys it. The event is an annual charity walk across the bridges of London, which he first did when he was a Department of Transport minister with responsibility for the capital between 1992 and 1996. He's done it ever since, and now he's Conservative candidate for Mayor of London, it makes good political sense to keep on going.

Starting in the City, at the north end of Tower Bridge, and finishing in the park at the south side of Battersea Bridge, the route folows London's main artery to cross its historic heart and 11 of its bridges. There are riverside promendades, famous buildings, changing skylines and the odd murky corner.

"What's good about it is that you see the city from its best vantage point, which is the river," says Norris. "And you start with that extraordinary explosion of new architecture and geometry on the north bank between Tower Bridge and Waterloo. Then you come to the metro politan West End between Waterloo and Westminster and, after that, it becomes more residential, quieter and calmer as you go down to Battersea. The river itself changes from high to low, and there's the sheer pleasure of seeing so many different places.

"Even someone as unfit as I am can do it without feeling that it's a massive burden. And it's not a competition - I walk with a group of friends from the department, and my son Edward, who's now 14, has come with me a couple of years."

Norris's ideal lunch spot would be the Oxo brasserie, with its wonderful view of the city between Blackfriars and Waterloo, or Ransome's Dock, tucked beside a small wharf in Battersea.

Up to 70 people do the walk on charity day, and they pause to eat sandwiches and an orange at the south end of Lambeth Bridge. This is one of the river's best spots for viewing the Houses of Parliament, where Norris was Member for Epping Forest until the last election.

The highlight of the walk for him, though, is not Westminster but Waterloo Bridge, the place he always takes visitors to show them what London really means. "You look east, and there's that great panorama of St Paul's and the City and Canary Wharf in the distance - unique, nothing else like it in the world. And to the west, the Palace of Westminster, Terry Farrell's Charing Cross station, the whole metropolitan area. It's a view that sums up the best of London. It's majestic, what Wordsworth called 'that mighty heart'."

You only need three hours to test out the rest of Words-worth's 1802 sonnet Composed on Westminster Bridge, including the first line: "Earth has not anything to show more fair." But if you want to do it for charity, the next organised walk is in November: date available soon from Imperial Cancer Research Fund on 020-8390 9575.

Legs 11... crossing those bridges

1 Tower Bridge (built 1894): a bus driver once had to jump the gap as the bridge opened under him. The 1,000-ton bascules have been up and down more often than - well, supply your own Norris joke.

2 London Bridge (1972): heads displayed on its medieval predecessor included those of William Wallace, Jack Cade, Thomas More and Bishop Fisher. They were parboiled in the gatehouse, then dipped in tar to preserve them.

3 Southwark Bridge (1921): Its Victorian forebear was a footbridge of three magnificent cast-iron arches, which bankrupted the Rotherham foundry that made them.

4 Blackfriars Bridge (1869): London's widest, at 105ft, it has pulpit-shaped pier heads to match its name, derived from the former Dominican monastery on the north bank.

5 Waterloo Bridge (1942): the longest at 1,250ft, and the first made with reinforced concrete beams. Wooden pilings from its predecessor were so well preserved they were pulled out of the clay and used to veneer new coaches for the London, Midland and Scottish Railway Company.

6 Westminster Bridge (1862): the oldest still in use. Its dominant colour of green matches the leather benches in the House of Commons.

7 Lambeth Bridge (1932): mainly red to match the benches of the nearby House of Lords.

8 Vauxhall Bridge (1906): the first to carry trams. The piers bear bronze statues of women holding symbols of the arts and sciences.

9 Chelsea Bridge (1937): A modern suspension bridge: the falling tide was ingeniously used to lower the central sections into position from barges.

10 Albert Bridge (1873): the only one of this group of bridges never to be replaced.

11 Battersea (1890): Flumini Vincula Posuit (he chained the river), says the monument on Victoria Embankment to Sir Joseph Bazalgette, who built London's main sewers and designed this bridge.

The practicals

Underground to Tower Hill to start the walk. From Battersea Bridge catch bus south to Clapham Junction rail station or north to South Kensingtom underground. Take an A-Z or large scale map. Bridge by Bridge through London by Tony Waters (80 pages, Pryor Publications, £4.99) gives details and sketches of all bridges to Teddington Lock. Tourist Board (020 7932 2000) supplies a free information pack on accomodation and guided walks.

Take an A-Z or large scale map. Bridge by Bridge through London by Tony Waters (80 pages, Pryor Publications, £4.99) gives details and sketches of all bridges to Teddington Lock. Tourist Board (020 7932 2000) supplies a free information pack on accomodation and guided walks.

fields.headline: Before the deluge
fields.standfirst: Turkey wants to build a dam far east on the River Tigris. If the plan goes ahead the historic town of Hasankeyf will be drowned and up to 25,000 Kurds will lose their homes. It would be rather like bulldozing Stonehenge... and the British government is likely to provide financial backing.
