webTitle: Sellafield told 'clean up your act or close down'

fields.headline: Sellafield told 'clean up your act or close down'
fields.standfirst: More about the British nuclear industry
fields.trailText: Government safety watchdogs yesterday threatened to shut down commercial activities at Britain's biggest nuclear site, at Sellafield, after damning reports set out a catalogue of "systematic management failures" which allowed workers to routinely falsify quality assurance records.
fields.body:
Government safety watchdogs yesterday threatened to shut down commercial activities at Britain's biggest nuclear site, at Sellafield, after damning reports set out a catalogue of "systematic management failures" which allowed workers to routinely falsify quality assurance records.

Three highly critical reports from the nuclear installations inspectorate (NII) demanded that senior management of British Nuclear Fuels (BNFL) be held responsible for the comprehensive failure of safety culture at the site, in Cumbria.

Laurence Williams, NII chief inspector, said: "It's no use sacking a few production workers. Responsibility must start at the top."

But the government decided to take no immediate action, instead giving Hugh Collum, the new BNFL chairman, two months to come up with sweeping management changes to restore confidence in the company.

A Downing Street spokesman said: "This is serious, it is unacceptable and something needs to be done about it. Something will be done about it."

Number 10 issued a statement supporting the actions of energy minister Helen Liddell. "I have asked Mr Collum for comprehensive and radical suggestions for change, which will deliver the management that the company needs, within two months," she said. "The review should regard no one at no level in the organisation as out of bounds. I know that Hugh Collum shares my view of the need for change."

The reports follow a series of safety incidents at Sellafield which prompted the inspection. At the same time, a set of falsified data was found involving mixed plutonium and uranium fuel (Mox) which was being manufactured at Sellafield for use in Japanese reactors.

The Japanese discovered they had been misled just before the fuel was loaded into their reactors in December and said they could no longer "trust" the company. They are demanding that Britain sends armed ships to Japan to bring the suspect fuel home.

The section of the plant where the falsification occurred is shut down and will not be allowed to restart until the NII is satisfied that the recommendations have been implemented.

This has placed in jeopardy government plans to sell off 49% of BNFL, which have been postponed until after the election. It has also made it near impossible for BNFL to justify opening its £300m Mox plant which needs ministerial approval. The company must prove it has orders for the fuel, but its main customer is Japan.

Poor design of the plant, the tedium of the job. and the ease with which the computer dating logging system was manipulated were all blamed for the falsification problem

Five production workers had been sacked but despite the NII's conclusions that management was to blame no other action has been taken. The report says the site is safe but "the standard of achievement was only just tolerable".

Individual workers were blamed for safety incidents when "there was a trail of poor standards tolerated by management". The attitude of blaming workers for management failures had hit morale, the report said.

Mr Williams said unless the company comes up with solutions within two months he will order the closure of "commercial operations from which the company makes its money."

BNFL chief executive John Taylor and Chris Loughlin, the BNFL board director responsible for Mox business, both of whom could lose their jobs, were yesterday in Japan trying to convince customers that Mox was safe and they should buy some after all.

Mr Taylor said: "We deeply regret these events and the problems they have caused for our customers. We now need to get on with implementing the action plan and restoring our credibility."

Brian Watson, head of the Sellafield site, said: "This has been a shock for us all. It is not good news for our Mox business. We have to drive forward and change the [safety] culture. We have to remember that nobody is saying that Sellafield is unsafe. Safety is, and will always be, our number one priority."

Pete Roche, a Greenpeace nuclear campaigner, said "These reports are a shocking expose of Sellafield's plutonium business. This is a company dealing with one of the most hazardous materials known to mankind and they have been shown to be guilty of lax management and falsifying records.

"The government must act decisively to end nuclear reprocessing and also refuse BNFL the go-ahead to start commercial production of Mox fuel. A mere management reshuffle would be like re-arranging the chairs on the Titanic. Plutonium, once thought to be more valuable than gold, is now worse than useless. This is a dangerous, dirty trade that should be confined to the dustbin of history."

BNFL chief executive John Taylor and Chris Loughlin, the BNFL board director responsible for Mox business, both of whom could lose their jobs, were yesterday in Japan trying to convince customers that Mox was safe and they should buy some after all. Mr Taylor said: "We deeply regret these events and the problems they have caused for our customers. We now need to get on with implementing the action plan and restoring our credibility." Brian Watson, head of the Sellafield site, said: "This has been a shock for us all. It is not good news for our Mox business. We have to drive forward and change the [safety] culture. We have to remember that nobody is saying that Sellafield is unsafe. Safety is, and will always be, our number one priority." Pete Roche, a Greenpeace nuclear campaigner, said "These reports are a shocking expose of Sellafield's plutonium business. This is a company dealing with one of the most hazardous materials known to mankind and they have been shown to be guilty of lax management and falsifying records. "The government must act decisively to end nuclear reprocessing and also refuse BNFL the go-ahead to start commercial production of Mox fuel. A mere management reshuffle would be like re-arranging the chairs on the Titanic. Plutonium, once thought to be more valuable than gold, is now worse than useless. This is a dangerous, dirty trade that should be confined to the dustbin of history."

fields.headline: Modified diet
fields.standfirst: Sue Wheat warns that it is now almost impossible for visitors to the US to avoid GM food
fields.trailText: Sue Wheat warns that it is now almost impossible for visitors to the US to avoid GM food.
fields.body:
Food is something most of us are pretty fussy about on holiday - either because we want to indulge ourselves and eat well or because we don't want to get ill. But certain places are considered "safe", including, undoubtedly, the US.

The biggest worry most tourists are likely to have is severe weight gain, such is the size and calorific value of the portions. But one potentially serious health issue that many Britons have followed closely at home is probably not given a second thought when they go on holiday - genetically-modified food.

Only three years after the first large-scale commercial harvest, GM crops now cover a quarter of US cropland - around 90 million acres - and are fully integrated into the American diet.

But only about a third of Americans are aware that GM foods are being sold. "There's a kind of schizophrenia here," says Charles Margulis, GM campaigner at Greenpeace. "On the one hand, we are extremely health conscious, but on the other we have very high sugar, high fat, high red meat diets. The GM issue is just another contradiction."

There are four main genetically-modified crops in the US - corn, soya, rape seed and cotton seed - and 60-70% of processed food in the US is likely to contain GM ingredients.

The multinationals that control the biotechnology insist they cannot separate GM crops from non-GM crops at source and are fighting the call for labelling.

A holiday-maker will find it practically impossible to eat or drink without consuming something that is genetically modified.

"Some potatoes are also GM so avoid fast-food french fries," says Margulis. "And a small percentage of tomatoes are GM, so processed tomato-based foods like ketchup may also be contaminated.

"Corn syrup is ubiquitous in virtually any sweetened drink," he explains, "so Coke and other sodas are likely to be made with a combination of non-GM and GM corn syrup."

Is the answer for the anti-GM tourist to avoid the US as a holiday destination? Sadly the influence of the US biotechnology companies growing GM crops goes much further than the US. Their crops are exported to Europe for animal feed and ironically, the more the US and European public protests about the issue, the more likely it is that GM crops will be dumped on poorer countries, as happened last September when Russia received illegal shipments of Novartis GM maize from the US.

"Exotic" environments - so vital for tourism - could also be threatened. Scientists are currently assessing the potentially harmful effect on Mexico's biodiversity of the recent arrival of 5 million tons of US maize - up to 35% genetically modified. A Cornell University study showed that 44% of the larvae of the monarch butterfly fed with milkweed contaminated with GM Bt-maize pollen died within 48 hours.

"The fall migration of monarch butterflies from Canada to central Mexican forests is a natural wonder," Dr Jane Rissler, senior staff scientist with the Union of Concerned Scientists, points out. "The loss of monarchs - and perhaps many other incredible species around the world - is too high a price to pay for engineered corn."

The Consumers Union website has a comprehensive list of everyday GM products sold in the US. The True Food Campaign can be contacted at 0171-865 8100.

fields.headline: Bloody Sunday rifles destroyed
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The Bloody Sunday inquiry yesterday expressed "grave concern" at the ministry of defence's admission that it had destroyed two army rifles despite assurances that the weapons would be preserved.
fields.body:
The Bloody Sunday inquiry yesterday expressed "grave concern" at the ministry of defence's admission that it had destroyed two army rifles despite assurances that the weapons would be preserved.

The admission, which provoked anger among nationalist politicians and relatives of the 14 people shot dead by paratroopers in 1972, was made in a written parliamentary answer by Geoffrey Hoon, the defence secretary. He told MPs that two of the remaining five rifles wanted by the inquiry were scrapped.

It was a matter of "deep regret", he said, and an MoD police investigation had been set up at which the inquiry would be invited to send an observer.

A spokeswoman for the inquiry said it "viewed the disposal of rifles with very grave concern and has asked the MoD for an explanation".

John Hume, the SDLP leader, yesterday described the episode as "very strange" but welcomed the investigation into "how and why it happened".

He added: "I would have thought that given that there is an inquiry going on into what happened on Bloody Sunday, that weapons of that nature would have been very carefully watched ... Obviously there are people who will believe it was done quite deliberately to remove evidence."

Sinn Fein's chairman, Mitchel McLaughlin, accused the prime minister of deliberately undermining the inquiry. He said Mr Blair "presided over a government which has allowed the course of proceedings to be stalled, obstructed and undermined".

The Alliance party deputy leader, Seamus Close, said: "It is not only the relatives of Bloody Sunday who are disgusted to learn that the MoD has permitted to be destroyed rifles which were being held as evidence for the inquiry.

"Anyone with a sense of decency and integrity will be incensed by this act of contempt. Apologies are as useless as the MoD's ability to secure the rifles.

"The culture of lies and deceit appears to have infiltrated yet another aspect of life. If the MoD couldn't defend two rifles, how could it defend a nation?"

Gregory McCartney, solicitor of the family of Jimmy Wray who was one of the 14 killed in the 1972 shootings, said: "This could not have happened accidentally. This can only be regarded as a deliberate attempt by the MoD to frustrate the workings of the Saville inquiry and prevent the truth of Bloody Sunday ever coming out."

The inquiry asked the MoD to locate 29 rifles thought to have been fired on Bloody Sunday. Mr Hoon said 14 had been destroyed as the part of a programme to take self-loading rifles out of service. Another 10 had been sold to private companies, leaving five in the MoD's possession.

Mr Hoon added: "Despite an embargo on the movement of the remaining five, two of these rifles were destroyed on January 26 and 28, 2000.

"That two rifles have been destroyed is a matter of deep regret and an investigation has been launched by the chief constable of the MoD police to which officers from the West Mercia constabulary will be seconded."

The inquiry said it had asked the MoD to see if any of the 10 rifles sold could be recovered.

fields.headline: Arts of poison
fields.standfirst: He painted Byron and knew Hazlitt - oh, and he was a murderer.  DJ Taylor  on Andrew Motion's Wainewright The Poisoner
fields.trailText: He painted Byron and knew Hazlitt - oh, and he was a murderer. DJ Taylor on Andrew Motion's Wainewright The Poisoner
fields.body:
Wainewright The Poisoner
Andrew Motion
Faber, £20, 305pp
Buy it at BOL

Not much remains of Thomas Griffiths Wainewright (1794 -1847). What does is shot beyond repair: a few paintings and sketches, including a sulky-looking self-portrait; scattered appearances in pre-Victorian gentlemen's magazines; a late-period ticket-of-leave appeal from his convict's lodgement in Van Diemen's Land.

Essentially he seems to have been a minor Romantic hanger-on, one of many small fry sizzling in the wake of mighty acquaintances. He painted Byron (a carefully romanticised version of an earlier portrait by Thomas Phillips) and knew Keats, Lamb and Hazlitt, as well as attracting the notice of a longer-lived generation of Victorian writers such as Thackeray's friend Bryan Proctor, who were able to give some account of him to a fascinated mid-century public.

Inevitably, given the rumours that gave Wainewright's reputation its gothic sheen, the artistic achievements were a sideshow to the main event. Later Victorians remembered him for a series of unexplained and sinister deaths, which coloured his memory to the exclusion of anything much else: the passing of his uncle in 1828 (which enabled the nephew to inherit a commodious property at Chiswick), the mysterious demise of his mother-in-law a year later, and finally a devious scam involving the death of his wife's half-sister a few days after the framing of a fistful of life insurance policies.

Eventually brought to trial in 1837 after a rash visit home from his French hiding place, Wainewright was arraigned on forgery charges, but no one - either during his transportation on the convict hulk or after his death 10 years later - was in any doubt of the greater guilt.

Subsequently he became a byword for Victorian notions of Romantic excess. Bulwer Lytton dramatised his career in Lucretia (benefiting from the input of an insurance company official); Dickens wrote a sensational serial, "The Hunted Man". The seal was set on Wainewright's peculiar position in the end-of-century art/morality standoff by Oscar Wilde's remark that "The fact of a man being a Poisoner is nothing against his prose" - which is true, perhaps, if not as startling as Wilde or indeed Motion appears to think it is.

No difficulty, then, in marking down Wainewright's attraction to his latest biographer. There is the irresistibly seductive vision of the Romantic extremist, plunging Byronically through a world of strychnine and high aesthetics; there are the tantalising byways populated by all manner of contemporary curios such as the artists Henry Fuseli and Theodore von Holst, the latter responsible for some highly graphic erotica. And above all there is the beguiling sense of a blank canvas - writing a life of which so little is known that a satisfyingly large amount can be inferred gives the biographer an importance which is not allowed him in those lives already commemorated by a dozen fat volumes of letters.

This is Motion's lure and his justification, but it is also his dilemma, and one which, despite all manner of graceful flourishes and a huge amount of lightly worn learning, I don't think he comes anywhere near to solving. Wainewright The Poisoner is described as an "experimental biography". Normally this kind of signposting awakens the direst forebodings. After all, the "experimental novel" tag is practically a guarantee of unreadability, and I have never studied anything calling itself an experimental poem without wanting to read the poet a lecture on scansion.

Motion's experiment, it turns out, is to use the very limited materials available as the bones of an extended confession, courtesy of his subject, with the footnotes appended to each chapter acting as a kind of brake: confirming some things, denying others and at their best providing a dialogue between fake-Wainewright and biographer (or - to be perfectly blunt about it - a dialogue between Motion and himself).

Considering this particular line of biographical attack, I should immediately declare an interest. In the course of writing Thackeray I soon identified three or four areas of Thackeray's life that I felt were crucial but where practically no information remained.

One of the most obvious was Thackeray's relationship with his wife Isabella in the years after her madness, a period when she was placed in the care of a well-disposed keeper named Mrs Bakewell. Uneasily conscious that a biographer ought to say something about the undocumented spectacle of the novelist visiting his wife in the sequestered house in Camberwell, but knowing that only fragmentary evidence existed for what was said, I ended up inventing a two- or three-paragraph "Bakewell Report" in which Isabella's chatelaine reflects on her employer's visits. At the time this seemed to me a legitimate device (several reviewers thought otherwise). But applied to a 300-page biography, especially of such an elusive and protean fish as Wainewright, it creates more problems than it solves.

The most obvious drawback, perhaps, is that the Wainewright voice, however carefully invested with authenticating references, is simply not interesting enough: goodish pastiche for a chapter or three, maybe, but, when enumerating the ranks of his arty acquaintance, not much more than a gazetteer. Throughout the book one looks for the sense of what might be called a personal myth - something that could raise Wainewright out of his world and turn him into a Romantic avenging angel rather than the also-ran we know him to have been. Somehow this never happens, and all that remains is the sense of an unreliable, disingenuous figure complaining that life has conspired against him.

From the reader's point of view, too, the whole thing is impossibly weighed down with imputation. With the criminal elements trailed in advance, we know what to expect, and consequently can only regard the artistic fragments (most of the paintings and drawings were dispersed after his death) as a preliminary to the real meat of Wainewright's life.

Which, of course, is Motion's point: the portrait of Byron and the strychnine in the soup are two sides of the same coin. And yet the Romantic extremist line never really convinces. A murderer may produce a work of art, but at the very least the knowledge that he has murdered is likely to colour and obscure any real appreciation of that art; Motion provides insufficient evidence that Wainewright had any great talent.

Though Wainewright The Poisoner is neatly done and crammed with beguiling detail, to read these accounts of seedy continental exile and the indignities of his final years in Tasmania (Wainewright had expected a light sentence in return for admitting to two minor fraud charges, but was grievously disappointed) is to hear a constant undertow of ghost voices, a sense of what the material would have made as a novel by Peter Ackroyd or A S Byatt rather than an "experimental biography" by the poet laureate.

This is not an insult: Motion's earlier The Lamberts and Philip Larkin: A Writer's Life are conspicuously well realised attempts on real lives. But for all the good intentions of this book - its refusal to be baffled by dead ends and the ceaseless crash of tree trunks felled across the pursuer's path - it has to be marked down as "honourable failure".

fields.headline: Star find by amateur astronomer
fields.standfirst: Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: Steve Foulkes, 39, yesterday celebrated becoming only the fifth Briton to see a supernova using a home telescope.
fields.body:
Steve Foulkes, 39, yesterday celebrated becoming only the fifth Briton to see a supernova using a home telescope.

He nearly missed the spectacular event. "I noticed a faint difference in the NGC 2415 galaxy, but it was so small I carried on. Later I re-examined the image, and there it was, a supernova." He has a 10in reflecting telescope that stands more than 9ft tall and dominates his back garden in Worcester.

His find was part of a two-year search of 10,000 galaxies with the UK Supernova Patrol. The dying star's brightness suggests it was in fact an extremely rare hypernova.

Mr Foulkes has been interested in stars since seven and built his own telescope at 14.

webTitle: Power grid put at risk by solar eruption

fields.headline: Power grid put at risk by solar eruption
fields.standfirst: Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: A powerful magnetic storm, caused by an eruption of hot, electrically charged gas from the sun, may hit earth this weekend.
fields.body:
A powerful magnetic storm, caused by an eruption of hot, electrically charged gas from the sun, may hit earth this weekend.

It would disrupt electricity supply grids worldwide, damage satellites, and provide a stunning display of the Northern Lights much further south than usual. However there would be no direct threat to life, and it is possible the vast cloud of gas, or plasma, could miss earth altogether.

The sun's eruption was spotted on Thursday by a joint European-Nasa unmanned space observatory, Soho. Two solar flares burst outwards, followed by a characteristic halo around the entire solar disc - a coronal mass ejection, when up to 10bn tons of plasma are hurled into space at up to 1,250 miles a second.

The sun's activity is entering the peak of its 11-year cycle this year, and scientists predict more space storms to come.

In 1989, 6m people in Canada were left without electrical power when a surge caused by a solar eruption knocked out Quebec's hydro-electric system. Three years ago, a TV relay satellite, Telstar 401, died as it was beaming an episode of Star Trek down to the US. In 1998, four-fifths of all pagers in the US failed when another satellite, Galaxy 4, was overwhelmed during intense solar activity.

"The thing is a cloud of gas carrying its own magnetic field," said Richard Harrison of the Rutherford Appleton laboratory in Didcot, Oxfordshire. "The earth has a magnetic field, and when you bring two magnets together you expect to see an effect."

A spokesman for Britain's national grid said: "Occasionally there have been localised effects. I don't think there's ever been a loss of supply.

"We are quite well prepared. We have a forecast based on satellites, so we can put contingency measures in place. A lot of them are quite similar to what we would do for normal severe weather."

fields.trailText: It seems to hang in space like some vast reclining Henry Moore nude. It is Eros, an asteroid the size of the Isle of Wight.
fields.body:
It seems to hang in space like some vast reclining Henry Moore nude. It is Eros, an asteroid the size of the Isle of Wight.

Humankind has never peered so closely at one of these eccentric orphans of the solar system, the lumps of rock that tumble around the sun between earth, Mars and Jupiter. For the first time, a spacecraft - Nasa's Near probe - has gone into orbit around an asteroid, sending back extraordinary pic tures of a mini-planet with a double hump a mile high on one side and a giant crater the size of a small city on the other.

Giant, solitary boulders dot the Erotic horizon - one is big enough to fill Wembley stadium - and lines running lengthwise over the asteroid's surface suggest it was smashed off a bigger planet in some ancient space collision.

During Near's year-long orbit of Eros, ending when the craft brushes the asteroid's surface with the edge of a solar panel and photographs the mark it leaves, all the Erotic features will be named after famous lovers. The probe entered orbit around the asteroid, one of the great feats of navigation of the space age, on Valentine's Day.

But there is a darker side to the mission. If earth was ever to make a rendezvous with an asteroid the size of Eros, it would kill us all. Nasa wants to learn enough about these space bodies to be able to take preventive measures should an asteroid or comet appear likely to hit our planet.

An asteroid smashing into earth is thought to have been responsible for the extinction of the dinosaurs 65m years ago, and a collision with a space body two-thirds of a mile across or bigger is thought likely every 300,000 years.

Eros's orbit around the sun takes it nowhere near earth, but there are an estimated 500 to 1,000 asteroids of dangerous size in the mercifully immense stretches of space between earth and the near planets.

Nasa has set up a taskforce called the near-earth asteroid tracking system to identify 90% of these potential menaces by 2010. None of the 322 it has found so far pose any threat.

A big asteroid hitting the earth would impact with such speed that its energy would be instantly converted to heat, creating an explosion with the force of millions of nuclear weapons. Besides the damage caused by the resultant blast and shockwave, the debris raised by the collision would blot out the sun for years.

Widespread scepticism that there was any need to spend money on an asteroid early-detection system was shaken in 1994 when the world saw pictures of cometary fragments smashing into Jupiter, producing explosions the size of earth.

fields.headline: Holidays on Mars 'within 50 years'
fields.standfirst:
GM trees could create climate for humans on red planet, American scientists' convention is told


Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: Within 50 years humans could begin to make a home on Mars with the help of genetically modified trees. Freeman Dyson, a physicist from Princeton in New Jersey, made the prediction at the American Association for the Advancement of Science's meeting in Washington DC yesterday.
fields.body:
Within 50 years humans could begin to make a home on Mars with the help of genetically modified trees. Freeman Dyson, a physicist from Princeton in New Jersey, made the prediction at the American Association for the Advancement of Science's meeting in Washington DC yesterday.

"I'm thinking 50 years ahead, when we are really in command of biotechnology. We are just tinkering at the moment," Professor Dyson told a gathering of astrophysicists and space biologists that discussed the prospects for tourism in space.

"Building habitats on Mars is something I have been dreaming about. It is clearly not going to happen in the next 20 years, but probably will in the next 50."

The way to do it, he said, was to grow the habitat - by breeding plants that would create their own greenhouses around themselves, and giving out oxygen that would allow animals to breathe. "That ought to revolutionise the whole business of operating outside the earth.

"The real problem with humans in space is: where do you go? You need habitats which are cheap and reasonably user-friendly. Forests, of course, are what we are -accustomed to. If forests will learn [through genetic modification] to build huge greenhouses over their heads, they can flourish on Mars and anywhere where there is water and suitable minerals. Maybe not on the moon, but certainly everywhere else in the solar system, there is water to be found.

"I think of a turtle growing its shell, and a polar bear growing fur - it's something that animals are very good at. But for some reason plants haven't learned the trick, so it's something we could teach them. We have to be able to write the DNA - and we don't know yet how to read it."

Yoji Kondo, a Nasa astrophysicist, told the meeting that 10 companies were trying to develop reusable spacecraft that would bring down launch costs and permit space tourism.

Kathie Olsen, Nasa's chief scientist, pointed out that biotechnology firms were using the space shuttle, and would command 30% of the international space station taking shape in orbit for commercial experiments. Nasa was working on diagnostic equipment that could accompany astronauts on a nine-month journey to Mars, and even experimenting with growing sweet potatoes in space.

Doctors had embarked on serious research into health problems that would arise on long journeys in zero gravity.

Prof Dyson added: "People do love to go to weird places for reasons we cannot fathom. Humans have this tendency to travel huge distances, for reasons that are very hard to discern.

"We are a restless bunch of creatures, and so many of us have too much money and don't know how to spend it."

webTitle: When it comes to pruning shrubs, shape is not the only consideration

fields.headline: When it comes to pruning shrubs, shape is not the only consideration
fields.trailText: I wrote last month about various ways to shape shrubs that have a permanent structure. To round the subject off, I'll take a look at renewable shrubs that have little or no individuality in shape, but that need regular pruning so as to gain maximum value from their flowers or foliage.
fields.body:
I wrote last month about various ways to shape shrubs that have a permanent structure. To round the subject off, I'll take a look at renewable shrubs that have little or no individuality in shape, but that need regular pruning so as to gain maximum value from their flowers or foliage.

These are the sort of shrubs that, having inherited them from a previous owner into whose property you have recently moved, you look at rather hopelessly, wondering what on earth to do and where to start. Once you have them under control, or if you started them from scratch yourself, the procedures are simple. You want to remove the old and tired wood, and leave or encourage the production of new.

When? If the shrub flowered in spring, prune it immediately afterwards. Always make sure it is well fed, so that it feels like responding to your treatment. A shrub that feels unable to make new wood is a hopeless case. A spring pruning is followed by months of growing weather, during which your shrub can make good its losses with young growth. Your pruning is containing the overall size of the shrub, which saves on space uselessly filled.

If the shrub flowers from summer on, there may be quite a bit of latitude over when to prune it. I dislike pruning a shrub that is a mass of foliage. It is difficult to get a clear picture of what you are doing. Also, in the presence of a lot of tender young shoots that you'll be wanting to encourage and leave, it is woefully easy (with a philadelphus, for example) to knock them right off in your clumsy enthusiasm for cutting out the flowered wood. If you leave the job until the winter, you'll be able to see, and judge, the bones of the shrub, and the young shoots will have toughened and no longer be inclined to drop off like the tip of a frightened lizard's tail.

So you can get into those shrubs now and for the next month, if you haven't done so already. Leave all the straight, unbranched young wood intact and remove the old, intricately branched, flowered wood. This should be cut back either to where a strong, young shoot arises off the old stem or, if none such exists, right back to the ground (leaving no stumps or snags to get in your way when pruning in future).

If the shrub doesn't need a legacy of wood on which to flower this year, but does it near to the ends of the young shoots that it will produce this year, then you can prune it hard back to stumps all over. These are the summer-to-autumn-flowering shrubs, such as the common Buddleia davidii , or the Spanish broom, Spartium junceum . Their pruning is normally delayed until March, with the idea that an earlier pruning might result, during a mild winter's spell, in their making new growth, only for it to be frosted if a cold spell followed. This danger can be exaggerated. I often prune if I'm there, ready to do it, rather than wait and then find I can't make the time to do it. I like to prune my hydrangeas, for instance, before their buds have expanded so far as to be easily knocked off, and that is often as early as March.

Now let us suppose that you are confronted by a huge old philadelphus or Kerria japonica or weigela that has never been pruned in its life. If you're told, "cut out the old wood and leave the new intact", you'll rightly protest that there's no new wood to leave. Then you need to create the circumstances that will encourage new wood production (there are, I admit, cases where it'll be best to remove the old monster altogether and to start again). So, making your cuts (probably with a slim saw) as close to the ground as possible, remove whole branches and leave whole branches growing. Next winter, complete the job; remove the other half. If you wish to minimise the shock, you can do this all in thirds. The point is that the shrub will have been forced to make young shoots and, after two or three years, you'll be starting with a clean sheet.

If you are pruning entirely for foliage effect, the method will be the same as for late-flowering shrubs: prune the shrub hard back all over. This encourages lush foliage production. Physocarpus opulifolius 'Dart's Gold' would be an example. You'll be sacrificing its flowers, but they are of no account anyway. The foliage is what you are interested in.

I grow a number of shrubs for (often spurious) sub-tropical effect. Ultra-hard pruning encourages them to produce leaves of enormous size on a shrub, rather than smaller leaves on a tree. Typical examples would be the tree of heaven, Ailanthus altissima (big, pinnate leaves); the big-leaf maple from the western US, Acer macrophylla ; Paulownia tomentosa , with huge, furry, rounded leaves (as a tree, it carries mauve, foxglove-like flowers); and Catalpa bignonioides 'Aurea', the golden-leaved catalpa. You can experiment with your own examples.

It is the same principle as is used by exhibitors of hybrid tea roses, who want the largest blooms and encourage their production by ultra-hard pruning and ultra-heavy feeding. This treatment has a weakening effect on the plant's constitution. Its life will be shortened. You'll just have to accept this, and you'll have a replacement ready for when it's time for a changeover. You'll be well advised to change the site where the replacement is grown, as well. Certainly with roses

webTitle: Table talk  Hussein Chalayan named fashion designer of the year

fields.headline: Table talk  Hussein Chalayan named fashion designer of the year
fields.standfirst: London fashion week: special report
fields.trailText: Hussein Chalayan, whose recent show featured chair covers that doubled as frocks and a coffee table that turned into a skirt, scored a victory for the avant garde yesterday when he won the British fashion awards' Designer of the Year award for the second year running.
fields.body:
Hussein Chalayan, whose recent show featured chair covers that doubled as frocks and a coffee table that turned into a skirt, scored a victory for the avant garde yesterday when he won the British fashion awards' Designer of the Year award for the second year running.

Chalayan, 29, who was born in Northern Cyprus but moved to London as a child, is widely agreed to have immense talent - the word "genius" is not infrequently used. His shows, staged for the past two seasons at Sadler's Wells theatre in London, have no need for celebrities or exposed nipples - the technically stunning clothes keep audiences spellbound.

Chalayan beat off stiff competition from design duo Clements Ribeiro and young designer Matthew Williamson.

The New Generation Designer award, intended to recognise emerging talent, went to Tracey Boyd. A close friend of Radio One star Zoe Ball, and a former children's books illustrator, Boyd has been showing on the official London Fashion Week catwalk for only two seasons, but has established herself as a commercially-savvy name.

Persuading Naomi Campbell out of retirement and into a minuscule white lace dress for Thursday night's show wasn't enough to snare Julien Macdonald the Glamour award, which went to Stella McCartney.

Top Shop beat Jigsaw and French Connection to the Retailer of the Year award. Other awards went to Ozwald Boateng for menswear, shoemaker Jimmy Choo for accessories, Maharishi, pioneers of the "utility" look, for street style, and recently revived fashion favourite Burberry in the classic category.

fields.headline: Euro files: MBA briefs
fields.trailText: • Erasmus University in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, will launch a 15-month part-time MBA course later this year, which will lead to a masters degree in e-commerce. The Global E-commerce Masters course will introduce the first batch of 30 students to all aspects of e-commerce and the consequences of worldwide electronic business activities.
fields.body:
 Erasmus University in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, will launch a 15-month part-time MBA course later this year, which will lead to a masters degree in e-commerce. The Global E-commerce Masters course will introduce the first batch of 30 students to all aspects of e-commerce and the consequences of worldwide electronic business activities.

The university will work with a consortium of colleges in Athens, Atlanta and Cologne, along with business schools in Copenhagen and Bergen. The joint venture is sponsored by the European Union and the G7 group of top industrialised nations.

 The Stockholm School of Economics (SSE) in Sweden has been accredited by Equis, the standards watchdog run by the European Federation of Management Development. The backbone of the school is its four-year MSc programme in Business Administration and Economics. See www.hhs.se

 Spanish business school, IESE has established an Entrepreneurship Foundation to provide funding for business plans written by its MBA students, executive MBA students and alumni. The foundation will provide seed funding and there are two internet-related projects already in the pipeline. See www.iese.es

 The National Economic Research Institution of Spain and the Tianjin Institute of Finance and Economics have established an international training centre in north China to train managing staffs for small and medium-sized enterprises.

The centre, financed by the Spanish government, will recruit its first group of students from May 2000 for one-year MBA courses.

The new training centre will also support European enterprises in expanding their businesses.

webTitle: Join the fast track to success

fields.headline: Join the fast track to success
fields.standfirst: Shorter MBAs have their strengths
fields.trailText: The transition from the 20th to the 21st century, has provoked an increase in interest in postgraduate business qualifications. Young, ambitious managers are desperate to keep their careers fizzing by checking out the prospectuses of MBA courses at leading business schools.
fields.body:
The transition from the 20th to the 21st century, has provoked an increase in interest in postgraduate business qualifications. Young, ambitious managers are desperate to keep their careers fizzing by checking out the prospectuses of MBA courses at leading business schools.

In the past decade, Europe has gained an appreciation of the value of the MBA. The number of European schools offering MBA courses has increased tenfold and the qualification has become almost mandatory among high-flying execs.

However, not all MBA courses offer financial and promotional benefits to justify the sacrifices they entail. The very proliferation of MBA courses has threatened to dilute their value. Anyone contemplating an MBA is therefore well advised to look into it carefully before they sign up.

For those who have been to the favoured schools, the leap is well worth it. Europe's burgeoning mergers and acquisition activity is powering growth in the demand for top drawer executives. Plus, as the lure of internet firms proves increasingly enticing, the demand for top MBA graduates willing to pursue a career in e-commerce is growing as fast as dot.com firms.

The big attraction about studying in mainland Europe is that it provides total immersion in the process of living and working abroad. Students learn what it's like to live in a foreign a country, which is the way of the future for management in a global economy.

The exposure to different way of thinking about management problems that comes with cultural diversity is also an important part of the learning process. Strong bilingual programmes can usually be found in countries with large domestic markets and clients, such as Spain, France and Germany

Increasingly, European recruiters are targeting the top business schools on their own continent when seeking new talent, according to a survey conducted by Cox Communications in association with Europe's largest management consultancies.

Another important consideration is the length of the course: as a rule of thumb, European business schools offer shorter courses compared to their transatlantic counterparts.

The most popular programmes for MBAs are the single-year courses, pioneered by European schools. Typical one-year programmes include those offered at leading schools such as Insead, IMD and Instituto de Empresa. Their philosophy is that studying for an MBA should not interrupt a student's career for too long. Most candidates have already been working for several years and don't want to put their career on hold for too long.

By comparison, most courses in the US and UK last almost two years, costing students substantially more in fees and loss of earnings.

Insead, for example runs an accelerated full-time MBA that actually lasts for 10 months. The course seeks to prepare participants by simulating business reality through problem solving in small groups. More than half the participants have studied or worked outside their home country before coming to Insead.

Shorter European MBAs have the advantage of reducing opportunity costs in the form of lost wages, but have the disadvantage of allowing little time for the digestion of material - a great deal of learning has to be crammed into a very short space of time.

Yet one-year, full-time courses are the ideal qualifications for management consulting firms, which are the largest recruiters of MBA graduates. While there have been rumours of a slowdown in recruitment by US firms, many of their European counterparts are planning to increase their numbers this year.

For details of MBA courses see www.mba.hobsons.com

Most candidates have already been working for several years and don't want to put their career on hold for too long. By comparison, most courses in the US and UK last almost two years, costing students substantially more in fees and loss of earnings. Insead, for example runs an accelerated full-time MBA that actually lasts for 10 months. The course seeks to prepare participants by simulating business reality through problem solving in small groups. More than half the participants have studied or worked outside their home country before coming to Insead. Shorter European MBAs have the advantage of reducing opportunity costs in the form of lost wages, but have the disadvantage of allowing little time for the digestion of material - a great deal of learning has to be crammed into a very short space of time. Yet one-year, full-time courses are the ideal qualifications for management consulting firms, which are the largest recruiters of MBA graduates. While there have been rumours of a slowdown in recruitment by US firms, many of their European counterparts are planning to increase their numbers this year. For details of MBA courses see www.mba.hobsons.com

webTitle: Your place at the heart of Europe

fields.headline: Your place at the heart of Europe
fields.trailText: The European Commission's Action Jean Monnet project is organising a one-day fair next weekend in Brussels to bring together students interested in EU integration programmes and the universities which offer them.
fields.body:
The European Commission's Action Jean Monnet project is organising a one-day fair next weekend in Brussels to bring together students interested in EU integration programmes and the universities which offer them.

Action Jean Monnet, set up in 1990, is aimed at promoting knowledge on European integration by providing start-up subsidies for new courses, chairs and modules. In the last decade, some 491 Jean Monnet chairs have been established and more than 1300 new courses have been created.

Around 250 000 students each year are now benefiting from these Jean Monnet courses in EU member States as well as in Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic.

Exhibitors at next weekend's event will include the University of Birmingham, University of North London, University of Amsterdam, University of Portsmouth, Centre International de Formation Europe, University of Limerick, Queen's University of Belfast, John Hopkins University, European Centre for Public Affairs Brussels, University of Loughborough, Universite Catholique de Louvain, University of Central Lancashire, University of Essex, University of Reading, University of Gent, University of Essex, University of Florence, University of Strasbourg, University of Exeter, University of Bristol, Katholic Universitiet Leuven, University of Catania and the University of Leeds.

The fair is supported by The Guardian and the University Association for Contemporary European Studies in London. It is also sponsored by European Voice, a weekly magazine which reports on events inside the EU institutions.

"This is a unique opportunity for academics, students and young professionals to find out exactly which courses are available in the EU, to meet the programme directors and to decide which courses would be most appropriate for them," says Adrian Scally, responsible for project development at European Voice. "We have every intention of making this a regular event to ensure that all interested parties have an ideal opportunity to sample what is on offer academically to prepare them for a career in EU-related professions."

Jacqueline Lastenouse of the Action Jean Monnet Project Unit says: "We are extremely excited to have this golden opportunity not only to attract potential students to our courses, but to raise awareness of our funding project among other universities and academic institutions who are interested in developing EU studies programmes."

The fair will take place on Saturday February 26 from 10am to 6pm at the Dorint Hotel. 11-19 Blv. Charlemagne, B-1000, Brussels. The hotel is centrally located and within walking distance to EU institutions such as the Council of Ministers, and European Parliament.

Admission to the fair is free. For more details, see the European Voice magazine website at www.european-voice.com/event/

webTitle: Are you too smart for your own good? Don't get tongue-tied

fields.headline: Are you too smart for your own good? Don't get tongue-tied
fields.trailText: In a perfect world we would pass the right exams, gain the correct professional certificates and walk into a job which neatly matched our qualifications. But as many graduates discover, it doesn't always work out like that.
fields.body:
In a perfect world we would pass the right exams, gain the correct professional certificates and walk into a job which neatly matched our qualifications. But as many graduates discover, it doesn't always work out like that and there may be occasions when you find yourself applying for jobs for which, it is deemed, you are "over-qualified".

Being refused a job because you're too well qualified does not, on the face of it, make a lot of sense. It's a bit like a millionaire trying to buy a packet of Polos, but being turned away because he has too much money.

But according to Daniel Porot, author of The 101 Toughest Interview Questions (Ten Speed Press) there are three essential criteria which every interviewer wants to be satisfied. Can you actually do the job? Will you fit into the organisation? And how much will you cost the company?

While a surfeit of the right qualifications will undoubtedly help you jump the first hurdle, being over-qualified could cause you problems with the next two.

"Most employers have had bad experiences in the past when hiring people and need to know that they won't be making a mistake by hiring you," says Daniel. "You must make the interviewer feel the risks to them are very limited if you are hired."

Look at your training and your list of BAs, BScs, MAs, MScs, PGCEs and PhDs. If they significantly exceed those being sought for a particular position you shouldn't be surprised or insulted if the "Don't you consider yourself over-qualified for this position?" question makes an appearance in an interview.

By thinking this through ahead of the interview you can prevent yourself from being blind-sided by what sounds like a trick question. Respond as you would to any other interviewer question or comment; use it as an opportunity to present your side of the story positively. Don't get defensive.

Ask yourself, "What is this interviewer really concerned about?" He or she probably isn't worried that you're just too darn smart or would bring too much expertise and knowledge to the job.

The concern may be that this job is just a stop-gap for you or that you're in desperate financial straits and that you will bail out as soon as you find something better. If you uncover this as your interviewer's rationale, use your CV to point to student or extra-curricular activities as proof that you have staying power.

Before the interview make a list of the top five or six reasons that you really want this job and why it is the logical next step for you in your career.

Is it an introduction to a new industry, an opportunity to relocate back to your home town or a foot in the door to a new career field? Evaluate this list for your strongest reasons and be ready to talk about them even before the over-qualification issue arises.

If the question is asked, make your reply a positive one. Thank the interviewer, with a smile, for their positive evaluation of you and your skills.

Answer with something like, "Thanks, I've worked hard to build up my portfolio of skills thus far, but like everyone else, I still have a lot to learn and from my research your company sounds like the type of place that I can do that."

A little humble pie doesn't hurt if you position yourself as a willing team player looking to join a winning team.

webTitle: Language skills are your EU passport

fields.headline: Language skills are your EU passport
fields.standfirst: Remember to lobby too
fields.trailText: As the frontiers of the European Union advance, so too do the career opportunities for graduates wishing to work in one of its institutions. Britain is under-represented in Brussels at present, but a postgraduate qualification in languages could be your way in.
fields.body:
Parlez vous francais? As the frontiers of the European Union advance, so too do the career opportunities for graduates wishing to work in one of its institutions. Britain is under-represented in Brussels at present, but a postgraduate qualification in languages could be your way in.

The administrative and policy-making institutions at the centre of European policy, such as the Commission, the Council of Ministers, the Economic and Social Committee and the Court of Justice are situated mainly in Brussels and Luxembourg where they employ around 25,000 people.

The Court of Auditors, the European Investment Bank, the European Monetary Institute and European Central Bank also recruit graduates but on a less extensive scale.

According to the Commission, successful candidates are usually those who demonstrate excellent communication skills, cultural awareness and an ability to work closely with people from other countries.

A background in law or international politics is advantageous too, but fluency in English and another language - usually French - is normally a pre-requisite.

According to the Association of Graduate Careers Advisory Services a postgraduate degree in languages is one of the most useful and well rewarded qualifications that graduates can get - though since few courses come with any form of financial assistance from the government, more postgraduates are opting for the part-time route.

The entry point to a job working for the EU is usually through an open competition advertised in the Official Journal of the European Communities, available in many careers services. If you are successful at the competition stage, your name will be placed in the 'book' - a kind of holding list - as potentially suitable for employment. Another entry point is through the UK Civil Service European Fast Stream

Once you're on the waiting list, it's time to make contact with people who can help you, such as employees of the institutions in which you are interested, and perhaps your local MEP too. Be prepared to lobby and promote yourself to get in. UKREP, the British representation in Brussels, can help you with this lobbying process once you have passed the open competition.

Then consider going to Brussels in person, seeking out some insiders who might be able to help. Directorate generals which have a British head can be particularly useful.

It may take up to a year to get off the 'reserve' list or 'book' and into a job so have a contingency plan to support yourself in the meantime. For example, you could try to secure a 'stage' or period of work experience with one of the institutions. Stages - which are advertised twice a year - are strictly temporary and people who complete a stage still have to apply for permanent jobs via an open competition.

For the last five years the EU has been running a scheme called Eures (European Employment Services) - a network of 450 'euroadvisers' across its member states. A euroadviser can help you apply for a five-month graduate traineeship within the European Commission. Eures also holds information on the annual competition for jobs in the Brussels administration

For more information see the website: www.europa.eu.int/

webTitle: Moving on up: An ABC guide to  successful  secondments

fields.headline: Moving on up: An ABC guide to  successful  secondments
fields.trailText: Feel that there's no sparkle left in your current post? Why not consider a secondment?
fields.body:
A. Second helpings

If you work for a flat organisation, feel there's no sparkle left and nowhere to go, how would the idea of trying out a new job whilst keeping your existing one appeal? That's just what a secondment can give: the chance to do something new with the safety net of your own job to go back to, is a real treat. It gives the freedom to be creative and take risks. That's why secondments often act as a springboard to some serious career development.

B. Home and away

Check if one of the existing schemes that encourage cross fertilisation between companies and other organisations could apply to you. The professional body representing your occupation will have details. If there's no ready made scheme, try tailoring your own. Propose spending time in an organisation your employer is keen to develop a partnership with, or another department in your company. Concentrate on what the employer stands to gain rather than your aspirations.

C. Second sight

Removing yourself before a take-over or major restructuring may not be wise. Whilst away in person try to remain in spirit. Remind the company you exist by updating your boss with regular reports. Keep in touch socially or by going to the odd staff meeting. Don't crow. Adopt a 'missing you dreadfully, working hard, learning lots that will add value when I come back' attitude. Nobody will believe you but they'll appreciate your tact.

fields.headline: Cool companies
fields.standfirst: No 27: Pitney Bowes
fields.trailText: No 27: Pitney Bowes
fields.body:
These are exciting times for employees at Pitney Bowes, the leading multinational provider of mailing and messaging products. The world of business communication is evolving at a head-spinning rate, with companies gasping for solutions to their increasingly complex messaging needs.

Pitney Bowes has a unique knowledge of mail, faxes, copiers, software, financing and messaging and this makes it well positioned to build its range of businesses in new ways.

The company offers a wide range of mailing equipment to suit low and high volume users and its current product line-up includes franking machines, scales, folders, inserters, sealers, labellers, letter openers and envelope printers.

The company provides more than 2m customers in 120 countries with products and services in mailing, office systems, production mail, business services, software solutions and financing. Its commitment to research and development has yielded a portfolio of more than 3,000 patents, placing it among the top 200 patent holders in the US for the last decade.

Pitney Bowes' US parent is now concentrating on producing internet software which allows the secure transfer of electronic documents.

It has, for example just received approval from the U.S. Postal Service to begin the final phase of beta testing for its ClickStamp Online and ClickStamp Plus products which allow users to instantly access postage, 24 hours a day, and print it onto envelopes from a standard ink jet or laser printer.

Pitney Bowes has been at the leading edge of office automation since 1922 when it introduced the first franking machine into Britain. Today it is market leader with a share of almost 50%.

The company also runs a nationwide support network of around 300 service and support staff working from local branches - tasked with ensuring that customers' general enquiries are answered and also that any technical difficulties are resolved as soon as possible.

Pitney Bowes is accredited with an Investors in People standard. "Investors in People is a tremendous concept. It links what we are trying to do as a business with the people in the business," says Gerry Duffy, the European human resource director at Pitney Bowes' UK headquarters in Harlow.

The company's commitment to staff training and development has also won Pitney Bowes a place in the influential book, Britain's Best Employers - a guide to the 100 most attractive companies to work for, produced by the Corporate Research Foundation.

The firm says it looks for people who want to lead, advance and make a difference to its customers. If you're interested in a career at Pitney Bowes, check out its website at www.pitneybowes.com/uk

fields.headline: Tip of the week
fields.standfirst: Time for a hasty retreat
fields.trailText: Time for a hasty retreat
fields.body:
Have you been thinking about changing careers or switching jobs? If you're not careful the new job could soon develop an uncanny resemblance to your old job.

So how do you break the cycle of bad jobs? What you need is time away to think and to clear your head says career columnist Amy Lindgren. "Fill your suitcase with note pads, a tape recorder, a favourite book or two, inspirational readings and maybe some chocolate. Don't expect a big revelation or a step-by-step plan to emerge.

"Instead, concentrate on letting go of your daily frustrations and relaxing your mind. The fruits of time alone may take months to develop."

fields.body:
 TV dreams: We told you we'd make you a star. Programme makers at BBC Education want to see if it's possible to groom a candidate for a top website job in just one week. A crack team of career experts will spruce up the volunteer's CV, train them in interview techniques and give them an image makeover. If you'd like to forward your name, email: candidate@bbc.co.uk

 Book of the week: The most difficult interview questions are the unexpected ones. Prepare yourself by reading Tackling Tough Interview Questions , (Hodder & Stoughton, £6.99), the latest entry in the Institute of Management's Successful Business in a Week series. And the first 20 Rise readers to email fiona.davenport@hodder.co.uk will receive a free copy.

 Mono tone: Do you see issues at work in black and white or shades of grey? People who think about office conflicts in rigid terms - like perfectionists and control freaks - are more susceptible to emotional and physical problems than those who are open-minded and flexible, say researchers at the University of Bradford Management Centre.

 Fly talking: We're talking offline, of course, but don't you think it's time you took a helicopter view of the low-hanging fruit? Corporate gobbledegook can be a useful tool to mask your inexperience or lack of expertise, but beware. One in 10 of the people questioned in a survey by recruitment firm Office Angels reckon frequent users are untrustworthy and pretentious.

 Espresso yourself: Strong coffee and plenty of it may reduce the risk of you being poisoned if your office is in an area where drinking water contains high levels of heavy-metal contaminants. An international team of scientists has found that while coffee is filtering, the coffee grounds mop up as much as 90% of the copper and lead dissolved in the water.

 Help us to help you: Each week Rise tries to bring you the news, advice and insight which will aid you on the first and second rungs of the career ladder. But are we scratching where you're itching? Email us at rise@theguardian.com with your ideas and we'll see what we can do.

fields.headline: Rollercoaster ride for graduate jobs
fields.standfirst: Hold tight: recruitment and salaries set to climb
fields.trailText: Is it safe to come out yet? After last year's cut-backs in graduate recruitment schemes, final-year students might wish they had been born a couple of years earlier. But the latest research suggests better times ahead.
fields.body:
Is it safe to come out yet? After last year's cut-backs in graduate recruitment schemes, final-year students might wish they had been born a couple of years earlier. But the latest research suggests better times ahead.

Figures from the Association of Graduate Recruiters confirm a fall of a third in the number of people recruited on to graduate schemes last years.

As might be expected in the current climate, industry was hardest hit with a fall of 50%, but overall, the 1999 vacancies show just 18,158 places compared with 27,417 in 1998.

However, the AGR believes the figures are just a one-off and says employers are anticipating a 20% growth in graduate recruitment during 2000.

Another survey published this week by Income Data Services is even more bullish, claiming that the largest employers plan to recruit 25% more graduates in 2000.

The 122 employers polled said they planned to take on a total of 7,000 graduate trainees. Nearly a third of blue chip companies surveyed said they were unable to fill all their vacancies, with most shortages in engineering positions.

Carl Gilleard, the AGR's chief executive, acknowledges last year's dip came as a surprise. "It is a sign of the volatility and uncertainty in the recruitment marketplace at the moment. In boom areas such as IT, training schemes just do not fit the moment, because people are so busy trying to keep up they could not do justice to training new people."

But he argues that different sectors have had to trim for different reasons. Some have cut back on head count as a defensive measure against hostile take-over bids, buy-outs and price cuts. Manufacturing has had a bad year due to the high value of the pound and the retail sector has undergone a major shake-up. In all of these areas, uncertainty has caused employers to adjust their recruitment plans downwards.

Fewer jobs, but for those who got them, impressive rewards: starting salaries have increased by 5% - four times the rate of inflation and many of the larger graduate recruiters are paying a starting salary of more than £25,000.

In the IDS study, the median starting salary for first degree graduates in 1999 was £17,500, expected to rise to £18,000 in 2000.

Pay ranged greatly from sector to sector. At one end of the spectrum Euromoney Institutional Investor offered trainee journalists just £9,000 while Citibank provisionally set its starting salary at £28,000. The employers surveyed said they expected starting salaries to increase by 3.2% in 2000, compared with 4.4% in 1999.

But the research findings also reflect a growing diversity of ways into work. While many graduates still find the idea of a structured career with a blue-chip very appealing, traditional graduate schemes have always been a minority route into work. And perhaps they are becoming more so. All the talk of students making a fortune from the dot.com ideas they dreamed up in their bedrooms - student.net, or Oxygen, are two such examples - makes the thought of big names with generations of stuffy pedigree behind them seem dreary to many talented graduates.

Gilleard agrees that many graduates are finding their way into work outside the specialist schemes. "Most major companies will always have schemes, but others will not find it the best way to bring people in. Many companies are recruiting graduates through normal, non-specialist recruiting. If graduates are gifted, they will inevitably make their mark.

"It has to be remembered that the cost of graduate recruitment can be anywhere between £5,000 and £14,000 and then you have to add on salary and development costs."

Cutting back on recruitment at a time of an overheated labour market might be an understandable reaction, but isn't it rather short-sighted in the light of other economic data?

With unemployment set to dip below 1m late this year and 74.4% of the population in work, employers are reporting serious shortages of capable managers - exactly the type of people graduates are supposed to become.

Experts argue that restructuring, downsizing and the increasing pace of mergers and acquisitions has meant a perpetual search for new blood to propel organisations forward - blood that was not associated with the previous regime.

Then again, ambitious graduates may be their own worst enemy. Graduates used to prove their worth by loyalty. Now they aggregate value to themselves by having a string of names on their CVs. Increasingly reluctant to stay put in one organisation for very long, their desire to be always on the move is making employers thinking twice before investing heavily in graduate programmes.

fields.headline: Top rung/Bottom rung
fields.standfirst: We sample life at either end of the scale at Royal & SunAlliance
fields.trailText:
Stephan Pater
Aged 48
Managing director Life and Unit Trust Royal & SunAlliance
fields.body:
Stephan Pater
Aged 48
Managing director Life and Unit Trust Royal & SunAlliance

Stephan Pater has become a very senior figure within Royal & SunAlliance - a connection that began when he was a teenager. "I approached the Royal at 16 and was advised to get a business qualification and then apply," he recalls.

So, after graduating in business administration in 1972 he went back to them and was told: "Here's the job we promised you before."

As well as a spell as a semi-pro footballer for Ross County, his CV includes 27 years of insurance industry experience covering 19 posts and fellowship of the Chartered Institute of Insurance.

Key moment: the merger of Royal and Sun Alliance in 1996 - "this was a coming together of two major players".

In his current post, Stephan heads up the life and unit trust business and runs the company's UK estate agency network - employing 6,500 staff with an overall turnover of £2bn.

The buzz? "I really get a kick out of keeping the organisation going forward and from helping it face the challenges of the market."

Must-have qualities: "Self-drive, enthusiasm, sense of humour, ability to take a risk and an overwhelming desire to succeed."

Paul Greensmith
Aged 25
Business graduate trainee Royal & SunAlliance

Never be afraid to say something new - that's Paul Greensmith's advice to graduates. "Insurance is changing - and new recruits at Royal & SunAlliance are encouraged to take a wider view and come up with fresh ideas to challenge the conventional way of doing things."

Paul graduated in history (Leicester) in 1996 and spent a year travelling in the US, Africa, Australasia and the Far East, before joining the company. "I decided early on I wanted to work in a multi-national company. I had offers from others, but I chose Royal & Sun Alliance because of its graduate training scheme."

He is coming towards the end of his 30 months of training which has covered all aspects of the business around the country, including project work in internal consultancy which involved setting up a call centre.

Paul is currently working in London market underwriting - an area in which he wants to continue when he qualifies.

Training and development: The 30 or so graduates taken on each year gain all-round insurance experience mixed with courses, in-house training, mentoring, appraisals and study leave to sit the ACII professional exams.

fields.headline: Upwardly mobile
fields.trailText: Steven Bell, MD of studentmobiles.com
fields.body:
Name: Steven Bell

Status: Managing director of studentmobiles.com

Past: Business studies graduate, Northumbria University. Turned down job with Procter & Gamble to knock on doors switching businesses to COLT telephone service. When customers started asking for mobile phones, he found a local supplier and sold them too.

Present: After borrowing £5,000 from his sister - the banks turned him away -he applied his first-hand knowledge of campus life to set up studentmobiles.com, tailoring networks and tarriffs to students.

Future: Having signed a distribution deal with Carphone Warehouse, the company employs a dozen people and is set for a stock market float. Wants to move into Europe and become first Wap provider for students.

Strengths: "I have a lot of self-confidence and I'm not a quitter."

Weaknesses: "Gaining credibility at a young age is difficult. And I still have problems getting out of bed in the morning."

Wisdom: "There's help available - you just have to find it. And if the banks won't give you money, ask your sister."

References: www.studentmobiles.com

fields.headline: The joy of curmudgeons
fields.standfirst: Beckett plays existential cricket, a Zoroastrian works at constitutional reform, and Antonio Vivaldi enjoys a bloody good fugue.
fields.trailText: Beckett plays existential cricket, a Zoroastrian works at constitutional reform, and Antonio Vivaldi enjoys a bloody good fugue.
fields.body:
No one, in the judgment of a Guardian writer on Wednesday, likes to be identified as a joyless curmudgeon. That statement has trilled through my head all week like a snatch of Berlioz blasting out of a mobile phone in a crowded railway train. How it brings it all back: those long smoke-filled evenings in Les Deux Magots, disputing philosophical conclusions with Sartre and Weil, Jean Cocteau and Diaghilev, Henry Miller and Anaïs Nin, Colette and Willy, Mistinguett and Josephine Baker, Stephane Mallarmé and Stephane Grappelli, Sam Beckett, Anouilh and Les Six. Many's the time that Cocteau would take me aside and say to me (or perhaps it was Edith Piaf): "Courage, mon brave! Take comfort from the conclusion..."

A pedant writes: Smallweed's reminiscences lack verisimilitude. I am not entirely sure what Mallarmé is doing in this galère. A symbolist poet much admired by the so-called decadents, he died in 1898, too early to frequent the sort of occasion described above.

Smallweed shirtily ripostes: I said nothing of Stephane Mallarmé, the symbolist poet. The Mallarmé in this case was a gas company executive with whom Cocteau was madly in love. Dear old Diaghilev was frantic with jealousy, but that is another story.

To continue. The observation quoted above would have been seized on speedily and greedily by our little sect, with the exception, of course, of Les Six, who used to sit in a corner saying nothing except "good on you, cobber" at 10-minute intervals.

A pedant writes: This is preposterous. Les Six was a group of composers consisting of Francis Poulenc and approximately five others.

Smallweed replies with a tooth-bearing snarl: Not in this case, sonny. Les Six was a former Tasmanian stumper turned anarchist poet. None of the others liked him much on account of his taciturnity, but Sam Beckett, himself no mean cricketer as you probably know, vetoed all attempts to expel him. As I was saying: I can just imagine Anouilh, having heard the remark translated into French, complaining of its illogic, on the basis that several people he knew were proud to be known as curmudgeons.

But others, among whom I imagine Sartre would have been pre-eminent, would have challenged the asseveration on a deeper philosophical level. Could it be right, they would have demanded, to speak of a joyless curmudgeon? Surely the very act of behaving like a joyless curmudgeon must have brought joy to the individual concerned, since otherwise he or she would not have so acted.

Indeed, as the great American bandleader Glenn Miller remarked when he paid us a visit shortly before his mysterious death, curmudgeons revelled in their curmudgeonliness, but had to disguise this aspect of their curious lives for fear that their joyless curmudgeonliness might become suspect. How true that was. What a blow this man's loss has been to the world of moral philosophy!

W hen I wrote last week I had not yet seen the letter to the editor complaining that a popular saying I quoted - "as zealous as a Zwinglian" - should have been given as "as zealous as a Zwinglist". Others complain that Zwinglian (or Zwinglist) should have read Zoroastrian. There is certainly some zealotry there. When the Wakeham commission on reform of the House of Lords took evidence in Birmingham they were addressed by, among others, a Zoroastrian whose case seemed to be that no reform would be whole or acceptable which did not find room in the place for at least one Zoroastrian.

But that is not the point which I need to make this week, which has more to do with the nature and teaching of cliché. My favourite Exonian savant writes to say that candidates in the 11-plus examination used to be asked to complete the following phrase: "as smooth as..." The answer was "silk". Anyone writing "a baby's bottom" was judged to be wrong and awarded no mark. I wonder whether they also used the formula "as bald as..." Perhaps "as a baby's bottom" would have got you a mark in that context since "coot" does not alliterate. Why "as bald as a coot" anyway? Are coots especially bald? I would check, but I haven't a coot to hand.

But my even more urgent purpose this week is to put things right on Vivaldi. Adrian Sunshine, of the London Chamber Players, writes to rebuke me for referring to this composer's work L'Estro Armonico as L'Estro Harmonico, which is not very Italian. The trouble is that a minion crossing the floor of my office last week with a trayful of redundant h's picked off the streets of London slipped and fell, spilling them on to the floor, since when these pesky creatures have been climbing up on our desks and infiltrating vharious peophle's cophy. I am sorry that one of them messed up Antonio.

Mr Sunshine does not, however, dispute my approval for the work in question, whose 12 concerti, he says, "are the greatest collection of perfect and imperfect cadences, and tonic, subdominant and dominant chords extant". I am sure I sensed this, without actually being aware of it. The minor matter of Vivaldi's active sex life is illuminated in a racy book called The Love Lives of the Great Composers, by Basil Howitt. Some of them got up to tricks from which even Henry Miller and Anaïs Nin might have had something to learn.

Vivaldi worked for many years as music master of the Ospedale della Pietà in Venice, which was full of teenage nuns, some in training, it was alleged, to be mistresses of the papal nuncio. But Vivaldi's reputed offence was conducting a ménage à trois with two sisters, the young contralto Anna Girò and her sister. Were Antonio (61) and Anna (30-something) lovers? "There is no absolute proof," Howitt observes disappointingly "but everything points that way, quite apart from the free and easy Venetian life style." Even though a senior priest, Antonio would not have been subject to any kind of, as it were, Girò check. He also, if I may say so, wrote a bloody good fugue.
