fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: I'm crazy about New Labour; Tony is like a god for me. Don't even think I don't adore Cherie, too, but she can't be my role model: I really don't look my best in saris or any eastern evening dress (if you do, try www.world-products.com or www.dreamscape.com/saree).
fields.body:
I'm crazy about New Labour; Tony is like a god for me. Don't even think I don't adore Cherie, too, but she can't be my role model: I really don't look my best in saris or any eastern evening dress (if you do, try www.world-products.com or www.dreamscape.com/saree).

I find it easier to be inspired by Maggie. I'm much younger and more fashionable, of course, but she's a strong-minded girl who wore weeny bits of gold before and has so many yummy diamond brooches now that she must be my sister under the skin. I hear Cherie collects only crystals. It makes me sad.

Even with the Nasdaq and Gordon being unbelievably kind to me, I still have to be sensible when it comes to buying diamonds, so I surfed the net. At www.certificatediamond.com I found a 7.1 carat emerald-cut solitaire at $93,000, which seemed good value (they take Visa), but then I thought I'd worry about it when I went clubbing. The real thing stays in the bank, and I wear a perfect imitation in cubic zirconia from www.interlap.com instead ($13.80). It fools everyone.

My friend Victoria's bauble looks positively anorexic next to mine. But I couldn't have boogied at the Dome on New Year's Eve while watching those wretched people just outside our enclosure (who had been denied food and drink and transport for hours) if I hadn't known one could do so much good through the net, too. If you go to www.thehungersite.com a map of the world flashes every three seconds wherever a person dies of hunger. Click your mouse, and the sponsors of the site give enough money for a bowl of food for the poor somewhere. I love it: someone pays for my charity, so I have more left for my rocks. Clever girl, me.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: A treat of a murder mystery, plus Beware the Dwarfs, Evening and Pedro Páramo
fields.body:
The Keepers Of Truth
Michael Collins
Phoenix House, £9.99
Buy it at BOL

Bill is a washed-up, washed-out reporter for a dying newspaper in a dead town. The college kid has grand dreams of writing a requiem for the industrial soul which has been ripped out of his mid-western home, but gets his fancy prose licked into shape by the hard-drinking, old-school editor, Sam. Only with the disappearance of Old Man Lawton and the determination of the local cops to fix murder on his son, Ronny, does the dust of the place get under Bill's nails. Collins creates a gripping picture of slow-moving, small-town life, and packs it into a treat of a murder mystery.

Beware The Dwarfs
Terri Paddock
Abacus, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Another girlie novel whose opening chapters promise much, but which fails to deliver. Shame, as the travails of Paddock's gaggle of SWAFs (single white anxious females) have moments of interest, and her portraits of the blokes who barely reach knee-high in the ideal-man stakes are occasionally poignant. Charlotte, Harriet, Liz, Rebbeca and Joyce are supposed to be the best of friends. All are after the same things - good sex, good careers and good lives - but their show of unity crumbles as they fight their separate ways out of dead-end jobs and grim flats.

Evening
Susan Minot
Vintage, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Youth, for Minot's dying heroine, Ann Lord, is a time to be cherished: a weekend in New England recalled as a moment of perfection in a lifetime of compromise. On her deathbed, the heavily sedated Ann snatches back her past. Three husbands and two boyfriends drift in and out of her mind, but it is the man she met at a friend's wedding 40 years ago, and fell in love with, to whom she returns. Minot tells the story of fleeting grand passion without sentimentality, capturing her heroine's past with brilliant clarity and describing beautifully the process of letting go of life.

Pedro Páramo
Juan Rulfo
Serpent's Tail, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

webTitle: Slice of the web tops off Domino's results

fields.headline: Slice of the web tops off Domino's results
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
dominos.co.uk
fields.trailText: Domino's Pizza said in less than six months its online e-commerce site had accounted for a 2% slice of its UK delivery sales and web customers brought the group higher margins.
fields.body:
Domino's Pizza said in less than six months its online e-commerce site had accounted for a 2% slice of its UK delivery sales and web customers brought the group higher margins.

Domino's, the UK's largest pizza delivery chain, said customers ordering over the internet and the interactive television service, Open, were spending 25% to 35% more than traditional customers. At least half of the orders from Open were new customers.

Colin Halpern, Domino's chairman, said: "The instant success we witnessed at the end of 1999 promises to be just the start of our e-commerce activities. By embracing e-commerce at such an early stage we have already earned a reputation as the primary food delivery brand in the UK both on the internet and interactive TV."

Domino's delivered its first pizza in Britain in 1985 and is an offshoot of the privately owned US pizza delivery chain of the same name.

The fast food group said it aimed within the next five to 10 years to sell around one-third of its pizzas through e-commerce.

The company reported its maiden results yesterday after listing on Aim last November. Total sales grew from £20.7m to £25.6m while like-for-like sales jumped 5.6%. Profits before tax were up 25% to £1.8m. However, once exceptionals were included the profit was £1.35m and lower than in 1998.

Domino's increased its number of stores from 175 to 201 in the year and intends to double that number in the next five years.

Stephen Hemsley, chief executive, said at least one-third of the stores would be owned by the company. He said Ireland was expected to be a substantial growth market, with its new store in Limerick reporting initial weekly sales of £20,000 - almost three times the average of other stores. Those sales have now fallen to levels of £14,000.

A final dividend of 29p increases the total payment to shareholders to 71p for the year.

webTitle: Quitting Europe 'would not bring big job losses'

fields.headline: Quitting Europe 'would not bring big job losses'
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Living standards would be slightly lower if Britain left the European Union, but the claim that 8m jobs would be lost was absurd, researchers said yesterday as rival factions argued over the single currency.
fields.body:
Living standards would be slightly lower if Britain left the European Union, but the claim that 8m jobs would be lost was absurd, researchers said yesterday as rival factions argued over the single currency.

The claim of 8m jobs at risk - nearly three times the usual figure cited - caused some embarrassment to the pro-European umbrella group, the Britain in Europe campaign, backed by Tony Blair, the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, and the former Conservative chancellor, Kenneth Clarke, which had publicised the figure.

The campaign had commissioned the prestigious national institute of economic and social research to assess the effect on the British economy if the state were to withdraw from the EU.

The institute's cautious findings were whipped up into a media sensation by pro-European campaigners ahead of next week's Out of Europe, Out of Work campaign launch, the latest effort by Britain in Europe to reverse the tide of Eurosceptic propaganda.

William Hague took his Keep the Pound campaign to a new market yesterday by launching a glitch-prone website, on which he exchanged views with other netties. Mr Blair was a "packaged politician" in the clutches of his spin doctors, he said.

The Eurosceptics did not get it all their own way. The former Tory foreign secretary, Sir Malcolm Rifkind, politely told his leader that voters wanted him to be "serious and statesmanlike" as well as young and energetic. Referring to the Keep the Pound launch in St Albans, Hertfordshire, he said: "Perhaps it would be wiser to abandon the lorry."

Yesterday the institute issued a reproachful statement rejecting "absurd reports" based on its work. If exports halved and prices and wages failed to adjust to new realities, employment would fall by 8m. "That does not mean we think this would happen."

The Business for Sterling lobby leapt on the report as proof of Britain in Europe's dishonesty, as did Conservative politicians. "Britain in Europe will stop at nothing in their hysterical attempts to scaremonger," said the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, who accused his rivals of "cynically distorted statistics".

The anti-Europeans have put out their own share of propaganda, with renewed efforts to intimidate pro-European Tories like Mr Clarke, who is to speak at a BiE council meeting on Wednesday, two days after the jobs campaign launch.

Claims that Mr Clarke will speak on a platform with Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, are not true. Nor is Mr Clarke under fresh threat of deselection in his Rushcliffe constituency, as was reported yesterday, he said last night.

The institute's research sets out a measured assessment of EU withdrawal - which is not Tory policy, though Labour says it is.

The report says 2.7m jobs are tied to EU exports and a further 0.5m indirectly so. But exports to Europe would not end completely if the UK left. National income would eventually fall by 1.5% and household income by 2.5%.

webTitle: Village fights to save heart of community - its school

fields.headline: Village fights to save heart of community - its school
fields.standfirst:
Protesters accuse Blair of only paying lip service to rural education
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Below the Cheviot Hills, near England's northerly frontier, the normally uncomplaining villagers of Milfield have been driven to desperation by the threat to remove the pillar from their community, already battered by the rundown of farming and redundancies on the border hills.
fields.body:
Below the Cheviot Hills, near England's northerly frontier, the normally uncomplaining villagers of Milfield have been driven to desperation by the threat to remove the pillar from their community, already battered by the rundown of farming and redundancies on the border hills.

A deputation was sent to Downing Street in defence of Milfield's greatest asset: the 100-year-old village school.

Since Northumberland county council announced its closure, along with two other small schools, at Kirknewton and Acklington, to save £157,000 annually, people have been driven to tears at public meetings.

"They're intent on tearing the heart out of our community without any thought to the future," said a school governor, John Logan, recently installed as landlord of the Red Lion, who has just cut his farming losses by terminating a century-long family tenancy.

"If we have a school we can attract more people to the area, and that means keeping businesses going - the shop, post office, cafe and our pub. Close it, and we're all in trouble."

Like many of the 300 villagers, and the local MP Alan Beith, Liberal Democrat deputy leader, he cannot reconcile the government's commitment to keeping village schools open - reinforced in the Commons this month by Tony Blair - with a Labour county council's determination to close some.

"It seems the prime minister is just paying lip service to the problems of rural areas," said Mr Logan.

Since the 1980s and 1990s when, as calculated by the countryside agency, 30 rural schools were axed annually in England, the rundown has been halted in many counties. Department for education guidelines published last April, emphasising wider community use of council buildings, say there should always be a presumption against closure.

But councils are under pressure to cut surplus places - and Northumberland, poised to cut £1m from its education budget from April, claims that there are 3,400 spare places in its 144 first schools.

Yet Milfield seemed to be doing everything right. Its hall is used for community events, pensioners join the children twice a week for lunch, while school computers are used to teach locals IT skills.

But it has only 14 pupils, taught largely by the headteacher, Elizabeth Carey, while Acklington has 11 and Kirknewton four.

During her six years in charge, Ms Carey has never taught more than 24. "But the numbers will go up again as younger people move into the houses round here," she said.

With a majority of councillors backing closure, the education secretary, David Blunkett, has had to intervene be cause of protests. For the first time he has used an appeals procedure under which an adjudicator is sent in to assess council plans and hold a public meeting.

In Milfield's case the adjudicator was the Rev Alan Billings, a former Labour colleague of Mr Blunkett on Sheffield council. Mr Blunkett is to make a final decision shortly.

Robert and Joy McClymont and their children, aged eight and four, live up the hills five miles away. The family, recent arrivals to the Cheviots, have had to move three times in the past year as Mr McClymont, a farmworker, has faced redundancies.

Now he has another job. "Milfield school was a great attraction," he said.

It if closes the children, who go to school by taxi, will face a round trip of 22 miles to Wooler.

Mr Beith said: "It is an entirely viable school, where numbers are likely to increase. Closure would be indefensible."

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.standfirst: First in a regular feature on the newest websites we manage to help you manage your money
fields.trailText: First in a regular feature on the newest websites we manage to help you manage your money
fields.body:
Specialist Internet mortgage providers are springing up almost daily, aiming to take the sweat out of choosing the best deal, with mortgage calculators and best-buy comparisons.

E-Loan claims to be the global market leader, offering 1,200 loans on its website, www.eloan.com/uk. A rival offering an independent service, with a minimum set-up charge of £150, is www.theloanhub.com. The Web-based personal finance operator eXchange holdings, which runs moneyeXtra.com and MoneyWorld.co.uk has launched a mortgage service, emfinance.com

The Independent Association of Estate Agents offers information on mortgages and property at mortgageseekers.co.uk.

Share dealer Charles Schwab is handing out commission -free trading for 30 days for investors who take out a self-select Isa through its online service, www.schwab-europe.com.

Independent adviser Chase de Vere tomorrow launches an online Isa application service in conjunction with Fidelity Investments and M&G, at www.chasedevere.co.uk.

A new Net stockbroker, Sharepeople, is charging a flat fee of £17.50 per deal, at www.sharepeople.com.

Neville James, which buys and sells second-hand endowment policies, has launched a site providing information on trading, prices and quotations - www.neville-james.co.uk.

Net shopping site bigsave.com has expanded into car insurance, promising 'some of the lowest rates to be found in the UK'. It works with a panel of 18 established car insurers. It is at www.bigsave.com .

Help with finding a private medical insurance policy is promised by a new service from www.moneynet.co.uk .

Leading Edge offers travel insurance for backpackers and travellers under 40. A month's cover for Europe will cost £19. The address: www.leadedge.co.uk. Direct Line is offering travel cover at directline.com

An insurance database, the Research Department, has produced a best buy table for single trip policies from across a range of on-line travel operators. The site can be found at www.trd.co.uk .

fields.headline: Criticised Lawrence case officer retires
fields.standfirst: Macpherson one year on: special report
fields.trailText: A detective with alleged corrupt links to the gangster father of one of the Stephen Lawrence murder suspects has been allowed to retire from the Metropolitan police and keep his pension.
fields.body:
A detective with alleged corrupt links to the gangster father of one of the Stephen Lawrence murder suspects has been allowed to retire from the Metropolitan police and keep his pension.

Sir William Macpherson's report expressed dismay that Detective Constable David Coles continued as a serving officer despite having unauthorised meetings "in the most suspicious circumstances" with Clifford Norris.

Norris was later jailed for drug smuggling, and his son, David, was one of the five prime suspects in the racist murder of Stephen Lawrence.

The Guardian has learned that Mr Coles, at the centre of corruption allegations at the inquiry, retired on medical grounds on February 10.

He had been on sick leave since June 1998, and will be entitled to a police pension, believed to be up to £20,000 a year.

The Stephen Lawrence inquiry heard that undercover officers from customs and excise had seen Mr Coles meeting Clifford Norris three times in 1988 in the Tiger's Head public house in Chislehurst, south-east London.

Customs officers observed packages being exchanged, and at one stage Mr Coles produced a calculator and was seen making notes.

After the third meeting, Norris, the target of a major customs operation, went on the run before he could be arrested.

Mr Coles was a sergeant in the flying squad at the time. Disciplinary charges were filed against him over an unrelated incident and a hearing recommended his sacking. But on appeal that was reversed and Mr Coles was demoted to detective constable.

He was warned over his meetings with Norris but allowed to continue as a serving officer.

The public inquiry referred to Mr Coles as Sergeant XX. In his report Sir William wrote: "It seems to us right that we should register our concern that this aspect of Sergeant XX's association with Clifford Norris was not formally pursued and that the disciplinary penalties which were subsequently imposed appear lax, particularly since they resulted in the continued em ployment of Sergeant XX in the CID in the same area of London.

"Regardless of the fact that the association was not subject to formal discipline procedures, it was plainly highly suspect."

Asked at the public inquiry in June 1998 about Mr Coles's continued employment, Assistant Commissioner Ian Johnston said: "On the facts as put to me, I'm appalled that this particular individual is still working for the Metropolitan police."

The public inquiry also heard that Mr Coles had been assigned to guard Duwayne Brooks, the main witness to Stephen Lawrence's murder, during the Old Bailey trial of three of the suspects.

Mr Brooks said: "Yet another officer has slipped the net. I am no longer surprised."

No officer criticised in the Macpherson report lost a day's pay.

Paul Wilson, chairman of the National Black Police Association, said Mr Coles's departure on a police pension would be seen as a conspiracy.

Mr Wilson, a serving Met officer, said: "People will read into this that the Met has something to hide. The perception of the community will be that there's a conspiracy to get this guy out with as little publicity as possible.

"It is most unsatisfactory that the Lawrences were not told. They should be apprised of everything relating to the inquiry.

"It leaves a bitter taste in the mouth, it really does."

Scotland Yard confirmed that Mr Coles never faced a disciplinary hearing regarding his meetings with Norris. It would not discuss why.

A source suggested that there was insufficient evidence to disprove beyond reasonable doubt Mr Coles's story that he was meeting Norris to try and cultivate him as an informant, though Scotland Yard sources have denied that there was any officially sanctioned effort to turn Norris into an informer.

A Scotland Yard spokeswoman said: "David Coles was medically retired from the Metropolitan police service as of February 10, following full medical scrutiny involving more than one doctor."

The spokeswoman added: "David Coles had completed 28 years' service at the time of his retirement."

webTitle: Huge anti-Haider rally expected to pack Hitler's square in Vienna

fields.headline: Huge anti-Haider rally expected to pack Hitler's square in Vienna
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Vienna is braced for a massive demonstration today in protest at the inclusion of the far-right Freedom party in the new coalition government of Austria.
fields.body:
Vienna is braced for a massive demonstration today in protest at the inclusion of the far-right Freedom party in the new coalition government of Austria.

Hundreds of thousands of people are expected to rally on Heldenplatz, where Adolf Hitler addressed around 250,000 Austrians in 1938 on the occasion of the Anschluss, the Germans' annexation of Austria.

Organisers and police agree in predicting that the turnout will be between 200,000 and 300,000 protesters. Those mounting the demonstration against the anti-immigrant party and its leader, Jörg Haider, hope the rally will be the biggest in Austria since the war - outstripping a candle lit anti-Haider rally in 1993.

Protests are also due today outside Austrian consulates and embassies in New York and around Europe, including London.

In Vienna, roads are to be blocked off to traffic. The national railway is laying on extra carriages to transport protesters from around the country. It says it expects to be "full to bursting".

Two days of protest began yesterday when - despite threats of disciplinary action - several thousand Vienna schoolchildren converged on the centre of the capital to demonstrate against the rightwing coalition, which was sworn in two weeks ago. Organisers said 20,000 pupils had joined the protest, but police put the number at 4,000.

Chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel, the leader of the conservative People's party, ended 30 years of Social Democrat-led government by agreeing a pact with Mr Haider after the latest national elections. An international outcry has ensued, with European Union countries and others - including the United States and Israel - downgrading bilateral relations with Austria.

Yesterday's student demonstration focussed on government plans to cut the numbers of foreigners in classrooms to 30%. Mr Haider, governor of the Austrian province of Carinthia, has aroused all this opposition because of his party's exploitation of anti-foreigner sentiment in Austria, and his past praise of Adolf Hitler's employment policies and description of Waffen SS veterans as men of "good character".

His pattern has been to stir up a furore by such utterances, then to apologise, and then to start the cycle of publicity and outrage again.

Mr Schüssel repeated his appeal for Austrians and the EU to judge Mr Haider by his deeds. He said the responsibility of government would transform the Freedom party, which has been given several key portfolios, including the finance ministry.

Mr Haider has accused the organisers of today's march - which include human rights groups, opposition political parties, trades unions and artists - of paying "simple people" to attend.

"It is well known that socialist youth officials are paying between 1,500 and 1,800 schillings [£67-£80] per day," he told News magazine.

Michael Grossmann, leader of the Social Democrats' youth wing, denied this: "Young people have principles and political conviction and are taking to the streets for that reason," he said. "It is an outrageous cheek to claim that young people would sell themselves for their political opinion."

Earlier this week an auction of works donated by Austrian artists, including Hermann Nitsch, raised enough money to cover the £90,000 cost of organising the demonstration.

The anti-racist organisation SOS Mitmensch, which is coordinating today's protest, gathered thousands of pounds in donations via the internet to advertise the demonstration in newspapers around the world.

Demonstrations have been taking place outside Vienna's parliament on a daily basis since the new government came into power.

Austria's Hollywood star, the actor Arnold Schwarzenegger, joined the chorus of protest this week, saying that as an immigrant to the US he felt "hurt" by Mr Haider's anti-foreigner remarks.

Gerald Matt, the director of Vienna's Kunsthalle contemporary art gallery, said: "The pages of history have turned back to our darkest chapter."

O5, an anti-Nazi group, has asked Austrians to offer their support to the protesters by hanging orange banners out of their windows.

fields.headline: Rural cash comes dear
fields.standfirst:
Levy on withdrawals from PO machines erodes Blair's promise on exclusion

Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Customers using cash machines in post offices face charges for withdrawals despite a pledge by Tony Blair that people in rural communities would not be excluded from banking services.
fields.body:
Customers using cash machines in post offices face charges for withdrawals despite a pledge by Tony Blair that people in rural communities would not be excluded from banking services.

Next week the Post Office is expected to disclose that Woolwich, which charges customers for use of "convenience" cash machines, has secured a contract for the first tranche of post office outlets outlined by the prime minister in a recent speech in Cornwall. Woolwich's bid is backed by Euronet.

Mr Blair, whose government has made a pledge to tackle "financial exclusion", had heralded the move to put more cash machines in post offices as way to achieve this aim. At the same time, the move was expected to help ensure the viability of the post office network.

In a speech earlier this month, the prime minister said the Post Office had struck a deal to provide 3,000 new cash machines in its outlets around the country, with the 400 due for installation by the summer.

"This big new expansion of the cash machine network will take [cash machines] into many communities which don't have this service at the moment - including many rural villages," Mr Blair said. "So that if you need to take out some money, you won't have to travel to a town to do it. And you'll be able to support your local post office by using the money there."

While the Woolwich refused to comment yesterday, rivals believe that if it has won the contract it would mean that customers using its cash machines in post offices will be charged £1 each time they use them - a standard practice by the former building society for its "convenience" machines.

Industry experts have pointed out that customers would have to shoulder some of the costs to pay for the installation and upkeep of the post office network.

Don Cruickshank, the former Oftel director who is leading the treasury backed investigation into banking, is thought to back the idea of the controversial surcharges.

The Post Office would not confirm that Woolwich had won the first of the cash machine contracts for 400 machines, which comes amid an already heated debate in the industry about the price customers should pay to take their money out of cash ma chines. The banks and building societies are meeting in a fortnight to try to reach an agreement about the way the charge should be levied after months of wrangling.

Until recently, some customers faced a "disloyalty" fee charged by their own bank or building society when they used a rival's machine. Others, particularly building society customers, are able to use all cash machines in the Link network for free.

But, Barclays has tried to change the industry by levying a £1 surcharge on its rivals' customers using its machines, while giving its own customer free access to the Link cash machine network.

Barclays, which has not yet introduced the charge after the threat of legal action by Nationwide Building Society, argues that the surcharge is fairer because it makes it removes "hidden" charges.

The issue is complicated by the fact that the banks with the big cash machine networks say it costs them millions of pounds a year to maintain them. Woolwich, for instance, levies its charge at certain locations where the machines might not be used very often which makes them expensive to install.

fields.headline: Hijack Afghans moved
fields.standfirst:
Stansted hijack: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: Afghan asylum seekers from the hijacked jet at Stansted were moved to an immigration detention centre yesterday as the total seeking to stay in Britain rose to 79.
fields.body:
Afghan asylum seekers from the hijacked jet at Stansted were moved to an immigration detention centre yesterday as the total seeking to stay in Britain rose to 79.

All the passengers still in the UK have now lodged claims for asylum. Forty left the fire service college in Moreton-in-Marsh, Gloucestershire, where they have been staying since last weekend, for Tinsley House, near Gatwick. The remaining 39 will join them today.

The last asylum claim was filed by a man held separately after telling police he sometimes had flashbacks that caused him to be violent.

A home office spokesman said the college was available only until Monday. Tinsley House "can cater for children, and we want to keep them all together".

webTitle: Latvia accused of targeting anti-Nazi fighters

fields.headline: Latvia accused of targeting anti-Nazi fighters
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Russia's acting president, Vladimir Putin, yesterday denounced the jailing in Latvia of a former resistance fighter convicted of committing war crimes while fighting the Nazis and local collaborators in 1944.
fields.body:
Russia's acting president, Vladimir Putin, yesterday denounced the jailing in Latvia of a former resistance fighter convicted of committing war crimes while fighting the Nazis and local collaborators in 1944.

Vasily Kononov, 77, is the first anti-Nazi fighter to have been found guilty of war crimes in a country which has failed to prosecute Nazi collaborators and fascist militiamen for their roles in the slaughter of thousands of Jews in the Baltic republic during the second world war.

Three weeks ago Kononov, a pro-Soviet partisan during the war, was jailed for six years for the murder of nine people in the east Latvian village of Mazie Bati in 1944 - the jailing that has enraged Russia.

"Latvia's repressive apparatus is increasingly targeting fighters in the anti-fascist resistance," Mr Putin said yesterday during a visit to Siberia. "This might turn into a mass prosecution of fighters against fascism."

Kononov denied involvement in murdering the nine Latvians. The killings were said to be reprisals for the deaths of 12 anti-fascist partisans and colleagues of Kononov during a battle in the village.

Holocaust historians view Latvians as some of the Nazis' most eager accomplices during the war, while the present Latvian authorities have come under fire for failing to prosecute alleged war criminals who helped the Germans.

Under the Molotov-Ribbentrop pact of 1939 between Stalin and Hitler, the Russians occupied the Baltic states of Latvia, Estonia, and Lithuania in 1940, only to be driven out by the Nazi invaders the following year.

Many Baltic nationalists, who were fiercely anti-Russian, fought alongside the Germans in driving the Russians out and then collaborated in the Holocaust.

Konrad Kalejs - the former Latvian militiaman alleged to have taken part in the wartime mass murder of 30,000 people in Latvia - fled from Britain to Australia last month after the home secretary, Jack Straw, ruled he could not be prosecuted but ordered his deportation.

Nazi-hunters, notably the Simon Wiesenthal Centre in Jerusalem, have accused Latvia of being soft on ageing pro-Nazi war criminals, and Moscow has complained that the focus of the Latvian war crimes investigations is on anti-fascist partisans.

While Latvia and neighbouring Estonia have hosted rallies of Nazi SS veterans in recent years, ageing partisans complain that their reunions have been banned.

"A man has been condemned for fighting fascism, an unprecedented world event," the Russian foreign ministry said of the Kononov verdict. "This trial creates a dangerous precedent which could usher in a hunt for scapegoats."

Several other former anti-Nazi fighters have been charged with war crimes in Latvia and one suspect is said to have committed suicide rather than surrender to the police. At the same time, the Latvians insist they have insufficient evidence to prosecute Mr Kalejs, who was kicked out of the US and Canada before going to Britain.

Prosecutors from Britain, the US, Canada, Israel, and Australia gathered in Riga, the Latvian capital, for two days this week to discuss the Kalejs case. Both the Simon Wiesenthal Centre and the Russian foreign ministry protested over their exclusion from the deliberations.

webTitle: Click on to an ISA before the tax year is logged off

fields.headline: Click on to an ISA before the tax year is logged off
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Independent financial adviser Chase de Vere Investments is launching an on-line Isa application facility this Monday. The service - whose launch coincides with the busiest period for ISA applications in the run up to the end of the tax year - will let customers apply for a range of Fidelity and M&G Iass on the internet.
fields.body:
Independent financial adviser Chase de Vere Investments is launching an on-line Isa application facility this Monday. The service - whose launch coincides with the busiest period for ISA applications in the run up to the end of the tax year - will let customers apply for a range of Fidelity and M&G Iass on the internet.

Fund managers Investec Guinness Flight are offering their e-commerce-focused unit trusts and Ias to on-line investors at a 2% discount. The WIRED@INDEX fund invests in blue chip companies with significant e-commerce involvment. The products can be applied for, bought and maintained on-line. Investors will also be able to access prices, performance details, and a charting facility through the website, www.wiredindexisa.com. Fund manager Fidelity Investments is offering customers discounts of up to £149 on Gateway computers to encourage them to use the internet and manage their investments on-line. The offer is open until April 5.

Skipton Building Society is offering internet investors an annual return of 7% gross through a 3-year Fixed Rate Bond. The bond, which can only be bought via the internet, matures on March 31, 2003, and is subject to a minimum investment of £5,000.

If you are thinking of buying or selling an endowment policy, with profits dealer Neville James's website, accessible at www.neville-james.co.uk , may prove useful. The newly launched site contains a guide to tradeable policies, a quotation request form and information on the prices Neville James is willing to pay for policies. A guide to the terminology is also available.

If you want to buy travel insurance on-line but are baffled by the range of policies on offer, check out the Research Department's Best Buy table for single trip policies at www.trd.co.uk. The table compares the prices and level of cover provided by more than 40 products available to buy online.

Cable-based internet service provider ISP Telewest Communications is offering unlimited internet access for £10 a month to 10 million UK consumers. The fee covers unlimited access to the web through Cable i-Net, Telewest's ISP. The service, Surf Unlimited, was developed after research showed that 36% of non-users are put off by phone-call charges.

fields.headline: Mortgaging: the future
fields.standfirst:
Jim Spowart, chief executive, Intelligent Finance

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Take the lumbering Halifax, a 49-year-old dour Scots banker and the tunes of Fatboy Slim and cook up IF, the Halifax's trendy new internet-cum-telephone bank.
fields.body:
Take the lumbering Halifax, a 49-year-old dour Scots banker and the tunes of Fatboy Slim and cook up IF, the Halifax's trendy new internet-cum-telephone bank.

Incongruous, yes, but it has been one of those weeks for the Yorkshire-based former building society which is reinventing itself at breakneck speed.

Well and truly bitten by the dot.com bug, on Wednesday the bank appointed trendy young things to its once staid board, Charles Dunstone of Carphone Warehouse and Coline McConville of America's Clear Channel, and on Thursday set up an e-venture with the not-so-young Peter Wood, inventor of Direct Line. Yesterday, Halifax let Jim Spowart out of his base on the outskirts of Edinburgh and presented IF to a collection of City analysts in a slick promotional video.

The result was another leg-up for the bank's share price, sickly of late, with the new dot.com credibility adding £4bn to its market value in just three days.

IF, formed from the middle letters of Halifax's name and standing for "intelligent finance", is revolutionary, according to Spowart, whose looks are more old-fashioned, grey banker than youthful e-designer.

But the marketing patter rolls smoothly off his tongue, with words such as "unique" , "innovative", "brilliant" injected at regular intervals in his broad Scottish accent. "It's going to take the market by storm. That's my own interpretation. It's more ambitious [than anything I've done before]," Spowart says.

An unlikely revolutionary, the 49-year- old is one of the few people to have started two banks from scratch, causing a step-change in the financial industry each time.

His first was the telephone banking arm of Direct Line, the "little red phone" insurance operation which made its founder, Peter Wood, a multi-millionaire.

The second was Standard Life Bank, which at times last year was snatching a 25% share of all new mortgages in Britain. It was causing so much pain to Halifax, the country's biggest mortgage lender, that its chief executive, James Crosby, hired Spowart last October to end his misery.

Now Crosby expects steely-eyed Spowart to turn the torture treatment on his rivals.

While IF will not go live until the summer after a £30m advertising campaign, the agony has already started for some. Standard Life, in particular, has been hit for six by the outflow of its banking staff, who have flocked to Spowart's new start-up and forced the mutual insurer into offering knee-jerk bonus payments as golden handcuffs. He has even used the same Scottish marketing agency, The Union, which helped him create Standard Life Bank.

But, despite claims to the contrary, Spowart insists he did not "poach" anyone and did not even try to match the bonuses, worth a year's salary in some cases, offered by his former employer.

"I've never ever said 'come with me to this venture'," he protests. So why have 50 followed him? "I give them leadership and creative thought," he says.

He sees himself as "approachable" and a leader of a team. "The most important asset you have is your staff. Every day in life I walk the floors. If you talk to your staff, they tell you what the customers are looking for."

For Spowart, walking the floors translates in to patrolling the call centres which are crucial to his low-cost, branchless banks. Described by many as the modern version of the Industrial Revolution's satanic mills, they are, Spowart insists good places in which to work.

"People don't perform well in a boring environment. A number of people talk about the energy when they walk through the door," he says of the new operations in Edinburgh and Livingston, where he will soon employ 1,200 people. He has made his home in Livingston.

He is proud of his record of creating jobs in his native country. Standard Life Bank employed a similar number of staff and Spowart says a Scottish base was the only condition he gave the Halifax when he took the job, running what was code-named greenfield.co until the unveiling of if.com yesterday.

He reiterates that people are crucial to the operation. "They are the ones dealing with the customers. If you treat your people well they'll respond."

Now used to being in the public eye - he says he gives interviews not for his profile but for his team and the banking operation - it has been quite a journey from Cowdenbeath butcher's son to creator of two of the most innovative banks of recent years. While fiercely protective of his wife of 25 years, Janis, he is still ambitious.

Growing up near the Fife coalfields, he had a choice between going down the mine, working at nearby Rosyth shipyard or joining one of Scotland's prestigious banks.

On leaving Beath high school he chose the last, joining National Commercial Bank which later became part of Royal Bank of Scotland. That was where, 20 years later, he got involved with Direct Line and it was from there that he decided to approach Standard Life with his idea for a new bank.

Within six months Spowart's bank at Standard Life had snatched 17% of the cut-throat mortgage market and within 18 months had grabbed £3bn of savings and £2bn of mortages.

This time, with Halifax, he reckons he can do it all over again and even better. He insists If is unique, and not a "me-too" version of the other, oddly named ventures on the net. While he refuses to reveal details of the five products - current accounts, savings, mortgages, credit cards and loans - he insists nothing like them will have been seen before.

It will not be an internet-only bank: he is a believer in the telephone and the internet, citing research from the US to say that "the human element is very important".

The golf-loving church elder is also used to the sceptics and the doubters. When he started selling mortgages over the phone at Direct Line, he was told it would never work. At Standard Life his "team" was selling mortgages in nine minutes. At IF he will get the sales process down to just six minutes.

His target audience now is the those who are hostage to the sluggish clearing banks rather than the trendy young things targeted by Prudential's egg.

He has some tough targets. Turning IF's start-up losses into a profit in three years and making a 15% return on capital, an unusually precise ambition for an internet start-up.

Few doubt Spowart's ability to bring in the masses - his target is to collect 500,000 customers in the first financial year- but many question his ability to create another bank that can turn in a profit. He knows his criticics' one-liners: "a one-trick pony", "pile 'em high and sell 'em cheap", "no strategy".

He retorts: "When you're successful, a lot of people don't like you. You've got to grow a thick a skin. These people [the critics] have achieved nothing themselves. 'A man without a strategy.' I don't think you get £4bn in mortgages without a strategy."

He is open to fresh criticism with IF, which he says will be his last grand venture. "I'm not poor. I'm not a millionaire. Personally I haven't made a lot of money, Don't get me wrong there's more to life than money ... This is probably the last big one I'm going to do."

His anxiety is that rivals will copy IF. The prototype website looks far from innovative, but it boasts of its title that "no word in the English language has more potential".

Spowart refuses to be knocked off course or listen to the detractors who were out in force yesterday. "The important thing is that you know, hand on heart, that the thing you're doing is successful."

The result was another leg-up for the bank's share price, sickly of late, with the new dot.com credibility adding £4bn to its market value in just three days. IF, formed from the middle letters of Halifax's name and standing for "intelligent finance", is revolutionary, according to Spowart, whose looks are more old-fashioned, grey banker than youthful e-designer. But the marketing patter rolls smoothly off his tongue, with words such as "unique" , "innovative", "brilliant" injected at regular intervals in his broad Scottish accent. "It's going to take the market by storm. That's my own interpretation. It's more ambitious [than anything I've done before]," Spowart says. An unlikely revolutionary, the 49-year- old is one of the few people to have started two banks from scratch, causing a step-change in the financial industry each time. His first was the telephone banking arm of Direct Line, the "little red phone" insurance operation which made its founder, Peter Wood, a multi-millionaire. The second was Standard Life Bank, which at times last year was snatching a 25% share of all new mortgages in Britain. It was causing so much pain to Halifax, the country's biggest mortgage lender, that its chief executive, James Crosby, hired Spowart last October to end his misery. Now Crosby expects steely-eyed Spowart to turn the torture treatment on his rivals. While IF will not go live until the summer after a £30m advertising campaign, the agony has already started for some. Standard Life, in particular, has been hit for six by the outflow of its banking staff, who have flocked to Spowart's new start-up and forced the mutual insurer into offering knee-jerk bonus payments as golden handcuffs. He has even used the same Scottish marketing agency, The Union, which helped him create Standard Life Bank. But, despite claims to the contrary, Spowart insists he did not "poach" anyone and did not even try to match the bonuses, worth a year's salary in some cases, offered by his former employer. "I've never ever said 'come with me to this venture'," he protests. So why have 50 followed him? "I give them leadership and creative thought," he says. He sees himself as "approachable" and a leader of a team. "The most important asset you have is your staff. Every day in life I walk the floors. If you talk to your staff, they tell you what the customers are looking for." For Spowart, walking the floors translates in to patrolling the call centres which are crucial to his low-cost, branchless banks. Described by many as the modern version of the Industrial Revolution's satanic mills, they are, Spowart insists good places in which to work. "People don't perform well in a boring environment. A number of people talk about the energy when they walk through the door," he says of the new operations in Edinburgh and Livingston, where he will soon employ 1,200 people. He has made his home in Livingston. He is proud of his record of creating jobs in his native country. Standard Life Bank employed a similar number of staff and Spowart says a Scottish base was the only condition he gave the Halifax when he took the job, running what was code-named greenfield.co until the unveiling of if.com yesterday. He reiterates that people are crucial to the operation. "They are the ones dealing with the customers. If you treat your people well they'll respond." Now used to being in the public eye - he says he gives interviews not for his profile but for his team and the banking operation - it has been quite a journey from Cowdenbeath butcher's son to creator of two of the most innovative banks of recent years. While fiercely protective of his wife of 25 years, Janis, he is still ambitious. Growing up near the Fife coalfields, he had a choice between going down the mine, working at nearby Rosyth shipyard or joining one of Scotland's prestigious banks. On leaving Beath high school he chose the last, joining National Commercial Bank which later became part of Royal Bank of Scotland. That was where, 20 years later, he got involved with Direct Line and it was from there that he decided to approach Standard Life with his idea for a new bank. Within six months Spowart's bank at Standard Life had snatched 17% of the cut-throat mortgage market and within 18 months had grabbed £3bn of savings and £2bn of mortages. This time, with Halifax, he reckons he can do it all over again and even better. He insists If is unique, and not a "me-too" version of the other, oddly named ventures on the net. While he refuses to reveal details of the five products - current accounts, savings, mortgages, credit cards and loans - he insists nothing like them will have been seen before. It will not be an internet-only bank: he is a believer in the telephone and the internet, citing research from the US to say that "the human element is very important". The golf-loving church elder is also used to the sceptics and the doubters. When he started selling mortgages over the phone at Direct Line, he was told it would never work. At Standard Life his "team" was selling mortgages in nine minutes. At IF he will get the sales process down to just six minutes. His target audience now is the those who are hostage to the sluggish clearing banks rather than the trendy young things targeted by Prudential's egg. He has some tough targets. Turning IF's start-up losses into a profit in three years and making a 15% return on capital, an unusually precise ambition for an internet start-up. Few doubt Spowart's ability to bring in the masses - his target is to collect 500,000 customers in the first financial year- but many question his ability to create another bank that can turn in a profit. He knows his criticics' one-liners: "a one-trick pony", "pile 'em high and sell 'em cheap", "no strategy". He retorts: "When you're successful, a lot of people don't like you. You've got to grow a thick a skin. These people [the critics] have achieved nothing themselves. 'A man without a strategy.' I don't think you get £4bn in mortgages without a strategy." He is open to fresh criticism with IF, which he says will be his last grand venture. "I'm not poor. I'm not a millionaire. Personally I haven't made a lot of money, Don't get me wrong there's more to life than money ... This is probably the last big one I'm going to do." His anxiety is that rivals will copy IF. The prototype website looks far from innovative, but it boasts of its title that "no word in the English language has more potential". Spowart refuses to be knocked off course or listen to the detractors who were out in force yesterday. "The important thing is that you know, hand on heart, that the thing you're doing is successful."

fields.headline: Hopes dwindle for Microsoft deal
fields.standfirst:
Out-of-court talks produce little progress as deadline approaches

E-finance: special report
Microsoft on trial: special report www.microsoft.com
fields.trailText: Hope is dwindling that out-of- court negotiations in the Microsoft monopoly case will result in a settlement before next week's closing arguments, an unofficial mediation deadline.
fields.body:
Hope is dwindling that out-of- court negotiations in the Microsoft monopoly case will result in a settlement before next week's closing arguments, an unofficial mediation deadline.

Neither the company nor the US justice department has given up on settlement talks before Richard Posner, the chief appellate judge in Chicago recruited to mediate.

But two-and-a-half months into the negotiations the sides have remained so far apart that they continue to meet one- on-one with Judge Posner rather than face-to-face, people familiar with the talks said.

In a sign that Microsoft is already looking beyond the settlement talks, it is cranking up a congressional lobbying campaign to fight a court ordered break-up of the software group.

Microsoft and Justice also appear to be at odds over how any settlement or court ordered sanction would apply to the company's latest product, Windows 2000.

Closing arguments are set for Tuesday before Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson in Washington, who has ruled already that Microsoft has monopoly power in personal computer operating systems with its Windows software.

In his findings the judge said that Microsoft harmed consumers, stymied competitors and stifled innovation. He has yet to rule on whether those actions broke competition law, and that will be the focus of arguments next week.

If Judge Jackson does rule against Microsoft, he would then consider sanctions -ranging from breaking up the company to enforced changes in its business practices.

Nobody has ruled out the possibility that Judge Posner, a widely respected legal intellect and antitrust expert, can come up with a solution that will be acceptable to both Microsoft and the government. Settlement talks can continue after closing arguments, but time is running out.

"I'm not optimistic about a settlement," said a source close to the talks. "There can't be a settlement between now and Tuesday - it's just too late."

Judge Posner apparently has yet to give up on a settlement because he is still holding sessions with each side.

Judge Jackson had warned attorneys that Judge Posner would end the talks if they seemed to be going nowhere.

A good deal of time in those sessions has been spent reviewing the facts of the case, saving any discussion of actual settlement proposals for late in the process.

Microsoft has argued to congressional staffers that it has put a good faith offer on the table - one that would require some sort of change in its conduct but which apparently has yet to satisfy the government. But industry attorneys advising the government are deeply sceptical about the potential of such plans to change the company's conduct.

"Nobody trusts Microsoft to disclose the information necessary to have the products of competitors inter-operate in a timely manner," one industry attorney said.

Until now, Microsoft has avoided talks of a forced break-up and focused on discussing why it has not violated competition laws.

But, in a fundamental shift in strategy, Microsoft lobbyists have begun outlining to congressional staff the problems that Microsoft believes loom with the government plan to seek a break-up of the group.

Meanwhile, the two sides seem to disagree on how the fundamentals of the case relate to Windows 2000. Microsoft officials see significant code and product differences between Windows 2000 and earlier versions of Windows.

But justice department lawyers and the 19 states involved in the case view Windows 2000 as the successor to the monopoly software Judge Jackson addressed.

The importance of the issue arose last week when complaints made by competitors were aired by the European commission's competition directorate.

They complained that Microsoft had bundled the desktop version of Windows 2000 with Windows 2000 for servers "in a way which permits only Microsoft's products to be fully operable".

fields.headline: Heavyweights promise cheaper insurance
fields.standfirst:
Net search

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The cost of buying car and home insurance may tumble after two of the biggest names in financial services this week announced ambitious plans for online general insurance operations.
fields.body:
The cost of buying car and home insurance may tumble after two of the biggest names in financial services this week announced ambitious plans for online general insurance operations.

The Halifax announced it would spend £150m on setting up "esure", which it claims will be the UK's first internet branded insurer focused on providing low-cost cover online to motorists and homeowners.

And Direct Line, the company credited with revolutionising the insurance industry in the 80s, said it was developing an internet site for motorists offering insurance, an auction facility and other services. Meanwhile, Tesco personal finance last month announced plans to provide online quotes for home, motor and travel insurance by the summer.

Most of the major insurers have invested in websites which allow you to buy policies, or at least get a quote, online.The benefits of buying on the internet are self-evident. It is more convenient, allowing you to buy insurance when you want, and should also be cheaper, as buying online saves the insurer a huge amount in overheads. But the same old rules of caution apply. To get the best deal, shop around. And remember to compare the level of cover offered by different policies, not just prices. Any search engine will help you find your insurer of choice. Or go to a website like Financial Information Net Directory (www.find.co.uk) which has links to main UK insurers' websites.

Buying insurance online is usually as simple as submitting your details electronically, waiting for a quote to be e-mailed back to you and entering your credit card details. The biggest deterrent to buying online is having to fill in countless electronic forms depending on how many quotes you want.

If this fills you with dread, try one of the internet insurance brokers. Companies like Screentrade, at www.screentrade.co.uk, do the shopping around for you. Screentrade describes itself as the UK's first online general insurance broker. Its service is free and allows you to get a selection of quotes from leading names and then buy online.

Using a broker may save you time but check how many insurers they approach on your behalf. Some will send your details to more companies than others and may get you a better price.

Screentrade currently has 17 firms on its motor insurance panel but only six on its home insurance panel and four on its travel insurance panel. Moreover, some brokers will only send you the cheapest quote they get, while others send a selection, letting you compare prices with the type of cover provided.

fields.headline: Sony ups the console stakes
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Sony yesterday unveiled the machine that could make it the world's dominant player in home entertainment. The PlayStation 2 will not only be the world's most advanced games console, it will also play DVD movies.
fields.body:
Sony yesterday unveiled the machine that could make it the world's dominant player in home entertainment. The PlayStation 2 will not only be the world's most advanced games console, it will also play DVD movies.

The company hopes that the new machine will become the focal point of a network of devices including televisions, audio systems and digital cameras, while also connecting users to the internet.

Sony is already the market leader in the games console business. Since entering the market five years ago it has sold more than 70m PlayStations worldwide, including 5.7m in Britain. This suggests that a fifth of all British households have PlayStations.

The system accounts for about a quarter of the company's turnover and up to 40% of its profits, according to Ray Maguire, the managing director of Sony Computer Entertainment in Britain.

The more powerful PlayStation 2 could do even better. Sony hopes to sell 2m units as soon as it goes on sale in Japan, and its factories are al ready producing half a million machines a month.

When the company offered 1,000 machines for Japanese users to pre-order over the internet yesterday its website crashed after taking 100,000 hits in a minute.

Frederic Diot, a senior analyst at Datamonitor, a UK-based market research company, said Japan is "voracious for any new consumer electronics". He expected Sony to sell 450,000 units in the UK this year, following a launch in the autumn. At a projected price of £299.99 the same launch price as the original PlayStation, sales would be worth £135m.

However the real money is in the games, which sell for between £20 and £35.

Mr Diot said that last year sales of console games were worth $6.4bn (£4bn) in the US and Europe, including £920m in Britain.

Datamonitor expects the market to be worth $17.2 bn (£10.7bn) by 2003.

In unit terms, the PlayStation currently has more than 70% of UK console games market, according to Rick Smith of ChartTrack, which collects data from retailers.

The rest is shared between the Nintendo 64, Nintendo Game Boy and Sega Dreamcast. Sony now has 40% of the software market tracked by ChartTrack, including PC games and CD-roms.

The company hopes to capitalise on the strength of its software line-up by enabling the PlayStation 2 to run most PlayStation software. Unlike personal computers, next-generation games consoles do not usually run programs written for earlier machines.

There have been five generations of console technology since Atari established a worldwide market with the VCS (Video Computer System) at the end of the 1970s.

Each generation of technology has been dominated by one firm, with Atari, Nintendo, Sega and Sony succeeding one another as market leaders.

The PlayStation 2 will undoubtedly be challenged by an improved version of Sega's Dreamcast, Nintendo's forthcoming Dolphin, and by the still-unannounced X-Box expected from Microsoft.

Sony hopes the PlayStation 2 will make it the first company to dominate two successive generations of console technology.

fields.headline: Executed soldiers honoured
fields.standfirst: Remembrance Day: special report
fields.trailText: A statue of a young soldier, blindfolded in front of a firing squad, is to stand at the centre of the first national memorial to the British servicemen executed during the first world war.
fields.body:
A statue of a young soldier, blindfolded in front of a firing squad, is to stand at the centre of the first national memorial to the British servicemen executed during the first world war.

It will be at the heart of a stand of 306 newly-planted trees at the National Memorial Arboretum in Staffordshire. Each will bear a plaque honouring a soldier shot at dawn by his own side "as an example to others", mostly for cowardice or desertion.

The wood will enshrine a growing mood of pity for the soldiers nearly 90 years after their deaths.

"It will mean that they have come home at last in the memory of the country they tried to serve," said John Hipkin, 73, founder of the pressure group Shot at Dawn.

The final statue will be eight feet tall, and finished in concrete by Andy DeComyn, 33, a third year art student at the University of Central England, in Birmingham.

"Submitting it was a long shot", he said, "I could not believe it when it was accepted. I was over the moon."

The boy is modelled on Private Herbert Burden, of the First Battalion Northumberland Fusiliers, who was shot for desertion in 1917.

webTitle: Anger as Shipman escapes trial over 23 deaths

fields.headline: Anger as Shipman escapes trial over 23 deaths
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: Families of 23 alleged victims of Harold Shipman, jailed for life last month for killing 15 of his patients, reacted angrily yesterday to news that the doctor will face no more murder charges.
fields.body:
Families of 23 alleged victims of Harold Shipman, jailed for life last month for killing 15 of his patients, reacted angrily yesterday to news that the doctor will face no more murder charges.

"I'm outraged that the CPS is not going to proceed," said Suzanne Bennison, whose grandmother Edith Brock died in November 1995. "If they think they can appease me by shoving a letter through my door and thinking I will go away quietly, they have chosen the wrong person."

John Hibbert, son of Hilda Hibbert, who died in a chair at home four years ago, said: "Shipman has literally got away with murder."

David Calvert-Smith QC, the director of public prosecutions, told the families of his "reluctant" and almost unprecedented decision not to proceed with new charges in letters delivered to their homes by courier early yesterday.

"I have reluctantly concluded that there are insurmountable legal difficulties to further trials taking place," he told them.

After giving his reasons, Mr Calvert-Smith added: "I hope my explanation is to some degree helpful to you and that you will in time be able to come to terms with your tragic loss."

Mr Calvert-Smith has overruled detectives who are convinced that Shipman killed the 23 women, all of whom were cremated. Although certain to be almost as disappointed as the families, they are unlikely to offer any public criticism of the DDP's decision. They will, however, continue to investigate 30 cases which came to light after Shipman's trial finished at Preston crown court.

Mr Calvert-Smith acknowledged in a statement that there was enough evidence for a second or even a third trial and admitted that his decision was exceptional.

"I have had to consider the effect of the enormous publicity upon any further trial of Harold Shipman on new charges, and that he has already been sent to prison for the rest of his natural life," he said.

"In reaching this decision, I have been acutely aware of the distress of relatives of the deceased and the understandable desire of some of them for a further public trial in a criminal court."

He said "a considerable majority" of the relatives of the alleged victims had accepted that a new trial could not take place and added that further proceedings could delay or hamper the progress of the public inquiry due to go ahead in Manchester.

"Normally a decision to prosecute would automatically follow if there is enough evidence for a realistic prospect of conviction of murder," he said. "But this has been an exceptional and, I hope, unique case."

He said any decision about the deaths of Shipman's other alleged victims would now be a matter for John Pollard, coroner of Tameside, Greater Manchester.

"I am now going to assess the whole Shipman situation fully," said Mr Pollard. "I will consider the inquests already opened, plus possible inquests on the other 23 alleged victims."

But even if Mr Pollard goes ahead with inquests on the 23 women, the absence of forensic evidence could mean relatives would not secure the verdicts they want.

Shipman, from Hyde, Greater Manchester, was convicted of murdering 15 women patients with lethal injections of diamorphine. After a four-month trial Mr Justice Forbes recommended he should spend the rest of his natural life behind bars.

Mr Hibbert contacted police about his mother's death when the murder inquiry began in 1998 and was later told that the evidence was conclusive.

"I was a bit disappointed that her case was not included in the original trial. But I understand that it wasn't practical to confront the jury with endless charges.

"Nevertheless, he was an evil monster running amok and getting away with it."

Mrs Bennison added: "I have had to wait three long weeks since the trial finished to hear something that I didn't want to hear.

"I'm finding it very difficult to comprehend what the DPP's letter means by insurmountable legal difficulties.

"It seems the British legal system has nothing in place for something like this.

"If Shipman confessed, I would be happy. I don't want him to be given another life sentence for Edith Brock. I want him either to admit what he did or for there to be some legal method whereby the finger can be pointed at him. His guilt has to be publicly recognised."

"But this has been an exceptional and, I hope, unique case." He said any decision about the deaths of Shipman's other alleged victims would now be a matter for John Pollard, coroner of Tameside, Greater Manchester. "I am now going to assess the whole Shipman situation fully," said Mr Pollard. "I will consider the inquests already opened, plus possible inquests on the other 23 alleged victims." Shipman, from Hyde, Greater Manchester, was convicted of murdering 15 women patients with lethal injections of diamorphine. webTitle: Tales of torture leak from Russian camps

fields.headline: Tales of torture leak from Russian camps
fields.standfirst:
Escaped Chechen victims tell of rape, beating and humiliation
Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Russia came under mounting international pressure to allow independent inspection of detention camps in Chechnya yesterday as reports of torture and rape of its civilians sparked a further exodus of refugees.
fields.body:
Russia came under mounting international pressure to allow independent inspection of detention camps in Chechnya yesterday as reports of torture and rape of its civilians sparked a further exodus of refugees.

Escapees from a Russian "filtration camp" north of Grozny, the destroyed Chechen capital, painted a picture of horrific abuses by masked Russian prison guards. International aid organisations and human rights monitors, which have been largely denied access to Chechnya, raised the alarm.

A Chechen man of 38 who spent weeks in the Chernokozovo camp north of Grozny before bribing his way out said women and men were being raped by masked Russians. The inmates, 16 to a cell, were beaten almost daily with iron bars, ordered to crawl before their Russian jailers, and forced to use their cramped cells as open toilets, he said.

Other former inmates said they had to stand all day with their hands raised.

"What's happening in these filtration camps is unspeakable," said Holly Cartner, the executive director of the Europe and central Asia division of Human Rights Watch. "We saw the same kind of torture and ill-treatment in filtration camps during the last Chechen war. The Russians must not get away with committing these abuses for a second time."

The Office of United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) reported that 3,000 Chechens had fled to neighbouring Ingushetia in the past two days.

"Many of the people say they would like to go home, but they are afraid to do so," said the UNHCR spokesman, Ron Redmond. "[The refugees] speak of looting, burning of property, and beatings by Russian troops."

In detailed and separate interviews with Human Rights Watch monitors based in Nazran, Ingushetia, three men gave shocking depictions of the conditions at the Chernokozovo detention centre, one of at least four camps the organisation says have been set up by Russian forces tightening their grip on Chechnya.

Yuri Biryukov of the Russian prosecutor general's office said there were less than 200 detainees at Chernokozovo, "most of them adult men who are members of illegal [Chechen] militias".

A man given the alias 'Waha', 38, told Human Rights Watch that he arrived at the camp last month with others, including a 42-year-old mother of four from the village of Tolstoy-Yurt. The day after he arrived, he heard the woman's screams.

"The woman was beaten mercilessly," he said. "From the noise, I could guess she was being beaten with rubber sticks. She was beaten for 15 minutes. Then for a half-hour we didn't hear from her at all. We could hear everything that was going on in the jail, but couldn't see. In a half-hour, we understood she was being raped. She was begging them not to do it. The soldiers were using bad language and this lasted for some time. Then everything stopped."

All three men spoke of rapes against both males and females at the same camp.

'Issa', 21, spent three weeks in Chernokozovo and said he was beaten every day except for three or four.

The Russian guards lobbed tear gas into the cells, the escapees said. All three said they were forced to run a gauntlet of up to 20 Russians who beat them with rubber truncheons or iron bars.

On the basis of the testimony from refugees, Human Rights Watch says hundreds of Chechens, mainly men, have been rounded up and taken to "filtration camps" in the past month.

Ireland's Mary Robinson, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights - who has just been refused Russian permission to visit the region - said this week she was receiving reports of similar abuses from the International Committee for the Red Cross, which is also being denied access to the prisoners.

Human Rights Watch called on the Russian authorities "immediately to put an end to the abuses in the filtration camps and to allow a permanent international monitoring presence to monitor the con duct of Russian authorities in the camps".

James Rubin, spokesman for the US state department, spoke in a similar vein in Washington: "We call on the government of Russia to conduct a full, comprehensive, and transparent investigation of alleged atrocities in Chechnya... Russia has a clear obligation to investigate the numerous credible reports of civilian killings and alleged misconduct by its soldiers, promptly."

On Thursday, Vladimir Kalamanov, the head of Russia's immigration service, was appointed as Russia's human rights ombudsman for Chechnya, in an apparent attempt by the acting president, Vladimir Putin, to deflect criticism.

The Council of Europe's human rights envoy, Alvaro Gil-Robles, is to visit Moscow next week and hopes to be allowed to travel to Chechnya.

'The guards wore masks and we could not look in their eyes'

'Waha', 38, Chechen male escapee from Chernokozovo camp, north of the Chechen capital, Grozny: "They called one man out of his cell. They took him out and without saying anything, they started beating him very cruelly with their feet and truncheons.

"We could hear everything. Then the soldiers ordered him to undress. Then they laid him on something, maybe they tied him to something. Something was done to him, an act like paedophiles do, sodomy.

"We heard him say: 'Please, please, this is not necessary.' After all this happened, the victim said: 'You have killed me.'

"There were two or three such cases, the same thing happened twice to that same person, and I think another man. They renamed him Alla. They said: 'From now on you will be Alla, a woman'."

'Akmed', 24: "Each time we went to the interrogation room or were called out for some other purpose, we were beaten.

"The guards were wearing masks and would not let us look in their eyes. I was ordered to fall down and crawl.

"They ordered me to take off my hat when I reached the door, and introduce myself. I said: 'Citizen officer, thank you for seeing me. According to your order, I have crawled here.'

"I reached the room, and one guard beat me with an iron stick."

fields.headline: Desert island storm
fields.trailText: Wave riding
fields.body:
You only need a few squawks from the herring gulls of Radio 4's Desert Island Discs signature tune and the ever-upward trajectory of a successful career flashes before you. It's so ritualised and formulaic, Sue Lawley may as well go home.

But last week it was different. The castaway was Stuart Hall, sociologist and creator of cultural studies, and within minutes we were contemplating the contradictions and ironies of Britishness. Thereafter we learned almost nothing about Hall's professional milestones, beyond passing references to his editorship of the New Left Review, his time developing cultural studies at Birmingham, and his Open University tenure.

Instead, this suddenly became a programme about ideas and feelings. In his native Jamaica, Hall lived the tension between a mother in thrall to all things British, and the actual colonial experience of being patronised. A Rhodes scholar at Oxford, he felt understandably alien, but in the decade of Suez and Hungary went on to help fight for democratic, anti-imperialist policies.

He was trying to re-imagine a Britain where difference was thought exciting rather than threatening. Lawley kept insisting that she was playing devil's advocate, but her topics - Sikhs and helmets, arranged marriages, the "multicultural utopia" - were deadly revealing.

Yet Hall never got prickly. Having argued that popular culture must be taken seriously, he did just that, engaging directly with Lawley's questions in a manner that suggested he knew exactly where they were coming from. The music - Miles Davis, Bob Marley, Billie Holliday - didn't just remind him of his experiences but was part of them. Hall is an elegant sociologist of his own life: rarely do modesty, eloquence and passion dance together so adroitly. Why has he never been Reith Lecturer? I think we can guess.

Black American comedian and civil rights activist Dick Gregory is of the same generation as Hall, and in Laughing Matters: Dick Gregory (Radio 4) he vividly described the Southern segregated culture in which he grew up. You could spend your life never seeing a white face, and if you shopped at a downtown store you weren't allowed to try on the clothes.

Gregory's big break came when he was accidentally booked to do a night at a Hugh Hefner Playboy Club in Chicago for an audience of Southern white men gathered for a frozen food convention. He had them in hysterics for six hours with jokes about the Ku Klux Klan, their laughter an implicit acknowledgement of the black experience.

The day after the Gregory programme, Andy Kershaw began a new six-part Radio 2 series retracing the journey from Virginia to California taken by Chuck Berry's po' boy in his 1963 song The Promised Land.

In programme one Kershaw also recalled the segregated South of the early 60s: remarkably, it was only in 1961 that African-Americans got the vote. Kershaw has made the musical travelogue his own, but it remains to be seen whether the historical dimension here won't cramp his extemporising skills. Given the persistently shoddy treatment he's received on Radio 1, it can't be long before he decamps to Radio 2 permanently.

Kershaw is a world music specialist, but Radio 3's luminous four-part series on Indian devotional music, Nights of the Goddess, makes one wonder about the usefulness of labelling Indian classical music "world music", as though it had more in common with reggae than Bach. Jameela Siddiqi guides us round festivals and concerts where the secular and the religious meet in demonic mandolins and lustrous ragas. Bombay, she told us, is now called Mumbai after the goddess Mumba Devi, and she rolled its vowels so melodiously that the city's very name seemed like music.
