fields.headline: Hunt saboteur loses £52,000 damages
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: A hunt saboteur who won £52,000 damages from a farmer who retaliated when attacked with a baseball bat yesterday had the award rescinded.
fields.body:
A hunt saboteur who won £52,000 damages from a farmer who retaliated when attacked with a baseball bat yesterday had the award rescinded.

The court of appeal ruled the farmer, William Kirkby, 55, was acting in self defence when he wrested away the bat and struck Harry Cross, 47, on the side of the head, fracturing his skull. Lord Justice Beldam said that the injury, which has led to Mr Cross having epileptic fits, was a result of his "criminal and unlawful" acts in attacking Mr Kirkby.

A high court judge sitting in Grimsby last year had ruled Mr Cross was entitled to the damages because Mr Kirkby, of Wootton, North Lincolnshire, had used excessive force, and that the defence of acting in self defence was not open to him.

Lord Justice Beldam said yesterday that the ruling had overlooked the fact Mr Kirkby "had done what he thought was necessary in the anguish of the moment". He should not have been expected to mea sure the violence he meted out with "mathematical precision" to comply with the law.

Mr Cross, of Halesworth, Suffolk, and his partner were on Mr Kirkby's land in 1992 during a meeting of the Brocklesby Hunt. Mr Kirkby, who had had to give up hunting after a fall from a horse, escorted the partner off his land using "reasonable force" after she bit him, but Mr Cross, a hunt saboteur for 20 years, threatened to kill him, said Lord Justice Beldam.

Mr Cross punched the farmer on his way to his car nearby, from which he took a baseball bat. The saboteur "became abusive and threatening" and in a rage smashed the bat. Mr Kirkby was alarmed and tried to walk away, but was hit on his arm and shoulder by Mr Cross, "who was looking for a fight".

Mr Kirkby grabbed the bat and hit Mr Cross a single blow, which ended the fight. Lord Justice Judge said the court found the blow was "not in revenge, or to teach him a lesson or give him a good hiding".

fields.headline: The tyranny of the telephone
fields.standfirst: The phone is one of the more disagreeable forms of human contact. It works much better than it used to, but only until you get through
fields.trailText: Alexander Chancellor: The phone is one of the more disagreeable forms of human contact. It works much better than it used to, but only until you get through
fields.body:
It used to be said that you could write a cheque on the back of an elephant, and your bank would still honour it. It's not that way now. In practically every transaction with companies or officialdom, you have to do things in exactly the way they tell you. If you pay a telephone bill, you must put your cheque in the envelope provided, write your customer code number on the back, fill in the pay-slip as required, and not under any circumstances staple the two together. If you pay a parking fine, you must write the penalty notice number - and very long it is, too - on the back of the cheque. If you pay an American Express bill, you must write your account number on the front of the cheque. And so it goes on.

Contemporary corporate culture insists on giving the impression that you, the customer, are king, and that everything is arranged for your greater convenience and happiness. But the opposite is really the case. Companies are in thrall to their own increasingly complicated operating systems. These systems are rigid and sacrosanct while they are in place, but they also change all the time. Those employees who are not "let go" because of new labour-saving arrangements are constantly having to come to terms with fresh ways of doing things. They have no time to consider the customer's interests. So far as the customer is concerned, their only purpose is to make him or her conform to systems that they themselves find hard to understand, and that are frequently teetering on the brink of collapse.

The rapid growth of the internet as a means of conducting transactions is the public's response to this bullying. Some people find the internet difficult to use, but they are prepared to make the effort in order to avoid more disagreeable forms of human contact. The telephone is now one of these. The telephone works much better than it used to, but only until you get through. Then you are met with baffling recorded options, warnings that your conversation will be taped (in your interests, of course), and normally a long wait to the accompaniment of horrible music before a human being comes on the line. If this happens, which it often doesn't, you will probably be required to supply a long reference number, which you don't have to hand, before that person will agree to speak to you. Once again, it is the company that dictates all the rules.

I have written to my bank in the past with a perfectly reasonable request for it to go on providing a service that it always provided before, only to be told in reply that its new system doesn't permit it to do so. We all have our own systems for doing things. But we are never asked what our systems are and how they can be accommodated. It is assumed we will understand that the company's system has to prevail. The company is much bigger and more important than we are. The company is marching with the times, exploiting technological advance to improve efficiency, and our duty is to support it in this endeavour. There is little point in us complaining that we are being much worse served as a result. The company will not care. It will simply regard us as an irritating obstacle to progress.

Tony Blair's control freakery is merely a symptom of a wider phenomenon, which demands compliance by the individual to whatever is considered by the people in charge to be in the public or the corporate interest. The phenomenon is universal, which is perhaps why Charlie Brown is the most popular comic strip character that has ever existed. Charles Schulz, his creator who died last weekend, shared with most of the people of the world a deep feeling of ineffectiveness. Charlie Brown is hopelessly ineffective. He is so ineffective that he makes the rest of us feel rather powerful. No wonder we love him.

The tragedy of this state of affairs is that it is so difficult for the individual to fight back. It is possible to sabotage the internet, as the hackers, or hacker, who closed down several of the best-known websites showed the other day. You can join the kind of woolly-headed protest demonstration that caused so much disruption at the conference of the World Trade Organisation in Seattle last year. You can refuse to buy genetically-modified foods. But none of this helps you to prevail in everyday situations. You could always staple your cheque to your pay-slip when you pay the telephone bill, but that would be only a minor irritant. You could even try writing cheques on the backs of elephants, but, alas, they wouldn't be cashed. I can think of no solution except to be like Charlie Brown and make the best you can out of life, even though you never get to kick the ball.

You could always staple your cheque to your pay-slip when you pay the telephone bill, but that would be only a minor irritant. You could even try writing cheques on the backs of elephants, but, alas, they wouldn't be cashed. I can think of no solution except to be like Charlie Brown and make the best you can out of life, even though you never get to kick the ball.

fields.headline: Underside
fields.trailText: • Oh to be in England ... six 747 airliners - one of them loaded with business people from go-go Malaysia -winged into Heathrow at 6.30am on Wednesday, their top-notch human cargo keen to get up close to Britain's world-beating economy. An hour later and the big birds were still stuck on the tarmac, world-beating BAA's one towtruck having conked out. The pilots, keen to interact with a world-beating hot shower, pestered the BAA controller, only to be told "I've got my schedule to adhere to", followed by a very definite over and out. Aboard the Malaysian jumbo, the aircrew passed on this caring, sharing message to the passengers. Much tut-tutting of the "I'd heard things were bad, but ..." variety.

 Oh to be in England ... six 747 airliners - one of them loaded with business people from go-go Malaysia -winged into Heathrow at 6.30am on Wednesday, their top-notch human cargo keen to get up close to Britain's world-beating economy. An hour later and the big birds were still stuck on the tarmac, world-beating BAA's one towtruck having conked out. The pilots, keen to interact with a world-beating hot shower, pestered the BAA controller, only to be told "I've got my schedule to adhere to", followed by a very definite over and out. Aboard the Malaysian jumbo, the aircrew passed on this caring, sharing message to the passengers. Much tut-tutting of the "I'd heard things were bad, but ..." variety.

 Down on the ground (eventually), they could have perused Salomon Smith Barney's ultra-tasteful industry report into UK food manufacturers. "Bombed out for good?", asks the investment bank over a photograph of what looks remarkably like Hiroshima just after its airborne visit from President Truman's emissaries in 1945. How very droll, chaps. Have another bonus.

 Drollery of a more agreeable type comes courtesy of the Yorkshire building society, which has put together a limited Yorks edition of Monopoly. Goodbye Piccadilly, hello High Street, Northallerton (yours for £220). The Mayfair and Park Lane of the north are York Minster and Castle Howard respectively, while the grot-end brown sites (Whitechapel and Old Kent Road on the original) become Skipton and Wellington Street, Leeds (£60 apiece). The nail-biting "chance" spaces are sponsored by an internet company, QXL.com. Quite coincidental, no doubt. The Humber Bridge is yours for a couple of ton, not bad considering the cost over-runs during construction, but mysteriously missing is the Hull city telephone department, shamefully privatised by our current "Labour" government.

 Elsewhere in the telephone business, Icstis, the body that regulates premium services, is getting tough. With those calling cards plastered over public kiosks? Not on its beat. With rip-off 0891 numbers offering heavy breathing services? Not this week. Hot enforcement topic of today is: "In order to bring dating services into line with the sex discrimination act, Icstis would like to alert service providers to the fact that offering a standard telephone charging rate to women for dating services, while making male callers use a premium rate number, may be illegal." Well, what's the Flying Squad waiting for?

 Its coppers can't be laid up with injuries, because we have the word of media corporation Pearson that the force - or at least its on-screen replica - has never been healthier. Pearson's in-house mag heralds a spin-off from The Bill, named after the series' hardman, chief inspector Burnside. Regrettably, Pearson's budget does not run to a new set for Burnside; instead, the magazine notes: "The familiar Sun Hill [home of The Bill] hospital set ... has been taken over." Producer Richard Handford added: "We won't be seeing any medical dramas in Sun Hill for a while!" Nor any budgetary ones.

 Over in Germany, that model of (hee, hee) budgetary probity, the Bundesbank (now a mere ATM machine for the Frankfurt Euro-bankers) is minting a farewell German mark coin, in gold, just to remind its former subjects what they are giving up for Wim Duisenberg's Kleenex currency. Near-neighbour Italy, whose money is also disappearing into the euro's maw, has no similar plans, the World Gold Council said on Thursday. Given the lira is at 1,878 to the dollar and gold trades at about $300 an ounce, a lira coin would tip the scales at 0.0000017 ounces. You'd need a microscope to see it. Not so much Keynes's barbarous yellow relic as a timorous little speck.

 To conclude with the great man, a light shining in Hertfordshire for Keynes's thinking beams out of the economics department of Bishop's Stortford high school. The pupils' splendid response to a Guardian economics desk competition brought forth half a dozen postcards bearing highly plausible answers. Each bore also an ink stamp from the Post Office declaring: "To be surcharged", a polite way of sticking our economics colleagues with 39p per card. But then it was Keynes's arch-critic, Milton Friedman, who declared that: "There is no such thing as a free lunch". Well done the Stortfordians for having none of it.

fields.headline: Fashion's love affair with fur
fields.standfirst: "Being in the rag trade is like being at public school: you get bullied at first, and then it's your turn to be a callous, sociopathic wretch"
fields.trailText: Julie Burchill: "Being in the rag trade is like being at public school: you get bullied at first, and then it's your turn to be a callous, sociopathic wretch"
fields.body:
Of course people shouldn't be encouraged to say that specific groups of people are stupid or verging on the mentally subnormal. That is, they shouldn't say it due to race or gender. But when a group of people have chosen to be the way they are, those choices may well have been stupid.

I think it is fair to say, then, that violent criminals are stupider than most people; likewise Catholics, because they believe that they literally eat the body of Christ in a soggy wafer - not even a tasty Jammy Dodger! And I don't think that anyone who has spent more than 15 minutes in their company can deny that fashion people are the most remarkably stupid set of people on earth. To believe that the way things look is more important than the way things are is as good a definition of cretinism as I have ever heard. That's why Naomi Campbell's periodic hissy fits about the "racism" of fashion and beauty always ring so hollow - she has a point but, in a business built on making the fat, the old and the plain invisible, why should blackness be sacrosanct, or "represented" in some way? There is no morality in modelling, except the way things look; if you accept this shamefully shallow set of rules, you cannot complain when your skin colour is not to someone's liking.

How predictable it was, then, that fashion should again embrace fur with such gusto: it looks good. That's why we like animals. And there is Naomi - who once swore that she'd rather go naked than wear fur - prancing down the catwalk in a mink. Poor Peta, the US anti-fur charity, but they should never have got mixed up with the fashionistas in the first place. Like I said, they're stupid - a perfect 10 isn't just their dress size, it's their IQ.

I'm afraid I've always been the little boy swinging on the lamp-post when it comes to compassion in fashion, and have in the past taken first-rate pops at the rag trade's love affairs with Aids (that's Aids as affecting rich, white, "artistic" men, of course, not the African women and children who make up 80% of the victims) and breast cancer (just what a woman who's just had a double mastectomy needs to make her feel good about herself: Yasmin le Bon's perfect tits coming at her through a skin-tight FASHION TARGETS BREAST CANCER T-shirt). The point is that anything that can be fashionable must, by definition, become unfashionable. Of all the industries, fashion is the very personification of capitalism, because, unlike cars or computers, which you're meant to replace when they get old, you're meant to replace your clothes three times a year and chuck the old ones away, even though they are still perfectly serviceable. That is the whole point of fashion, and precisely why the whole 90s thing about fashion people pretending to care about "The Planet" was such a huge, brilliant joke.

So let us not castigate the likes of Puffy Combes, Tommy Hilfiger and John Galliano for draping their models in animal corpses (often with heads and paws left on), but rather give them three cheers for being so honest about the miserable, unimaginative business they tout their sad asses in. And three cheers, too, for those "unspoilt" daughters of Albion, Karen Elson (brown-and-white striped mink jacket at Carolina Herrera) and Erin O'Connor (fluffy Tuscan lamb collar at Marc Jacobs) for proving that a down-to-earth, working-class funny face can be every bit as morally incontinent as the most stuck-up supermodel goddess.

It's like being at public school, being in the rag trade: you get bullied at first, and then it's your turn to be a callous, sociopathic wretch. Last year, Elson was rejected by Dolce & Gabbana for being, at size 10, "too fat". The year before, she had been the toast of Milan. At 19, she was declared passé and superseded by 16-year-old Devon Aoki, the new favourite of Versace, Chanel, Yamamoto and Lagerfeld. Aoki looks permanently surprised, shocked by her good fortune. Hers is not a face that one can imagine ever expressing rebellion or contempt; neither are those of Audrey Marnay or Zora Star, two impressionable teenagers also being talked up by the designers and photographers who like their women young, dumb and grateful. These girls are, above all, passive, as the fashion writer Mimi Spencer put it after observing them up close: "They look disconcertingly inexperienced - not merely in a sexual way, but in every sense imaginable. In magazines and on catwalks, they look like girls who have never opened a book, a can of soup, a door."

It was disgusting to behold the recent spectacle of raddled old designer queens, all living like princes and as right-wing as kings, coming on like some Marxist scourge about how disgustingly over-paid supermodels are. "Times are changing, and they have to realise that there is a world-wide economic crisis," said a Fendi spokesman on why his house no longer wanted to employ supermodels. But none of the designers seems to have considered the notion that the fashion houses themselves, as well as the supermodels, might consider charging less for their grossly inflated products.

If Claudia Schiffer is "a joke, finished", what does Karl Lagerfeld think he is? If supermodels are so stupid, how come it's Christy Turlington and not Jean-Paul Gaultier who has gone back to college? No, the supermodels' crime was not greed and temper - which are taken as proof of highly-strung genius in male designers - but changing from malleable, mouldable girls into women who dared open their mouths and express opinions. Worst of all, they insulted the great god Fashion itself. "It was a very dull point in fashion; people needed to gossip about us to make fashion more interesting," said Turlington of the start of the supermodel feeding frenzy.

The supermodels saved their money and got out: Schiffer and Elle Macpherson into films, Crawford into being Cindy Inc, Christiansen into photography. Only Linda Evangelista - long hailed the most "professional" of the models, the "chameleon", ever ready to change her hair colour at the whim of a bored designer; ie, giving the impression that she's the model, with the least fixed sense of herself - seems unable to move on. Last year on the catwalk, she seemed confused, and gave part of her fee back; in a US TV commercial for Visa, she intones blankly, "I have no identity."

The perfect blank canvas with no other career to sustain or inspire her is a warning to all women who place their faith in fashion. Like the dead animals it parades on its catwalks, fashion is red in tooth and claw and, as in Nature, it is inevitably the bodies of women that are sucked dry and flung aside.

webTitle: Three witches cast an evil spell

fields.headline: Three witches cast an evil spell
fields.trailText: Channel surfing
fields.body:
The three Halliwell sisters are witches. They're like the weird sisters in Macbeth but with better haircare products and bra technology. Prue can move objects with her thoughts. Piper can stop time. Phoebe can see the future. I can see the future too and I foresee that Charmed will be transferring from Living on cable to Channel 5 on terrestrial, ooh, next month. If only I could stop time! If only I could move a very large object and crush Channel 5's transmitters!

Charmed is Buffy-lite, a teen series that strives to capitalise on youthful angst and the near- ubiquitous fetish among white American brats for the supernatural in suburbia, for lighting black candles and playing godawful Goth music in the fiercely guarded privacy of their otherwise well-appointed bedrooms. But, because Charmed was produced by the tacky Aaron Spelling media-industrial complex, Thanatos is not given his proper head here, and a feeble simulacrum of Eros instead prevails. What this means in production-design terms is that the witches wear pastels and have a sunny house in San Francisco filled with lots of unremittingly heterosexual beaux who have what are called "neat buns", whatever they are. The sisters are played by Shannen Doherty who was in Beverly Hills 90210, Holly Marie Combs who was in Picket Fences and Alyssa Milano who was in Melrose Place. I think you know what I'm saying.

The credit sequence of Charmed echoes the montage of Buffy the Vampire Slayer, the typography plunders its prototype's crypto-Gothic text, and the title music makes me want to drive a stake through Aaron Spelling's heart. It is a symbolically castrated reading of The Smiths' How Soon Is Now?, unforgivably omitting the self-pitying teenage-oriented pay-off to Morrissey's line"I am the son and the heir", namely "To a shyness that is criminally vulgar". Adolescent awkwardness, death-wish fantasising and the fondness for anomie-expressing blood-red lipstick, so cleverly analysed in Joss Whedon's scripts for Buffy, are here cynically manipulated.

Indeed, Charmed is a show dreamed up by the sort of zombies Buffy is always sending to oblivion. Dead-eyed jokers with no souls. They have mixed Charlie's Angels with a voguish Gothic, and added a dash of bland glamour. "Damn, we're good!" they tell each other, looking over their Powerbooks and sucking on skinny lattes. "We're gonna trash Party of Five in the all-important 14 to 24 demographic! Lunch at Spago's - I'm buying!"

In Charlie's Angels, the quartet were hardly autonomous. They had an unseen, libidinous mentor called Charlie who, when he wasn't urging the girls to fight crime, seemed to be constantly engaged in sexual harassment with hotsy-totsy women who - neat trick, this - were anything but unseen. Thus the powers that the Angels had (linguistic skills, martial arts proficiency and, in Farrah Fawcett's case, a fast hand with a high-powered hair dryer), which on paper may have cheered feminists, were not their own, but were directed by some sexist creep on the other end of a phone. As a result, as the late 70s turned to the early 80s, women TV viewers had to transfer their hopes to Cagney and Lacey.

In Charmed, too, the witches' supernatural skills, which one might have thought would give them autonomy in a male- dominated world, are only a source of worry to them. They unwittingly inherited their powers from their ancestors and are assailed by envious warlocks, trolls and other people with green contact lenses. In terms of the show's visual tropes, this means that the girls are all-too-often a clump of decorous open-mouthed reaction shots, the very picture of gormless, if putatively sexy, fluffheadery.

Still, the dopier American critics have affected to like Charmed. Aaron, God knows how, put a Spelling on them. Perhaps they were anxious to be down with what they think the kids want. For this offence, they will have to drink pints of lager and black while listening to The Cure for all eternity.

fields.headline: Cut it out
fields.trailText: It strikes me as weird that anyone should want to have healthy limbs removed and it is understandable that hospitals should ban this kind of surgery (Surgical solution, G2, February 18). I find it equally bizarre that anyone would want to have part of their nose, chin or jaw removed, or a few pounds of their flesh cut away for cosmetic reasons.
fields.body:
It strikes me as weird that anyone should want to have healthy limbs removed and it is understandable that hospitals should ban this kind of surgery (Surgical solution, G2, February 18). I find it equally bizarre that anyone would want to have part of their nose, chin or jaw removed, or a few pounds of their flesh cut away for cosmetic reasons.

Sticking needles through the ears, eyebrows, nose, nipples and genitals and inserting jewellery in the holes also seems strange to me, yet this sort of mutilation is becoming quite acceptable. The removal of a limb is actually a logical outcome of the current trend.
Jackie Rigden
London
J.Rigden@ion.ucl.ac.uk

Sticking needles through the ears, eyebrows, nose, nipples and genitals and inserting jewellery in the holes also seems strange to me, yet this sort of mutilation is becoming quite acceptable. The removal of a limb is actually a logical outcome of the current trend. Jackie Rigden London J.Rigden@ion.ucl.ac.uk

fields.headline: So loyal to Islamabad
fields.trailText: Your article on the Pakistan high commissioner and Jinnah film project was a typical example of defaming Pakistan by its enemies in the Indian lobby (Diplomat accused over film funds, February 17). Dr Akbar Ahmed is the first competent person in his job and has taken up the Kashmir issue and exposed Indian terrorism there.
fields.body:
Your article on the Pakistan high commissioner and Jinnah film project was a typical example of defaming Pakistan by its enemies in the Indian lobby (Diplomat accused over film funds, February 17). Dr Akbar Ahmed is the first competent person in his job and has taken up the Kashmir issue and exposed Indian terrorism there.

Naturally Indians are upset, hence a spate of baseless attacks are emerging to discredit him. The high commissioners before him were totally inactive, just looking after the wealth of their political masters. Film director Jamil Dehlavi, though Pakistani by birth, belongs to that elite class who were brought up and educated at the expense of Pakistan and have no love or sense of loyalty to the country.
Bashir Malik
Cambridge

 I was the first British actor to be offered a part in the film Jinnah. The first draft screenplay I read was by Guy Slater and Akbar Ahmed. When Jamil Dehlavi was engaged as director he and I met several times to discuss the project. The next draft screenplay contained several new scenes and alterations by Mr Dehlavi. I didn't know how much of the first draft, if any, remains in the filmed screenplay. But there is clearly a lined if not a linear descent from one to the other and it would be ludicrous to suggest that Mr Ahmed, as the author of the project, had "misappropriated" funds paid to him as scriptwriter, if the suggestion were not so calumnious and politically motivated. I'm sorry that Jamil Dehlavi, a director whose work I admire, has allowed himself to be embroiled in this calumny.
Corin Redgrave
London

 In Kashmir where gross human rights violations - rape, murder and torture - continue, as can be confirmed by Amnesty International, about 70,000 civilians have been killed. Even today there are 700,000 troops occupying Kashmir. So by pushing Pakistan into the corner and labelling it a "terrorist state", India will kill two birds with one stone: neutralising Pakistan and isolating Kashmir.

The Indian propaganda is working. Pakistan is often seen as a troublemaker, fomenting violence in Kashmir and harbouring designs on India. But India has a population of one billion, an aggressive nuclear programme and the fourth largest army in the world, which it has used ruthlessly, both internally - against Sikhs and Kashmiris - and externally.

Yet if you ask an average American or European to associate images with India, these would be of Gandhi, yoga, Ayuvedic medicine and the Maharishi. For Pakistan it would be Islamic fundamentalism and the threat to democracy under military rule. These images have become so strong that while people talk of "an Islamic bomb", no one mentions "a Hindu bomb".

There are almost a million Pakistanis in Britain - and a large number in the US. Most of them are good citizens who have contributed significantly to their new countries. In Britain, they have made and are making a major impact and there are now politicians, mayors and councillors of Pakistani origin. Those in the government and the Pakistani community should pause and consider the implications of declaring Pakistan a "terrorist state". The shadow of this will fall on their children, families, businesses and social lives.

India should realise that it shares the same enemies as its neighbour - a population explosion, poverty, the degradation of the environment, and a spiralling trend towards ethnic and religious intolerance. The subcontinent could be a vast powerhouse for the world, with its huge reservoirs of talent, brains and energy, if its people could work together.
Prof Akbar S Ahmed
High Commissioner for Pakistan

fields.headline: Rash of views on nappies
fields.trailText: I was bemused to read that reusable, recyclable (not recycled) nappies are the subject of canny marketing (How green is your baby? G2, February 17). The majority of the companies that supply reusable nappies are small, often run by mothers working from home. No match, then, for the marketing prowess of the multinationals. They have few advocates other than the Real Nappy Association, which operates independently and on a shoestring. New parent magazines are loath to tackle the nappy debate - much of their revenue is generated by advertising disposables.
fields.body:
I was bemused to read that reusable, recyclable (not recycled) nappies are the subject of canny marketing (How green is your baby? G2, February 17). The majority of the companies that supply reusable nappies are small, often run by mothers working from home. No match, then, for the marketing prowess of the multinationals. They have few advocates other than the Real Nappy Association, which operates independently and on a shoestring. New parent magazines are loath to tackle the nappy debate - much of their revenue is generated by advertising disposables.

There are grave concerns about the chemical content of disposables. Despite being banned from use in tampons, the chemical superabsorbers aren't independently tested and their long-term effects are unknown. The only ones engaging in clever marketing, and reaping massive profits, are the multinationals. They do so at great financial cost to parents, especially those on low incomes, and an even greater one in environmental terms.
Siobhan Carolin
London

 Bibi van der Zee asks whether the "extra work" involved in cotton nappies is worth it. As long as the chemical gel used in disposables is unregulated and can prove fatal to domestic animals, my answer is emphatically yes. The image she creates of cloth nappies belongs to the days of boiling terry squares: two-three extra weekly loads of washing in an automatic machine is hardly onerous
Anna Garland
Market Drayton, Shropshire

fields.headline: Sellafield fall-out
fields.trailText: Your report (Shutdown warning to Sellafield, February 18) did not say why the nuclear installations inspectorate is pressing BNFL to clear the backlog of highly radioactive liquid waste. It is because a serious accident affecting the ageing tanks holding this waste could disperse between 10 and 100 times the amount of radioactive released at Chernobyl. This is why Irish concern is so intense and why Bertie Ahern raised the matter with Tony Blair in November 1998. It is also why the safety inspectorate set 2015 as the deadline for converting the liquid into a more stable solid form as long ago as 1995.
fields.body:
Your report (Shutdown warning to Sellafield, February 18) did not say why the nuclear installations inspectorate is pressing BNFL to clear the backlog of highly radioactive liquid waste. It is because a serious accident affecting the ageing tanks holding this waste could disperse between 10 and 100 times the amount of radioactive released at Chernobyl. This is why Irish concern is so intense and why Bertie Ahern raised the matter with Tony Blair in November 1998. It is also why the safety inspectorate set 2015 as the deadline for converting the liquid into a more stable solid form as long ago as 1995.

Without a fourth vitrification line to convert the liquid into a more stable solid form, BNFL will miss the 2015 deadline. The safety inspectorate has reissued its warning about the deadline now precisely because BNFL is falling behind.

At the French reprocessing plant at La Hague in Normandy we understand there are six vitrification lines to convert volatile liquid wastes to a solid form. There is no backlog. BNFL's reluctance to increase vitrification capacity at Sellafield is because the company does not want to spend the money, it would rather we carry the risk.

It is disingenuous of BNFL to say it could not comment on the report before publication. It lobbied most of last year to get the report toned down.
Cllr Ken Wyatt
Nuclear Free Local Authorities nfznsc@gn.apc.org

 At last the truth is out. Homer J Simpson is the safety officer at Sellafield, not Springfield. Bring on Montgomery Burns.
DJ Browning
Altrincham, Cheshire mufc1@compuserve.com

 Has the time arrived for BNFL to change the name back to Windscale?
David Fish
Coventry

 At least there is a simple solution to the safety problems. How much is it going to cost to alter all the roads signs when they change its name again?
Wayne Jones
Melton Mowbray, Leics

webTitle: Time for a rethink on Iraq

fields.headline: Time for a rethink on Iraq
fields.trailText: The resignation of Dr Hans von Sponeck, UN humanitarian coordinator in Iraq, and Jutta Burghardt, head of the UN World Food Programme in Baghdad (Second official quits UN Iraq team, February 16) is serious. These two resignations in the wake of the former UN humanitarian director, Dennis Halliday, in 1998 indicate the gravity of the impact of UN sanctions.
fields.body:
The resignation of Dr Hans von Sponeck, UN humanitarian coordinator in Iraq, and Jutta Burghardt, head of the UN World Food Programme in Baghdad (Second official quits UN Iraq team, February 16) is serious. These two resignations in the wake of the former UN humanitarian director, Dennis Halliday, in 1998 indicate the gravity of the impact of UN sanctions.

During our visit in May 1999 we, like Maggie O'Kane (I feel the madness more, G2 February 17), watched helplessly as children suffering from sicknesses ranging from diarrhoea to leukaemia were dying before the eyes of their anxious parents. We talked, too, with both Dr Sponeck and Jutta Burghardt about the rationing programme that all Iraqis need to access to ensure some nutrition. As always, the poorest suffer most. The middle-class average monthly wage is little more than $3. This buys only the barest minimum. One church leader we visited fed 30 families for nearly a week on the scraps left over from the meal he provided for us and officials we were obliged to have with us. The double bind of a cynical regime with the uncontrolled impact of well-intentioned sanctions is effectively causing a silent genocide. The resignations demand a radical reappraisal of the sanctions policy, while ensuring resources for making weapons be rigorously prevented from entering Iraq.
Colin Bennetts, Bishop of Coventry
Peter Price, Bishop of Kingston

webTitle: Hot cross voters New-style primaries light up US elections

fields.headline: Hot cross voters New-style primaries light up US elections
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText:
It is payback time in South Carolina today, latest stop on the US primary trail, as voters deliver their verdict on the Republicans' Bush-McCain "slugfest". More than the presidential election itself, in which most Americans simply do not vote, such primaries give ordinary people the chance to get involved, air their views - and sling some cathartic abuse.

And, for a few days at least, the political high-and-mighties must listen and respond A contest like South Carolina's is the closest America's national leaders ever really get to eye-contact politics. Everybody is watching them, close up, for ideas, for gaffes, for character flaws, for grace under pressure. Town hall meetings, live debates, and stump appearances intensify this popular scrutiny. The voters, briefly, are empowered. Then the bandwagons move on and, typically, everybody settles down for another four years of griping about "Washington".
fields.body:
It is payback time in South Carolina today, latest stop on the US primary trail, as voters deliver their verdict on the Republicans' Bush-McCain "slugfest". More than the presidential election itself, in which most Americans simply do not vote, such primaries give ordinary people the chance to get involved, air their views - and sling some cathartic abuse.

And, for a few days at least, the political high-and-mighties must listen and respond A contest like South Carolina's is the closest America's national leaders ever really get to eye-contact politics. Everybody is watching them, close up, for ideas, for gaffes, for character flaws, for grace under pressure. Town hall meetings, live debates, and stump appearances intensify this popular scrutiny. The voters, briefly, are empowered. Then the bandwagons move on and, typically, everybody settles down for another four years of griping about "Washington".

Rule changes have allowed primary voters to exert far greater influence this year. In South Carolina and next week in Michigan, the Republican primaries are open to all, regardless of party affiliation or the lack of it. It was the independent swing vote which handed John McCain his New Hampshire victory. Crossover support may help him decisively today.

This phenomenon has upset the two-party system, confounded conventional campaign tactics and befuddled pollsters. Commentator William Safire calls it "the invasion of the party snatchers". With the virtual collapse of Ross Perot's Reform party as a viable alternative, this new voter freedom has become even more important. George W Bush has suffered most so far. His unexpected need to attract traditionally Democratic voters as well as Republicans and independents has muddled his conservative platform. But free votes can cut both ways. Anything that weakens the stranglehold of the Republican and Democratic machines and renders the political process more inclusive gets our vote.

fields.headline: Not funny
fields.trailText:
Of course columnists have licence to go beyond what might be read in the more adult parts of your paper, but Catherine Bennett's patronising benevolence and her quotations from Hallam Tennyson are offensive (Peace or poetic justice, February 17). I can tell her, as someone who has spent many years working with violent men in the probation service in London and for the last three years with those who perpetrate domestic violence on their partners, that the locus of such contemptible behaviour is not dependent on race, class, creed or nation.
You may throw up your hands in dismay at the stalled - and hopefully only stalled - peace process, but to resort to tired stereotypes really isn't funny.
Dermot Brady
London

webTitle: Such men are dangerous But women are less afraid to speak out

fields.headline: Such men are dangerous But women are less afraid to speak out
fields.trailText:
Our front-page story yesterday made shocking reading: between 118,000 and 295,000 women are raped or sexually assaulted every year. This starkly compares with just 6,000 cases of rape and 17,500 incidents of indecent assault which reach the ears of the police. What we have to confront is the fact that sexual violence against women is far more widespread than previously realised and that the law is a remarkably ineffective instrument for protecting them.

These are disturbing truths which must prompt long and hard reflection. We need more than a quick fix to identify and eliminate a few deviants; these figures indicate a pattern of behaviour amongst a large group of younger men.
fields.body:
Our front-page story yesterday made shocking reading: between 118,000 and 295,000 women are raped or sexually assaulted every year. This starkly compares with just 6,000 cases of rape and 17,500 incidents of indecent assault which reach the ears of the police. What we have to confront is the fact that sexual violence against women is far more widespread than previously realised and that the law is a remarkably ineffective instrument for protecting them.

These are disturbing truths which must prompt long and hard reflection. We need more than a quick fix to identify and eliminate a few deviants; these figures indicate a pattern of behaviour amongst a large group of younger men.

That in turn depends on a social context which legitimises or at least allows it. Two issues must be faced here. Firstly, 43% of all attacks are acquaintance rapes; women's fear of the stranger in the street is to that extent misplaced. The real threat is from someone they know. This in part reflects a collapse in sexual etiquette; many traditions now abandoned as sexually repressive often also served to protect women. Along with liberation has come exploitation as women (and sometimes men) find themselves under strong social pressure to have sex.

Secondly, we are all influenced by a pervasive sexualised culture in which women's bodies are objectified and used to sell everything from bath-cleaners to cars; the messages of male potency, sexual aggression glamourised as passion, and female submission can be subtle but powerful. The pursuit of sexual pleasure is often elevated over considerations of respect and responsibility towards another person. The expectations put on schools to counter such influences is often unrealistic. One cause for hope here is the developing sense that such sexual isation is no longer as commercially valuable as it was.

Though the figures look horrifying, one can also argue that they represent a heartening shift in female perception. Throughout history, women have been the victims of sexual violence; jus primae noctis, whereby the lord helped himself to the bride on the night of the wedding was only the most outrageous. Much of it, women have had to suffer in silence, powerless to protect themselves; it was only in 1991 that a woman was finally able to accuse her husband of rape. In these statistics, we hear for the first time women naming their experience. Two hopeful changes could follow from that. Their growing confidence could fuel the assertiveness they need to protect themselves and seek redress from the law. Secondly, men shamed by women's new willingness to describe what has been forced on them could become more self-aware; such notions as passivity representing consent may die away along with other 19th-century male illusions about female sexuality.

Such developments have to be underpinned by a framework of law enforcement sympathetic to women. The police have learned a lot about that, but clearly there is still a long way to go. Plus, in this highly emotive territory where the issue of consent in acquaintance rape is often murky and sometimes not susceptible to legal scrutiny, there is room for some recourse other than the ordeal of the courts. Universities have set up counselling services which help and support a woman dealing with a deeply disturbing experience, and these need to be available more widely through GPs. But readiness to tell the truth as it is experienced is a big advance in itself, and possibly the beginning of an unprecedented historical revolution.

fields.headline: The bosses blundered
fields.standfirst: So far subordinates are paying the price
fields.trailText: Laurence Williams, the chief inspector of nuclear installations, is absolutely right in his devastating report on safety failures at the Sellafield processing plant: management at every level must bear responsibility. The directors cannot duck their share of it simply by sacking five production workers. It would be inexcusable if the dreadful chronicle of systematic management failure - including the falsification of quality assurance records for reprocessed plutonium bound for Japan - did not lead to heads rolling right up to the top.
fields.body:
Laurence Williams, the chief inspector of nuclear installations, is absolutely right in his devastating report on safety failures at the Sellafield processing plant: management at every level must bear responsibility. The directors cannot duck their share of it simply by sacking five production workers. It would be inexcusable if the dreadful chronicle of systematic management failure - including the falsification of quality assurance records for reprocessed plutonium bound for Japan - did not lead to heads rolling right up to the top.

Two things are particularly worrying. First, the report covers a period when BNFL knew there were increasing worries in the country at large about the safety of nuclear power. Yet this did not appear to have seeped into their consciousness at all. Indeed, the report suggests that the directors were distancing themselves from responsibility for safety. Second, it also covers the period when the company (which made pre-tax profits of £228m last year on sales of £1.5bn), was being made more "efficient" in the run-up to its proposed 49% privatisation. As a result, thousands of jobs had been cut to make BNFL more attractive to investors. webTitle: Kosovo is out of bounds, Nato warns Belgrade

fields.headline: Kosovo is out of bounds, Nato warns Belgrade
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The Nato secretary-general, Lord Robertson, yesterday warned the Serbian government to stay out of Kosovo, saying that Nato would remain in the province for as long as was necessary.
fields.body:
The Nato secretary-general, Lord Robertson, yesterday warned the Serbian government to stay out of Kosovo, saying that Nato would remain in the province for as long as was necessary.

"No hot air from Belgrade is going to push Nato out of Kosovo," Lord Robertson said, following criticism of Nato by the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, at this week's congress of his Socialist party of Serbia. "There may be quite a lot of stupid people in Belgrade but I don't think that there are people stupid enough to think that they can come back into Kosovo again," Lord Robertson said.

The former British defence secretary was in Tirana to meet with the Albanian prime minister, Ilir Meta, who told him that Albania would support a "democratic and multi-ethnic Kosovo".

"I am delighted that prime minister Meta is telling this region and the world that Albania is committed to a multi-ethnic Kosovo, where all the different groups of people have the right to live in peace and safety," Lord Robertson said after the meeting.

Mr Meta said he had assured Lord Robertson that "there is in Albania no wish to promote the idea of Greater Albania or any such concept".

Lord Robertson said K-For peacekeeping troops would be reinforced in the northern Kosovo town of Mitrovice due to ethnic violence. He said peacekeepers would not tolerate violence from either side.

In Washington, the supreme commander of Nato in Europe, General Wesley Clark, said he expected peacekeeping troops to stay in Bosnia and Kosovo for as long as President Milosevic remained in power.

Gen Clark told the US congress that Mr Milosevic must be tried on war crimes charges and Yugoslavia must become democratic before the Balkans conflicts are resolved.

webTitle: How the sellers sink the market

fields.headline: How the sellers sink the market
fields.standfirst: If you go down to the woods today, you'd better go in disguise, writes Tony Levene. Because the bears are having their secret picnic and the value of your shares is going to be eaten away.
fields.trailText: With the Footsie - the FTSE 100 index - dipping below the psychologically important 6,000 point level for a brief time earlier this week, most investors will need no reminding that shares are on the slide. Although prices have since recovered a little, they are still a long way short of the pre-millennium euphoria which sent the Footsie to 6,930 on the last trading day of last year
fields.body:
With the Footsie - the FTSE 100 index - dipping below the psychologically important 6,000 point level for a brief time earlier this week, most investors will need no reminding that shares are on the slide. Although prices have since recovered a little, they are still a long way short of the pre-millennium euphoria which sent the Footsie to 6,930 on the last trading day of last year

But the near 10% Footsie fall this year is not the whole story. Most stocks are in a secret bear market with many top name companies falling as fast and sometimes more furiously than in living memory's past two big dips in share prices - 1987 and 1974.

For outside new economy go-go stocks in "TMT" - market jargon for the technology, media, and telephones sectors - shares have been on a slippery slope ever since internet mania started last autumn. As our chart shows, the gap between the main share market and the new FTSE techMARK index is gaping.

In the secret bear market, popular shares such as Abbey National, Alliance & Leicester and Railtrack have all lost some 40% of their value over the past quarter. And Halifax has only been saved from this ignominy by annoucing its esure e-finance tie-up with Direct Line motor insurance founder Peter Wood, sending the hitherto out of fashion stock shooting up 20%.

Many others have fallen in bear market style since their 1999 highspots: Powergen is down by some 55% while Glaxo Wellcome has lost 30%.

The UK stock market was the worst performer of any major economy during January, according to strategy expert Simon Rubinsohn at stockbrokers Capel Cure Sharp.

He says that only eight sectors gained in January including electronic and electrical equipment (+20%) media/ photography (+34%), with software and computer systems the star performer with a +53% gain.

Telecoms did less well with a 17% gain - similar to the advance in information technology and hardware. Mr Rubinsohn says: "These are the new economy sectors and they are in fashion. Most of the eight are in technology or anything even feebly related with technology. And the buying interest is there even though most of the eight sectors have experienced recent earnings downgrades."

But strip out the few winning sectors and the rest of the market has suffered a bloodbath. On the slide are previous high flyers such as banking and mining, oil and gas (despite fast firming crude oil prices) and pharmaceuticals.

What appears to be happening is that institutional fund managers are ditching anything that smacks of old economy to chase shares in companies with an e-tag. This has been reinforced by index trackers rushing to increase stakes in Vodafone AirTouch following the Mannesmann deal, reducing the weighting of other shares in the index.

The gap between dot.com and old economy company is clear. Lastminute. com had sales of £2.6m and earned £190,000 for its owners in the year to September 1999. It is valued at £400m. Thompson Travel Group is worth £740m - nearly twice as much - but on sales more than 500 times higher.

All this leaves companies in the secret bear market looking very cheap. The gap between the valuations given to "growth" stocks and to those which had become mature remained more or less constant for most of the nineties. Analysts measure this by dividing share prices by after tax earnings. During this period growth stocks sold on around 27 times earnings while the others traded on 12 times.

But over the past months the growth stock ratio has nearly doubled while the rest of the market has sunk back. Rubinsohn says: "The old economy or value end of the equity market looks historically attractive. And some companies in building and retailing are seeing profits forecasts upgraded."

And he warns that "the higher the fashionable stocks go, the greater the risk that a setback will occur".

Fund managers are starting to take notice of the value argument. Geoff Miller at Exeter Asset Management believes it is time "to change investment strategy from growth into more value orientated situations."

He likes companies such as British Land, whose share price stands at a 40% discount to the underlying value of the properties in its portfolio, housebuilders where Barratt has seen a shares collapse despite record sales; train operator FirstGroup whose share price has halved over the past year despite good cash flows and even British Telecom, caught betwen technology and utility status.

Others whose valuations have slid include (with recent and 12 month high prices) are: Imperial Tobacco (430p-789p); Debenhams (151p-502p); British Energy (250p-680p); bus group Arriva (140p-440p) and sugar group Tate & Lyle (216p- 500p).

fields.headline: Rescuing the wrecks
fields.standfirst:
Why are empty homes allowed to rot when there is a national housing shortage? Elizabeth Langton looks at the problem and some of the solutions

www.emptyhomes.com
www.landreg.gov.uk
fields.trailText: The government is facing a national housing shortage and widespread homelessness, yet the number of homes standing empty has shot up, official figures revealed this week. More than 750,000 properties were left empty in England last year - a rise of 11,500 on the previous year and the first since 1993.
fields.body:
The government is facing a national housing shortage and widespread homelessness, yet the number of homes standing empty has shot up, official figures revealed this week. More than 750,000 properties were left empty in England last year - a rise of 11,500 on the previous year and the first since 1993.

The news comes as ministers are urging planners and housebuilders to put every inch of land in urban areas to good use before building on greenfield sites. Abandoned properties are a magnet for petty crime, vandalism and drug dealing and with their steel or boarded up doors and windows make for depressing eyesores. Living next door to an empty home can also knock 10% off the value of your own property, say experts.

The Empty Homes Agency, a charity campaigning to bring empty properties back into use, says the sharpest rise in abandoned properties was in the private sector where more than a third had been empty for a year or more.

But, says Ashley Horsey, the charity's chief executive, there are almost as many reasons behind the abandonment as there are properties. "Maybe it belongs to grandad who's moved into hospital or long-term care. The family might not live in the area or have forgotten about it.

"Many people are scared of becoming landlords. Too often people have said to us they would rather keep the property vacant than risk having a bad tenant." Owners might not have the money for extensive repairs or be unaware of grants. And with prices shooting through the roof in some parts of the country, owners are biding their time before they sell.

Although 53% of empty homes are in the north and midlands, the rest are in south, east and west of the country. "There are 112,000 empty homes in London alone," says Mr Horsey, "And there is no shortage of people who want to live in the capital."

Councils can take action against owners whose buildings become dangerous structures or an environmental health hazard because of fly-tipping. The ultimate sanction is a compulsory purchase order but, says Mr Horsey: "An empty property strategy should be as much about encouraging the owners of empty properties to do something with them as it is about sanctions."

The Empty Homes Agency says major changes are needed to bring large swathes of housing stock back into service. About 150 councils have yet to introduce an empty property strategy; Mr Horsey says this should be a statutory duty.

In Slough, the council, Ealing Family Housing Association and a regeneration agency pooled resources to breathe new life into empty properties. The housing association bought and refurbished 45 properties in the town centre which were then let to people on the council's housing list. A derelict space around a Blockbuster Video in the high street was turned into eight flats. In Warwick, the district council appointed an empty property officer to set about "knocking heads together and push private sector landlords to bring empty homes back into use", says spokesman Derek Dyas. But he became a victim of his own success: as the number of empty properties dwindled there wasn't enough of a problem to justify a dedicated officer.

Where empty properties do pop up, the council is taking an innovative approach. Some owners want to bring empty properties back into use but can't afford the repairs. In its current state the property may not be worth enough to secure a loan. The Nationwide building society has agreed to lend money for repairs if the local authority underwrites the loan.

"The building society lends on how much it would be worth when all repairs are done. For example, a home worth £50,000 derelict may be worth £100,000 when repaired. The building society would lend on £100,000. We have an approved list of contractors so it is a relatively safe bet for the council," says Mr Dyas. Soon, a large, double-fronted regency building in Leamington Spa will be brought back to life thanks to the scheme.

The Empty Homes Agency says the government must end perverse incentives to keep homes empty by letting local authorities charge full council tax on properties that owners are making no effort to bring back into use: at present empty homes are charged half the normal rate.

Mr Horsey wants to end the discrepancy where VAT is zero rated on new homes but charged at 17.5% for refurbishing existing homes and to harmonise the rate at 5% for both.

The agency is calling upon the public to report abandoned properties to the local authority. London residents can call the Empty Homes Hotline 0870-901-6303 where staff can ensure that councils are aware of the property and its state.

Those interested in rescuing an old wreck can trace its owner for just £4 via the Land Registry which holds details of who owns property in England and Wales.

The government must act now to reverse the rise in empty properties, says Mr Horsey. With seven empty properties for every homeless person in England alone, there's no excuse to let what could be good homes rot.

fields.headline: Cleaning up the small print
fields.standfirst: The Court of Appeal has now barred banks from using unfair terms.
fields.trailText: Earlier this month the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) secured a victory in the Court Of Appeal on a difficult and important point under the Unfair Terms in Contract Regulations that will significantly help people who get into difficulties repaying loans.
fields.body:
Earlier this month the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) secured a victory in the Court Of Appeal on a difficult and important point under the Unfair Terms in Contract Regulations that will significantly help people who get into difficulties repaying loans.

The Regulations, introduced in 1995 and amended last year, make unfair "small print" invalid. This can be relied on by consumers when they have a dispute with a business. The OFT also has powers to insist on a business not using an unfair term in its standard conditions at all. Last year the Consumers' Association, trading standards officers and regulatory bodies such as Ofwat were granted similar powers.

The OFT asked the First National Bank, an Abbey National subsidiary, to stop using terms that meant it could carry on charging interest on debts even after getting a court judgment. Normally once judgment is given in Consumer Credit Act claims, interest stops being chargeable. In purely economic terms there is little logic to this. However, the thinking behind the law was that there is no point in adding to the financial difficulties of people already in debt. Effectively, the Abbey was using a term which few borrowers would appreciate the significance of to put itself in a better position than Parliament had intended it to be.

At first, the judge accepted the bank's argument that borrowers would not expect to be any better off as a result of a judgment being obtained against them. After all, before judgment there was no disputing the bank's entitlement to interest. Therefore they would hardly complain that it was unfair. That, the Court of Appeal decided, was not really the point. The regulations require businesses to act "in good faith". This meant the bank had to consider consumers' interests as well as its own in devising the terms. The bank had used its strong bargaining position to brush aside protection to which consumers are entitled.

It will still, theoretically, be possible for the bank to ask the court to order interest after judgment, but this will no longer happen automatically. In cases where borrowers genuinely cannot pay, few judges are likely to agree to add to their woes by making such an order. The judgment is good news for anyone who has been required to pay interest added after a county court judgment. They can now contact the lender and ask for a rebate. Any such payments made in the past six years should be returnable.

An anomaly became apparent during the case. As well as First National, it emerged that 32 other lenders use similar terms. The OFT had not received complaints about any of these. Until it receives complaints it cannot require businesses to stop using an unfair term.

The Consumers' Association is investigating mortgage lenders' terms and would welcome examples of any term, including ones relating to post-judgment interest, so they can take action. Alternatively, the OFT can make any lender abide by the Abbey National decision.

Richard Colbey is a barrister

fields.headline: Great loo-roll rip-off
fields.standfirst:
We pay more for our groceries than the French, Germans and Americans, says Patrick Sherwen

A full copy of the price comparison report can be found on the DTI website: at www.dti.gov.uk/CACP/cp/ipr
fields.trailText: Unless you start every day with a bowl of cornflakes, always change into a long-sleeved shirt for work and frequently enjoy chocolate chip cookies with your morning cup of tea, you are almost certainly spending more on your weekly shop than do your American, French and German counterparts.
fields.body:
Unless you start every day with a bowl of cornflakes, always change into a long-sleeved shirt for work and frequently enjoy chocolate chip cookies with your morning cup of tea, you are almost certainly spending more on your weekly shop than do your American, French and German counterparts.

This was one of the findings of the Department of Trade & Industry's (DTI) report published this week comparing prices in the UK with those in France, Germany and the US. The survey took in 56 everyday items and tried to make like-for-like price comparisons across the four countries.

Of the 56 items which were surveyed, those that cost UK consumers more money outnumbered those that did not eight to three - the three being those mentioned above. The DTI's basket of over-priced goods contained: a Sega Dreamcast games console, the top 10 CDs, a two-litre bottle of Coca Cola; some tinned dog food, a can of lager, a bottle of shampoo, ground coffee and a four-roll pack of lavatory paper. Of these the biggest rip-off, appropriately enough, was the lavatory paper. For every sheet we use in the UK the French can afford to use another one and a quarter for exactly the same cost.

The next worst culprit was the shampoo, which is 93% more expensive in the UK than in the US. The prices of the other 45 items surveyed were not found to be significantly different.

Stephen Byers, secretary of state for trade and industry, says he is pleased with the exercise and is considering whether it should be repeated annually to continually monitor trouble spots. In the case of a competition problem the OFT would refer the case to the Competition Commission which would conduct a thorough investigation and make recommendations for change, as it is with pricing practices in the motoring industry and competition between supermarkets.

webTitle: What it is to be  that well-heeled

fields.headline: What it is to be  that well-heeled
fields.trailText: After accountants Arthur Andersen announced that its employees no longer have to dress formally for work, those forsaking the suit and brogues for chinos and loafers would do well though to take note of legendary couturier Sir Hardy Amies, when he said: "It is totally impossible to be well dressed in cheap shoes." For him the only shoes worth wearing were bespoke hand-stitched ones.
fields.body:
After accountants Arthur Andersen announced that its employees no longer have to dress formally for work, those forsaking the suit and brogues for chinos and loafers would do well though to take note of legendary couturier Sir Hardy Amies, when he said: "It is totally impossible to be well dressed in cheap shoes." For him the only shoes worth wearing were bespoke hand-stitched ones.

Although traditional bespoke leather shoes cost an average £1,000 a pair, for the well-heeled nothing less will do. While a niche market, there are still a handful of shops in London and a few across the country tailoring leather to the idiosyncrasies of the foot. Customers are either those for whom money is no object, those with a medical problem or else someone looking something out of the ordinary.

James Taylor & Son, situated near London's Baker Street, has been in the traditional shoe making business since 1857. Sales manager David Worrell, explains: "There is very little we can't do. Everything from classical shoes, copying old favourites, copying from shoes seen in magazines to building shoes for people with a particular disability."

The shoes are made in the same way that they have been for centuries. After the customer has discussed style and type of leather required, measurements of both feet are taken. A wooden replica of the foot, known as a last, is then carved and from this patterns of the shoe are cut from leather. The whole thing is hand stitched and, once constructed, the shoe stays on the last for about a week. This process including two or three interim fittings takes about three months.

For this labour intensive dedicated service, a basic shoe at James Taylor costs £995 + VAT while a full brogue is £1,235, although the prices do include a shoe tree. To copy the customer's own style costs an extra £50. These are the prices for the first pair of shoes. Subsequent ones cost £200 less as the last has already been made. The lasts are kept for at least 10 years, which may seem long but remember the idea is that these are shoes that are meant to last almost a lifetime, designed to keep on being repaired. If a pair of shoes has to be ordered on medical grounds and a medical certificate is produced, the VAT doesn't have to be paid.

The most prestigious bespoke name in the land is the bootmaker John Lobb, which has been dressing the feet of the Royal family since the 1860s. The shop currently holds three Royal warrants. Prices for a traditional brogue start at £1,570 + VAT and take six months to make, while for someone perhaps wishing to celebrate a big City bonus, a shoe made from crocodile skin costs £4,305. The St James's premises should not be confused with the John Lobb high street shoe retailers in which the Lobb family has only a small stake and is run by Hermes.

Not all bespoke shoe makers are restricted to the West end of London. Philip Taylor, or The Cordwainer, while based in the north-west of England, travels all over the country measuring up feet and fitting shoes. With lower overheads he charges between £400-£500 for men's shoes and slightly less for women's. A large proportion of his customers are those with foot problems. The British Footwear Association produces a book offering a wide range of special needs shoe makers.

While there is a small but steady market in traditional bespoke shoes, there are those who want something with more of a contemporary design. The shoemaker Tim Little fills the gap between traditional/formal and high fashion producing everything from the classic black Oxford to lime green loafers. He is famous for his blues obsession and many of the shoes come with blues influenced names such as Little Red Rooster and complete with a blue sole. Basic costs are £850 and take around six weeks to make. An innovation is the semi-bespoke service where a shoe is selected from the normal range and then an existing last is modified to cope with unusually shaped feet. An off-the-peg shoe costing £190, for example, would then sell for £380.

Strict vegetarians wanting a well-crafted shoe need not despair. While traditional shoemakers may blanch at the very thought of not using leather, there are a few businesses offering animal-friendly footwear. These are semi-bespoke with a breathable polyurethane material replacing the leather. Green Shoes, based in Totnes in Devon, offers a basic made-to-measure shoe for £73, while a stylish Chelsea boot costs £95. At Made to Last, in Leeds, the average price for a shoe is £79.

The whole point of leather shoes, though, is that they can be polished and polished. Sir Hardy Amies said that even new shoes should look as if they have been polished for 20 years. If someone is prepared to pay hundreds of pounds for a pair, they will want to look after them.

The Traditional Victorian Shoeshine Company, which has stands at places such as Burlington Arcade, charges £2.50 a shine or £5 for a military shine. The company will even clean customers' shoes in their own homes, as it did with the Duchess of York, who was reported to have paid £250 to have her collection cleaned.

fields.headline: Bright horizons for capital adventurers
fields.standfirst: Venture trusts, which invest in developing industries worldwide, look to be set for a new stage of growth, says Robin Stoddart
fields.trailText: It looks set to be a bright year for venture capital. That is just as well since, unless newer firms grow fast enough to replace the former giants that are rapidly being dismembered or sold off, the outlook for the economy would be dim. Cutbacks and repayments, not expansion, are the goals of much of British industry, banking and commerce.
fields.body:
It looks set to be a bright year for venture capital. That is just as well since, unless newer firms grow fast enough to replace the former giants that are rapidly being dismembered or sold off, the outlook for the economy would be dim. Cutbacks and repayments, not expansion, are the goals of much of British industry, banking and commerce.

Some of the venture capital trusts (VCTs) set up with appealing tax incentives are approaching the end of the five-year period for which investors are locked in before the reliefs qualify with the Inland Revenue. A good performance will make it easier for the managing groups to raise funds on a larger scale as they launch additional trusts. Among investment trusts the £10bn venture and development capital sector has been the top performer over the years.

Larger private investment funds appear to be reaping large returns, but they are usually more involved in buyouts than start-up ventures. UK pension funds are dragging their feet and missing out on the opportunities being seized by private equity funds.

More encouragingly, 3i, Europe's largest development investment trust, looks to be finding many more winners after a rather uncertain start. There was some delay before it wholeheartedly moved into advanced technology last year. Some good profits are being taken in this area, including a recent software sale to Hays, the transport and business services group. The shares now stand at a big premium on the conservative directors' valuation of the unquoted portfolio and at four times the flotation price in 1994.

Some VCTs have also reached a big premium on the valuations of their holdings, though it has only appeared in recent weeks in a thin market. Until this year low valuations led managers to institute buy-backs of their shares in some cases - hardly the object of the exercise in promoting and developing young companies capitalised at no more than £15m.

Over the years there has been no shortage of applicants for business capital, but they have constantly complained that banks were unsympathetic, while the backers declared that high prices were being asked for minority stakes in companies whose management lacked reliability and depth. Successes in internet development and telecommunications advances have to end such doubts.

Sharp gains have been scored by a handful of VCT shares in recent weeks after excellent progress by companies in which they had invested at an early stage of development. Pride of place goes to Quester, the independent manager of more than 10% of the £700m raised by VCTs since their introduction in 1995. Two directors spent several years with 3i. In launching their latest fund, Quester VCT 3, the board were able to show outstanding progress by investments in their two earlier funds, including multiple appreciation in software firms XKO, Sopheon and JSB. These now have market listings which brought in a big following as the technology boom developed.

Previously a 240% profit in C-Dilla, where £500,000 was invested in 1996, was distributed tax-free to shareholders. Such capital distributions have been rare, though Pennine, one of the VCTs investing primarily in London's Alternative Investment Market (Aim) distributed part of the profit it made on Cirqual, the light engineer.

The performance of VCT's mainly investing in Aim shares has often been sluggish, though BWD Aim VCT and Aim DistributionVCT have shown an outstanding market performance. The sudden leap in Quester shares owes a lot to expectations for unquoted companies like Orchestream, a softwear product that gives priority to specified internet data and Sibelius Software in the computer music score field.

After soaring to a big premium on asset valuations, Quester 1 & 2 shares settled back with gains of half on full-issue cost before the 20% saved on income tax. Quester 3 should achieve a high subscription both sides of the impending tax year end.

Baronsmead, run by Friends Ivory & Sime of Edinburgh, has had one of the most chequered careers. The first VCT experienced a fair number of failures, as in a smaller way did Quester.

Retailers like Revelation, Whittard and Dawn' til Dusk have been poor investments. But the biggest disaster in the whole VCT sector was the full £1m-plus loss sustained in a few months on the Douglas Llambias financial executive employment consultancy business, which collapsed in the face of poor financial and business controls.

But hard on the heels of this setback the flotation of SDL, which has just an nounced software contracts with a leisure travel firm and betmaker.com along with Microsoft in a pilot scheme, brought a multi-million upward valuation. Baronsmead retains nearly 10% of SDL.

The next largest holding IRS has also done well and the appreciation of holdings such as Aortech, the heart valve developer, and Landround, the promotions company now in receipt of bid approaches, easily offset the £1.8m written off the £20m-plus fund. Baronsmead is raising funds in a third VCT issue and more such offers are likely soon.

webTitle: It pays to plan for rainy days

fields.headline: It pays to plan for rainy days
fields.standfirst: If something bad happens to you, your dependants will need shelter, says Jill Papworth
fields.trailText: The most important investments you may ever make are in products designed to protect your family financially should you be unable to support them for reasons beyond your control.
fields.body:
The most important investments you may ever make are in products designed to protect your family financially should you be unable to support them for reasons beyond your control.

Reductions in welfare benefits mean you cannot rely on the state to provide adequately for your family. So, before considering stocks, shares and savings, it's vital to invest in a safety net for your family.

Both men and women should ask themselves the following questions to identify gaps in their protection net: How would the family income drop if I could no longer work? How much, if any, cover do I get from my employer or company pension scheme?

Full-time mothers might ponder the findings of Legal & General's latest "Value of a Mum" survey, which shows that paying someone to run the house and care for children would cost an average of £313 a week.

Ideally, ask an independent financial adviser to recommend the best solutions. For details, ring the IFA promotion hotline on 0117-971 1177 or visit the website at www.unbiased.co.uk.

The key products to consider are life insurance, critical illness cover, and replacement income cover or permanent health insurance (PHI). Term insurance is the simplest and cheapest form of life cover, especially suitable for families on tight budgets. It is designed to provide cover for a specific period, say during the term of a mortgage or until children are grown up. If you survive it pays nothing.

You can choose a term policy that pays out a one-off, tax-free lump sum on death or a family income benefit policy, which pays a monthly, tax-free income after death for the remaining term of the plan. The latter is useful for dependants who need a regular income without the hassle of investing a lump sum.

Term insurance does not cost as much as one might expect, but premiums vary dramatically for the same cover so it is worth shopping around.

Critical illness cover, which pays out a tax-free lump sum if you are diagnosed as suffering from one of a pre-defined list of serious conditions such as a heart attack, kidney failure or cancer, is expensive compared with term insurance but arguably as important.

A healthy man or woman stands a one-in-5 chance of suffering a critical illness before reaching the age of 65. And, of the one in eight healthy women who will contract cancer before they are 65, 70% will survive for more than a year after diagnosis and 50% for more than five years. The payout from a critical illness policy can be used to replace the patient's income and to cover costs such as nursing care.

It is easier to compare critical illness premiums, since the introduction of a set of standard terms and conditions to which most insurers adhere.

Barry Davys of Davys Direct says clients tend to choose critical illness cover over permanent health insurance. "Most people prefer the lump sum paid out by critical illness policies to the regular income from PHI," he says. "PHI policies also won't necessarily pay out if you become ill or disabled but are still able to work and policies usually have a 'deferred period' so you have to be off work for a month, three months or even a year before you can start claiming. Critical illness policies have the advantage of paying out on diagnosis."

Cost comparisons are available from Davys Direct on 08457 660 559 or at www.davysdirect.co.uk.
