webTitle: Help to build a better world for your child

fields.headline: Help to build a better world for your child
fields.trailText: The basic question everyone should ask before entrusting their savings to a third party is: "What can you do for me?"
fields.body:
The basic question everyone should ask before entrusting their savings to a third party is: "What can you do for me?"

But if you're setting up investment plans for your children, the question has a more poignant significance.

Are investment managers going to use your children's nest egg for projects that will create a healthier, fairer world? Or are those carefully collected coppers going to fund companies that damage the environment?

Lee Coates, director of independent financial adviser the Ethical Investors Group, is surprisingly relaxed about the whole issue. "My attitude is that if people are happy investing in companies which kill or pollute, they should be allowed to - that's democracy," he says.

Rather more sombrely, he points out a dilemma facing parents of would-be investors. "If you're saving on behalf of a child, you need to consider questions such as are they themselves likely to want children? They would be devastated if 20 years down the line they find they can't have them, because they've got asthma from pollution caused by the very companies they've invested in."

There is now a growing acceptance of ethical savings products in the financial marketplace. But these do not tell the whole story.

Insurance companies such as Friends Provident, Clerical Medical and Legal & General all run ethical or environmental funds. But the lion's share of their business is not invested in ethically screened stocks. And, according to the recent Capital Punishment report from Friends of the Earth, all three have mainstream products invested in the likes of oil giant Exxon and mining group Rio Tinto.

Ethical funds are still dwarfed by mainstream funds mainly because of the perception that they do not perform as well. "People invest to get the best possible returns they can," agrees Steve Abbott, marketing director at Legal & General, whose ethical trust, launched last July, runs on a filtered tracker system; the fund mimics the FTSE 350 less those stocks that fail the ethical screening process.

"But in fact backtesting of our fund shows that over the last five years, it would have outperformed the FTSE 350 index," says Abbott. "However, that's pot luck - if you screen out certain stocks on non-financial criteria, they are just as likely to outperform as underperform."

Having said that, there is an argument that companies that keep their noses clean, environmentally speaking, or that are engaged in activities which benefit the environment, will, over time, achieve a better bottom line than companies fined for pollution or unable to capitalise on the trend towards a cleaner, healthier society.

webTitle: Sending in the troops to fight a price war

fields.headline: Sending in the troops to fight a price war
fields.standfirst: Playdough
fields.trailText: Toy soldiers are a little like Dinkies. You think they are collected by children, but if you go along to an auction for toy cars you will see grown men, (it is mostly men) bidding for these items. They are often garage owners, car dealers or racing enthusiasts. Similarly with toy soldiers: they may be considered a children's hobby, but bidders at auction are often military enthusiasts or former soldiers.
fields.body:
Toy soldiers are a little like Dinkies. You think they are collected by children, but if you go along to an auction for toy cars you will see grown men, (it is mostly men) bidding for these items. They are often garage owners, car dealers or racing enthusiasts. Similarly with toy soldiers: they may be considered a children's hobby, but bidders at auction are often military enthusiasts or former soldiers.

Auction houses have regular sales of toy soldiers. They are among the oldest collected toys, almost as old as the real thing. Little soldiers were entombed with Egyptian Pharaohs to protect them in the afterlife.

Commercially produced toy soldiers first appeared in the 18th century. These were flat, tin figures made in Germany, so-called because of their two-dimensional nature. Less than 1mm thick, they looked like small cut-outs.

Solids, or solid toy soldiers, are full models cast in metal. The French were pioneers of this sort of soldier. Manufacture started around the time of the French revolution and it was then that the scale of 54mm, which has proved standard, became popular.

Flats and solids made of plastic and aluminium as well as tin are collected but far and away the most popular are the lead alloy soldiers made by the British firm Britains. These are distinct from model soldiers that are sculpted and made from a variety of materials.

These hollow-cast soldiers were invented by the Britain family and first went into production in 1893. The point about collecting soldiers is that you can play with them, use them for planning military campaigns, repair them and repaint them. It is a very different collecting area to stamps or paintings, where you simply admire them.But, as with stamps, there are collecting clubs, magazines and catalogues. Toy soldiers, like coins and certain areas of glassware, for some reason underwent a roller-coaster ride in the 80s and early 90s. Prices were high in the roaring 80s and then crashed in the recession of the early 90s.

They are now recovering. This is due, according to Daniel Agnew, specialist at Christies's South Kensington, to the strength of collecting generally in the late 90s. It is also because in the 60s the British government banned the use of lead in toy soldier manufacture because it was deemed dangerous for children. So the lead solders made up until the 50s became classics and now have a rarity value.

Prices for Britains can range from a few pounds to hundreds of pounds for an individual piece or thousands for a set. Guardsmen and household cavalry were made in abundance and are cheap - anything from £3 to £30. Rare sets fetch more.

A forthcoming auction at Christie's, South Kensington, mainly of Britains, gives some idea of prices. It includes the Widmer family collection of toy soldiers. Widmer, an American colonel, started his collection in 1925 when he was 10. It includes a first world war 50-piece tank display set, made by the German manufacturer Heyde and estimated to fetch £1,000 to £1,500.

A rare Britains set made for CFE, an early 20th century toy wholesaler in London, includes two wagons with teams and mounted drivers, officers and 10 escorts. This 1907 army supply column with its original box has an estimate of £2,500 to £3,000.

Representing the civilian range is a 4cm high pair of Britains Lambeth Walk dancers, produced in 1939 at the time of the hit musical Me and My Girl, which are estimated at £200 to £300.

All this suggests that the going rate for a Britains toy soldier that's part of a set is around £100 to £150, more or less what it was in the 80s, and the sum of the whole, a set does not appear to be greater than the individual parts. But there are exceptions. At another sale, one of the earliest Britains figures - a Barbary Coast Corsair complete with dagger and pistol - sold for £400.

But whatever the rarity, it is essential that the items are in mint condition and in their original boxes. Boxes, as with Dinky toys and dust wrappers on books, greatly enhance their value. Without the boxes the value can halve. This is ironic, really, since it means that the soldiers were probably never used for their original purpose - as toys.

For further information telephone Christie's South Kensington, 020-7581-7611, or www.christies.com

fields.headline: A principled approach
fields.trailText: Cara and Bill Adair  hope to turn the dream of a good life into reality when they leave Sheffield to live in a converted barn in Wales. But unlike most other homebuyers, their environmental principles extend to their finances, since part of the purchase price will come from their savings account with Triodos Bank.
fields.body:
Cara and Bill Adair hope to turn the dream of a good life into reality when they leave Sheffield to live in a converted barn in Wales. But unlike most other homebuyers, their environmental principles extend to their finances, since part of the purchase price will come from their savings account with Triodos Bank.

The bank runs a range of accounts by which deposits can support specific projects, such as organic farming and research into sustainable energy technology. "We saw an ad for the bank in the Guardian, and we started the account because we know what they were spending their money on," says Ms Adair, 30,a teacher originally from Connecticut. "A lot of ethical funds don't invest in companies that behave badly, but they still invest in companies that do nothing for the environment.

"Triodos takes a more active approach. Even if we could get a higher interest rate elsewhere, we've opted for less money, but hopefully we're doing something better."

The Adairs have also started a Triodos young saver account for their daughter Matilda, who was born in November. They put in £100 and will add to it with birthday presents and other gifts, so that when she is older, she can use it for higher education or to go travelling.

"I can't claim to be active in terms of environmental issues," says Ms Adair. "It's a bit lazy on our part, but we know the bank is doing something worthwhile with our money."

webTitle: How to cut short your home loan - and save thousands

fields.headline: How to cut short your home loan - and save thousands
fields.standfirst: Flexible mortgages used to be the preserve of the wealthy. Not any longer, reports Tracey Boles
fields.trailText: Using a lump sum to pay off all or some of your mortgage can save you and your family thousands of pounds and cut short the length of your mortgage term by months or even years.
fields.body:
Using a lump sum to pay off all or some of your mortgage can save you and your family thousands of pounds and cut short the length of your mortgage term by months or even years.

And the best mortgage with which to make such payments is the increasingly popular flexible variety.

Truly flexible mortgages should allow over and under payments, let you borrow back on payments already made, and offer payment holidays. They should also calculate interest daily.

The Malhi family from Slough intend to save themselves more than £80,000 and pay off their loan nearly six years early by making substantial overpayments in a few years' time. When housewife Indy, 29, goes back to work as a marketing assistant, they will use £1,000 of her salary to make a lump sum payment each month. The Malhis - Indy, husband Kam and children Ryan, nearly three, and Gavina, one - took out a 25-year base-rate tracker mortgage for £95,000 with Alliance and Leicester last October. They repay £558 a month.

"When the children are older I will go back to work and we will put nearly all of my salary into the mortgage," Ms Malhi says. "We aim to spend the savings on a better quality of life for us and the kids. We will put the money into the children's education and have things like holidays which are a luxury at the moment."

Flexible mortgages used to be the preserve of the wealthy; the payoff for flexibility was above average interest rates.

But big lenders NatWest and Abbey National have just rushed out affordable products to join those on offer from the likes of the Woolwich and First Active Financial. The Abbey National deal offers a 1.1% discount for six months, taking the interest rate down to 5.65%. After that the rate is guaranteed to be no more than 1% above the base rate.

Flexible mortgages are the best vehicles for making the most of lump sum payments because timing is crucial. Many mortgage lenders only credit payments to accounts once a year, so if you pay in several thousand to your mortgage in February it may not impact on the outstanding debt until the next January. Flexible mortgages offer a way round this problem because most calculate interest daily. There are no penalties and often no limits attached to making overpayments.

Siobhan Hotten of independent financial adviser John Charcol says: "They are a useful tool for reducing debt. Companies are competing on features and there is something for everyone in flexible mortgages."

But some are more flexible than others. Check exactly how often over and under payments are allowed, and whether a minimum payment is required. The Bank of Scotland personal choice mortgage requires a minimum overpayment of £500. And the Woolwich open plan mortgage charges interest monthly rather than daily.

Another type of flexible mortgage is a current account loan, which is a financial package complete with current account features. Virgin One and First Active Financial offer them.

With this type of loan you can use your salary to help reduce the amount of interest you pay over the life of the loan. Since interest is calculated daily, there is an immediate benefit from the reduction in your mortgage balance when your wages are paid in. And that is without any extra payments.

Take a woman with a 25-year mortgage who earns £20,000 a year. If she put down a 20% deposit and borrowed £70,000, she would pay 7.05% interest. The effect of her salary temporarily reducing her mortgage balance each month would save £4,715 in interest and clear the loan nine months early. Less dramatic than the Malhi example, but no overpayments have been made.

Interest is effectively being earned at the mortgage rate. Put another way, you are investing your money in a supersafe, high-interest rate environment. Paying off a mortgage early can be a better way of using extra cash than leaving it in low-return instant access accounts.

A basic-rate taxpayer would need a savings account paying over 10% to find as good a home for spare cash as paying off the mortgage - higher-rate taxpayers would need nearly 13% - rates that simply do not exist.

But Ms Hotten cautions that current account mortgages complete with ATM cards and drawdown facilities are only for the financially disciplined, not for those who ever have an overdraft as interest will mount up against them.

fields.headline: Keep heirlooms in the family
fields.standfirst: Planning can prevent inheritance tax from eating into your legacy, writes Liz Loxton
fields.trailText: People whose wealthy parents have failed to find a tax-efficient way of organising their affairs before death have a pretty high incentive to go hunting for high-value heirlooms. Inheritance tax for estates worth more than £231,000 on death is levied at a steep 40%. Works of art can be used to settle or defer the tax bill indefinitely.
fields.body:
People whose wealthy parents have failed to find a tax-efficient way of organising their affairs before death have a pretty high incentive to go hunting for high-value heirlooms. Inheritance tax for estates worth more than £231,000 on death is levied at a steep 40%. Works of art can be used to settle or defer the tax bill indefinitely.

In practice, inheritance tax (or IHT) is a thorny issue for the less well-off, too. One problem is that assets, particularly family homes and shareholdings, are increasing steeply in value while chancellors generally stick to raising the exempt band for IHT in line with inflation. Last April Gordon Brown increased the nil-rate band from £223,000 to £231,000.

The chancellor is rumoured to be in favour of beefing up the IHT regime. Last year he closed the loophole that enabled taxpayers to give a home to a trust and then lease it back.

Planning for an IHT liability is a difficult balancing act. The rules allow taxpayers to make gifts - potentially exempt transfers - during their lifetimes. Providing they survive the gift by seven years, it will not attract IHT. But donors needs to work out how much of their estates they can afford to give away and how much they will need to live comfortably.

A common response is to take out a life insurance policy to fund the liability. There are joint last survivor policies available that pay out on the second person's death. Providing the policy has been written into a trust, the policy proceeds will be outside the estate and the benefits on death will not attract IHT. Clerical Medical, Scottish Provident, Scottish Amicable and Standard Life all have joint last survivor policies.

The problem with insurance policies is that you have to pay for them. Many people resent the idea of forking out premiums to fund a future tax liability. One option is to make use of whole of life insurance schemes that include an investment bond. The bond provides an income of which 5% can be withdrawn tax-free.

"The advantage of this kind of approach is that it helps individuals balance the cost of premiums against their income needs," says Anne Gregory-Jones, a tax accountant at HLB Kidsons.

Investment bonds are more attractive than trusts because their capital growth is liable to less tax - 20% to 23% as opposed to the 34% attracted by trusts. Insurance plans don't get caught up in the probate process, so funds are available soon after death, and life premiums have come down in price over the past 10 years.

Because our life expectancy is now so much greater, however, the value of our assets and therefore our IHT liability does not stay static. Investment advisers and independent financial advisers therefore look for ways to freeze tax liability by placing assets outside the estate.

Philip Rose, managing director of IFA Wentworth Rose, says a useful way of achieving this is through a loan. By setting up a trust with yourself as the main trustee and your heirs as the beneficiaries, you can then make a loan - interest-free and repayable on demand - into the trust.

This means that any growth on the capital remains outside your estate for IHT purposes. Prudential Insurance, Clerical Medical and Legal & General all set up loan trust plans.

The chancellor is unlikely to reduce the 100% relief on business property. Tax consultant Simon McKie points out that this is good news for anyone with shares listed on AIM, as they qualify for business property relief.

Singer & Friedlander manages an AIM fund, and although the risk-averse may not be keen on this market, it could prove a useful home for at least part of even the most cautious investor's portfolio.

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: Standard interview question: "Why do you want this job?"
fields.body:
Standard interview question: "Why do you want this job?"

Standard response: "I am excited by the challenge it offers/ the increase in responsibility/the chance to work with a successful organisation." Give the truthful answer - because you would do anything to get away from your present boss - and you would see the rejection letter in the interviewer's eyes. Explain your subsequent resignation to HR and it is more likely to focus on lack of career prospects and your new employer's reward package than your relationship with your boss.

There is a conspiracy of silence about the fact that just as applicants are often seduced into organisations they often leave because working there proves a different reality. It's not that people can't work with difficult or demanding bosses. It's that working for a boss who doesn't care about staff as individuals is demotivating.

Being valued means being given a clearly defined set of expectations which match talents and abilities, so there is the chance to do a good job. It means getting positive feedback when the work is good and constructive feedback when it falls below expectations. It doesn't mean, as one multi-national company did, introducing a official caring policy, where bosses were expected to give each staff member a birthday card. The result: embarrassed managers wandering from the isolation cell of their office asking sotto voce for the identity of the person whose name was on the card.

If valuing simply contributed to an office feelgood factor, it could be discounted as nice to have once goals had been delivered. However, in a study by Gallup, A Hard Look at Soft Numbers, which involved 200,000 employees, teams who rated their manager highly on the valuing indicators were consistently more productive and profitable, had higher retention and customer satisfaction ratings.

webTitle: Strategies to avoid the student debt trap

fields.headline: Strategies to avoid the student debt trap
fields.standfirst: Start saving now to give your children a hassle-free education
fields.trailText: The death by a thousand cuts of state-subsidised higher education is now complete with the introduction of tuition fees. This follows the end of maintenance grants.
fields.body:
The death by a thousand cuts of state-subsidised higher education is now complete with the introduction of tuition fees. This follows the end of maintenance grants.

The National Union of Students estimates that people studying outside London will need to find £5,881 a year to fund their education. By 2010 they could be looking at a bill of up to £30,000 for three years in higher education.

One solution is for parents to impoverish themselves. The universities and the government are keen to point out that only a third of students in England and Wales will pay the full whack, a third will pay no tuition fees and the rest will face a means-tested contribution.

Or you could try moving. Scotland is ditching tuition fees for its own and European Union students but not for those with English, Welsh or Northern Irish addresses. The Scottish Endowment Access Fund to will also help poorer students from next year, giving them £2,000 a year if their annual family income is less than £10,000.

But none of this is likely to save most young people from graduating with five-figure debts and loans to repay when they start earning just £10,000 a year.

Last month the government announced an extra £64m to assist poorer students in England and Wales. This will provide heavily means-tested access funds and hardship loans - and these will be available only after the full student loan has been taken up.

The alternative to all this is for parents to save up while their offspring are still at school. For many, that will be an extra burden on top of the home loan, pensions, and other demands on the family purse. It's no surprise then that paying for higher education is the next big finance issue and institutions are gearing up for expansion into this area.

One of the first financial institutions to offer a special product is a friendly society, Tunbridge Wells Equitable, which last summer launched a university bond offering investment opportunities for parents of children aged eight or under. This takes advantage of the £25 a month tax-free savings entitlement of a child and gives with-profits endowments timed to mature at the beginning of each year of higher education.

For those whose children are older, a way of finding funds may be for both parents to work or to remortgage the family home.

Scottish Widows Bank has introduced an Education Fund Mortgage with a flexible borrowing approach and the capacity to overpay the mortgage in advance.

You can remortgage your home and buy a property for the student's use. Your remortgage costs can be offset against rental from other students for tax purposes.

Mark Ireland, an independent financial adviser from Winchgate Insurance in Bristol, says raising money on the parental home has the advantage of reasonable home loan rates.

Students themselves can get a mortgage with a parent acting as guarantor. Nationwide and Cheltenham & Gloucester offer these.

Lenders who offer buy-to-let schemes are on the increase - but be warned, not all of them want student tenants. Halifax Mortgage Services is an exception. You will need a 20% to 25% deposit. Interest rates will be higher than normal and the loan amount will be limited so that the rent is at least 130% of the interest.

Buying a student home is a good capital investment, says Liz Atkinson of Property Concept in Clifton Village, Bristol. She advises buyers to look outside the less popular areas because prices are rocketing in traditional student zones while rents remain static. Ultimately, the easiest way to hold down student debt is to stay at home and take the bus to your local campus.

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: Jeremy Newton Chief executive of the National Endowment for Science, Technology and the Arts
fields.trailText: When did you first become a manager?
fields.body:
When did you first become a manager?

In 1980, as deputy director of the Regional Arts Association for the East of England.

What has been your best moment in management?

It was reading the CVs of the first wave of nominees for Nesta Fellowships and realising the effect we could have on the worlds of science and the arts by enabling these individuals to fulfil their potential.

What was your greatest mistake?

Not sticking to my guns when I was setting up the Arts Council's Lottery Fund and my original proposal to cap awards at £20m was opposed.

Which deal would you most like to have done?

To have financed the making of the film The Full Monty.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

Disloyalty (rare, but deeply upsetting when it does happen).

Does your organisation have a glass ceiling?

No.

What management wisdom is most over-rated?

"The best is the enemy of the good."

What one lesson you have learned would you would pass on to young managers?

Take more risks and don't take yourself too seriously.

Which management guru do you believe in?

William Shakespeare.

Who is your management hero?

Sir Peter Hall. He ran the RSC and the National Theatre brilliantly and would have run the Royal Opera House even more brilliantly if he hadn't been stopped before he got started.

Who is your favorite politician?

Harriet Harman, the member of parliament for Peckham.

What phrase or saying do you most over-use?

Brilliant!

Apart from your family, what else makes you happy?

Listening to the songs of Pete Atkin and Clive James

And what annoys you most?

Wasted potential, wasted opportunities and wasted time.

How do you relax?

Going to the cinema or theatre.

What was your last cultural experience?

Seeing Ted Hughes's play The Iron Man.

What is your favourite city?

Venice.

What is your greatest regret?

That my father died long before I was sensible enough to seek his advice.

What is your greatest fear?

Serious illness.

What will be the big business issue of the next decade?

How to harness the creativity and imagination of individuals and teams.

What would you really like to have been?

A stand-up comedian.

fields.headline: A lucky, lucky throw
fields.standfirst: My big break
fields.trailText: Ask any style conscious woman what fashion accessory she would select to top with a stunning evening dress or snuggle over a winter coat and chances are it'll be a pashmina.
fields.body:
Ask any style conscious woman what fashion accessory she would select to top with a stunning evening dress or snuggle over a winter coat and chances are it'll be a pashmina.

The much-sought-after silk and cashmere woven shawls from Nepal regularly accompany top celebs like Sharon Stone and Jerry Hall to lavish parties and premieres; even the Queen is rumoured to have one.

For 400 years the pashmina has been a must-have luxury item for India's elite. It began making waves in the west, after high-flyer Sophia Swire decided to swap her substantial salary as a City stockbroker for an infinitely more humble existence as an aid worker in Pakistan.

"When I first saw the shawl at a charity event in 1989, I thought wow, I've got to have one for myself and my friends," recalls Sophia.

Her unexpected chance to turn her passion for pashminas into profit came after a call from Vogue fashion director Lucinda Chambers in 1993. Lucinda saw one of Sophia's friends sporting the luxury shawl and was intrigued. The two met up in London and Sophia agreed to allow supermodels Kate Moss and Christy Turlington to show off the shawls for a fashion shoot.

Lucinda suggested that Sophia sell pashminas to upmarket clothing retailer Browns, based in London's South Molton Street. "I thought Browns was way out of my league and went in there trembling. But the fashion buyer went mad for my shawls and ordered some immediately.

"It was then I realised that I had a business opportunity and a product that was a joy to work with because everybody wanted a Sophia Swire pashmina."

As the business began to grow she also set up a UK registered education charity to benefit illiterate children in rural Pakistan. "I used to spend 70% of my life with the charity," recalls Sophia. But it became apparent that if she focused more on Sophia Swire pashminas she would make a better financial contribution to the charity.

"It's only in the past 18 months that I have devoted myself wholeheartedly to the business and seen it grow by 600%" reveals Sophia, who donates a healthy percentage of her business profits to the charity.

Competition from rivals muscling in on the pashmina phenomenon was also instrumental in her determination to devote more time to the business. "I've had to sharpen up to stay ahead of my imitators," she says candidly.

"Sophia Swire pashminas have always been known as the best. But I'm not complacent. I'm working on stunning hand-knit cashmere coats and cashmere sweaters, as well as a whole new range of embroidered pashmina shawls."

Sophia is fired up that her decision to abandon a lucrative City career has made a difference to children in Pakistan and transformed her own life. While working in the City it became apparent that she wanted to do more than negotiate multi-million pound deals. The turning point came on Black Monday when friends returned from lunch to find their desks cleared and surviving colleagues resorted to backstabbing to save their jobs.

"Colleagues who were supposed to be senior to me were busy trying to take over some of my top clients to consolidate their own position. There came a point during a stand up argument with my boss that I thought: 'This is ridiculous. I would rather fight for something I believe in' ."

She decided to become an aid worker and went on a three-week holiday to Pakistan and returned to the country three months later to become an aid worker.

"My family thought I was mad. But I followed my path which meant that for a number of years it was extremely rocky financially," says Sophia.

If Sophia had stayed in the City she would be earning a six-figure sum. Today, she's got a better deal, as the proprietor of a multi-million pound brand. "I could have wimped out and considered a job in the City as my big break, but I didn't. I followed my heart and gut instincts and got an even bigger break."

webTitle: Black hole in the MBA curriculum

fields.headline: Black hole in the MBA curriculum
fields.standfirst: Managers of the future will have to be aware of the issue of environmental protection. But there is scant education in this field, says Roger Cowe
fields.trailText: Business schools continue to churn out thousands of MBAs from whom tomorrow's corporate leaders are supposed to emerge, and provide re-education for hordes of executives currently on the verge of leadership.
fields.body:
Business schools continue to churn out thousands of MBAs from whom tomorrow's corporate leaders are supposed to emerge, and provide re-education for hordes of executives currently on the verge of leadership.

There is an unquestioned acceptance that the challenges facing business are greater than ever and changing faster than ever, necessitating this huge investment. Yet there appears to be an enormous hole in the management training provided by the business schools - the issue of sustainability, or environmental protection and social equity.

Tomorrow's business leaders are getting virtually no exposure to this issue, which is likely to be one of the most complex and significant challenges they will face.

The experience of Monsanto over genetically modified foods, Shell's 90s battles in the North Sea and Nigeria, and Microsoft's difficulties with the US authorities, should be enough to convince any management educator that these issues matter. But no matter how tough the going is now, it will get tougher.

Governments are still struggling with global issues such as climate change and waste. In 10 or 20 years' time, however, when today's students take the helms of their companies, they will have to operate with much stricter controls over energy and resource use. They will have to grapple with the challenge of growing their businesses while shrinking the impact their operations have on the environment. And they will almost certainly face much closer scrutiny of the way they operate in local and global communities. So why is the rising generation of executives not being immersed in these issues?

That question was the focus of a recent gathering of international business educators and environmentalists under the auspices of the Environment Foundation in the precincts of Windsor Castle. The leading sustainable business academic, professor Stuart Hart from the university of North Carolina, laid the blame squarely at the door of the educators. "Companies are way ahead of the business schools," he said. "Over the next decade coverage of sustainability will increasingly be demanded. There is a growing number of companies looking for assistance."

He believes that academic structures have prevented most business school staff from understanding, let alone teaching, this potential transformation. Professor Hart is out to change that. He has set up a Sustainable Enterprise Initiative at North Carolina's Kenan-Flagler business school, where he is professor of strategic management. The aim is to teach the three dimensions of sustainability - economic, environment and equity.

The North Carolina development stands out not only for its pervasiveness but also because it is so rare. A detailed analysis of US management education by the World Resources Institute found that a fifth of all MBA programmes in the US have some coverage of social or environmental issues. But most of that was accounted for by superficial consideration of business ethics.

There was virtually no teaching in core courses and barely any research. The WRI noted, in its report Beyond Grey Pinstripes that: "As long as environmental and social issues do not permeate the core curriculum they will not strongly influence future managers."

The European picture is no different from that over the Atlantic, despite greater government and EU enthusiasm for sustainable development, and a more positive attitude by European companies.

Only a smattering of courses from Europe's leading business schools make any acknowledgement of the sustainability challenge. There are some signs of progress, though nothing as comprehensive as Professor Hart's Sustainable Enterprise Initiative. For example, Warwick Business School has significantly expanded its Corporate Citizenship Unit, the London Business School is currently running an optional course on sustainability and the London School of Economics this month launched a brief series of evening seminars exploring "the corporate role in society". The most exciting developments come from outside the institutions, however.

The World Business Council for Sustainable Development - a multinational club which encourages business action - is currently testing a virtual sustainability course.

The material has been developed with a consortium of 10 companies, including General Motors, Deloitte and Touche and Sony. It combines information and material for role-playing by sustainability project teams. The intention is that this site will become a focal point for sustainability, attracting material from many sources.

Separately, the European Business Network for Social Cohesion - a kind of pan-European Business in the Community - is building course concepts and materials for use in management education.

The trouble is that, as everyone at Windsor agreed, there is a good old-fashioned economic problem at the root of the limited supply. Despite these initiatives, there is still virtually no demand for such courses from companies or business students.

fields.headline: This is my England
fields.standfirst: Andrea Levy is English born and bred. Sure, she has Jamaican parents, but so what? That hardly justifies why many of her compatriots make her feel a stranger in her own land. After all, if she was white and foreign, would anyone bat an eyelid?
fields.trailText: Andrea Levy is English born and bred. Sure, she has Jamaican parents, but so what? That hardly justifies why many of her compatriots make her feel a stranger in her own land. After all, if she was white and foreign, would anyone bat an eyelid?
fields.body:
I was recently in New Zealand on a literary visit sponsored by the British Council. At a book reading, a young white man asked me, "Where are you from?" England, I replied. "You don't look English," he said. "Well, this is what English looks like sometimes," I answered. He laughed in an unconvinced sort of way. So I asked him, "What do you think an English person should look like?" He pointed to another white person - a woman with fair hair, then to himself. Both of them were born and bred New Zealanders, but somehow they were more English than me.

This was in a country where, later, while speaking to a Maori man in 70s, I was told that anyone with even the smallest fingerful of Maori blood is a Maori. No matter how tenuous the connection, no matter what country they live in, if they have Maori blood, then they are considered to be part of that culture.

Identity! Sometimes it makes my head hurt - sometimes my heart. So what am I? Where do I fit into Britain, 2000 and beyond?

One of the 492 people who looked around the old British Empire colony of Jamaica, saw that there were no jobs, no prospects, and decided to chance his arm in the Mother Country. His identical twin brother had been in the RAF, stationed in England, during the war, and was returning to do a further round of service. My dad accompanied him, leaving behind in Jamaica his new bride, my mum, who waited impatiently for the call to join him.

But I do know that, when he boarded the ship, he knew himself to be a British citizen. He travelled on a British passport. Britain was the country that all Jamaican children learned about at school. They believed Britain was a green and pleasant land - if not the centre of the world, then certainly the centre of a great and important Empire that spanned the globe, linking all sorts of countries into a family of nations. Jamaica, he thought, was just Britain in the sun.

But it was too late; he already loved England by then. On the passenger list, the twin brothers are put down as having different ages, which might have been a clue. My dad wanted to be his own man, and England was the place to do it.

(I've switched from saying Britain to saying England. Britain is the state. You're only British when you're outside the islands. When, for example, I'm in Europe or America, I'm British. It makes me feel somehow bigger. But as soon as I set my feet down on the land of Britain, I know I'm either in England, Scotland, Wales or Ireland - separate countries without any doubt.)

My mum joined my dad in his one room in west London six months after the Windrush had docked. But they soon found that they were foreigners in England, and this shocked them. The things they thought of as quintessentially English - manners, politeness, rounded vowels from well-spoken people - were not in evidence. She had one advantage: she spoke English. And one disadvantage: she was black (or coloured, as we were termed then).

We were good citizens of this country (although the police did their best to thwart my brother in this). Never in trouble. Always polite. Never diddled the electricity meter. We lived in a council flat in Highbury, north London, next to the Arsenal football ground. In the world outside our flat, I was a north London girl. I went to the local school. Spoke like a cockney. Offered to mind people's parked cars on match days. Played rounders, skipping and two balls. I liked Mojos and gobstoppers; could blow a great bubblegum bubble. On TV I watched Coronation Street, Emergency Ward Ten, Dr Who. Cathy Come Home made me fear homelessness. The Sound Of Music made me long to be Julie Andrews. (I even convinced myself I looked like her - but no one else could see it.)

At school, they taught me to read, write and do arithmetic (well, with the last one, heaven knows they tried). I studied Shakespeare and the Metaphysical poets. I learned to play the piano, and could sing and accom pany myself to Greensleeves. I learned history - focusing on Gladstone and Disraeli - where at one time I truly did know all about the repeal of the Corn Laws and free trade. (None of this was unusual to my parents: it was what they had learned in their schools in Jamaica.)

I was educated to be English. Alongside me - learning, watching, eating and playing - were white children. But those white children would never have to grow up to question whether they were English or not.

But if I answered "Jamaica", lips would curl or tongues would tut. They didn't want to know about the sun, the sugar cane, the rum punch. They didn't want to try our rice and peas. I remember a white American girl coming to school. You'd have thought that Doris Day herself was now a pupil. Everyone wanted to be her friend. To see her toys, to hear her parents' wonderful accent, to try their food with an "Ooohh isn't it lovely". America was a great place to come from.

Everything from Jamaica was odd to me. We got a parcel sent every Christmas. (Were we the only family who received parcels from Jamaica and not the other way around?) A gooey Christmas cake from someone called "my mother's mother". A bowtie for my brother and hand-stitched dresses for us girls. But we kids preferred English Christmas cake with white icing that cracked your teeth. Woolly jumpers would have been better, we said. And my brother sulked that the bowtie was guaranteed to get him teased beyond endurance.

We had a tin of sweetcorn in the cupboard that had come from a Jamaican parcel. I remember my mum opening it and us kids running around excited. Not because we were keen to try it, but because it was so weird. I tasted a niblet and spat it out, saying it was disgusting. (This was the early 60s - bear with me - salad was exotic.) My dad liked a thing called guava and got all sentimental when he thought of it. I didn't know what it was. But I did know the lyrics of a song that went something like, "Rub it on my belly like guava jelly", and got very embarrassed when he mentioned it again. And both my parents danced about like lunatics when Miss Jamaica won Miss World.

I wanted just to fit in and be part of everything that was around me, and these strange parents were holding me back.

Then I grew up.

More black people emigrated to England from the 50s onwards - from the Caribbean, from Africa. People came from India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Uganda. People from across the old Empire coming home to the Mother Country. After all, didn't she owe us? Along with this immigration - this safety in numbers - came a new interest for me in the country my parents had left. I was gaining a fledgling sense of pride in having a Jamaican heritage. Tentative at first - Bob Marley records, saying the word '"feisty", practising sucking my teeth in front of the bathroom mirror. Until it grew into a need to visit Jamaica.

My mum had recently been back after 40 years away. She came home telling me what a bloody awful place it had become. Hot, violent, poor. It was not the place she remembered. She still had family there, but most had now emigrated to America or Canada. My dad didn't want to go back, even to visit. He preferred his memories and told me wistfully that he had no one there now - no family, no friends. He had made his home England. He didn't want to miss the football. And without much problem he could now get his beloved guavas here.

Jamaica is an island where - apart from the aboriginal population, the Arawak - people were brought as slaves or indentured labourers. The white people there owned plantations and their workers. Some worked as overseers, the famously cruel bakra. Jamaica was a place of hard labour. The Jamaica I found was a brochure-beautiful island. A place where the colonists had left but, as we used to say in north London, "they'd taken their ball home with them". Taken the wealth, leaving an economy struggling with debt and trying to diversify so as to compete in a global market.

However, the jewel in this island for me was my family. In Kingston, they welcomed me like a prodigal daughter. They told me that I looked like a Jamaican, even when I embarrassed them with my English ways - my liking for sitting in the sun, my insistence on making tea in a teapot and shivering in my woolly jumper, complaining about the "Christmas breeze". When I left, I wanted to know more about the people who formed me.

It is hard for anyone to research their genealogy, but it is even harder (though not impossible) for someone with my background. Most of the records are incomplete or unavailable at best; destroyed or non-existent at worst. I discovered it would take a great deal of time, patience and expensive travelling for me to put together my definitive family tree. So I did the next best thing. I talked to my mum.

It was simple. I asked her to tell me everything she knew about everyone she could remember. My mum claims that when I was little I wasn't interested in her family background. I claim that I asked her all the time, but that she wouldn't tell me. I got the impression that she had come to this country to gain a future, not to dwell on a past. Whatever the truth of it, at some point, thankfully, we merged. I was interested and she was willing to tell.

I learned about her grandfather - my great-grandfather - among many others. A man from Scotland who had flame-red hair. A fisherman who could turn his hand to anything and who liked to wash his money every Sunday. What was he doing so far from home in Jamaica? Where was his family? My mum didn't know - she only knew of him. I had to look in the Scottish history books to find that, like a reverse image of my dad's story, many men left the hardships of the Highland life to chance their arm in the Caribbean. This Scottish great-grandfather of mine left behind him the flaming hair, which my brother inherited and which got him teased beyond endurance.

My father's father fought in the first world war with the British West Indies Regiment. He was born Jewish. His family had been in Jamaica for generations, but probably originated from North Africa. My grandfather had "married out", to a woman of Indian/ African/Spanish descent, and had taken the Christian faith while fighting in the war. His Jewish family disowned him and all his issue.

And, further back, my "mother's, mother's, mother's, mother" was born a slave. She had children by her white English master, who probably had several other children by his slave women and by his white English wife. I don't know what happened to him, but maybe some of his other descendants are reading this now.

The stories that I learned from my mum I pieced together into what I call a fictional family tree for my novel Fruit Of The Lemon. I tried to place those stories in context - where they belong - at the heart of a history that Jamaica and Britain share. There is a tendency to believe that the recent immigration into this country, started by my intrepid dad and others, was where our relationship began. But nothing could be further from the truth. There was an excellent programme on Channel 4 recently about Britain's slave trade , which showed the extent to which many of England's aristocratic families gained their wealth through slavery. Cities such as Bristol and Liverpool were built with the money from the slave trade. What the programme also showed was that not only do black people have ancestors who are white, but also some ordinary British white people are connected by family ties to the black people of the Caribbean or to the estimated 20,000 black people who settled in Britain as a result of the trade. The history of Britain is inextricably linked with that trade, and therefore with somewhere like Jamaica. Indeed, without the trade in slaves Jamaica as we know it would not exist.

When you look at family trees - anybody's family tree, people's individual histories, not the winner-takes-all history of nations - the question of identity becomes very complicated. It would be nice and simple if we were all pure. If we all came from where our parents, grandparents and beyond came from. If we all just took on our forefathers' culture. Wouldn't it be nice if we could say that all Africans are black and all English are white? Wouldn't it be simple if, when some racist (as many have done in my time) shouts at me to go back to where I came from, that I got an image of Jamaica in my head instead of thinking that I must go back to minding cars outside the Arsenal? It would make for easy argument - it would help the bigots' cause. We would all fit into our separate boxes, and in times of change, such as those that we are now living through, we could retreat into them and lick our wounds. But it is not like that. Any history book will show that England has never been an exclusive club, but rather a hybrid nation. The effects of the British Empire were personal as well as political. And as the sun has finally set on the Empire, we are now having to face up to all of these realities.

Empire is over and, as Britain is being devolved down into its component parts, there is a loss of identity that has settled upon England. Darcus Howe, in his recent Channel 4 programme, White Tribe, went on a journey to find English culture, which so many believe resides only in the white population. Many blamed the multi-cultural nature of England for the country's plight. But this sense of loss was always going to happen - losing something as powerful as an empire will always hurt. It was going to happen even if my dad had not set sail on the Windrush; it was going to happen even if Idi Amin had not expelled the Asian population from Uganda. But perhaps the vitality of multi-culturalism is now the catalyst that is speeding up a necessary period of soul-searching.

I am English. Born and bred, as the saying goes. (As far as I can remember, it is born and bred and not born-and-bred-with-a-very-long-line-of-white-ancestors-directly-descended-from-Anglo-Saxons.) England is the only society I truly know and sometimes understand. I don't look as the English did in the England of the 30s or before, but being English is my birthright. England is my home. An eccentric place where sometimes I love being English.

When I hear that the surge of energy needed after a good television programme is because everyone is getting up to make a cup of tea, it makes me smile. I, too, was there with my teapot after the last episode of Only Fools And Horses. I love that our national dish has become curry. And the view from London's Waterloo Bridge just takes my breath away. I hate being English when I hear what happened to Stephen Lawrence. When every day seems like a battle against racism, and hatred, and the quiet, polite hostility that holds many black and Asian people back from fulfiling their potential. I want to belong to anywhere but this place where I am made to feel like an outsider - not welcome, definitely not welcome at all.

Saying that I'm English doesn't mean I want to be assimilated; to take on the majority white culture to the exclusion of all other. (I cannot live without rice and peas. I now dance like a lunatic when Jamaica wins anything. And I will always make a noise when moved by emotion.) I will not take up a flag and wave it to intimidate. And being English will not stop me from fighting to live in a country free from racism and social divisiveness.

There are many white people here who are appalled that someone like me could be English. And there are many black people with similar backgrounds to mine who do not wish to be called English. But national identity is not a personal issue. It is political. It cannot be decided at the whim of the individual. Englishness must never be allowed to attach itself to ethnicity. The majority of English people are white, but some are not. If we say otherwise, it is in tacit agreement with the idea of racial purity, and we all know where that dangerous myth can lead. Let England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland be nations that are plural and inclusive.

Last year, I was in Scotland reading at the Edinburgh Festival. I was telling the audience about my great-grandfather with the flame-red hair. After the reading, a Scottish woman came up to me, held my arm and whispered, "You know, I could just tell you were Scottish."

There are many white people here who are appalled that someone like me could be English. And there are many black people with similar backgrounds to mine who do not wish to be called English. But national identity is not a personal issue. It is political. It cannot be decided at the whim of the individual. Englishness must never be allowed to attach itself to ethnicity. The majority of English people are white, but some are not. If we say otherwise, it is in tacit agreement with the idea of racial purity, and we all know where that dangerous myth can lead. Let England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland be nations that are plural and inclusive. Last year, I was in Scotland reading at the Edinburgh Festival. I was telling the audience about my great-grandfather with the flame-red hair. After the reading, a Scottish woman came up to me, held my arm and whispered, "You know, I could just tell you were Scottish."  Andrea Levy's latest novel, Fruit Of The Lemon, is published this month in paperback by Review, priced £6.99. fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Where good wine costs less?
fields.body:
I have, over the past 11 years, watched with detached bemusement as Sainsbury's has gradually let Tesco steal its thunder, its customers and its reputation as the place where 'good food costs less'. But is JS now biting back? Is the company's new slogan to be 'where good wine costs less'? On the basis of the four bottles below, all on special offer until the February 26, this is no idle speculation.

Sainsbury's non-vintage Mendoza Country Red (15 points, out of 20, reduced to £2.79), from Argentina, is stickily rich yet accomplished; it's a terrific candidate for a takeaway Indian or a restaurant of this culinary persuasion that permits customers to bring their own bottles. On a more prosaic level, it is a consummate bangers-and-mash wine. Not so Mendoza Country White (14.5 points, also £2.79), which is happier paired with salads, pastas, risotti. It is rich, balanced, clean and not remotely OTT. Merlot delle Venezie Connubio 1998 (16 points, down to £3.49) is darkly blackcurranty, with nary a whiff of leather (merlot's trademark), and has an abundance of dry tannins. It's a wonderful glug for serious quaffers and bargain-minded trencherwomen.

Sainsbury's Bordeaux Blanc, a non-vintage wine, rating 14.5 points and costing a risible £2.79, is utterly simple, but charmingly uncomplicated and gracious. Gently fruity and freshly finished, it will not disgrace a dish such as roasted cod with a herb crust of minced pistachio nuts and pomegranate seeds, which is the sort of dish that I knock up standing on my head, because I always spill half the ingredients on the kitchen floor.

Over at CWS superstores, meanwhile, there is the magnificently authoritative Leasingham Cabernet Sauvignon/Malbec 1996 (16.5 points, £8.99), from Australia. My tasting notes, I see, contain the extravagance that the 'partnership of the wood, fruit and tannins is a sensual ménage à trois of guile and gutsiness'. Certain wines, I'm afraid, bring out the pretentious prat in all of us. Two further worthy reds at the Co-Op are Pomorie Country Cabernet Merlot 1998 (15.5 points, £2.99), from Bulgaria, and Chteau Pierrousselle 1998 (15 points, £4.79), from France. The Bulgar is a simple masterpiece of deft gluggablility, with the tannins to grip food and palate. The French is a perfectly respectable claret with a hint of new world non-moodiness and harmony.

At Majestic, there is Primitivo del Salento Sigillo Primo 1998 (16 points, £4.99): big, rich, rousing, soft, cockle-warming (yet young and fresh), this is a cheeky red of entertaining and immediate drinkability. Majestic's Viña El Salado Extremadura 1998 (15 points, £4.49), from Spain, is not so immediate, for it takes some seconds for the fruit to enrich the throat, but the wait is worthwhile. As it is with compatriot, Ochoa Tempranillo Garnacha Navarra 1998 (15 points, £4.99), though here the hint of roasted nuts on the finish completes a fruity medley of mature richness and texture.

At Waitrose, there is Domaine Boyar Merlot/Gamza 1998 (15.5 points, £2.99), which offers superb class for the money. Waitrose also has a ripe bargain in Domaine de Rose Syrah/Merlot Vin du Pays d'Oc 1998 (16 points, £3.29). This is full of hints of the Midi sun, herbs and landscape - a colourful, rich yet far from rustic wine. Also at Waitrose - or, rather, at 30 Inner Cellar stores of this civilised retailer (01344 424680 for details) - there is Wirra Wirra Vineyards Church Block Cabernet Shiraz Merlot 1997 (16.5 points, £9.49), from Australia. It is a wonderful blend of striking richness and very stylish tannins: aromatic, all-action and endearing (but not unreasonably pricey, considering the pleasure it provides). Oddbins might have the odd bottle knocking about, too.

Last, at Booths, there is Domaine du Trillol Corbières 1996 (15.5 points, £4.25), which has a soft, delicately chewy edge of tobacco and some very accomplished fruit that finishes with style. It has wit, Mr Engel, wit - this Huddersfield reader has written to enquire what this characteristic implies when found in a wine, and asks if it means that the bottle will leap out of the aisle and tell a joke? The answer is: not quite. Jokes are rarely witty. Wit is dry, unexpectedly delicious and brings a smile to the mind as well as the belly. Just like this wine, sir.

fields.headline: Eating out
fields.standfirst: One's 10 years old, the other 10 months: Matthew Fort on the restaurant age gap
fields.trailText: One's 10 years old, the other 10 months: Matthew Fort on the restaurant age gap
fields.body:
This a tale of two restaurants. One has been with us in its present form for 10 years; the other for 10 months, more or less. One is its chef/patron's one pride and joy, the other part of a mini-chain. One is the idiosyncratic product of its owner's own rather idiosyncratic character. The other is sharply focused, sharply designed and sharply modish in the menu department. One is the Quality Chop House, a short shift from the Guardian's front door. The other is Parade, a slightly longer shift from my front door, in Ealing.

I have written about the Quality Chop House before, and extolled the virtues of its proprietor, quondam Frenchman, habitué of the Groucho Club and short-order chef supreme, Charles Fontaine. To call him a short-order chef may seem to do him less than justice. Nothing could be further from my intention. It's just that the food on the menu seems plain: salmon fishcakes with sorrel sauce, liver and bacon, corned beef hash with fried egg, steak and chips, artichoke vinaigrette, potted shrimps. But this plainness becomes beauty when done with attention to each detail and brought to a state of consistent brilliance by much practice. These are, in short, the definitive examples of these dishes, and so are as satisfying as any you can eat anywhere. Basse cuisine becomes haute cuisine when pursued with such skill and vigilance.

The salmon fishcake is a case in point. It comes on its own, a majestic tower of fishcake rising like a piscine Old Man of Hoy out of a sea of light, creamy sauce, whose emollient smoothness is flecked with little strips of lemony sorrel. The cake itself is a wonderful, harmonious balance of fish, potato and breadcrumbs, the whole miraculously light, with the subtle flavour of salmon permeating the mass. There is no need for teeth to eat such a fishcake. Just crush each forkful against the roof off your mouth with your tongue, thereby releasing the flavours, and then savour them and swallow slowly.

Just as the menu has not changed much over the decade (although there are the odd nods in the direction of contemporary menu obsessions, such as the warm tuna salad, Ceasar salad, asparagus with pecorino, and roast sea bream with lemon and tomato), neither has the place. It is still the most uncomfortable restaurant in London - and, quite possibly, in Britain - but then it was that before Charles took it over. The backs to the bench seats are made from old doors and are set at an angle to encourage a rigid, straight-backed posture, rather than easeful slouching, and the tables are set just below a comfortable eating height, unless you happen to be significantly challenged in the height department. But Charles's genius was not to change it, bar chucking a pot of white paint at the walls, cleaning the place up a bit and, in time, adding on a second room next door. It remained quite identifiably the same place that it always had been: "progressive working-class caterer", as the legend etched into the shop-front window has it. The working classes may have changed a bit (but not that much: the bottles of Heinz tomato ketchup, HP sauce and Colman's mustard still sit on little ledges just above head height at each table) and the former clientele would wince at the prices (you should be prepared for around the £20-£25 a head mark), but the ethos of the place has not. It is still pretty bloody-minded and has the purity of obduracy about it. It is what it is.

Parade could scarcely be further removed from this. It is brought to us by the team that made Sonny's in Barnes and Sonny's in Nottingham classics of the family-friendly, wallet-warming neighbourhood restaurant genre. It has clean, spare lines, with a hint Scandinavian sensibility - a kind of cross between John Pawson and Alvar Aalto. The walls are hung with pictures of a dazzling cheerfulness. It is a model of the carefully considered, well-thought-through, tasteful modern-eating experience. It is comfortable and well-run. And the menu is a model of modern eating - tuna tataki; crab cannelloni; warm salad of duck, Jerusalem artichokes, poached egg and balsamic vinegar; cep and field mushroom risotto cakes, mozzarella and rocket; roast cod; braised lamb shank; potatoes mashed, crushed or galetted; caperberries and lentils and onion marmalade and pinenuts.

I have eaten in Parade twice recently, and both times you could not help but admire the intelligence of it. There were a couple of dishes that erred on the side of good manners when it came to flavours - when you serve butter with skate, for example, it must be black, not simply melted, and the capers must be plentiful to cut the rich-ness of the dish; and Old Fogarty complained that he expected a lot more oomph from a braised lamb shank than his actually delivered. Having said that, a ham hock, leek and parsley terrine with piccalilli was as sweet, chunky and hunky as the most devoted lover of chunky, hunky terrines could wish for; a sauté of lamb neck and tongues with celeriac purée was perfectly calculated to keep the winter chill at bay; and, at another lunch, my elder brother gave a highly complimentary running commentary of a mountainous dish of sea bream with bouillabaisse sauce, noodles, courgette and squid, and he is no fool in gastronomic matters.

The wine list is put together with care and good sense, and without the taint of financial greed that characterises too many London restaurants these days. In fact, with first courses priced at £5.50, all main courses at £12 and puddings at £5, Parade sets its stall out with clarity and purpose. The two bills I paid there were £64.80 and £70.80 apiece, including wines, coffees and waters.

The critical acclaim with which it has been greeted is unanimous, and I can't dissent from it. But, if I am honest, my heart belongs to the Quality Chop House. I can admire Parade. I can see that what it does, it does very well. But I cannot love it. It is a pasteurised cheese to The Quality Chop House's unpasteurised offering, a high-quality print to an original painting. There will be many who will prefer Parade's snap, crackle and pop to the Quality Chop House's steady, rhythmical beat, and who will not be able to understand my affection for the latter. That's fine. There's plenty of room for both

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Keen as . . . mustard
fields.trailText: Keen as . . . mustard
fields.body:
The subject: A plant - no, a whole slew of different plants. A powder. A paste. A seed. A name attached to little pots of cress. A colour. Very confusing.

The basics: Mustard plants are all species of two genera, brassica and sinapis. Mustard as a condiment is made mostly from B. juncea and S. alba , which produce brown(ish) and yellow(ish) seeds respectively. Mustard as a vegetable is far more complicated, and that's why I'm ignoring it completely! (Anything for a quiet life.)

The details: When you fracture the husks of mustard seeds, enzymes and water create the pungent flavours that we crave on bangers, etc. But the compounds responsible quickly break down if left to their own devices - as you will already know if you've made your own and left it too long. Quick, save that tang with acid! Originally, it was grape must, which is the 'must' in 'mustard'. Nowadays, we use vinegar, from spirit-type crapola up through Vinaigre Ancien de Bourgogne. No prizes for guessing which is better. Colour is usually ordained by the variety used and the amount of husk ground in, but a deep yellow may be the work of turmeric. Coarse-textured grain mustard, with the husks cracked rather than ground, has its uses. Especially if it's from France. French mustard is the best mustard. Famous names: Dijon (pale, but pretty strong), Bordeaux (brown and mild), Meaux (grainy, mild and represented in the UK mostly by the excellent Pommery brand). Warning: don't buy French mustard that isn't made in France. Warning: don't ever eat American mustard on anything except an American hot dog.

The easy way out: Is that a joke?

Where to buy: English: anywhere. And, yes, Colman's really is the one. French: anywhere, but far cheaper in France. Look for smaller, pricier brands to get ace vinegar.

fields.headline: A man for all seating
fields.standfirst: With no fanfares, Matthew Hilton designed some of the most stylish furniture of the 90s, his work the essence of urban cool. Now, fame beckons, thanks to Habitat and a major exhibition. Charlotte Abrahams meets him.
fields.trailText: With no fanfares, Matthew Hilton designed some of the most stylish furniture of the 90s, his work the essence of urban cool. Now, fame beckons, thanks to Habitat and a major exhibition. Charlotte Abrahams meets him.
fields.body:
Matthew Hilton, one of Britain's leading designers, is going public. And not before time. Whereas the rest of the Brit pack - Ron Arad, Tom Dixon, Jasper Morrison et al - have found fame along with commercial success, Hilton's name, despite the huge popularity of his furniture, has remained unknown to all but the most design-savvy. His trad-meets-modern Balzac armchair and the curious, sculptural Flipper table are not only two of the Conran shops' best sellers, they are icons of late-90s loft living: so much so, that it is now almost impossible to open any glossy guide to loft life without seeing them, and London's Geffrye Museum has bought them for its 90s room. According to David Dewing, director of the museum, "They are already classics of late-20th-century design."

But Hilton himself has stayed out of the spotlight: no diffusion ranges, no shock tactics for the press, just consistently good-looking, functional furniture that people want to buy. Now, however, his approach is set to change - "I think I could do with more attention," he says - and he is going public. But don't expect a signed range of kitchen accessories launched with razzmatazz. Hilton is a modest man, and though he admits that part of him wishes he "could produce those things that break barriers", he accepts that he isn't that type of designer. "I don't seem to be like that. I suppose you have to accept what you are and get on with that."

What Hilton is, however, is a designer who produces work which, says Dewing, is "understated, honest and straightforward, which has been designed for a purpose, and never sacrifices the functional in favour of style". So his new attempt to raise his profile will be a quiet thing, evolving, rather than exploding, from three separate events.

The first is the Wait chair. Designed between 1998 and 1999, and manufactured by the German company Authentics, Wait is a modern take on the standard plastic stacking chair. Highly functional, seriously smart and very cheap, it has brought Hilton's work to a different and far wider public (there are 3,000 of them in the Dome, for example) and looks poised to usurp Robin Day's Polyprop as the nation's iconic plastic chair.

"I think it marks a change in my design," he says. "I'm still interested in that SCP and Driade market [British and Italian manufacturers of very beautiful, very expensive furniture], but I'm also interested in a larger market. I'm more interested now with the things that concerned me at college. Making things that work, improving products, improving people's lives. Hopefully, this chair will be reaching those people who don't judge things the way people involved in the design community do."

Hilton is obviously excited about this change of approach, and cites Wait as one of his favourite pieces. Asked if we can expect more mass-produced, high-quality, low-cost, contemporary classics, he nods, "I hope so." And then he admits to the next profile-raising move - the job of head of furniture design at Habitat. His appointment is great news for everyone who lusts after serious contemporary design, but can't afford to spend a month's earnings on an armchair, and has generated the same kind of excitement that greeted Tom Dixon's appointment as the store's design director in 1998.

Dixon himself is clear about why he wanted Hilton on board, describing him as a very experienced and considered designer, but Hilton wasn't easily persuaded. "Tom started talking to me about nine months ago," he says. "I had quite a difficult time deciding, but the thing that finally persuaded me was that there is a lot of positive energy there - people really want to do things - and the economy's good, and they have the resources. It feels like a good time. Ever since I started as a designer, people have been saying, 'I wish the market would grow. The rest of Europe won't sell here because they think the market's tiny,' but that's changing now. Companies like Habitat and Ikea are going to change things quite a lot. It's early days - I've only spent six days there [he begins properly in April] and we're trying to work out where we're going. I hope I'll be able to influence things and that they'll be pieces of mine for sale."

The third profile-raising event is Matthew Hilton: the exhibition. Furniture For Our Time opened at the Geffrye Museum last Tuesday, and represents a major retrospective of Hilton's work. You can see the Tension table that he designed as part of his 1979 degree show and that was spotted by the specialist press. There are the first tubular steel pieces he did for SCP, the British manufacturing and retail company founded by Sheridan Coakley, so beginning an association that continues to this day and that Hilton describes as the most important working relationship he has. There is also the sculptural metalwork - pieces such as the swan candlesticks and 1988 Antelope table, the Shaker-inspired wood furniture and the famous upholstery, made for both SCP and Driade.

Hilton was pleased to be asked to do the exhibition, glad to have a recognition that had nothing to do with commerce, and he likes everything that is in the show. He admits, however, to having found the process of selection, with its inevitable digging through the past, uncomfortable. "I had to go back in my mind and look at pieces of work and think about why I was doing it - and that reminded me of lots of things that were happening at the time. I think things have changed a lot. I think that I was probably a lot more personally involved in my work and it was quite a struggle, so all that digging was quite difficult. I think I'm more nervous about putting my work into this situation than I ever have been about any trade show. It feels like there's going to be a lot of people watching and judging."

No doubt there will be, but they are unlikely to be harsh judges - in Catherine McDermott's book that accompanies the show, an overwhelming number of design luminaries queue up to offer praise. Hilton maintains that all he is trying to do is "design good things", and now, at long last, more than just industry insiders are going to realise it. fields.bodyText: Matthew Hilton, one of Britain's leading designers, is going public. And not before time. Whereas the rest of the Brit pack - Ron Arad, Tom Dixon, Jasper Morrison et al - have found fame along with commercial success, Hilton's name, despite the huge popularity of his furniture, has remained unknown to all but the most design-savvy. His trad-meets-modern Balzac armchair and the curious, sculptural Flipper table are not only two of the Conran shops' best sellers, they are icons of late-90s loft living: so much so, that it is now almost impossible to open any glossy guide to loft life without seeing them, and London's Geffrye Museum has bought them for its 90s room. According to David Dewing, director of the museum, "They are already classics of late-20th-century design." But Hilton himself has stayed out of the spotlight: no diffusion ranges, no shock tactics for the press, just consistently good-looking, functional furniture that people want to buy. Now, however, his approach is set to change - "I think I could do with more attention," he says - and he is going public. But don't expect a signed range of kitchen accessories launched with razzmatazz. Hilton is a modest man, and though he admits that part of him wishes he "could produce those things that break barriers", he accepts that he isn't that type of designer. "I don't seem to be like that. I suppose you have to accept what you are and get on with that." What Hilton is, however, is a designer who produces work which, says Dewing, is "understated, honest and straightforward, which has been designed for a purpose, and never sacrifices the functional in favour of style". So his new attempt to raise his profile will be a quiet thing, evolving, rather than exploding, from three separate events. The first is the Wait chair. Designed between 1998 and 1999, and manufactured by the German company Authentics, Wait is a modern take on the standard plastic stacking chair. Highly functional, seriously smart and very cheap, it has brought Hilton's work to a different and far wider public (there are 3,000 of them in the Dome, for example) and looks poised to usurp Robin Day's Polyprop as the nation's iconic plastic chair. "I think it marks a change in my design," he says. "I'm still interested in that SCP and Driade market [British and Italian manufacturers of very beautiful, very expensive furniture], but I'm also interested in a larger market. I'm more interested now with the things that concerned me at college. Making things that work, improving products, improving people's lives. Hopefully, this chair will be reaching those people who don't judge things the way people involved in the design community do." Hilton is obviously excited about this change of approach, and cites Wait as one of his favourite pieces. Asked if we can expect more mass-produced, high-quality, low-cost, contemporary classics, he nods, "I hope so." "I had quite a difficult time deciding, but the thing that finally persuaded me was that there is a lot of positive energy there - people really want to do things - and the economy's good, and they have the resources. fields.headline: How to... pull yourself together
fields.trailText: There are some days, many of them in February, where everything is so miserable and depressing that you can feel all your energy, confidence and self-respect disappearing over the horizon with its arse on fire. You then have a choice: either you can immediately book yourself a four-month holiday in the Caribbean or, if that's not possible for some reason, you can pull yourself together.
fields.body:
There are some days, many of them in February, where everything is so miserable and depressing that you can feel all your energy, confidence and self-respect disappearing over the horizon with its arse on fire. You then have a choice: either you can immediately book yourself a four-month holiday in the Caribbean or, if that's not possible for some reason, you can pull yourself together.

The difficulty is that when you're feeling glum, the last thing you want to do is to pull yourself anywhere. The only thing you want to pull is the phone out of the wall, the top off a bottle of gin and the duvet over your head.

Oddly, when you're feeling low, the first instinct is to do a whole range of things that immediately make you feel worse; you sleep with someone 90% unsuitable for the 10% comfort factor; you go shopping for clothes that are 90% overpriced and 10% suitable, and then you eat a catering tub of ice cream, which makes you feel 90% sick and 10% depressed. You then don't go to a party because you feel so miserable and then you wonder why no one phones you (because they're all at the party).

When you feel glum, you think that the world is an awful place, that everything in it is conspiring against you, and that never has one person suffered so much. Try standing in front of a mirror, repeating that to yourself and see if you can keep a straight face. If you can, then put yourself through the following emergency de-glumming programme.

First, get moving. Either take your dog for a walk so long it thinks it's auditioning for a remake of Incredible Journey, or go to the gym and test your Lycra to destruction. When you get in, put a load of washing on, make something large and hot to eat, wash up all your dirty dishes, tidy up the whole house, throw lots of old things away, pour yourself a large drink and then look through your photo album to remind you of the good times. (Don't do this if you generally look like a dork in photos.) Have another large drink, put your favourite CD on at an unethically high volume and then dance around like an idiot until you collapse with exhaustion.

And finally, when you get into bed, remember however bad things are, they're a lot worse in other parts of the world. Except in the Caribbean of course.
