fields.headline: Asher Gilbert
fields.standfirst: Asher 'Harry' Gilbert, 87, was born in east London. He began training as a hairdresser at 14 and opened his first salon at 20. He founded his Paddington wig shop in 1956. In the cellar of the shop he developed 'Liquid Life', an 'elixir of youth'. He was made famous by the BBC docusoap Paddington Green.
fields.trailText: Asher 'Harry' Gilbert, 87, was born in east London. He began training as a hairdresser at 14 and opened his first salon at 20. He founded his Paddington wig shop in 1956. In the cellar of the shop he developed 'Liquid Life', an 'elixir of youth'. He was made famous by the BBC docusoap Paddington Green.
fields.body:
What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Perfect health.

With which historical figure do you most identify?
None, but most people look at me and say it's Einstein.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
Being a workaholic.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
There isn't one - I don't assess people.

What has been your most embarrassing moment?
I once had to restrain my wife in a temper fit which was embarrassing for everyone who was there.

What is your greatest extravagance?
Ballroom dancing.

What objects do you always carry with you?
Scissors. I've been mugged once before.

What is your most unappealing habit?
That I like to shave every day.

What is your favourite fantasy?
Still sex!

How did you vote in the last election?
Labour.

How will you vote in the next election?
Labour.

Should the Royal Family be scrapped?
Yes.

Do you believe in capital punishment?
No, I believe in an eye for an eye, but too many mistakes have been made in capital punishment.

Do you believe in monogamy?
No, it is only practised in England because there are not enough women to give a man two wives.

What or who is the greatest love of your life?
My present partner.

How often do you have sex?
Every day except Sunday.

What would you motto be?
I am the shop and the shop is me.

How would you like to die?
I've been declared dead twice. Once, I woke up and heard the nurse saying, 'It's no good, Mrs Gilbert, your son is dead', and I sat upright and stared at her. So what is death?!

How would you like to be remembered?
As I am known, as an honest person whose word can always be trusted.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
To live life!

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum
fields.standfirst: 'I'm not saying her skirt's too short, but I'm sure I got a brief flash of her cervix'
fields.trailText: 'I'm not saying her skirt's too short, but I'm sure I got a brief flash of her cervix'
fields.body:
Aunt Elspeth and I have been bulk-buying herbal remedies. She's on devil's claw, Harriet's on evening primrose, and Henry's on Holly. Holly Atkinson, that is - his girlfriend. Harriet says she is cool, which means haughty and half-naked. I don't really feel I have made her acquaintance, but I have been granted a glimpse of her belly-button.

I am on a diet of wild yam in a last-ditch attempt to revive my moribund libido. Perhaps this is a mid-life crisis prompted by Henry's wild oats. I would like one more briefs encounter before I succumb to an elderly regime of gardening and the Antiques Roadshow.

Approach TV in hope, but ex-Spouse is sprawled moodily in front of it, like an advert for someone urgently in need of St John's wort. My thrusting new libido will be wasted on him.

"Mum?" Harriet appears. "Can Kate and I go an' see Macy Gray at the Wembley Arena? You know you like Macy Gray." I do. That smoky, husky voice, those curly eyelashes, that curious hunched-up stance, like a potto peering into a howling gale. But why can't she confine her appearances to TV? Why this arduous pilgrimage all the way to Wembley? Heart sinks at thought of teenage girls singing, and possibly puking, in the back of my Volvo.

When I was a girl, Wembley meant International Women's Hockey. How I fancied those Amazons! I had libido to spare in those days.

Make non-committal noise and escape to kitchen. Prepare elderflower 'n' hibiscus tisane to restore my serenity, and perhaps even my serendipity. Bolt down another two wild yam tablets and try to remember when I last fancied somebody. Not counting Michael Portillo. He's an aphrodisiac personified: he's Spanish, he's fly, and he's irritating - to William Hague and Tony Blair, at least. Wonder if Portillo ever suffers form pre-PM tension.

"Is there any hot waterr , dearr ? It's time for my devil's claw." Aunt arrives clutching anti-arthritic product. "There's a peculiar smell coming down through my ceiling, Dulcie." Aunt's room is below Henry's. "It smells a bit like bonfires."

"I expect its just Holly's joss-sticks, Auntie."

"Sometimes Henry's eyes look terribly glazed. Aren't you worried about him, dearr ?"

Saved from further Calvinist innuendo by the arrival in the kitchen of the Anti-Christ herself, ie, Holly. She opens the fridge, takes out two Cokes, and disappears again without a word. I'm not saying her skirt's too short, it's just that as she bent down to ransack the fridge, I'm sure I got a brief flash of her cervix. Perhaps I should be reassured that the equipment necessary for the production of grandchildren is so evidently in place. Perhaps I should give this wild yam a miss, and find a herb that fortifies the dandling, not the dangling, parts.

"Mum? If I do all the ironing for a month, will you let me go and see Macy Gray?"

"Auntie - would you mind asking Gordon what he'd like for supper?" Do not wish aunt to eavesdrop on my negotiations with Harriet, during which I know I shall be utterly routed.

Besides, am getting peckish. Experience sudden desire for a mashed Swede. Perhaps my libido is starting off with root vegetables, and working its way down the evolutionary scale towards men.

"Mum? If I do all the ironing and clean the oven every week may I per-lease go to see Macy Gray?"

"No way!... Oh, all right."

The aunt returns. " Gorrdon says he could murrder a Kohl Rabi. Do you think he's joking?"

Eventually, I manage to watch the Antiques Roadshow video and - oh wonder! I feel a distinct twinge of lust for Hugh Scully. However, any man hoping to get lucky with me will have to soften me up first with Georgian lowboys and important teapots.

Much later, whilst browsing through The Daily Mirror left by Holly, discover Macy Gray is also performing in Bournemouth. Serendipity-doo-dah! Harriet & Co can attend the concert whilst I practise geriatric flirtation at a tea-dance to the strains of Victor Sylvester.

webTitle: The good, the fad and the ugly

fields.headline: The good, the fad and the ugly
fields.standfirst: An emphasis on new ideas might keep the fashion victim happy, but does it really improve the garden? Stefan Buczacki worries that we are losing the plot
fields.trailText: An emphasis on new ideas might keep the fashion victim happy, but does it really improve the garden? Stefan Buczacki worries that we are losing the plot
fields.body:
I certainly received some odd looks from residents washing their cars. But then, I was peering over most of their walls, trying to see what was in the back gardens as well as the front. Fortunately, I avoided the attention of the local constabulary, although walking the streets of a large proportion of residential Stratford-upon-Avon did take several hours of a Sunday morning. Nonetheless, had the long arm of the Warwickshire police decided to take an interest in my doings, I had an explanation ready: "Good morning, officer, I'm just looking for some bamboo."

In one sense, it's been a part of British gardening for ages; bamboo canes have supported our flopping perennials since, well, I'm not too sure: I suppose since the Orient was opened up to trade with the west. But, in truth, it wasn't canes that interested me. My survey constituted a search for living bamboo; bamboo as garden plants. And my mission was impelled by something that I had recently read in three separate newspapers and magazines: that bamboo is in fashion, that you must have bamboo in your garden, that it is the "in" thing to grow. Well, thank goodness, not in Stratford-upon-Avon, not yet, it isn't.

I would be lying if I said that I didn't see any. There were three clumps of the rather pretty, yellow-striped Pleioblastus auricomus (Arundinaria viridistriata, for those with longer memories; the names of bamboos have undergone complete revision and contortion of late). But plainly, they had been there for ages and were approaching their replacement date. They certainly hadn't been planted in response to any recent edict of horticultural fashion. I saw one poor specimen of Shibataea kumasasa , the bamboo that is interesting for being untypical in its branched stems, and I even saw one fully Orient-influenced garden (inspired by a holiday in Hong Kong, perhaps; the house was called Dun China) in which something that I couldn't identify was clearly, like many of the hardier bamboos, making a serious takeover bid for the entire plot.

And, I admit, I was interested to see a rather fine specimen of Nandina domestica 'Fire Power', the so-called sacred bamboo. Although it isn't a real bamboo (it's a member of the Berberis family), it does look very like one and provides a more manageable, hardy substitute for European gardens if an Oriental feel really is required. But that was it.

My Sunday morning was given over to this research because I've long suspected that garden fashions have about as much relevance to real gardeners as the catwalks of London, Paris and Milan do to the clothes that people wear on the number 19 bus. Garden centres tell me that they haven't been aware of any special interest in bamboo over the past few weeks, so perhaps my fears aren't being realised. Or are they, because, awful to relate, friends in the trade did volunteer that they have had a good many enquiries about decking. And I know where that comes from, too.

You can't switch on a gardening programme or open a book these days without a confrontation with wooden planks. And what a frightful waste of good space they are. The average garden today is less than 200 sq m. So what on earth possesses anyone to think we ought to cover it up with wooden boards, least of all with boards painted in bright colours? Decking is the stuff of stage sets and places to moor your boat. In the real world of real gardening it quickly becomes both unsightly and downright dangerous; try walking over wooden boards after a winter's rain and algae have had a go at it.

It's one thing to guide people to new developments in gardening, to steer them in the direction of ideas that they may not have thought of or to suggest plants only recently available and that just might be improvements on something that went before. We used to do it weekly during my years on Gardeners' Question Time. But there's a big difference between doing that and suggesting that they must follow a style. I just don't like to see folk being urged to buy something that I know will either turn out to be useless or will give their garden a totally anachronistic feel. Let's be honest, most gardening fashion starts with people who do far too little gardening and far too much sitting in offices and thinking about it.

British gardening is eclectic, always has been. That is its enduring glory. Like the British nation, it has evolved over the centuries and absorbed influences piecemeal. Yes, the word is evolved. It has never before been subject to the sudden, overnight change that has arisen not because of a process of natural selection but because of someone's whim or someone's response to the latest press release.

Yes, of course, gardening has absorbed trends. The introduction of naturalism and the influence of the Arts and Crafts movement in the 19th century are among more familiar examples. Simultaneously, small groups of horticulturists found themselves thinking and working along similar lines, people saw their creations and tried them, before either retaining or rejecting them. But no one talked of "must-haves". You'll read a good many words of the really great garden designers, even recent ones such as Geoffrey Jellicoe, Sylvia Crowe, Gertrude Jekyll, Lawrence Johnston, or just possibly Vita Sackville-West, before you find "fashion".

Of course, I'm not so blind that I can't see the reason. Gardening today is far less about real horticultural quality and far more about selling of products. And who are the losers? I think gardeners are, because they have been encouraged to think more in terms of doing what everyone else does and achieving results by the quick fix; and in the process failing to learn and appreciate that gardens are living, changing, dynamic entities with their own momentum. To think of gardens as you think of decor is to miss much of the satisfaction that the subject offers. No matter what the media tells you, gardens can't be treated like outdoor rooms.

I imagine that the fashionable thrusting of bamboo into our lives comes partly from one or two bamboo nurseries suddenly becoming more commercially-minded and partly from the same source that has resulted in an entire section of my local bookshop being given over to feng shui. Someone has decided that, at the moment, the east is in. But much of the result of gardening in the Oriental manner is that British gardeners are being urged to cover up their gardens in a way that they haven't previously been covered up. That, I am sure, is where this wretched decking comes from, because a version of it does appear in some Japanese and Chinese gardens, where wood has always played a far more important role than it does in gardens of the European tradition. But the significant difference is that most of the wood in the former is there to be looked at, not to be walked on.

If covering up your soil is truly what appeals to you, even if a bit of an Oriental influence is really what you want, let's look at something that is far more practical than decking, far more harmonious with our horticultural history, far cheaper, far easier to lay, far more versatile; and that doesn't entail wasting valuable growing space. Let's look at stone chips and gravel. Yes, there's still a smack of the Orient about them, although, in truth, I think that in the British gardening tradition stones and gravel really take their inspiration from nothing further east than Norfolk. The use of gravel in our gardens is derived far more from the shingle of places such as Blakeney than it is from Beijing.

Gravel and stone chips have attributes that no decking ever will. They won't go rotten, they won't become slippery and, above all, they won't turn a large slice of your garden into a sterile, wooden wasteland. Plants will grow through gravel; and extremely handsome they will look. And in choosing plants that look appropriate for a gravel bed, by all means turn your attention to the grass family, the Poaceae , but not to the sub-family Bambusoideae , which really is alien to British gardening. Plant proper, non-woody grasses such as the blue-leaved Festuca glauca 'Blaufuchs', the gently rustling Briza media or the loveliest of all golden grasses, Milium effusum 'Aureum'.

But don't, please don't, plonk a piece of something totally alien into your garden just because someone tells you it's the thing to do. I recall, not so long ago, a knowledgeable media gardening colleague telling me that, in his new series, he wanted to concentrate on real English gardening. Good news, I thought, and I watched the first programme. Almost the very first thing he did was to announce that, in the middle of his rural English plot, he was going to create a Mediterranean garden. I remember thinking at the time: Oh no, the press releases must have got him, too
fields.bodyText: I certainly received some odd looks from residents washing their cars. But then, I was peering over most of their walls, trying to see what was in the back gardens as well as the front. Fortunately, I avoided the attention of the local constabulary, although walking the streets of a large proportion of residential Stratford-upon-Avon did take several hours of a Sunday morning. Nonetheless, had the long arm of the Warwickshire police decided to take an interest in my doings, I had an explanation ready: "Good morning, officer, I'm just looking for some bamboo." In one sense, it's been a part of British gardening for ages; bamboo canes have supported our flopping perennials since, well, I'm not too sure: I suppose since the Orient was opened up to trade with the west. But, in truth, it wasn't canes that interested me. My survey constituted a search for living bamboo; bamboo as garden plants. And my mission was impelled by something that I had recently read in three separate newspapers and magazines: that bamboo is in fashion, that you must have bamboo in your garden, that it is the "in" thing to grow. Well, thank goodness, not in Stratford-upon-Avon, not yet, it isn't. I would be lying if I said that I didn't see any. There were three clumps of the rather pretty, yellow-striped Pleioblastus auricomus (Arundinaria viridistriata, for those with longer memories; the names of bamboos have undergone complete revision and contortion of late). But plainly, they had been there for ages and were approaching their replacement date. They certainly hadn't been planted in response to any recent edict of horticultural fashion. I saw one poor specimen of Shibataea kumasasa , the bamboo that is interesting for being untypical in its branched stems, and I even saw one fully Orient-influenced garden (inspired by a holiday in Hong Kong, perhaps; the house was called Dun China) in which something that I couldn't identify was clearly, like many of the hardier bamboos, making a serious takeover bid for the entire plot. And, I admit, I was interested to see a rather fine specimen of Nandina domestica 'Fire Power', the so-called sacred bamboo. Although it isn't a real bamboo (it's a member of the Berberis family), it does look very like one and provides a more manageable, hardy substitute for European gardens if an Oriental feel really is required. But that was it. My Sunday morning was given over to this research because I've long suspected that garden fashions have about as much relevance to real gardeners as the catwalks of London, Paris and Milan do to the clothes that people wear on the number 19 bus. Garden centres tell me that they haven't been aware of any special interest in bamboo over the past few weeks, so perhaps my fears aren't being realised. Or are they, because, awful to relate, friends in the trade did volunteer that they have had a good many enquiries about decking. And I know where that comes from, too. You can't switch on a gardening programme or open a book these days without a confrontation with wooden planks. And what a frightful waste of good space they are. The average garden today is less than 200 sq m. So what on earth possesses anyone to think we ought to cover it up with wooden boards, least of all with boards painted in bright colours? Decking is the stuff of stage sets and places to moor your boat. In the real world of real gardening it quickly becomes both unsightly and downright dangerous; try walking over wooden boards after a winter's rain and algae have had a go at it. It's one thing to guide people to new developments in gardening, to steer them in the direction of ideas that they may not have thought of or to suggest plants only recently available and that just might be improvements on something that went before. We used to do it weekly during my years on Gardeners' Question Time. But there's a big difference between doing that and suggesting that they must follow a style. I just don't like to see folk being urged to buy something that I know will either turn out to be useless or will give their garden a totally anachronistic feel. Let's be honest, most gardening fashion starts with people who do far too little gardening and far too much sitting in offices and thinking about it. British gardening is eclectic, always has been. That is its enduring glory. Like the British nation, it has evolved over the centuries and absorbed influences piecemeal. Yes, the word is evolved. It has never before been subject to the sudden, overnight change that has arisen not because of a process of natural selection but because of someone's whim or someone's response to the latest press release. Yes, of course, gardening has absorbed trends. The introduction of naturalism and the influence of the Arts and Crafts movement in the 19th century are among more familiar examples. Simultaneously, small groups of horticulturists found themselves thinking and working along similar lines, people saw their creations and tried them, before either retaining or rejecting them. But no one talked of "must-haves". You'll read a good many words of the really great garden designers, even recent ones such as Geoffrey Jellicoe, Sylvia Crowe, Gertrude Jekyll, Lawrence Johnston, or just possibly Vita Sackville-West, before you find "fashion". Of course, I'm not so blind that I can't see the reason. Gardening today is far less about real horticultural quality and far more about selling of products. And who are the losers? I think gardeners are, because they have been encouraged to think more in terms of doing what everyone else does and achieving results by the quick fix; and in the process failing to learn and appreciate that gardens are living, changing, dynamic entities with their own momentum. To think of gardens as you think of decor is to miss much of the satisfaction that the subject offers. No matter what the media tells you, gardens can't be treated like outdoor rooms. I imagine that the fashionable thrusting of bamboo into our lives comes partly from one or two bamboo nurseries suddenly becoming more commercially-minded and partly from the same source that has resulted in an entire section of my local bookshop being given over to feng shui. Someone has decided that, at the moment, the east is in. But much of the result of gardening in the Oriental manner is that British gardeners are being urged to cover up their gardens in a way that they haven't previously been covered up. That, I am sure, is where this wretched decking comes from, because a version of it does appear in some Japanese and Chinese gardens, where wood has always played a far more important role than it does in gardens of the European tradition. But the significant difference is that most of the wood in the former is there to be looked at, not to be walked on. If covering up your soil is truly what appeals to you, even if a bit of an Oriental influence is really what you want, let's look at something that is far more practical than decking, far more harmonious with our horticultural history, far cheaper, far easier to lay, far more versatile; and that doesn't entail wasting valuable growing space. fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText:
The concluding words of The End Of Innocence (February 12), 'We seem to have forgotten what it was like to tres-pass gingerly into . . . the world of grown-up sexuality', should be addressed to those amnesiac adults who interrogate child suspects. We must stop punishing children for behaviour that is imitative, but innocent of the informed intent of its adult counterpart. Nothing guarantees a dysfunctional adult sexuality more than having sex indelibly associated with wrongdoing as a child.
Belinda Braggins
London SE23
fields.body:

We must stop punishing children for behaviour that is imitative, but innocent of the informed intent of its adult counterpart. Nothing guarantees a dysfunctional adult sexuality more than having sex indelibly associated with wrongdoing as a child.
Belinda Braggins
London SE23

When I was at primary school in the 50s, another boy persuaded me to look up the girls' skirts. I shall never forget the gentleness with which the teacher persuaded us not to do it again. When I read of those now prosecuting children left, right and centre, I begin to feel dirty, guilty and frightened; too frightened to sign this letter for fear of being branded. I begin to feel abused myself, by the zealots who have retrospectively criminalised my childhood.
Anon

'It inevitably and rightly falls on us adults to guide and police children's sexual development'. Why?
Patrick Selden
Manchester

How many other students have had a 'parse the glarse' experience (A Darker Blue, February 12)? Mine happened not amidst the spires of Oxford, but in the redbrick of Manchester. There was one fundamental difference, however: I did receive the requested drinking vessel.
Linda Marshall
Staines, Middx

What a brilliant and touching extract from Stuart Jeffries' book. Compare with your cover story. I refer to the description of the R family: we are told that they dressed 'ferociously neatly', in 'fiercely ironed suits'; we read that the grandmother has a 'mock-antique phone'. Is this not exactly the same sneering, patronising attitude that Jeffries deplores? It demeans the writer of an otherwise fascinating piece.
E Trussell
Sudbury, Suffolk

To use Brideshead Revisited as a yard- stick for complaining about the shortcomings of one's own experience of Oxford is as sensible as expecting every childhood holiday to resemble the adventure stories of Enid Blyton.
nick@tucker.u-net.com

Hunter Davies suggests that a miracle is about to be revealed at Spurs (After The Fall, February 12). George Graham's methodical organisation and bent for discipline is shaping his inner circle, and the promised land is but a leap of faith over the Thames. Did no one tell them that it took Moses 40 years and untold prayers to get there?
Paul Harris
Chatham, Kent

Food, February 12: 'Steaming is claimed to preserve water-soluble nutrients that are lost by boiling, but this is largely a myth' - Peter Barham and Len Fisher. Food, February 12: 'Steaming is a fast, efficient method of cooking vegetables, conserving more nutrients than when boiled' - Joy Larkcom. Here's the truth: in steaming or boiling vegetables, bad fairies come and steal the nutrients, but good fairies steal them back and return them to the steamed ones only, but leave the boiled veg without nutrients and so unhappy. This is from a reliable source.
Edward Hardy
London W10

fields.headline: The hold of the old
fields.standfirst: Let's be honest: the British just don't like modern buildings. Jonathan Glancey believes it's much more than a simple matter of taste.
fields.trailText: Let's be honest: the British just don't like modern buildings. Jonathan Glancey believes it's much more than a simple matter of taste.
fields.body:
Images Of England is a computer database of the country's 360,000 listed buildings. It is being compiled by the National Monuments Record for English Heritage. More than 500 volunteer members of the Royal Photographic Society are taking the individual pictures. The project, which is backed by the Heritage Lottery Fund, is due for completion in 2002. "It will offer," says Victoria Fenner, leading the Images Of England team from an office in the former Great Western Railway works in Swindon, "a snapshot of our listed architectural heritage."

These are the facts. What more does anyone need to know? Nothing, perhaps, although we might ask why all the bother? What is it with the English and their obsession with conserving buildings? Surely, we, the forward-looking, strong and joyful citizens of New Britain, should by now have cured ourselves of our chronic nostalgia? Maybe, but we haven't, and it's very unlikely that we will, because we don't want to.

We're more than fond of our architectural heritage, and will do almost anything to preserve the least-deserving Victorian pile. Or streamlined 30s factory, 50s school, 70s office block. Images Of England aims to enhance our knowledge of the stock of historic buildings we say we want not just to keep, but, as far as is technically possible, to keep from change.

There are an awful lot of listed buildings in Britain. Perhaps you live in one. Perhaps, before long, there will be the conservation equivalent of the trainspotter who, in the days before "passengers" were demoted to "customers", would underline the numbers of engines he had "copped" in his locospotter's guide, and in a couple of years' time he (probably he) will be gurning outside your house, ticking it off his unfeasibly long list. Perhaps there will be a prize awarded to the first listed-building buff who checks out all 360,000. A candelit evening at Sir John Soane's Museum, Lincoln Inn's Fields. A weekend for two at the Grand Hotel, Scarborough. Drinks in the Lord Chancellor's apartment in the Palace of Westminster, to inspect, first-hand, the newly hand-printed Pugin wallpaper . . .

Maybe. Yet our famous obsession with old buildings and heritage is a phenomenon that needs some unravelling. In so many walks of life, we are prepared to see our world change - in clothes, music, cars, food, holidays, ways of working, consumer goods. Buildings, however, are generally considered best when old, and modern architects are generally to be mistrusted. "The only good architect," the historian and conservationist Gavin Stamp told me when I joined the Architectural Review as assistant editor, "is a dead architect." Although meant in jest (but possibly not), Stamp's jibe summed up the feeling so many English people have nurtured since the second world war. While it is true that English architects made many mistakes, often at the behest of impatient developers and bombastic local authorities, the standard of architectural design in England has probably risen over the past 20 years, and we have much to be proud of.

Nevertheless, we cling to the past as if history was some sort of constant companion. It isn't - history is as slippery a creature as a wet fish on a market stall. Our perception and interpretation of it changes with each new biography of a famous person, or study of some past civilisation. Yes, but not buildings. There they stand, immutable witnesses to the spirit of those who commissioned, designed, built and used them. Comfortable and reliable backdrops to our own lives. Old friends.

Fine. But when does a building become an old pal? Where does history start, and what makes a building historic rather than simply old? When will conservationists start loving the Dome? What we felt was a hideous building when we saw it for the first time when we were 30 becomes a precious monument that we must save for the nation 30 years on. It doesn't seem that long ago - 20 years at the most - when the majority of architectural historians and conservationists railed against virtually any post-war building. Post first world war, that is. Buildings from the 20s on - unless they were designed by late-flowering Neo-Classicists such as Edwin Lutyens, Herbert Baker or Albert Richardson - my dears, there was no hope for them. Pretentious, pseudish, meretricious trash, designed or copied from designs by lying, tricky foreigners.

For an earlier generation - those born in the late Victorian and Edwardian eras, and trying to escape it - the fronds and prickles of high-Victorian architecture were inept and vulgar. When Kenneth Clark (Lord Clark of Civilisation) published The Gothic Revival in 1929, in which he enthused about the re-creation of medieval style, it was widely thought to be a squib, a tease, a wind-up. His contemporaries, John Betjeman, then assistant editor of the Architectural Review (and, much later, poet laureate) and Osbert Lancaster, the gifted pocket cartoonist, were thought to be taking the mickey out of contemporary architects when they used their precocious gifts to support the prickly churches and houses of such celebrated Victorian Goths as Pugin, Butterfield and Street, of Pearson, Bodley & Garner and Temple Moore.

They weren't. In fact, Betjeman's genius, often misunderstood, was to promote the best contemporary architecture (he was a member of MARS - Modern Architecture Research, the English arm of CIAM, the Comité Internatiaux d'Architecture Moderne founded by Le Corbusier and gang on the continent) while deriding most of it (because so much was so bloody awful), and to open our eyes to buildings that he felt we really couldn't afford to lose - from the grandest Tudorbethan country house to a Great Western signal box on some obscure rural branchline that would be sentenced to death by the infamous Dr Beeching in the early 60s.

There were those who found Betjeman's stance ill-considered (he was called a "vulgar Fleet Street man" by one pompous modern architect whose buildings will never survive the test of time as well as the shortest poem by the future "nation's teddy bear"); they tended to believe that proper architecture had come to an end in the 1830s and had only begun again in England in the 1930s.

Further back, in the 18th century, the Georgians found the great cathedrals of their medieval predecessors either "gloomy piles" - as, for example, Tobias Smollet's Humphrey Clinker did on his fictional travels through England - or simply rather amusing. They scratched their initials into the lovingly-carved stones and watched, very often, as the glories of old Catholic England fell into a state of romantic decay.

So the story goes back. And back. When the Romans came to England, they were rightly fascinated by Stonehenge. They did, as far as we know, no damage to it. Perhaps they listed it, scheduled it for preservation. This we don't know. What we do know is that, since the second world war, the English - and for that matter the British in general - have become quite obsessive about preserving their built heritage and, unlike previous generations, possess a largely uncritical view of the buildings of the past. Here's the opposite of what might be the New Labour mantra "new good, old bad": "old good, new bad".

Why? For many reasons, but not simply because so many new buildings of the 50s and 60s appeared to be so very aggressive and oblivious to their surroundings. One other reason is that the Blitz and later assaults on English towns and cities by V1 and V2 "revenge weapons" destroyed so much of the matter and character of the places we knew as home and as quintessentially English, that we learned - not always in time and in the teeth of opposition from opportunistic architects, insensitive planners, over-ambitious or just plain corrupt local politicians - to cling to the wreckage and to save, at first, the best of the buildings falling around us, and then every old building we could. Between 1940 and 1970, there had simply been too much destruction. While we could accept, and even enjoy, the obvious comforts and benefits of the post-war world - the NHS, holidays abroad, cars, refrigerators, central heating, radiograms and frozen fish fingers - we couldn't accept what was fast becoming the wholesale destruction of the backdrop to the everyday drama of our lives: a handsome Georgian terrace here, a heaven-seeking Victorian church there.

Once we'd got to grips with looking after country houses and wobbly old churches lost in fields of foxgloves, bit by bit we began to want to protect the architecture that serves us everyday in simple yet endearing ways - a railway station, working men's cottages, a railway works such as that at Swindon. What had begun as an elite mission to save a passing world of grand old values - in the spirit of Evelyn Waugh deploring the fate of the great English country house in Brideshead Revisited - descended from Parnassus to the marketplace. By the 80s, and certainly by the time the Prince of Wales launched his attack on modern architecture in a speech delivered to members of the Royal Institute of British Architects at Hampton Court Palace in 1984, England had become the most comprehensively listed and architecturally pickled country in the world.

Where once conservation battles had been championed by the likes of Betjeman and fought by a slowly growing number of well-connected pressure groups - the Georgian Group, the Victorian Society - now local groups up and down the country battled to save the most obscure old building. But not only old. The destruction of England's architectural fabric - at first by the Luftwaffe and then by holier-than-thou (and sometimes plain unholy) alliances of architects, planners, developers and local politicians - eventually shocked the majority of thinking people into wanting to preserve what was left of their heritage. It wasn't long, however, before discrimination appeared to go through the window, and obscure local interest groups were campaigning to preserve every last building that was more than 50 years old.

It is simply not true that every old building is of historic and architectural interest. Many Victorian buildings, in fact -including most of the dull, red-brick ranks of terraced houses in which the great new middle classes choose to live around the inner belt of our towns and cities - are as dull as a Morris Marina. Yet, just as you will find a Morris Marina owners' club in England as surely as you will find a McDonald's on every high street, so, sooner or later, you will come across a local society bustling with keen people, many retired with time on their hands and far too bright to sit around watching telly or murdering the lawn for the fifth time that week, who wish to conserve a rather dreary building. This may well have been a hack job in its day and despised by anyone with taste, but that is not the point. The point is that there are people with enough spare time to bother with such old buildings; people that mistrust the new, believing contemporary architects are most likely to design something worse, and that, in their view, we can ill afford to lose historic buildings when, thanks to ill-thought-through government policy, builders are invading our green belts and farmland with cynical new houses, each with a veneer of historic detailing, double-glazing and twin garage.

More than this, perhaps, the fight for our architectural heritage is also a form of protest. Since Margaret Thatcher came to power in 1979, England, as the rest of Britain, has been forced under the yoke by increasingly authoritarian governments. Under Thatcher, we had a nanny-knows-best state, a curious and very un-English marriage of free-market economics and domineering social control. Under her favoured successor, Tony Blair, we have witnessed an equally un-English assertion of free-market economics, together with an obsession with all things new, and increasing social control.

Naturally, the John Bull-Boadicea spirit still alive in the breasts of the many English people prompts them, whether knowingly or not, to resist. People essentially disenfranchised by parliament for five years at a time scout for skirmishes that they can win. The classic car lobby will fight for the survival of at least enough four-star petrol to power the nation's impressive collection of old Wolseleys, Bentleys, Jags and Armstrong-Siddeleys. The railway preservation movement will fight any attempt by Railtrack to block steam trains from running on metals that rightly belong to the nation and not to shareholders; the latter are more interested in profit than they are in public service or in the sheer delight of watching the "Duke of Gloucester" or "Duchess of Hamilton" roar across Shap Fell with a 12-car Pullman special. The classic air craft lobby will fight sortie after sortie for the right to fly Sopwith and Supermarine machines over densely-packed crowds who travel for miles to old airfields to see them perform their aerial ballets.

Much the same is true for many of those involved in the conservation of buildings. This, along with gardening, fishing, moaning, arguing with traffic wardens, self- deprecation and surfing the net has become a part and parcel of our lives. The National Trust, dedicated to the care of historic buildings and landscapes, boasts more than two million members; it is, quite simply, the largest pressure group in the country.

Even so, there is a case for saying that although this appeases popular English sentiment, we have preserved far too many buildings. There was always a case for protecting buildings of all sorts, from castles and palaces to the tiniest chapel and most obscure farmhouse of pre-18th century England, because these are rare. Before the Industrial Revolution, England's population was quite small, and the number of buildings it needed consequently low. As many of these were poorly built, few were ever likely to survive. We treasure those that have lasted through to our own times. By the end of the 18th century, new buildings were rising to meet the demands of a rapidly expanding and exponentially wealthy country. This social and economic revolution happened to coincide with an age of sophisticated and universally accepted taste in architecture. It really is hard to find an ugly or unlikeable building from the period between 1660 and 1830. Today, although not without a supreme effort by the conservation lobby over 75 years, we tend to revere what we know loosely as Georgian architecture and wish no more to be pulled down to make way for yet another multiplex cinema, shopping mall or postmodern-style office block.

While we might approve of an intelligent new building, we feel in our bones - quite rightly - that the old and undistinguished is most likely to be replaced by the new and trashy, especially if there is a fast buck to be turned. When we get to the 19th and 20th centuries, however, we really have got carried away. The Victorians built a lot of horrid architecture alongside the fairytale wonders of Pugin, Burges, Butterfield and Co. In the second half of the 20th century, we built cubic acres of brutally and often cynically "func tional" buildings that have proved to be anything but. Many deserve to be demolished.

Yet, even here, conservationists insist on fighting to conserve the most meretricious buildings. The very tweedy chaps and chapesses who once loathed any building raised after 1918 have, from the 1980s, battled to protect grim office blocks and sad shopping centres. This building here is a rare work - members of bodies such as the Twentieth Century Society will bark - of RSJ Gasket (1892-1978), the little-known architect who designed the Co-Op distribution centre at Neasden Lane, 1934. A plan, section and at least one elevation of the scheme, adapted from a rejected 1924 project for a miners' hostel in Prague by an unpromising pupil of Erich Mendelsohn, appeared on page 94 of the Architect's Journal (14.7.33). This is an important work. It must be listed.

This office, over here, is an extremely rare example of the CRASS (Constructions Raised At Startling Speed) method of system-build, asbestos-lined design. Dating from 1964-67, it was a "paradigmatic" work by the Radical Design Unit (Quentin Lisp, Gawaine de Stamp, Letitia Hangeron and Jim Stalin). An exhibition of the original scheme has been held recently at the Architectural Association, Bedford Square, curated by the husband-and-wife team Laura and Tobias Truste-ffund, senior partners of Ugh! whose latest "ironic" cyber-bar and art space, Koolhaas, in happening south Kentish Town, recently featured in an eight-page Blueprint exclusive. By the time they retire to a converted barn on the north Norfolk coast, Laura and Tobias will be prominent members of the local listed-buildings committee of English Heritage. And here's another... no, that's enough.

Many of the most delightful of all historic buildings, however - save those which are a pure aesthetic law unto themselves: Salisbury Cathedral, the Mausoleum at Castle Howard, Arnos Grove tube station - are products of change, accretion and even partial demolition. We thrill to the way our finest old cathedrals, the purity of Salisbury aside, are composed of different styles and elements, a Norman arcade here, a decorated Gothic chancel there. We like the way our best cities are not over-preserved, but restlessly alive. As in so many areas of our lives, it's the mix, the contradictions, the unlikely and the unexpected that we thrill to. Life is not much fun when too ordered or deliberately sheltered.

Conservation has got a little out of hand, yet until governments, architects, advertising agencies and other bodies responsible for trying to reshape our lives stop banging on about how everything new is better than everything old, the English will dig in their heels and hold the forces of overt modernism at bay. We say we like gentle change, even though England is changing at a faster pace than at any time since the brutal birth pangs of the Industrial Revolution. For better or worse, listed buildings - all 360,000 of them - are increasingly the havens we retreat to when the pace of change seems too fast

 More information on www.imagesofengland.org.uk
fields.bodyText: Images Of England is a computer database of the country's 360,000 listed buildings. It is being compiled by the National Monuments Record for English Heritage. More than 500 volunteer members of the Royal Photographic Society are taking the individual pictures. The project, which is backed by the Heritage Lottery Fund, is due for completion in 2002. "It will offer," says Victoria Fenner, leading the Images Of England team from an office in the former Great Western Railway works in Swindon, "a snapshot of our listed architectural heritage." These are the facts. What more does anyone need to know? Nothing, perhaps, although we might ask why all the bother? What is it with the English and their obsession with conserving buildings? Surely, we, the forward-looking, strong and joyful citizens of New Britain, should by now have cured ourselves of our chronic nostalgia? Maybe, but we haven't, and it's very unlikely that we will, because we don't want to. We're more than fond of our architectural heritage, and will do almost anything to preserve the least-deserving Victorian pile. Or streamlined 30s factory, 50s school, 70s office block. Images Of England aims to enhance our knowledge of the stock of historic buildings we say we want not just to keep, but, as far as is technically possible, to keep from change. There are an awful lot of listed buildings in Britain. Perhaps you live in one. Perhaps, before long, there will be the conservation equivalent of the trainspotter who, in the days before "passengers" were demoted to "customers", would underline the numbers of engines he had "copped" in his locospotter's guide, and in a couple of years' time he (probably he) will be gurning outside your house, ticking it off his unfeasibly long list. Perhaps there will be a prize awarded to the first listed-building buff who checks out all 360,000. A candelit evening at Sir John Soane's Museum, Lincoln Inn's Fields. A weekend for two at the Grand Hotel, Scarborough. Drinks in the Lord Chancellor's apartment in the Palace of Westminster, to inspect, first-hand, the newly hand-printed Pugin wallpaper . . . Maybe. Yet our famous obsession with old buildings and heritage is a phenomenon that needs some unravelling. In so many walks of life, we are prepared to see our world change - in clothes, music, cars, food, holidays, ways of working, consumer goods. Buildings, however, are generally considered best when old, and modern architects are generally to be mistrusted. "The only good architect," the historian and conservationist Gavin Stamp told me when I joined the Architectural Review as assistant editor, "is a dead architect." Although meant in jest (but possibly not), Stamp's jibe summed up the feeling so many English people have nurtured since the second world war. While it is true that English architects made many mistakes, often at the behest of impatient developers and bombastic local authorities, the standard of architectural design in England has probably risen over the past 20 years, and we have much to be proud of. Nevertheless, we cling to the past as if history was some sort of constant companion. It isn't - history is as slippery a creature as a wet fish on a market stall. Our perception and interpretation of it changes with each new biography of a famous person, or study of some past civilisation. Yes, but not buildings. There they stand, immutable witnesses to the spirit of those who commissioned, designed, built and used them. Comfortable and reliable backdrops to our own lives. Old friends. Fine. But when does a building become an old pal? Where does history start, and what makes a building historic rather than simply old? When will conservationists start loving the Dome? What we felt was a hideous building when we saw it for the first time when we were 30 becomes a precious monument that we must save for the nation 30 years on. It doesn't seem that long ago - 20 years at the most - when the majority of architectural historians and conservationists railed against virtually any post-war building. Post first world war, that is. Buildings from the 20s on - unless they were designed by late-flowering Neo-Classicists such as Edwin Lutyens, Herbert Baker or Albert Richardson - my dears, there was no hope for them. Pretentious, pseudish, meretricious trash, designed or copied from designs by lying, tricky foreigners. For an earlier generation - those born in the late Victorian and Edwardian eras, and trying to escape it - the fronds and prickles of high-Victorian architecture were inept and vulgar. When Kenneth Clark (Lord Clark of Civilisation) published The Gothic Revival in 1929, in which he enthused about the re-creation of medieval style, it was widely thought to be a squib, a tease, a wind-up. His contemporaries, John Betjeman, then assistant editor of the Architectural Review (and, much later, poet laureate) and Osbert Lancaster, the gifted pocket cartoonist, were thought to be taking the mickey out of contemporary architects when they used their precocious gifts to support the prickly churches and houses of such celebrated Victorian Goths as Pugin, Butterfield and Street, of Pearson, Bodley & Garner and Temple Moore. They weren't. In fact, Betjeman's genius, often misunderstood, was to promote the best contemporary architecture (he was a member of MARS - Modern Architecture Research, the English arm of CIAM, the Comité Internatiaux d'Architecture Moderne founded by Le Corbusier and gang on the continent) while deriding most of it (because so much was so bloody awful), and to open our eyes to buildings that he felt we really couldn't afford to lose - from the grandest Tudorbethan country house to a Great Western signal box on some obscure rural branchline that would be sentenced to death by the infamous Dr Beeching in the early 60s. There were those who found Betjeman's stance ill-considered (he was called a "vulgar Fleet Street man" by one pompous modern architect whose buildings will never survive the test of time as well as the shortest poem by the future "nation's teddy bear"); they tended to believe that proper architecture had come to an end in the 1830s and had only begun again in England in the 1930s. Further back, in the 18th century, the Georgians found the great cathedrals of their medieval predecessors either "gloomy piles" - as, for example, Tobias Smollet's Humphrey Clinker did on his fictional travels through England - or simply rather amusing. They scratched their initials into the lovingly-carved stones and watched, very often, as the glories of old Catholic England fell into a state of romantic decay. So the story goes back. And back. When the Romans came to England, they were rightly fascinated by Stonehenge. They did, as far as we know, no damage to it. Perhaps they listed it, scheduled it for preservation. This we don't know. What we do know is that, since the second world war, the English - and for that matter the British in general - have become quite obsessive about preserving their built heritage and, unlike previous generations, possess a largely uncritical view of the buildings of the past. Here's the opposite of what might be the New Labour mantra "new good, old bad": "old good, new bad". Why? For many reasons, but not simply because so many new buildings of the 50s and 60s appeared to be so very aggressive and oblivious to their surroundings. One other reason is that the Blitz and later assaults on English towns and cities by V1 and V2 "revenge weapons" destroyed so much of the matter and character of the places we knew as home and as quintessentially English, that we learned - not always in time and in the teeth of opposition from opportunistic architects, insensitive planners, over-ambitious or just plain corrupt local politicians - to cling to the wreckage and to save, at first, the best of the buildings falling around us, and then every old building we could. Between 1940 and 1970, there had simply been too much destruction. While we could accept, and even enjoy, the obvious comforts and benefits of the post-war world - the NHS, holidays abroad, cars, refrigerators, central heating, radiograms and frozen fish fingers - we couldn't accept what was fast becoming the wholesale destruction of the backdrop to the everyday drama of our lives: a handsome Georgian terrace here, a heaven-seeking Victorian church there. Once we'd got to grips with looking after country houses and wobbly old churches lost in fields of foxgloves, bit by bit we began to want to protect the architecture that serves us everyday in simple yet endearing ways - a railway station, working men's cottages, a railway works such as that at Swindon. What had begun as an elite mission to save a passing world of grand old values - in the spirit of Evelyn Waugh deploring the fate of the great English country house in Brideshead Revisited - descended from Parnassus to the marketplace. By the 80s, and certainly by the time the Prince of Wales launched his attack on modern architecture in a speech delivered to members of the Royal Institute of British Architects at Hampton Court Palace in 1984, England had become the most comprehensively listed and architecturally pickled country in the world. Where once conservation battles had been championed by the likes of Betjeman and fought by a slowly growing number of well-connected pressure groups - the Georgian Group, the Victorian Society - now local groups up and down the country battled to save the most obscure old building. But not only old. The destruction of England's architectural fabric - at first by the Luftwaffe and then by holier-than-thou (and sometimes plain unholy) alliances of architects, planners, developers and local politicians - eventually shocked the majority of thinking people into wanting to preserve what was left of their heritage. It wasn't long, however, before discrimination appeared to go through the window, and obscure local interest groups were campaigning to preserve every last building that was more than 50 years old. It is simply not true that every old building is of historic and architectural interest. Many Victorian buildings, in fact -including most of the dull, red-brick ranks of terraced houses in which the great new middle classes choose to live around the inner belt of our towns and cities - are as dull as a Morris Marina. Yet, just as you will find a Morris Marina owners' club in England as surely as you will find a McDonald's on every high street, so, sooner or later, you will come across a local society bustling with keen people, many retired with time on their hands and far too bright to sit around watching telly or murdering the lawn for the fifth time that week, who wish to conserve a rather dreary building. This may well have been a hack job in its day and despised by anyone with taste, but that is not the point. The point is that there are people with enough spare time to bother with such old buildings; people that mistrust the new, believing contemporary architects are most likely to design something worse, and that, in their view, we can ill afford to lose historic buildings when, thanks to ill-thought-through government policy, builders are invading our green belts and farmland with cynical new houses, each with a veneer of historic detailing, double-glazing and twin garage. More than this, perhaps, the fight for our architectural heritage is also a form of protest. Since Margaret Thatcher came to power in 1979, England, as the rest of Britain, has been forced under the yoke by increasingly authoritarian governments. Under Thatcher, we had a nanny-knows-best state, a curious and very un-English marriage of free-market economics and domineering social control. Under her favoured successor, Tony Blair, we have witnessed an equally un-English assertion of free-market economics, together with an obsession with all things new, and increasing social control. Naturally, the John Bull-Boadicea spirit still alive in the breasts of the many English people prompts them, whether knowingly or not, to resist. People essentially disenfranchised by parliament for five years at a time scout for skirmishes that they can win. The classic car lobby will fight for the survival of at least enough four-star petrol to power the nation's impressive collection of old Wolseleys, Bentleys, Jags and Armstrong-Siddeleys. The railway preservation movement will fight any attempt by Railtrack to block steam trains from running on metals that rightly belong to the nation and not to shareholders; the latter are more interested in profit than they are in public service or in the sheer delight of watching the "Duke of Gloucester" or "Duchess of Hamilton" roar across Shap Fell with a 12-car Pullman special. The classic air craft lobby will fight sortie after sortie for the right to fly Sopwith and Supermarine machines over densely-packed crowds who travel for miles to old airfields to see them perform their aerial ballets. Much the same is true for many of those involved in the conservation of buildings. This, along with gardening, fishing, moaning, arguing with traffic wardens, self- deprecation and surfing the net has become a part and parcel of our lives. The National Trust, dedicated to the care of historic buildings and landscapes, boasts more than two million members; it is, quite simply, the largest pressure group in the country. Even so, there is a case for saying that although this appeases popular English sentiment, we have preserved far too many buildings. There was always a case for protecting buildings of all sorts, from castles and palaces to the tiniest chapel and most obscure farmhouse of pre-18th century England, because these are rare. Before the Industrial Revolution, England's population was quite small, and the number of buildings it needed consequently low. As many of these were poorly built, few were ever likely to survive. We treasure those that have lasted through to our own times. By the end of the 18th century, new buildings were rising to meet the demands of a rapidly expanding and exponentially wealthy country. This social and economic revolution happened to coincide with an age of sophisticated and universally accepted taste in architecture. It really is hard to find an ugly or unlikeable building from the period between 1660 and 1830. Today, although not without a supreme effort by the conservation lobby over 75 years, we tend to revere what we know loosely as Georgian architecture and wish no more to be pulled down to make way for yet another multiplex cinema, shopping mall or postmodern-style office block. While we might approve of an intelligent new building, we feel in our bones - quite rightly - that the old and undistinguished is most likely to be replaced by the new and trashy, especially if there is a fast buck to be turned. When we get to the 19th and 20th centuries, however, we really have got carried away. The Victorians built a lot of horrid architecture alongside the fairytale wonders of Pugin, Burges, Butterfield and Co. In the second half of the 20th century, we built cubic acres of brutally and often cynically "func tional" buildings that have proved to be anything but. Many deserve to be demolished. Yet, even here, conservationists insist on fighting to conserve the most meretricious buildings. The very tweedy chaps and chapesses who once loathed any building raised after 1918 have, from the 1980s, battled to protect grim office blocks and sad shopping centres. This building here is a rare work - members of bodies such as the Twentieth Century Society will bark - of RSJ Gasket (1892-1978), the little-known architect who designed the Co-Op distribution centre at Neasden Lane, 1934. A plan, section and at least one elevation of the scheme, adapted from a rejected 1924 project for a miners' hostel in Prague by an unpromising pupil of Erich Mendelsohn, appeared on page 94 of the Architect's Journal (14.7.33). This is an important work. It must be listed. This office, over here, is an extremely rare example of the CRASS (Constructions Raised At Startling Speed) method of system-build, asbestos-lined design. Dating from 1964-67, it was a "paradigmatic" work by the Radical Design Unit (Quentin Lisp, Gawaine de Stamp, Letitia Hangeron and Jim Stalin). An exhibition of the original scheme has been held recently at the Architectural Association, Bedford Square, curated by the husband-and-wife team Laura and Tobias Truste-ffund, senior partners of Ugh! whose latest "ironic" cyber-bar and art space, Koolhaas, in happening south Kentish Town, recently featured in an eight-page Blueprint exclusive. By the time they retire to a converted barn on the north Norfolk coast, Laura and Tobias will be prominent members of the local listed-buildings committee of English Heritage. And here's another... no, that's enough. fields.headline: Shaken & stirred
fields.standfirst: Ward Eight
fields.trailText: Ward Eight
fields.body:
This classic, bourbon-based cocktail was first mixed sometime around the beginning of the 20th century and became an immediate favourite among more sophisticated drinkers of the bar set. In 1934, having successfully weathered the storm that was US prohibition, the Ward Eight was named cocktail of the year. The original Boston recipe has survived unaltered ever since. A truly victorious drink.

50ml bourbon

15ml fresh lemon juice

15ml fresh orange juice

1 dash grenadine

1 dash egg white

Combine all the ingredients in a chilled cocktail shaker, give it a thorough shake, pour into a Martini glass and garnish with a wedge of fresh lemon.

 Tadgh Ryan, head barman, at home, 1 Leicester Square, London WC2.

fields.headline: Home sweet home...
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 32¾
fields.trailText: I cannot understand why nobody wanted to take on the tenancy of this house.
fields.body:
Saturday, February 5, 2000, 12 Arthur Askey Way, Gaitskell Estate

I cannot understand why nobody wanted to take on the tenancy of this house.

It is dry, centrally-heated, has three bedrooms, a new bathroom, a well-equipped kitchen and a large through lounge. The windows are double-glazed and there is a front garden with a hard standing area for a car and a back garden with a medium-sized tree. The council has completely redecorated.

When I asked Pamela Pigg from the council's homeless unit why the house had been vacant for over a year, she said, "I have to tell you, Mr Mole, that this house is notorious".

She wouldn't elaborate. Perhaps a famous Leicester person lived here once. Gary Lineker, perhaps, or Willie Thorne? Both came from humble beginnings before climbing their respective ladders to the land of fame.

Glenn and William have mixed feelings about the move. They are happy to have a bedroom each, but Glenn said, "I aint 'ard enough for the Gaitskell, Dad, and neither are you." William asked, "Why have all the shops got barbed wire over the windows?"

I told him a ridiculous lie about the Territorial Army using the shopping parade for a weekend exercise, but it was obvious that even he, the most gullible of boys, didn't believe me. It has to be faced: we are living among what sociologists call "the underclass", and what my father, reluctantly driving the box van containing my few sticks of furniture, called "Satan's spawn".

However, our immediate neighbours, the Ludlows, with whom we share a party wall, seem to be very quiet types. I haven't heard so much as a peep from them. I know their name because somebody has painted "the Ludlows live here" in black gloss paint on the front of their house.

Sunday, February 6

I left the boys watching TV and walked to the newsagents. There was a notice on the grilled door: "Glue or cigarettes will not be served to miners, and balaclavas must be removed." I removed my balaclava and went inside.

An Asian man stood behind the counter. A woman I took to be his wife was stocking the magazine racks with what appeared to be pornography.

"Good morning," I said cheerfully. "The Observer, please."

"You're too late, m'duck, the vicar's been in an' got the only copy," said the man, in a broad Leicester accent.

"You only stock one copy of a great national newspaper?" I checked.

"We got plenty more," he said indicating the News Of The World, the People and Sunday Sport."

I asked him to order two copies of the Observer in future. As I was leaving, I said, as pleasantly as possible, "Isn't it against your religion to serve pornography?"

He bridled and said, "No, I'm a Catholic, we're from Goa, an' anyway, what's wrong with the naked female body, eh? What you got against it?"

I fear I have got off on the wrong foot with the Goans. After being searched at the entrance of the mini-supermarket, Food Is U, by a fat man in a security-guard's uniform, I went inside and attempted to buy some croissants and a box of fresh orange juice. I returned home with a thick-sliced loaf and a bottle of Sunny Delight. There were two aisles of cakes and biscuits, and one aisle devoted entirely to fizzy drinks.

When I have settled in, I may write to the manager and point out that he should widen his customer base.

Friday, February 11

My mother visited my new home today. She was obviously unnerved by the journey through the estate. "You'll never survive it, Adrian," she said. She had brought the new dog to see us, but it refused to get out of the car. I posted a Valentine to Pandora and signed it "Oh Pandora, still adore ya."

Sunday, February 13

The Ludlows are back from "opening the caravan up in Chapel-Saint-Leonards". There are two adults, six children and three big dogs. The noise is indescribable.

Valentine's Day

Not a single card, not one.

webTitle: Jeb Bush plans affirmative action ban in Florida, muddies brother's campaign

fields.headline: Jeb Bush plans affirmative action ban in Florida, muddies brother's campaign
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Governor Jeb Bush of Florida - whose elder brother George W Bush, the Texas governor, is battling to win the Republican presidential nomination - is pushing ahead this weekend with a controversial "One Florida" programme which aims to eliminate affirmative action programmes from a state where one in four inhabitants is black or Latino.
fields.body:
Governor Jeb Bush of Florida - whose elder brother George W Bush, the Texas governor, is battling to win the Republican presidential nomination - is pushing ahead this weekend with a controversial "One Florida" programme which aims to eliminate affirmative action programmes from a state where one in four inhabitants is black or Latino.

The programme is likely to be passed on Tuesday, after the Florida board of regents - which controls the state's university system in which 35% of the 219,000 students are from minorities - voted by 12-0 this week to approve it.

Most political observers had assumed Jeb Bush's public role this year would be to keep his head down and avoid jeopardising his brother's campaign.

But if that was the strategy, it has failed, as the Florida governor's plan has provoked protests and sit-ins across the state, and led one black minister to equate him with Hitler.

The One Florida plan gives Mr Bush executive power to end race-based admissions to all Florida's state-run colleges and universities. It scraps the state's system of race-based preferences in the award of public sector contracts.

Similar moves to end affirmative action have already taken place in Texas, California and Washington state.

Mr Bush's plan was announced last November in an attempt to ward off efforts by affirmative action opponents to submit the issue to a state-wide referendum this year - a vote that would undoubtedly polarise the Florida electorate on racial grounds and would happen on the day that George W Bush hopes to be on the ballot in the presidential election.

Jeb Bush's plan includes safeguards designed to draw the sting of abolition. He guaranteed that all 18-year-old school leavers who finished in the top 20% of their class could go to college. This week, to safeguard minority businesses, he proposed a statewide system of registration and regular monitoring.

"This is not the end of affirmative action. This transcends affirmative action," he said.

But during protests last month his office in the state capital Tallahassee was occupied, and the governor caught on camera telling staff to "Kick their asses out". He later agreed to hold consultative meetings to discuss his plans.

At a rally of 4,000 in Miami, a speaker was cheered for telling the governor: "Black folk ain't going back to no damn plantation."

webTitle: Gloves off in Republicans' dirty war

fields.headline: Gloves off in Republicans' dirty war
fields.standfirst:
The US elections: special report

McCain supporters says rattled Bush is using smears and lies to derail rival's bid for the White House
fields.trailText: As the song Signed, Sealed, Delivered blared out of the speakers at George W Bush's last Charleston rally before today's crucial Republican primary, most of the crowd surged towards the candidate. But one man made a beeline for the press podium.
fields.byline: Julian Borger in Charleston, South Carolina
fields.body:
As the song Signed, Sealed, Delivered blared out of the speakers at George W Bush's last Charleston rally before today's crucial Republican primary, most of the crowd surged towards the candidate. But one man made a beeline for the press podium.

"I'm just an ordinary Charleston voter. I'm not from the campaign, but there's something you ought to know about John McCain," he said conspiratorially. He declined to identify himself but promised: "There's a Pulitzer prize in this stuff."

The "stuff" was a complex story which portrayed Mr McCain, the Arizona senator challenging for the Republican presidential nomination, as betraying the interests of his fellow war veterans by secretly supporting rule changes that would have deprived them of health care.

That is a serious allegation in a state where a third of the voters are war veterans, and all the more impressive coming from an ordinary citizen. Strange, then, that minutes later he was seen climbing onto the Bush campaign bus.

The last hours of this Republican primary are turning nasty. Mr Bush, shocked by the scale of Mr McCain's upset victory in New Hampshire, has "gone negative", unleashing a blizzard of advertisements impugning his opponent's integrity. There is mounting evidence that that the nervous Bush camp is also using "dirty tricks" to smear Mr McCain.

Momentum

The reason is clear - the result of today's ballot could determine the Republican nomination, giving the winner momentum to power through the rest of the primaries and, perhaps, to the White House.

Mr Bush, previously the clear frontrunner, never expected to be as threatened as he now is - hence the dubious tactics. These include the mass mailing and emailing of outrageous claims about the McCains' private life by Bush supporters, including an allegation by a professor at the ultra-conservative Bob Jones university that the senator had fathered a string of illegitimate children.

The polls yesterday suggested this aggressive campaign might be working. A Gallup poll carried out for CNN and USA Today showed Mr Bush leading Mr McCain by 52% to 40%. An NBC poll showed the Texas governor six points ahead.

But Mr McCain has a big lead among independents and Democrats, who are per mitted, under South Carolina rules, to take part in today's primary. The McCain camp is hoping they will show up in record numbers, as they did in New Hampshire last month.

But the reformist Republican challenger is facing a withering and well-funded onslaught, in which the most insidious technique is known as "push-polling". This seeks to disseminate harmful information or disinformation about an opponent without identifying its origin. McCain supporters have received hundreds of telephone calls from people asking a series of politically-loaded questions under the guise of conducting a legitimate poll.

Dick Bennett, a political pollster, said that between 10 and 15% of the people he had surveyed had received a negative call, usually about Mr McCain. A woman attending a McCain rally claimed that her 14-year-old son had been told by a "pollster" that Mr McCain was a "cheat, liar and fraud".

Mr Bush has vowed to fire anyone on his campaign using such crude language. His spokesman, Ari Fleischer said a Houston firm linked to Mr Bush's campaign, Voter-Consumer Research, had only called 300 homes for "legitimate research" purposes.

Bruce Ransom, a politics professor at South Carolina's Clemson university said the cruder telephone calls were probably being made by "a collateral organisation - an organisation supporting him, such as a pro-life group working on his behalf".

"Nobody ever admits to doing push-polling - it's like admitting you're a drug abuser," said Darrell West, a political science professor at Brown university.

The ferocity of the Bush campaign in South Carolina has knocked the McCain camp off-balance. It initially issued counter-advertisements accusing the Texas governor of negativism and distortion. But last week, Mr McCain reversed policy, renouncing the use of advertisements targeting Mr Bush's record. He told supporters that his former fellow-inmates from the Vietnamese prisoner-of-war camp where he spent more than five years "would not have been proud of me for running a negative campaign".

But Mr McCain's change of heart may have come too late and has left him unable to respond fully to his rival's attacks. Mr Bush is currently appearing in television commercials accusing his rival of hypo crisy, and expressing his hurt at having been compared to President Clinton - the lowest of blows in Republican politics.

This has influenced public perceptions. In a Gallup opinion poll released yesterday, more South Carolina voters said they thought Mr McCain was attacking Mr Bush unfairly (39%) than the other way round (35%). The percentage of voters saying they have a negative impression of Mr McCain has also climbed significantly.

Showdown in Charleston The candidates face off

McCain

On-the-job experience

A senator for Arizona since 1986

Military experience

The country's best-known war hero: a navy pilot who was shot down over Vietnam and held prisoner in appalling conditions for more than five years

Campaign funding

Raised $36m and has spent $26m

Skeletons in closets

Proudly claims to have "tomcatted" as a young top gun.

Unfaithful to his first wife, Carol. But no evidence of adultery while married to current wife, Cindy. Not a whiff of drugs in the senator's past, but Cindy has admitted to having been addicted to prescription pills

Slogan

I will always tell you the truth

Bush

On-the-job experience

Five years as Texas governor

Military experience

Spent the Vietnam war in Texas, as a pilot in the air national guard

Campaign funding

Raised $70m (a record) and has so far spent $50m (another record)

Skeletons in closets

Admits to once having been "young and irresponsible", womanising and drinking in his pre-political years.

Will not answer questions about drug use before the start of his political career. There is no evidence of his having been unfaithful to his wife, Laura

Slogan

A reformer with results

fields.headline: Mice with Down's syndrome engineered
fields.trailText: Scientists, after breeding laboratory mice genetically engineered to catch cancer, give birth prematurely or develop mad cow disease, have now created a mouse with Down's syndrome.
fields.body:
Scientists, after breeding laboratory mice genetically engineered to catch cancer, give birth prematurely or develop mad cow disease, have now created a mouse with Down's syndrome.

The condition occurs in one in 700 human births, is the commonest inherited chromosome disorder and represents the chief cause of mental retardation. A Down's baby has three copies of chromosome 21, instead of the usual two.

Roger Reeves of Johns Hopkins university told the meeting yesterday that the Down's mice had been bred with three copies of the chromosome - and had the skull and facial hallmarks observed in people with Down's syndrome. Those people have face, skull and brain abnormalities, and often have deficiencies in the immune system, heart, gut and muscles.

The mice were intended as an animal "model" for the study of the syndrome in humans.

"Nobody knows exactly why having too much of a chromosome would lead to the developmental problems you see with Down's syndrome," Dr Reeves said.

"We believe this model will explain that in a way we couldn't before. Is this model good enough to reflect what goes on in humans? Yes, it's about the strongest parallel you can get."

webTitle: Stop feeling bad for eating chocolate - it does you good

fields.headline: Stop feeling bad for eating chocolate - it does you good
fields.body:
Don't feel guilty about the after-dinner mints. Cocoa, the source of chocolate, contains compounds that could help protect against hardening of the arteries.

Researchers from the University of California, Davis, have announced that human trials showed eating chocolate could reduce clotting of the blood cells linked to cardiovascular disease. "With balance and moderation, chocolate can contribute to a healthy diet," said Carl Keen.

Volunteers were fed chocolates while the anti-oxidant capacity of their blood was measured. Anti-oxidants, also found in fresh vegetables, fruit and red wine, scavenge the blood for free radicals linked with cancer and some chronic diseases.

Scientists have already suggested that the fat in chocolate, from cocoa butter, could be beneficial.

Louis Grivetti, from the same university, said that cacao beans were used as medicine by the Olmecs of Mexico in the 16th century to alleviate fever, short breath and faintness of the heart.

Over the 400 following years, manuscripts revealed 100 medicinal uses of chocolate, including an antidote for those suffering from lassitude, apathy and exhaustion, and a sedative for the "over-stimulated".
