webTitle: Three questioned over stabbing of traffic warden

fields.headline: Three questioned over stabbing of traffic warden
fields.trailText: Three men were last night being questioned by police in connection with the stabbing of a traffic warden who was attacked by a motorist after a row over a parking ticket in Southall, London.
fields.body:
Three men were last night being questioned by police in connection with the stabbing of a traffic warden who was attacked by a motorist after a row over a parking ticket in Southall, London.

The 35-year-old warden was stabbed once in the thigh and left lying in a pool of blood on the pavement. He had recorded a car's registration number, but had not issued a ticket to an illegally parked vehicle. As he walked away from the car the driver followed him down the street arguing.

Inderjit Singh, manager of an electrical store opposite the scene, said: "As the warden was taking the number down the driver came out of the car and started shouting and swearing. The warden slowly walked away, but the boy chased him and started kicking him. There was a fight going on and the traffic warden put his hands up, trying to protect himself.

"The driver must have have stabbed him in a fraction of a second because as he ran off I saw the warden's leg pouring with blood."

Mr Singh said that the driver, wearing a black baseball cap, went back to his car and drove away.

Solicitor Ariya Sriharan, who rushed to help the traffic warden, said: "He had been stabbed in the thigh and he was bleeding very heavily. He was lying on the pavement and blood was spurting from his leg.

"I think the knife must have hit an artery. He was very quiet and was obviously in agony."

A police spokesman said the warden was taken to hospital where he was treated for his injury and released.

webTitle: National upsets the form book at awards

fields.headline: National upsets the form book at awards
fields.trailText: It should have been a shoe-in for the might of Disney's The Lion King, but the National Theatre upset the form book yesterday by sweeping the Olivier Awards.
fields.body:
It should have been a shoe-in for the might of Disney's The Lion King, but the National Theatre upset the form book yesterday by sweeping the Olivier Awards.

Trevor Nunn and his experimental ensemble of actors, including Patricia Hodge and Simon Russell Beale, took nine awards and gave critics who branded his regime "conservative and unimaginative" something to think about.

His evening was crowned when he won best director for three plays at the National. "The ensemble has been wonderful," he said. "I've never had so much fun in rehearsals."

The National even showed the West End how it should be done by winning the best musical and best new musical for Leonard Bernstein's Candide and Honk! The Ugly Duckling.

The Lion King, which had been tipped to sweep the board, won just two awards, for best choreographer and costume designer.

Even the triumphant writing team behind Honk! was surprised at the turnaround. "I guess the judges couldn't get tickets for The Lion King," said composer George Stiles.

There was disappointment too for Spend, Spend, Spend, the hit musical about the pools winner Viv Nicholson. It took just two awards, including one for Barbara Dickson as best actress in a musical.

The most rapturous ovation was saved for Peter O'Toole, 67, who picked up the outstanding achievement award from Lord Olivier's widow, Joan Plowright, for his performance in Jeffrey Bernard Is Unwell.

Aware that there might be the faint sound of spinning underground, O'Toole admitted that he and Laurence Olivier were not exactly soulmates.

"We shared a dressing room for Hamlet at the Old Vic and we hit a few snags.

"I was not speechlessly happy about his positioning of the shower. And Larry was less than ecstatic about where I kept the Guinness. I kept the Guinness in the shower."

Who won what at the Oliviers

Best actress Janie Dee for Comic Potential at the Lyric

Best actor Henry Goodman for The Merchant Of Venice at the National Theatre

Outstanding musical production Candide at the National

Outstanding achievement award Peter O'Toole for his role as Jeffrey Bernard in Jeffrey Bernard Is Unwell

Best supporting actor Roger Allam for Money at the National

Best supporting actress Patricia Hodge for Money

Best director Trevor Nunn for Summerfolk, The Merchant of Venice, and Troilus and Cressida, all at the National

Best new musical Honk! The Ugly Duckling, music by George Stiles, book and lyrics by Anthony Drew, at the National

Best actor in a musical Simon Russell Beale for Candide

Best supporting performance in a musical Jenny Galloway for Mamma Mia at the Prince Edward

Best actress in a musical Barbara Dickson for Spend, Spend, Spend at the Piccadilly

Best new opera production

Welsh National Opera's Hansel and Gretel at Sadler's Wells

Outstanding achievement in opera English National Opera for its high standard of production and championing the works of Handel

Best new dance production Nederlands Dans Theater 1's Symphony of Psalms at Sadler's Wells

Outstanding achievement in dance Jiri Kylian for his artistic excellence and outstanding direction of Nederlands Dans Theater 1's season at Sadler's Wells

Best entertainment Defending The Caveman, starring Mark Little, written by Rob Becker, at the Apollo

Best costume designer Julie Taymor for The Lion King at the Lyceum

Best choreographer Garth Fagan for The Lion King

Best new comedy The Memory of Water by Shelagh Stephenson at the Vaudeville

Best set designer Rob Howell for Richard III, RSC at the Savoy, Troilus and Cressida at the National, and the Almeida's Vassa at the Albery

Best lighting designer Mark Henderson for Plenty, Spend, Spend, Spend, Suddenly Last Summer, The Forest, at the National; The RSC's The Lion, The Witch And The Wardrobe, The Real Thing at the Donmar Warehouse; and the Almeida's Vassa

Best new play Goodnight Children Everywhere by Richard Nelson, RSC at The Pit

fields.headline: British GP drowns in Australia
fields.trailText: A British doctor and an Irish colleague have drowned off the east coast of Australia.
fields.body:
A British doctor and an Irish colleague have drowned off the east coast of Australia.

Richard Reynolds, 30, from Halebarns, Greater Manchester, and his friend Susan Clarke, 29, were swept out to sea by a powerful rip tide at North Stradbroke Island, just off the coast from the Queensland capital Brisbane yesterday afternoon.

A friend tried in vain to revive them when they were brought ashore by rescuers. The distraught woman, who raised the alarm after losing sight of them in the water, is receiving counselling, the foreign office said.

"Conditions at the time were fairly rough," a Queensland police spokesman said. "Although it was a fine day, they were the sort of conditions that only an experienced surf swimmer should have taken on."

Dr Reynolds had gone to Australia to work for several months after spending three years in Lancaster training to be a GP, his mother, Sheila Reynolds, a retired GP, said. "He had always wanted to enter medicine and he was planning to settle down in a general practice when he returned to this country." His late father Hubert was also a GP, two of his three older brothers are doctors, and his sister is a nurse.

Another brother, Simon, 40, deputy editor of the Edinburgh Evening News, said: "We are all devastated by the news. He was just a very kind, generous, hard-working bloke. He had wanted to be a GP pretty much all his life."

The two were caught in a rip which swept them away from Main Beach near Point Lookout on North Stradbroke Island. The island, an hour by ferry from Brisbane, is notorious for its unpredictable rips. Locals said eight tourists have been drowned on the island in the past two years.

fields.headline: 'Blunder' over naval vetting
fields.trailText: A navy chief petty officer jailed for passing a top secret document about an alleged threat of an Iraqi anthrax attack to the Sun newspaper should never have been cleared to see classified documents, the security commission says in a report to Tony Blair.
fields.body:
A navy chief petty officer jailed for passing a top secret document about an alleged threat of an Iraqi anthrax attack to the Sun newspaper should never have been cleared to see classified documents, the security commission says in a report to Tony Blair.

Steven Hayden was cleared to see increasingly sensitive information despite a history of financial and personal problems - including years of sexual abuse when he was a child.

The report says that while Hayden was on a night watch in March 1988 he saw a top secret intelligence report on the alleged anthrax threat. He passed it to a Sun journalist and the newspaper subsequently paid him £10,000.

The commission says the way the ministry of defence handled Hayden represented a "clear failure" in personnel security. The MoD admitted that it would have been better if clearance had been denied at the start.

Hayden's senior officers argued that taking away his clearance would make him a security risk since he would become embittered.

The commission says that confidential medical reports on armed forces personnel should be made available to line managers. It also says that MoD security vetters should pay more attention to threats from "cheque-book journalism".

Hayden was sentenced in October 1998 to 12 months in prison for breaching the official secrets act Richard Norton-Taylor

fields.standfirst: Steve Grand  Programmer with designs on artificial intelligence
fields.trailText: Steve Grand is trying to build a glider which will have the imagination of an eagle. He thinks he has already created life of a sort inside a computer, and hundreds of thousands of people agree with him: he wrote Creatures, a complicated simulation of life which was marketed as a game and sold so many copies that there are now more creatures available for adoption on the internet than there are elephants in the world. But he left the company he had co-founded because he is more interested in making life than games, which explains why he was lecturing on the subject at the ICA last week. Like real animals, his creatures are born, breed, must eat or die. But are they alive?
fields.body:
Steve Grand is trying to build a glider which will have the imagination of an eagle. He thinks he has already created life of a sort inside a computer, and hundreds of thousands of people agree with him: he wrote Creatures, a complicated simulation of life which was marketed as a game and sold so many copies that there are now more creatures available for adoption on the internet than there are elephants in the world. But he left the company he had co-founded because he is more interested in making life than games, which explains why he was lecturing on the subject at the ICA last week. Like real animals, his creatures are born, breed, must eat or die. But are they alive?

"I hate that question. But I think it's not unreasonable to say that those creatures are alive. I think of them as things rather than lines of computer code."

Not the least extraordinary thing about him is that he is a programmer who justifies his ideas as "reasonable" instead of "rational". Also, he is 42 but has the enthusiastic and unbattered look of someone about 16, except for greying hair at his temples and a few lines around his eyes. He grew interested in artificial intelligence by accident. "I started out training as a teacher and then realised too late thatI was actually interested in the growth of children's minds and not teaching them. It's a bit like the difference between painting animals and lion taming. So I was penniless; and just before I left college, I spent my girlfriend's life savings on a computer." (They are still married).

He started writing educational software. "In those days, it was all computer aided learning, which I hate. I wrote a series of programs that created worlds in time and space and let children wander around in them. That got me involved in computer games, and I hate computer games, except for flight simulators. So after a while, he wrote Creatures instead. "It was a nine-month project. I started in 1992 - and finished in 1996."

There is a definition of life that says it is a system that persists through metabolism and/or reproduction. Creatures do all that. They learn. They eat. They have emotions, survive, find mates, and evolve.

"But everyone knows there is more to life than sex, and these creatures have only some of the higher characteristics. Especially they have no imagination."

Interesting animals do have imagination, he believes. That is to say, animals more complex than insects, but much less advanced than humans, have an inner model of the world which is different from the outer one. They do not simply respond to stimuli in more or less complex ways.

Of his glider he says: "It will be in a messy, noisy, and dangerous environment. I want it to learn to stay up by taking advantage of updraughts. It will know which way up it is; which way it is facing. It will be able to feel the set of the controls. It will have emotions, needs, drives. It will think crashing is painful and being upside down is uncomfortable."

Whether or not it makes sense to say that such a machine can feel the drives that have been programmed into it, it seems interesting how limited these emotions are, and how narrow a world this glider will perceive if it flies successfully. It will know little of what is on the ground - apparently neither do glider pilots - and it does not worry Steve Grand. "Presumably birds of prey have a world view that is entirely made of updraughts and mice."

fields.headline: Police killing of IRA man 'lawful'
fields.standfirst:
Northern Ireland: special report

Inquest verdict on unarmed terrorist suspect shot in hotel
fields.trailText: An unarmed IRA quartermaster who was shot six times in a hotel room by a police officer was lawfully killed even though the raid by a specialist firearms unit had gone "badly wrong", a coroner's jury ruled yesterday.
fields.body:
An unarmed IRA quartermaster who was shot six times in a hotel room by a police officer was lawfully killed even though the raid by a specialist firearms unit had gone "badly wrong", a coroner's jury ruled yesterday.

The decision was condemned by Sinn Fein and the family of the victim, Diarmuid O'Neill, who died in a hail of bullets fired through a cloud of CS gas by an officer codenamed "Kilo".

Giving evidence from behind a screen, the officer, who worked for Scotland Yard's SO19 unit, said he thought O'Neill, 27, had a weapon and intended to kill him.

Following the verdict, the coroner John Burton said he was unhappy at the way the three week inquest had been conducted. "This is a democratic society. That society has required the police officers to take risks on our behalf. I have subjected them to three weeks' sustained attack without the protection afforded by the criminal court, with no pretence of natural justice and there is nothing that I can do about it. The need to change the law to prevent this is to me overwhelming."

Earlier Dr Burton had angered Michael Mansfield, counsel for O'Neill's family, by telling the jury that a verdict of unlawful killing would make the IRA member seem a martyr and might suggest the bombing campaign he was helping to mastermind was justified.

O'Neill was shot when officer Kilo ran into room 303 of the Glenthorne Road hotel in Hammersmith, west London, on September 23, 1996.

The raid followed a three month surveillance operation on a suspected IRA cell following bombings at Canary Wharf and in Manchester. The SO19 team had discovered six tons of explosives, detonators, and AK47 assault rifles in north London and believed another attack was imminent.

A bugging device was placed in O'Neill's car and the jury, sitting at Kingston crown court, heard him telling an accomplice that any police officer who confronted him would have to be killed.

The hotel raid, however, was a disaster. A duplicate room key did not work and an electronically powered ram battered a hole through the door without opening it, ruining the element of surprise. Ten rounds of CS gas were thrown into the room making it difficult to see.

Officer Kilo denied he had shot O'Neill out of panic. "Through the smoke I saw a figure by the door. I screamed 'show me your hands'. I didn't have good vision. The figure didn't move and said nothing. I couldn't see his hands. I feared for my life."

O'Neill's father, Eoghan, said he would consider appealing against the verdict, or seek a public inquiry. "The police have got away lightly. They were deaf, blind and dumb. They should never have gone in there with the gas."

Sinn Fein policing spokes-man Gerry Kelly said the decision did not surprise anyone in Ireland. "There is no expectation that Irish people alive or dead can achieve justice in British courts.,"

The head of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch, Deputy Assistant Commissioner Alan Fry, said he would review the way specialist operations are conducted.

webTitle: Halifax plans begging letters to clients

fields.headline: Halifax plans begging letters to clients
fields.trailText: Halifax, Britain's largest mortgage lender, will write to more than 200,000 customers every month for a year to convince them to stay with the bank.
fields.body:
Halifax, Britain's largest mortgage lender, will write to more than 200,000 customers every month for a year to convince them to stay with the bank.

The former building society, which is feeling the pressure of competition, hopes to prevent existing customers defecting.

The bank also hopes to woo customers to an internet and telephone bank unveiled yesterday. IF - intelligent finance - aims to attract 500,000 customers in the first year.

Halifax's share of the mortgage market is declining. It once controlled 19% of home loans but last year sold just 6% of all mortgages taken out.

The move to write to Halifax's 2.5m customers is being led by Andy Hornby, the 32-year old head of Halifax's retail operations who joined from Asda last year. Mr Hornby also said he intended to "radically simplify" its mortgage products.

James Crosby, the chief executive, said: "The key is to improve customer retention. We're just contacting people and being in touch, something financial services companies haven't done."

The Halifax's plans pleased the stock market. Despite the fact that profits are holding steady at £1.7bn, Halifax shares surged 73p to 625p, continuing a rise which has added £4bn to the market value of the bank over the last three days. This is good news for the 3m people who still own shares in the bank after its conversion from a building society - although the shares are still worth 149p each less than when the building society demutualised in 1997.

The Halifax has also sought to bolster its board by appointing two younger non-executive directors - including the businessman behind the Carphone Warehouse, Charles Dunstone, 35 - and starting up an internet insurance venture with Peter Wood, the creator of Direct Line, who once earned £42m a year.

Halifax, which yesterday brought forward to 2002 its target for diversifying away from its core mortgage and savings products by 50%, is also preparing to offer banking and insurance facilities to small business customers through its internet ventures.

"All banks' share prices have been knocked by the new world economy. This has to be a display that the dinosaurs are fighting back," said John-Paul Crutchley, banking analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, an investment bank.

fields.headline: Food for thought and Freud
fields.standfirst: Lesley Chamberlain: Writer, reader and cookery enthusiast
fields.trailText: This afternoon Lesley Chamberlain will talk at the Royal Festival Hall, London, about Freud and his impact on religious belief. Hers is a remarkable life which has seen her move from journalism through cookery writing, poverty and school teaching as a single parent, to reincarnation as an expert on Nietzsche and as the wife of Pavel Seifter, the Czech ambassador.
fields.body:
This afternoon Lesley Chamberlain will talk at the Royal Festival Hall, London, about Freud and his impact on religious belief. Hers is a remarkable life which has seen her move from journalism through cookery writing, poverty and school teaching as a single parent, to reincarnation as an expert on Nietzsche and as the wife of Pavel Seifter, the Czech ambassador.

We talked at the ambassador's residence in Hampstead, north London, in the room where Ms Chamberlain now writes, which is large enough to have a grand piano tucked away in an alcove.

"It certainly is a lot easier than being a south London school teacher, which is an outrageously downtrodden life. When we got married I had to go out and get some different clothes: not the clothes that kept me going in a south London garret."

She joined Reuters in 1977 - the alternative was a job teaching Russian and German in Aberystwyth. "If you're a German idealist, where do you take your ideas in the world? I was terribly serious about my work, which I wasn't really teaching. So somehow or other I applied for Reuters. I had never in my life met such a rude lot of people as those who interviewed me. I was so astonished at their rudeness that I got up and offered to go home."

So of course they hired her and sent her to Moscow.

"There are three great shocking things in life: living with someone; having a child; and contact with Soviet Russia. I used to go and sit in the Lenin library and read whatever struck me as interesting. I think that's when I realised I would never get away from my real interests, which were literature and philosophy. I had been working on late 18th century German thought, and when I got to Moscow I found a sort of parody of it plastered up on the streets" - in the political posters that were everywhere before the advertising came.

"I used to really hope that nothing would happen at work so I could go on reading, though I wrote a lot of features. A lot of the work I did in the Lenin library was reading the earliest Russian cookery books in the room reserved for academicians. I was in a community that I felt I belonged to. I used to sit there in the evenings and come out groggy at 10pm with the rest of the brain workers. It was a deeply romantic place from a western point of view."

From this experience came a book on Russian cooking, which is still in print.

She did not want to be a journalist. But she now had a daughter and so stayed with Reuters for seven more years. She left in 1986 to write the books she wanted to. She travelled widely in eastern Europe and wrote a book about her adventures and another cookbook. But by the time the Berlin wall came down and eastern Europe became fashionable, she could no longer afford to travel there.

So she taught in South London for nearly 10 years, writing books that were not published, and articles for small, highbrow magazines. She was rescued by food, the Rough Guide, and Nietzsche.

"I was asked to become a judge in a competition for European food writing. I had this invitation to lunch in Alba, near Turin. I was determined to take it: I raised the money for the plane ticket and bought a guide book. All praise to the Rough Guide because the section on Turin begins with a long guide to Nietzsche. And because I am always afraid of being bored on public occasions, I won't travel without a book, so I took Nietzche's letters from Turin. It was a marvellous experience of food and wine, but best of all was what I was reading, and when I came back, I had the outline of my book clear.

"I had finally returned to where I had wanted to set out from."

Shortly after the book was published, she met her husband. What has she done since marrying him? Worked on her book on Freud.

webTitle: Prescott takes on a spin doctor of his own

fields.headline: Prescott takes on a spin doctor of his own
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: John Prescott, the long-time scourge of news managers in New Labour's Millbank media machine, has finally succumbed to the inevitable - and taken on his own spin doctor.
fields.body:
John Prescott, the long-time scourge of news managers in New Labour's Millbank media machine, has finally succumbed to the inevitable - and taken on his own spin doctor.

Derek Plews, an Ulsterman and a former journalist, will have the task of presenting the deputy prime minister in a more positive light, while trying to steer him clear of the occasional off-the-cuff gaffes which have bemused - and occasionally enraged - his parliamentary colleagues.

Mr Prescott's friends were insisting last night that the decision to appoint 39-year-old Mr Plews had certainly not been forced on the secretary of state for environment, transport and the regions by Downing Street.

Rather, Mr Prescott, who sometimes seems to take pride in being off-message, was said to have taken on Mr Plews himself, to ensure that he was being portrayed positively as one of the senior players at the heart of government.

This week Downing Street strengthened its grip on Mr Prescott's department by sending in the cabinet office minister Lord Falconer, a close friend of Tony Blair, to head a special unit to co-ordinate regional initiatives

However, he will have to report to Mr Prescott, who staged a strong rearguard action to ensure that he remained in command.

Yesterday, another senior Downing Street official was appointed as director of communications at the DETR.

Alun Evans, 41, a career civil servant, is currently working in the department on secondment from Downing Street, where he heads the strategic communications unit.

Before that he was principal private secretary to the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett.

Mr Evans replaces Simon Dugdale, a long-serving government public relations specialist, who left the DETR abruptly last year.

webTitle: Science Museum in talks with Smith as crisis threatens jobs

fields.headline: Science Museum in talks with Smith as crisis threatens jobs
fields.standfirst: Science Museum
fields.trailText: The Science Museum in London is in "crisis talks" with the government over funding, with a cash shortfall threatening jobs, expansion of facilities, and free admission for all.
fields.body:
The Science Museum in London is in "crisis talks" with the government over funding, with a cash shortfall threatening jobs, expansion of facilities, and free admission for all.

The museum administration declined to comment yesterday for fear of jeopardising delicate negotiations with the culture secretary, Chris Smith, and his civil servants.

But one source told the Guardian that, based on the government's grant offer for the next financial year, the institution would face a £4m shortfall - even if it kept its policy of charging for adults.

There are concerns that redundancies might be the only way to bridge the gap.

There was anger that the government was holding back on support for the Science Museum, the national repository of the country's scientific heritage, when it could afford a £32m loan for the Millennium Dome, the source said.

The museum trustees have refused to fix a budget for 2000-01 on the basis of the government's initial proposals, complaining of a lack of clarity over Mr Smith's intentions on free admission.

"There are crisis talks going on with the government daily, trying to sort this out," said another source, adding that the stumbling block was less free admission than grants for the running costs of a huge new extension to the museum due to be unveiled on June 27.

The £50m Wellcome Wing, built with cash from the Wellcome Foundation and the heritage lottery fund, will increase the museum's public space by almost a third and include an IMAX cinema.

One plan had been to use the new attraction as justification to increase the admission charge for adults to £8.50 from £6.90. The trustees would rather scrap the entrance fee altogether, as the government wants - but it is not clear where the money is going to come from.

A spokesman for the department of culture, media and sport said that talks were under way involving all museums, not just the Science Museum.

The minister would make an announcement about "further steps to increase free access to museums" before the end of March, he said.

But nothing could be settled until the government had agreed with customs and excise on museums' VAT status.

After that, it would be up to the museums themselves to decide whether they wanted to charge admission or not.

webTitle: Gang of four guilty of drowning student

fields.headline: Gang of four guilty of drowning student
fields.trailText: Four young men who beat, robbed and kidnapped an A-level student and left him to drown after throwing him off a bridge were convicted of his killing yesterday.
fields.body:
Four young men who beat, robbed and kidnapped an A-level student and left him to drown after throwing him off a bridge were convicted of his killing yesterday.

Jonathan Coles, 18, was pushed into the River Ouse at a beauty spot in Tyringham, Buckinghamshire, early on June 11 last year, a few hours after leaving a nightclub where he had been celebrating a friend's birthday.

Brian Alleyne, 21, Dwayne Dawkins, 20, and Darren Matthews, 17, all of Milton Keynes, were found guilty of Jonathan's murder by an 11-1 jury verdict at Luton crown court. Jason Canepe, 20, of Milton Keynes, was cleared of murder, but had pleaded guilty to manslaughter.

Jonathan's tormentors took his glasses, severely disabling him, and ignored his protests that he could not swim. The court was told the men pushed him over the 25ft high bridge, near Newport Pagnell. According to Dawkins, Matthews punched Jonathan's fingers and prised them away as he tried to cling to the parapet.

As he struggled in the 16ft-deep river, one of the men ran down and shouted: "Go on, go on, you are almost there." His body was found six days later.

When he was killed Jonathan had three exams to go before completing his A-levels at Sir Henry Floyd grammar school in Aylesbury. The youngest of five children, he lived in Wendover, Buckinghamshire, with his parents.

"He was a confident, outgoing young man, with an active social life. He had a promising future. He was not athletic. He wore glasses and was very shortsighted," said William Coker, prosecuting.

On June 10 1999 Jonathan went out with friends to the Empire nightclub in Milton Keynes, leaving at 2am. He left with Stuart Smith and Brett Horton to hail a taxi but became involved in an apparently unprovoked argument.

He was assaulted by a youth who cannot be named for legal reasons, and then as he ran away was chased by others, including the four convicted yesterday. He became separated from his friends and was beaten, punched and kicked.

Bleeding, he flagged a car down but it was Canepe's, containing Alleyne, Dawkins and Matthews, the court heard.

The men went to a house in Gifford Park looking for some other youths whom Jonathan had been with that night and then to a cash machine where they tried to draw money from his empty account, before taking him to Tyringham.

"He could not swim and there is direct evidence that at least two of them knew that," Judge Geoffrey Rivlin said.

"Not the least care was taken to see if he would survive. He was left in the river in a secluded place in the dead of night and no one lifted a finger to help him. They went home, knowing something terrible had happened, and joined a conspiracy of silence and lies."

In evidence Dawkins said: "I cannot swim myself. I knew what he was going through, but I did not do anything."

Alleyne and Matthews were also unanimously convicted of kidnap and robbery. Dawkins had admitted manslaughter but was convicted of murder, as well as kidnapping and robbery. Canepe was convicted of kidnapping but was cleared of robbery during the trial.

Adjourning sentencing for reports, the judge said: "Three of you will be aware that there is only one sentence I can pass." He ordered that Dawkins and Canepe be kept apart from Alleyne and Matthews.

webTitle: Welsh children's home staff jailed for assaults

fields.headline: Welsh children's home staff jailed for assaults
fields.standfirst:
More about the Wales child abuse scandal
The issue explained: Children in care
fields.trailText: Two former senior staff at a south Wales children's home were jailed for a total of 23 years yesterday for sexual assaults on boys in their care.
fields.body:
Two former senior staff at a south Wales children's home were jailed for a total of 23 years yesterday for sexual assaults on boys in their care.

Barrie Alden, 66, former deputy principal of Ty Mawr residential home, near Abergavenny, was sentenced to 15 years after being convicted of 10 charges, including serious sexual assaults.

John Wright, 56, a former housemaster, was jailed for a total of eight years after he was convicted of six charges, including indecent assaults. The two had denied the charges, and were each found not guilty of other charges in a six-week trial at Newport crown court. Judge Thomas Crowther QC said: " Your behaviour showed a pattern of showing favour and care and then abusing that trust."

Alden, from Norwich, and Wright, from Talgarth, Powys, committed the offences on eight boys at the council-run home for vulnerable children from the 1960s to the 1980s. The home was closed in 1991.

The two were arrested in Operation Slight, a police investigation into abuse at children's homes in Gwent. The judge ordered that both must register as sex offenders "indefinitely" on their release.

webTitle: Let me through! I'm a columnist

fields.headline: Let me through! I'm a columnist
fields.trailText: Lost in music
fields.body:
It's the opening night of the capital's all-new Rock nightclub (promotional soundbite: "London's answer to Studio 54"), next to Embankment tube station. No one I know was deemed important enough to be invited and I've managed to acquire only one lonely passport to paradise, so the plan is to initiate conversations with celebs by posing as Don, a forklift truck driver from Oldham who went to school with all four members of All Saints. I've got my "watching the Dukes of Hazzard with Melanie" and "breaking into Gateway with Natalie" anecdotes rehearsed, but first I've got to get past the bouncers.

The scene outside Rock is somewhere between an auction, a confectionery free-for-all where three Curly Wurlys must be distributed between 200 children, and picking teams for playground football. Consequently, my magic leather armband (entry guaranteed) is about as useful as a sheet of toilet paper with "I once shared a cab with the drummer from Sad Cafe" written on it. The head doorman tells us that the guest list is full, and he can only let guests in when a few people leave. Which is true, with one catch: he doesn't let in the plain people at the front of the queue with the wristbands; he lets in the beautiful ones at the back in the Armani suits.

The woman next to me complains to the bouncer that Felicity is waiting inside for her, and she must get in and meet her by the DJ booth; the bouncer ignores her. The woman next to her pleads that she's a personal friend of someone from Hepburn; the bouncer says it doesn't matter who she is, then proceeds to let in the third reserve make-up girl from the Big Breakfast. I half-heartedly mumble something along the lines of "Why do they get in, when we're the ones with the wristbands?"; the bouncer looks at me like's he's wondering how I got out of his nasal cavity on to the pavement so quickly. A bloke in a suit thrusts his preternaturally glamorous girlfriend at the bouncer like a sacrificial offering; the bouncer lets them both in. Drat! I think to myself: if only I hadn't left Cecilia, the It-girl/heiress/celebrity daughter I sometimes hire out for these occasions, in the Met Bar.

I know I could probably talk myself into this place, but a long history of hopeless situations outside clubs has left me scarred and defeated. It's not that I'm no good at bullshitting - I like to consider myself an expert. Just last week, I effortlessly convinced a group of 10 complete strangers that I was Hands McNair, an Afro-Swedish porn director who moved to Hartlepool in order to escape the limelight and pursue a career in Dada toast embroidery, and that one of my companions for the evening was Ken Ramone, the lesser-known brother of Joey and Dee Dee who drew the blueprint for punk, then jacked it all in when he became fanatical about orienteering. But put a bouncer in front of me and it all goes wrong, and memories of being picked last for rugby matches and ambushed outside the CDT block by Grabber "The Grabber" Spencer flood back.

Don doesn't get a chance to make his ligging debut in the end, since, in its attempt to emulate Studio 54, Rock - which, from what I can gather, doesn't have anything to do with rock at all - is already mimicking the New York club's outrageously elitist door policy. As I'm giving up hope after a frankly pathetic 20 minutes of waiting around, a couple of style journalists arrive behind me, and implore Rock's PR representative, who's now turned up at the door, looking flustered, to let them in. "We won't write about it... honest," they say. I begin my hangdog journey home, wondering why you'd invite a journalist to the opening of a club if you didn't want them to write about it, and where the hell I parked my forklift truck.

fields.headline: Memoirs of a teenage Trot
fields.standfirst: In 1984 the miners were on strike, the IRA bombed Brighton's Grand Hotel, and  Gary Younge,  aged 15, joined the revolution. But it couldn't last
fields.trailText: In 1984 the miners were on strike, the IRA bombed Brighton's Grand Hotel, and Gary Younge, aged 15, joined the revolution. But it couldn't last
fields.body:
Between my first kiss and my first A level there came Trotsky. I am sure I would have met him sooner or later, plastered against the wall in a student union bar or on a street corner hiding behind a petition. But he came to me on a sunny day in Hyde Park. It was 1984; the year of the miners' strike, the IRA bombing of the Grand Hotel in Brighton, and Ronald Reagan's victory in the US presidential elections. I was 15 - a self-important teenage vegetarian who felt that all was not quite right with the world.

I had spent most of the day wondering around London with a Socialist Workers Party banner for company, protesting against the visit of the South African president, PW Botha. I had been avoiding the eyes of paper sellers and policemen, when a young man with acne caught me unawares and offered me a copy of Young Socialist. I bought it, read it in less than five minutes - all the articles were basically the same "Thatcher is horrible, miners are great, socialism is even better" - and thought little more about it.

A few weeks later I pulled the paper from the bottom of my bag, wrote to the editor and asked if I could join the revolution with much the same degree of forethought as others in my peer group applied to join fan clubs. I was bored. It was something to do. And there would probably be girls there too, so, who knows, I might even come by a second kiss.

Given the range of anti-social behaviour available to a hormonally besieged adolescent, there were worse things I could have turned my attentions to than the overthrow of capitalism. I would be lying if I said that I was aware of precisely what I was getting into. I knew I was joining some kind of socialist outfit. I suspected it was the younger section of the Labour Party - as it happened it was the youth wing of the Workers Revolutionary Party. This was not a problem for me. After all, if you're going to go into politics at that age you might as well get some cred and join something nobody's ever heard of.

When I discovered they were Trotskyists this did not bother me much either. I didn't really know what Trotskyism was. I scarcely knew who Trotsky was. The leader of the Red Army who had been ousted and later executed in exile by Stalin had, it turned out, left a legacy for those who supported socialism but could not stomach the Soviet Union. I knew him better as Snowball from George Orwell's Animal Farm.

In my naivety I presumed that, since socialism was underpinned by the notion of solidarity, those who believed in it would club together - especially given that they were relatively small in number. I didn't know at the time that there were at least 57 varieties of hard-left party, some with less than 57 members in total. How could I know that there was a significant difference between the Revolutionary Communist League of Britain (RCLB - Maoist) and the Revolutionary Communist Party of Great Britain Marxist-Leninist (RCPGBM-L - pro-Albanian)? In short, I didn't know very much. But then I didn't have to.

The WRP credo was fairly straightforward. Britain in 1984, they believed, was more or less at the same stage as Russia in 1916 - a nation on the brink of revolution. All that was needed to push it over the edge was a general strike. If we could get everyone out together, we could bring the nation to a standstill, form some soviets, replace the police with a workers militia and then Bingo! - capitalism would be dead before you could say Fourth International.

The simplicity of the thesis was a great source of comfort. The party was providing such a comprehensive and unwavering world view that I felt I would never have to work out anything again. It provided a reason for everything that was bad - from the famine in Ethiopia to racist policing - about capitalism. For every problem there was only one solution - revolution. Every issue could be shoehorned into this single transferable analysis, it seemed.

Concerns with details of policy, from taxation to nuclear disarmament, were little more than micromanaging. This sense of self-confidence, bolstered by a similar lack of self-knowledge, lent a distinctly cult-like air to the entire enterprise which, as is the way with cults, I only really became aware of when I'd left. Moreover, the party's uncompromising and often unreasonable stance on most issues dovetailed neatly with the petulant, know-all stage I was going through. If adults ever hit me with the phrase: "You think you've got the answers to everything don't you?" I would think, but never say: "I do actually. Seizing state power from the bourgeoisie and placing it in the hands of the working class as the first step towards a more just world."

I actually pitied those who missed the big picture. I lamented the wasted lives of all the adults who tried to work out their views on individual issues on a case-to-case basis. They were playing dot-to-dot; I had the huge, broad brush. And I was clearly not alone in this. My guess is that there were about 2,000 members, including high-profile actors such as Vanessa Redgrave and Frances de la Tour.

The two main leaders were a Sri Lankan called Mike Banda and a Londoner, Gerry Healy. Their arrival at the microphone during meetings was always met with reverent hush that went beyond the demands of average party discipline. I remember little about Banda's speaking style, but Healy's was unmistakeable. He would shout and scream into the microphone, ranting fluent gibberish. And as he prodded the air with his little finger, his face would get redder and redder until his entire bald head was a small, round pate of scarlet.

Commitment to the party was total. If Britain was about to explode into revolution then it followed that a revolutionary party had to be ready and waiting in the wings. And if the party was to be ready then its members had to be at battle stations at all times, with no excuses and definitely no time off for good behaviour. It meant that everything - births, deaths, marriages, exams, you name it - had to take second place to the preparations under way for the glorious and imminent day when we would not so much inherit the earth as nationalise it, collectivise it and then forbid anyone from inheriting anything ever again.

"The needs of the individual must be subordinated to the needs of the party," chimed the mantra. And it was observed religiously. I spent about three nights a week and at least half the weekend selling papers, attending meetings and organising events.

No birthday, no party, no football match could compete with the demands of the revolution; you simply did not blow out workers' power for a disco or a date. I had a purpose in my life that felt both beyond and above school and parents. Raised under the strictures of Caribbean matriarchy, I felt little need for more discipline in my life but I welcomed my first dalliance with a tradition possessing its own flag (red) and its own anthem (The Internationale). And it was exciting too.

Unusually for the hard left, its youth base was greater among the working class than among students. While there was a general tone of seriousness that affected everyone in the party, life in the Young Socialists - most, on average, only a few years older than me - was a rowdy kind of fun. Not only did it provide an instant group of friends but also a limitless amount of things to do with them. We went to the picket lines in Nottingham, to conference in Blackpool and countless demonstrations in London, all of which meant coach trips and the underage beer-drinking and snogging that went with them.

The older members, however, were apparently a different story. The demands of party work undoubtedly played havoc with their personal lives. A mixture of teachers, council workers and actors, they were, for the most part, a humourless bunch of drones who wore a harried and haggard look which suggested that Armaggedon, not revolution, was just around the corner. They were socially disabled - incapable of talking about anything else but the party because they had long since shut everything else out of their lives.

The fact that nobody else wanted a general strike not only confirmed our cult status, it gave us a messianic edge. Our detractors were either capitalist lackeys - like the TUC - or just plain chicken, like the Communist party, which did actually want a general strike, but only for 24 hours. Thanks to our superior analysis, we were in the possession of a valuable and exclusive truth - the world, as we knew it, was about to end.

However implausible this may seem now, it did not strike me as a completely unreasonable proposition then. Where class conflict is concerned, 1984 was a spectacular year. With bloody pitched battles between the police and pickets at Orgreave, courts sequestrating union assets, bailiffs removing Greenham Common protesters and showdowns brewing between leftwing councils and the government over rate-capping, the idea that parliamentary democracy was in crisis and preferred foul means rather than fair to crush dissent did not seem a fanciful one.

Nor did it seem odd to suggest that, if the miners were going to win, they were going to need the help of other unions. But then I was at infants' school when the miners brought down a Conservative government and had not yet been born when students brought central London to a standstill over Vietnam. I had no idea that I was witnessing a violent but regular episode of the never-ending bump and grind between labour and capital. I would soon learn that, while 1984 may have been spectacular, it was by no means exceptional.

It was nothing like Russia in 1916. For the following year saw not revolutionary upheaval but the biggest defeat the British working class had suffered in over half a century. And by the time the miners went back to work, my revolutionary career was already winding to a close. I can trace the beginning of its demise to a meeting in the party headquarters in Clapham. A red-faced Healy was raging on at the top of his voice and I was watching the clock. I had told my mum I would be back by 6pm. It was already five, I was an hour and a half from home and Healy had only just started.

He finally wound up an hour later and, as I made for the door, a burly man stopped me and told me they weren't letting anyone out during the interval. I explained the situation, but he wouldn't budge. I asked if I could just go out and call home and tell my mum where I was. "The phones around here are bugged, comrade," he said sternly.

"I don't give a shit if they find out that I'm going to be late home," I said. But the doorman was not for moving. I got back at 10pm in tears and in trouble. A few weeks later I went on a weekend school trip to Howarth as part of my A-level English syllabus on Wuthering Heights. When I returned, my mother, who had just about had it with the revolution by this time, told me that the party had been ringing constantly. I called the WRP organiser and received a vicious tongue-lashing.

"You can't just piss off to Yorkshire without telling anyone," he screamed. "Don't you know that the state are picking people up left, right and centre at a time of crisis like this?" "Like who?" I asked. "Never mind who," he shouted, and then delivered a stern lecture on party discipline. By this stage I had had enough. The miners were trickling back to work, the revolution was clearly not around the corner and I was sick of grown-ups playing soldiers. The security blanket of intellectual certainty I had felt when I had joined no longer comforted me. Any suggestion that there was more to politics than class struggle - like race and gender - was met with fierce rebuke.

I was 16 and had already outgrown the revolution. When I did turn up I started to feel harassed. When I refused to go paper-selling one weekend I was accused of being an MI5 agent; when I expressed a casual interest in Fidel Castro I was told that I only liked him because he was black. I started making excuses for not going to meetings and concentrated more on my school work instead. I had been taking an evening course in French and had entered myself for A-levels. I told the WRP that I would need some time off party work for revision. My request was refused. That was the final straw.

I knew that if I didn't intervene at this stage my mother would, and I would rather have taken on the self-appointed representatives of the working class than her any day. I called when I knew the local organiser would be out and told his flatmate I was leaving the party. I didn't sleep that night, so tortured was I by the portentousness of my actions. The next day he came round and lectured me again on party discipline.

Revolutions don't come without hard work, and hard work needed sacrifice, he said. He sounded like a clergyman trying to save a marriage. But he might as well have been talking to the stack of pamphlets that was always sitting in his car. My mind was made up. "I'm leaving," I told him. "Nobody leaves this party, Gary," he said. "They either get kicked out or they die." Given that I am still here to tell the tale, I can only presume that I was expelled in my absence. I had as few qualms about leaving as I did about joining. My nine months in the WRP were a great political and personal education.

In time I would learn the damage of dogma, the power of rhetoric and the fact that politics is not just an extracurricular activity. I discovered that, when it came to debate, shades of grey suited me better than black and white, but that complexity should never be used as an excuse for inaction. And while I never joined a Trotskyist party again, my experience did not leave me with a vitriolic disdain for Trotskyists - although I do think that Trotsky himself would be rather disappointed by many of those who struggle in his name.

In any case, five months after I was "kicked out", Healy would suffer the same fate. Accused by Banda of "cruel and systematic debauchery" after abusing his influence to coerce younger, female party members into bed, and secretly buying himself a £15,000 BMW with party funds, his expulsion made "Reds in the bed" tabloid headlines. Banda's attack coincided with a 180-degree shift in the party's politics, towards Labour under Neil Kinnock. The Redgraves sided with Healy and split to form a separate group, the Marxist party. The hard left had just sprouted a 58th variety.

In my naivety I presumed that, since socialism was underpinned by the notion of solidarity, those who believed in it would club together - especially given that they were relatively small in number. I didn't know at the time that there were at least 57 varieties of hard-left party, some with less than 57 members in total. How could I know that there was a significant difference between the Revolutionary Communist League of Britain (RCLB - Maoist) and the Revolutionary Communist Party of Great Britain Marxist-Leninist (RCPGBM-L - pro-Albanian)? In short, I didn't know very much. But then I didn't have to. The WRP credo was fairly straightforward. Britain in 1984, they believed, was more or less at the same stage as Russia in 1916 - a nation on the brink of revolution. All that was needed to push it over the edge was a general strike. If we could get everyone out together, we could bring the nation to a standstill, form some soviets, replace the police with a workers militia and then Bingo! - capitalism would be dead before you could say Fourth International. The simplicity of the thesis was a great source of comfort. The party was providing such a comprehensive and unwavering world view that I felt I would never have to work out anything again. It provided a reason for everything that was bad - from the famine in Ethiopia to racist policing - about capitalism. For every problem there was only one solution - revolution. Every issue could be shoehorned into this single transferable analysis, it seemed. Concerns with details of policy, from taxation to nuclear disarmament, were little more than micromanaging. This sense of self-confidence, bolstered by a similar lack of self-knowledge, lent a distinctly cult-like air to the entire enterprise which, as is the way with cults, I only really became aware of when I'd left. Moreover, the party's uncompromising and often unreasonable stance on most issues dovetailed neatly with the petulant, know-all stage I was going through. If adults ever hit me with the phrase: "You think you've got the answers to everything don't you?" I would think, but never say: "I do actually. Seizing state power from the bourgeoisie and placing it in the hands of the working class as the first step towards a more just world." I actually pitied those who missed the big picture. I lamented the wasted lives of all the adults who tried to work out their views on individual issues on a case-to-case basis. They were playing dot-to-dot; I had the huge, broad brush. And I was clearly not alone in this. My guess is that there were about 2,000 members, including high-profile actors such as Vanessa Redgrave and Frances de la Tour. The two main leaders were a Sri Lankan called Mike Banda and a Londoner, Gerry Healy. Their arrival at the microphone during meetings was always met with reverent hush that went beyond the demands of average party discipline. I remember little about Banda's speaking style, but Healy's was unmistakeable. He would shout and scream into the microphone, ranting fluent gibberish. And as he prodded the air with his little finger, his face would get redder and redder until his entire bald head was a small, round pate of scarlet. Commitment to the party was total. If Britain was about to explode into revolution then it followed that a revolutionary party had to be ready and waiting in the wings. And if the party was to be ready then its members had to be at battle stations at all times, with no excuses and definitely no time off for good behaviour. It meant that everything - births, deaths, marriages, exams, you name it - had to take second place to the preparations under way for the glorious and imminent day when we would not so much inherit the earth as nationalise it, collectivise it and then forbid anyone from inheriting anything ever again. "The needs of the individual must be subordinated to the needs of the party," chimed the mantra. And it was observed religiously. I spent about three nights a week and at least half the weekend selling papers, attending meetings and organising events. No birthday, no party, no football match could compete with the demands of the revolution; you simply did not blow out workers' power for a disco or a date. I had a purpose in my life that felt both beyond and above school and parents. Raised under the strictures of Caribbean matriarchy, I felt little need for more discipline in my life but I welcomed my first dalliance with a tradition possessing its own flag (red) and its own anthem (The Internationale). And it was exciting too. Unusually for the hard left, its youth base was greater among the working class than among students. While there was a general tone of seriousness that affected everyone in the party, life in the Young Socialists - most, on average, only a few years older than me - was a rowdy kind of fun. Not only did it provide an instant group of friends but also a limitless amount of things to do with them. We went to the picket lines in Nottingham, to conference in Blackpool and countless demonstrations in London, all of which meant coach trips and the underage beer-drinking and snogging that went with them. The older members, however, were apparently a different story. The demands of party work undoubtedly played havoc with their personal lives. A mixture of teachers, council workers and actors, they were, for the most part, a humourless bunch of drones who wore a harried and haggard look which suggested that Armaggedon, not revolution, was just around the corner. They were socially disabled - incapable of talking about anything else but the party because they had long since shut everything else out of their lives. The fact that nobody else wanted a general strike not only confirmed our cult status, it gave us a messianic edge. Our detractors were either capitalist lackeys - like the TUC - or just plain chicken, like the Communist party, which did actually want a general strike, but only for 24 hours. Thanks to our superior analysis, we were in the possession of a valuable and exclusive truth - the world, as we knew it, was about to end. However implausible this may seem now, it did not strike me as a completely unreasonable proposition then. Where class conflict is concerned, 1984 was a spectacular year. With bloody pitched battles between the police and pickets at Orgreave, courts sequestrating union assets, bailiffs removing Greenham Common protesters and showdowns brewing between leftwing councils and the government over rate-capping, the idea that parliamentary democracy was in crisis and preferred foul means rather than fair to crush dissent did not seem a fanciful one. Nor did it seem odd to suggest that, if the miners were going to win, they were going to need the help of other unions. But then I was at infants' school when the miners brought down a Conservative government and had not yet been born when students brought central London to a standstill over Vietnam. I had no idea that I was witnessing a violent but regular episode of the never-ending bump and grind between labour and capital. I would soon learn that, while 1984 may have been spectacular, it was by no means exceptional. It was nothing like Russia in 1916. For the following year saw not revolutionary upheaval but the biggest defeat the British working class had suffered in over half a century. And by the time the miners went back to work, my revolutionary career was already winding to a close. I can trace the beginning of its demise to a meeting in the party headquarters in Clapham. A red-faced Healy was raging on at the top of his voice and I was watching the clock. I had told my mum I would be back by 6pm. It was already five, I was an hour and a half from home and Healy had only just started. He finally wound up an hour later and, as I made for the door, a burly man stopped me and told me they weren't letting anyone out during the interval. I explained the situation, but he wouldn't budge. I asked if I could just go out and call home and tell my mum where I was. "The phones around here are bugged, comrade," he said sternly. "I don't give a shit if they find out that I'm going to be late home," I said. But the doorman was not for moving. I got back at 10pm in tears and in trouble. A few weeks later I went on a weekend school trip to Howarth as part of my A-level English syllabus on Wuthering Heights. When I returned, my mother, who had just about had it with the revolution by this time, told me that the party had been ringing constantly. I called the WRP organiser and received a vicious tongue-lashing. "You can't just piss off to Yorkshire without telling anyone," he screamed. "Don't you know that the state are picking people up left, right and centre at a time of crisis like this?" "Like who?" I asked. "Never mind who," he shouted, and then delivered a stern lecture on party discipline. By this stage I had had enough. The miners were trickling back to work, the revolution was clearly not around the corner and I was sick of grown-ups playing soldiers. The security blanket of intellectual certainty I had felt when I had joined no longer comforted me. Any suggestion that there was more to politics than class struggle - like race and gender - was met with fierce rebuke. I was 16 and had already outgrown the revolution. When I did turn up I started to feel harassed. When I refused to go paper-selling one weekend I was accused of being an MI5 agent; when I expressed a casual interest in Fidel Castro I was told that I only liked him because he was black. I started making excuses for not going to meetings and concentrated more on my school work instead. I had been taking an evening course in French and had entered myself for A-levels. I told the WRP that I would need some time off party work for revision. My request was refused. That was the final straw. I knew that if I didn't intervene at this stage my mother would, and I would rather have taken on the self-appointed representatives of the working class than her any day. I called when I knew the local organiser would be out and told his flatmate I was leaving the party. I didn't sleep that night, so tortured was I by the portentousness of my actions. The next day he came round and lectured me again on party discipline. Revolutions don't come without hard work, and hard work needed sacrifice, he said. He sounded like a clergyman trying to save a marriage. But he might as well have been talking to the stack of pamphlets that was always sitting in his car. My mind was made up. "I'm leaving," I told him. "Nobody leaves this party, Gary," he said. "They either get kicked out or they die." Given that I am still here to tell the tale, I can only presume that I was expelled in my absence. I had as few qualms about leaving as I did about joining. My nine months in the WRP were a great political and personal education. In time I would learn the damage of dogma, the power of rhetoric and the fact that politics is not just an extracurricular activity. I discovered that, when it came to debate, shades of grey suited me better than black and white, but that complexity should never be used as an excuse for inaction. And while I never joined a Trotskyist party again, my experience did not leave me with a vitriolic disdain for Trotskyists - although I do think that Trotsky himself would be rather disappointed by many of those who struggle in his name. In any case, five months after I was "kicked out", Healy would suffer the same fate. Accused by Banda of "cruel and systematic debauchery" after abusing his influence to coerce younger, female party members into bed, and secretly buying himself a £15,000 BMW with party funds, his expulsion made "Reds in the bed" tabloid headlines. Banda's attack coincided with a 180-degree shift in the party's politics, towards Labour under Neil Kinnock. The Redgraves sided with Healy and split to form a separate group, the Marxist party. The hard left had just sprouted a 58th variety.

fields.headline: Stepping out of the shadows
fields.standfirst: Gwen John's art has survived thanks to the fame of her brother Augustus. Now it's time to recognise her as a unique talent, says  Maev Kennedy
fields.trailText: Gwen John's art has survived thanks to the fame of her brother Augustus. Now it's time to recognise her as a unique talent, says Maev Kennedy
fields.body:
One can't help feeling that Augustus John's friends must have been heartily sick of his sister Gwen. From their days in the Slade art school to the desolate end of her short life, Augustus insisted that they include Gwen in their exhibitions, admire her spare little drawings, her oils of cats and girls as wan and bony as herself, even buy them.

Once Augustus roared that Gwen was the greater artist and one day everyone would recognise it. How pleased he would have been if this had happened is a moot point. It is a source of extreme irritation to Angus Stewart, who is curating the largest exhibition of Gwen's work since the Barbican in 1985 - over 100 works will be shown in London at the Spring Olympia antiques fair - that the two are measured against one another.

"It's degrading to any woman only to see her in the context of a man in her life, but it is a particularly wrong way to view Gwen John. She is singular, of herself," he says. At the same time, he concedes that without being lit by the blaze of Augustus, Gwen would have vanished into the darkness.

Most of the pieces for the exhibition come from private, anonymous loans. In a few cases, Stewart recognised unsigned Gwen John works whose owners did not realise what they possessed. "It is quite possible that her name would now only be known to a handful of appreciative collectors. She is a major figure in British art, but she probably would never have been that without his reputation keeping hers alive."

Life had thrown Augustus and Gwen together early. She was eight and he was six when their mother died, leaving them and two siblings with a father who was incapable of showing love. Gwen inherited his lean looks and his fierce silences.

Augustus was the roaring boy, full of black depressions and huge glees, swaggering around Montparnasse, painting like a man possessed, trailing women and babies in his wake, leaving every home - just ahead of the bailiff - knee-deep in tattered drawings. She was thin, ascetic, shy but stubborn. The force of her personality terrified her family, friends and the few men and women with whom she fell violently, self-destructively, in love. A neighbour in Paris, Louise Roche, said: "She treated her body as though she were its executioner."

He painted vibrant portraits of the great and good, and rolled about on divans with aristocratic ladies. She painted street children and servant girls, using less and less colour, until nothing remained except foggy greys, greens and yellows. He left his flourishing signature on thousands of works, and earned (and spent) a small fortune from them. She frequently left pieces half finished or unsigned, and gave away more than she sold.

Gwen John has been taken up by a feminist strand of art revisionism, which views women in terms of what they might have achieved had they not been hamstrung by oppressive men. The villains, in this version of her life, are Augustus John and the sculptor Rodin. She wrote literally thousands of letters to Rodin, moved home to live near him at Meudon, just outside Paris, and lived mainly in a hut near his old home for the 22 years she outlived him. He wrote her a handful of sometimes harsh letters (some are being lent for the exhibition by the Gwen John archive at the National Library of Wales), complained that her sexual demands wasted his energy, rationed her visits, used her as a model but attached a more beautiful head, and sometimes barred the door against her. Significantly, she drove the object of her last attachment, a woman Christian missionary, to almost identical attempts to restrain her.

As part of the research for this exhibition, Stewart visited the Musée Rodin in Paris. They showed him a self-portrait that Gwen had given Rodin, but declined to loan it. "It was pitiful," he says. "The drawing was put away in a cupboard, unframed. It is a beautiful drawing, but she has the most abject, beseeching expression on her face. She is holding something in her hands; I believe it is one of her letters, which she is begging Rodin to accept."

Stewart refuses to blame Rodin. Mostly he was patient towards her, and supportive of her work, while Gwen was obsessive and demanding. "A stalker, that is just what she was. I do not think he was interested in her. That is not a crime." He thinks the damage had already been done by someone, or something, else. "Look at the earlier self- portraits, and the early drawings of her by Augustus. She's no conventional beauty, but she's a handsome, fashionably dressed, confident young woman. The contrast with the later images of her is appalling."

He thinks something happened in one of the more extraordinary episodes in her life, when Augustus's wife Ida and mistress Dorelia - originally a friend of Gwen's, and the subject of her most imposing portraits - were both tormented by the effort to live in a menage à trois plus children. Gwen persuaded Dorelia, in 1903, to walk to Rome. They almost starved and froze, and only reached Toulouse. Dorelia came out of it more confident, and briefly broke from the charmed circle, taking a younger lover. Gwen came out of it, Stewart believes, somehow permanently damaged.

The Gwen John show will be seen beside a collection of pots by Dame Lucie Rie, also curated by Stewart, who sees many parallels in the women's deliberate paring down of form and colour, until only an essence and a restrained but powerful sensuousness remained.

In September 1939 Gwen decided she had to see the sea again. She took the train from Paris to Dieppe, where she collapsed in the street. She may have starved herself - she had repeatedly fasted to the point of collapse over the previous decades. Two weeks later she died in the town hospital, and was presumably buried in a pauper's grave, which is now lost. "One cannot explain Gwen John away," Stewart says. "No matter whether you think her good, bad or indifferent, there isn't anyone else like her. She is, and that's it."

 Gwen John and Lucie Rie is at Spring Olympia, London W14 (0171-370 8212), from Tuesday.
