webTitle: The Girl, the Bad and the Ugly

fields.headline: The Girl, the Bad and the Ugly
fields.standfirst: The Dollars movies introduced the spaghetti westerns decades ago, so why are we still fascinated by them?  Lucy O'Brien  meets the artist who created The Woman With No Name, while  Vera Rule (below) talks to Christopher Frayling about his new biography of Sergio Leone
fields.trailText: The Dollars movies introduced the spaghetti westerns decades ago, so why are we still fascinated by them? Lucy O'Brien meets the artist who created The Woman With No Name, while Vera Rule talks to Christopher Frayling about his new biography of Sergio Leone
fields.body:
Two years ago I heard about a group of American women who were all called Linda. They were agitated that the name was becoming less common, so they decided to hold Lindaland conventions. That made me think, what would my Linderland be like?" says artist and former punk musician Linder Sterling.

Her forthcoming exhibition, The Return of Linderland, details that world, drawing on the films of Sergio Leone and the myth of the western cowboy for inspiration. With the help of three prosthetics technicians, she will transform herself into a young Clint Eastwood and, with a cast of local Manchester lads, reproduce scenes from Leone films. These will be freeze-framed and added to a show that includes a short film in which images of modern cowboys and country and western line-dancers merge with those of young men in her north Manchester community, and 12 foot cinematic diptychs that capture the drama of Leone, with attention to the detail of a gun, a face, or someone's shoe.

"I find glorious parallels between Leone's portrayal of the heroic and the malign with that of legal and illegal activity in north Manchester - or 'Gunchester'," says Linder. "Think of it as Lowry with guns."

Linder has always opted for confrontation. In the late 70s she dressed in raw meat and a black dildo, and sang love songs in avant punk band Ludus. Combining pop art collage with punk anarchy, she juxtaposed images of hardcore porn with pictures from Woman's Realm and Factory album sleeves. Her graphic montage for the Buzzcocks' Orgasm Addict record cover, for instance, depicting a "glamour" nude with a household iron for a head and her nipples replaced with gleaming teeth, has become a feminist classic.

By the late 80s she had given up music to concentrate on visual art. In the early 90s she documented the solo tours of her former lover Morrissey in a book of photographs called Morrissey Shot. Then in 1997 she put on a one-woman show What Did You Do in the Punk War, Mummy? at London's Cleveland Gallery - complete with Ludus album cover The Seduction, which features a woman's hips dressed in sexy fishnet stockings, belt and sanitary towel. Soon after that she filled a room in a disused school in Widnes with 42 tonnes of salt - "a preserving, purging installation piece" - that paved the way for the creation of Linderland.

For this exhibition Linder casts herself as the Woman with no Name, invoking the spirit of Ann Lee, the charismatic founder of the 18th-century Shaker movement, an illiterate working-class Manchester woman who was persecuted by the authorities and to some extent written out of history.

"More and more I think that what is important is what is not included - the discard, the invisible - this is where the clues to truth hide," says Linder. In her show young lads and grizzled country line dancers create their own temporary celebrity and become Linderland superstars. "People who usually feel anonymous or ignored will be named and elevated to gallery status. I am making work which lots of different people can relate to - dismantling the status of art."

In Linderland there will also be a Shaker-inspired line-dancing performance piece on Saddleworth moor. Line dancing has always fascinated her. "It echoes punk in that it's always in obscure clubs and people make their own clothes. Men and women sit at sewing machines to get their image together. There's no Armani, Nike or Gap - all labels are banished." Linder has a great belief in the pragmatic DIY process of art, something that stems from her childhood.

Born in Liverpool in 1954 into an Irish working-class family, her mother was a hospital cleaner, her father a builder. Her parents go ballroom dancing six nights a week ("my mum's always sewing sequins on something"), and have an innate ability to make things. "Part of me is very grounded and earthy. Almost mundane - get the bricks and the cement," says Linder.

Unsurprisingly, she gives short shrift to the "culture of irony" in Brit pop art. She may be dressed up as a cowboy, but she isn't kitsch. "I'm bored by the whole materialist culture of irony that happened back in the 90s. All that stuff seems so 20th century now, self-serving and contemptuous of its audience."

She created some of the most enduring images of punk, yet argues that "shock" artists like Damien Hirst and Tracey Emin are not punk's natural descendants. "The legacy of punk has bred a lot of envy in people who'd like to be pretenders to punk's throne. Punk was never funded and never subsidised. Also, we trusted no one," she asserts. Linderland is a place that's highly unfashionable; it's about "faith and politics and community, a world where the terrain is harsh and people are volatile, but deep down they're concerned with real choices of survival."

Up north, Linder is mapping out her own territory.

'Sergio looked at Clint Eastwood and saw a block of marble'
Location: a lounge for design dons in the Royal College of Art, central London. Grey-clothed eminences drift back to class after lunch, leaving the college rector, Christopher Frayling, enthusing about finding, near Almeria in Spain, not just the foundations of the bridge dynamited in Sergio Leone's Duck, You Sucker, a spaghetti western now known only unto true devotees, but gun emplacements dug for its stars, James Coburn and Rod Steiger. Oh, and 15 miles north of Monument Valley in Arizona, he spotted the remains of the brick arch from which Charles Bronson's "brother" was hanged in Once Upon a Time in the West...

There are respectable reasons for all this fan talk. Frayling's biography of Leone, Something To Do With Death, is released next month, and FilmFour is running a season featuring Leone's Clint Eastwood movies.

Frayling first saw A Fistful of Dollars, then on belated release in Britain, one afternoon at the Odeon, Cambridge, after the 1967 May ball, which ended in a row with his girlfriend, followed by a bout of blokeish gloom. He was cheered up and turned on by the movie. That bad attitudinousness! That foul cigar butt! The western hero as a logo, The Man With No Name as a brand name, his gunhand filling the widescreen frame, all action and image projection and no inner life. Everything a lad in a post-girl mood could want.

Perhaps the crucial line in Frayling's biog is Leone's confession that at 14 he couldn't join the Italian resistance during the second world war because his mamma wouldn't let him. But there is also a waspish account of why he cast Eastwood as Fistful's mysterious hero. "The story is told that when Michelangelo was asked what he had seen in one particular block of marble, which he chose among hundreds of others, he replied that he saw Moses," Leone said. "I would offer the same answer to the question why did I choose Clint Eastwood, only backwards_ What I saw, simply, was a block of marble. And that was what I wanted."

Frayling converted his reaction to A Fistful of Dollars and its follow-ups into a culture studies tome on spaghetti westerns in the 70s, seriously valuing Leone when his films were B-rated in the US and Britain. He delved into the archaeology of Italian pop cinema and found Leone's father had been a director of silent sword-and- sandal epics. Frayling left a copy of the book at Sergio Leone's office, full of info on Papa that was new to Leone Jr. They met at the maestro's request in a London hotel in 1982 and then regularly to talk until Leone's death in 1989, so this first biography of Leone has been decades in the making.

Frayling obviously still relishes what Leone created: the western as a Catholic, Latin, Mediterranean carnival, alluding to the Sicilian and Neapolitan puppet plays Leone knew, in which the pretensions of chivalry are mocked and tall, noble heroes come to the same end in the dust as picaresque clowns. (Leone's gun battles, Frayling points out, aren't stand-up duels. They circle around arenas: bullfighting dances of death.) The screen was Leone's means of apprehending the world and his way of expressing it.

Artists need a landscape of the imagination. It doesn't have to be real: what the Japanese call "landscapes of our dreams" (for example, Paris as imagined by MGM) may well have greater power. Leone's "landscape of dreams" was the west. He adored the western, for which there was a worldwide demand unsatisfied since Hollywood circa 1960 demoted the genre to television series, rather than big-screen production. In Fistful, Leone dodgily borrowed a plot from Kurosawa's samurai adventure Yojimbo (itself swiped from Dashiell Hammett's comic novel of Montana corruption, Red Harvest) and shot it as a western. He quoted the westerns he knew by heart, their physical world and significant scenes magnified, transformed through the lens of his own culture. Not to mention the yellow Almerian skies under which spags were cheaply shot, with - as Frayling discovered - actors pissing behind rocks for lack of facilities.

Frayling believes Leone's visceral grasp of imagery, the way he put together Ennio Morricone's music, sun and shadow, made him an artist of collages - the preferred surrealist technique. (He once saw a surrealist painting by De Chirico that Leone bought the year he made The Good, the Bad and the Ugly: high-contrast light on a colonnade and on a cow-catchered western locomotive - the whole movie on a small canvas.) That made Leone, in Baudrillard's description, the first postmodernist director, "the first to understand the hall of mirrors within the contemporary culture of quotations".

Although Leone is not at present in critical favour, especially in his native land, the original movie brats of the Lucas-Spielberg-Carpenter generation venerated him and paid onscreen tribute. (Frayling will soon stage an exhibition on the spags in the scholarly Gene Autry museum in Los Angeles, taking pasta right into the heartland of the red-meat western: he's really chuffed about that.) Tarantino or John Woo's chief choice for any climax of conflict is the Mexican stand- off, Leone-style. And movie Tex-Mex as we know it was very much Leone's invention, the duster coats, the cantina and church, the snorts of burros. Frayling's students, he notes, "get" Leone immediately.

It's not all style, Frayling insists: Leone had content, too. Not necessarily intellectual content - there was not much in the pronouncements of his festival-attending auteur phase. But as a story-teller, he was Scheherazade-class, could raise millions for a project just on his prolonged description of its opening shot punctuated with draws on his Havana cigar. And regard how he stocked his horizon-width screens with clutter of some character, with his passion for the handmade object. He encouraged designer Carlo Simi to build western towns stoutly, one reusing mighty logs from Orson Welles's Falstaff: they stand even now. He borrowed real museum weaponry (anachronistic, but great-looking) for his wars. He was in the David Lean league for trains onscreen. Leone was a spectacularist - the west as amphitheatre show. Tortillas and circuses.

The coffee's cold, college admin awaits, Frayling has to go. Leone, he remarks on his way out, was only 60 when he died. Juvenile for a maker of westerns. We briefly imagine Leone living to oversee the TV mini-series he concocted about a Colt custom-made for Clint Eastwood and then passed hand to hand across the west. Fairytales for adults, what Leone always wanted to make. They wouldn't shoot it in Almeria now. They'd locate in the US south-west, maybe do exteriors down around Durango, locales busting a gut to resemble the west Leone imagined into being 35 years ago. Frayling recalls how Leone flew a minion to Utah for a sample of sand so he could colour-match a wall in an interior in Cinecitta.

Wow. That's heroic untruth. The essence of movies. We're at the college front door. Remember, says Frayling, shaking hands, print the legend.

fields.bodyText: Two years ago I heard about a group of American women who were all called Linda. They were agitated that the name was becoming less common, so they decided to hold Lindaland conventions. That made me think, what would my Linderland be like?" says artist and former punk musician Linder Sterling. Her forthcoming exhibition, The Return of Linderland, details that world, drawing on the films of Sergio Leone and the myth of the western cowboy for inspiration. With the help of three prosthetics technicians, she will transform herself into a young Clint Eastwood and, with a cast of local Manchester lads, reproduce scenes from Leone films. These will be freeze-framed and added to a show that includes a short film in which images of modern cowboys and country and western line-dancers merge with those of young men in her north Manchester community, and 12 foot cinematic diptychs that capture the drama of Leone, with attention to the detail of a gun, a face, or someone's shoe. "I find glorious parallels between Leone's portrayal of the heroic and the malign with that of legal and illegal activity in north Manchester - or 'Gunchester'," says Linder. "Think of it as Lowry with guns." Linder has always opted for confrontation. In the late 70s she dressed in raw meat and a black dildo, and sang love songs in avant punk band Ludus. Combining pop art collage with punk anarchy, she juxtaposed images of hardcore porn with pictures from Woman's Realm and Factory album sleeves. Her graphic montage for the Buzzcocks' Orgasm Addict record cover, for instance, depicting a "glamour" nude with a household iron for a head and her nipples replaced with gleaming teeth, has become a feminist classic. By the late 80s she had given up music to concentrate on visual art. In the early 90s she documented the solo tours of her former lover Morrissey in a book of photographs called Morrissey Shot. Then in 1997 she put on a one-woman show What Did You Do in the Punk War, Mummy? at London's Cleveland Gallery - complete with Ludus album cover The Seduction, which features a woman's hips dressed in sexy fishnet stockings, belt and sanitary towel. Soon after that she filled a room in a disused school in Widnes with 42 tonnes of salt - "a preserving, purging installation piece" - that paved the way for the creation of Linderland. For this exhibition Linder casts herself as the Woman with no Name, invoking the spirit of Ann Lee, the charismatic founder of the 18th-century Shaker movement, an illiterate working-class Manchester woman who was persecuted by the authorities and to some extent written out of history. "More and more I think that what is important is what is not included - the discard, the invisible - this is where the clues to truth hide," says Linder. In her show young lads and grizzled country line dancers create their own temporary celebrity and become Linderland superstars. "People who usually feel anonymous or ignored will be named and elevated to gallery status. I am making work which lots of different people can relate to - dismantling the status of art." In Linderland there will also be a Shaker-inspired line-dancing performance piece on Saddleworth moor. Line dancing has always fascinated her. "It echoes punk in that it's always in obscure clubs and people make their own clothes. Men and women sit at sewing machines to get their image together. There's no Armani, Nike or Gap - all labels are banished." Linder has a great belief in the pragmatic DIY process of art, something that stems from her childhood. Born in Liverpool in 1954 into an Irish working-class family, her mother was a hospital cleaner, her father a builder. Her parents go ballroom dancing six nights a week ("my mum's always sewing sequins on something"), and have an innate ability to make things. "Part of me is very grounded and earthy. Almost mundane - get the bricks and the cement," says Linder. Unsurprisingly, she gives short shrift to the "culture of irony" in Brit pop art. She may be dressed up as a cowboy, but she isn't kitsch. "I'm bored by the whole materialist culture of irony that happened back in the 90s. All that stuff seems so 20th century now, self-serving and contemptuous of its audience." She created some of the most enduring images of punk, yet argues that "shock" artists like Damien Hirst and Tracey Emin are not punk's natural descendants. "The legacy of punk has bred a lot of envy in people who'd like to be pretenders to punk's throne. Punk was never funded and never subsidised. Also, we trusted no one," she asserts. Linderland is a place that's highly unfashionable; it's about "faith and politics and community, a world where the terrain is harsh and people are volatile, but deep down they're concerned with real choices of survival." Up north, Linder is mapping out her own territory. 'Sergio looked at Clint Eastwood and saw a block of marble' Location: a lounge for design dons in the Royal College of Art, central London. Grey-clothed eminences drift back to class after lunch, leaving the college rector, Christopher Frayling, enthusing about finding, near Almeria in Spain, not just the foundations of the bridge dynamited in Sergio Leone's Duck, You Sucker, a spaghetti western now known only unto true devotees, but gun emplacements dug for its stars, James Coburn and Rod Steiger. Oh, and 15 miles north of Monument Valley in Arizona, he spotted the remains of the brick arch from which Charles Bronson's "brother" was hanged in Once Upon a Time in the West... There are respectable reasons for all this fan talk. Frayling's biography of Leone, Something To Do With Death, is released next month, and FilmFour is running a season featuring Leone's Clint Eastwood movies. Frayling first saw A Fistful of Dollars, then on belated release in Britain, one afternoon at the Odeon, Cambridge, after the 1967 May ball, which ended in a row with his girlfriend, followed by a bout of blokeish gloom. He was cheered up and turned on by the movie. That bad attitudinousness! That foul cigar butt! The western hero as a logo, The Man With No Name as a brand name, his gunhand filling the widescreen frame, all action and image projection and no inner life. Everything a lad in a post-girl mood could want. Perhaps the crucial line in Frayling's biog is Leone's confession that at 14 he couldn't join the Italian resistance during the second world war because his mamma wouldn't let him. But there is also a waspish account of why he cast Eastwood as Fistful's mysterious hero. "The story is told that when Michelangelo was asked what he had seen in one particular block of marble, which he chose among hundreds of others, he replied that he saw Moses," Leone said. "I would offer the same answer to the question why did I choose Clint Eastwood, only backwards_ What I saw, simply, was a block of marble. And that was what I wanted." webTitle: It's not the peace that counts, it's the winning

fields.headline: It's not the peace that counts, it's the winning
fields.standfirst: Simon Hoggart's Diary
fields.trailText: The joy of panto | Ikea rage
fields.body:
In the wake of this awful week, we'll be told again that the people of Northern Ireland yearn for peace. Why, we will be asked by various bien pensants, can't the politicians not get their heads together and give them what they crave? As I keep saying, it's nonsense. The people of Northern Ireland yearn for victory. Over 32 years there have been innumerable elections, for Stormont, Westminster, Europe and local councils, all carried out with great fairness. There is a free market in votes, and if the electorate wanted peace, they could choose it. They prefer not to.

 We've just finished the script for our local panto, Snow White. It'll be performed in April, which isn't as silly as it sounds, since it's after Christmas that people have time on their hands. There is a national shortage of dwarfs, and last year commercial pantos were having to import them from Belgium. This isn't a problem for us, since we simply use full-sized people. Titchy, the lead dwarf, is over six feet tall. For one happy moment, I thought we were going to have one of the school's black mums as Snow White, though it didn't work out. The joy of a panto is that it's all under your control. You're not stuck with what Rodgers & Hammerstein or Harold Pinter decreed.

The church authorities have turned over the hall to the school, which means now that they have no right to vet the script. This has led to problems in the past, such as the following exchange. First witch: "Where' s the Fairy Godmother?" Second witch: "She's in bed with the dreaded lurgy." Third witch: "Oh, I dunno, I quite like Italian men myself." This was finally allowed if we added: "No, silly, it means that she's ill."

We have made liberal use of David Letterman's lists of "things which sound dirty but aren't really, such as 'frosting the doughnut' and 'jumping the turnstile', plus hoary old favourites such as, Greengrocer: "Would you like to squeeze my plums?" Nigel: "I don't think that will be necessary." Kids love double entendres, even when they only get one of them.

 Our daughter's Ikea chest of drawers collapsed again this week. It was her own silly fault; she'd been putting clothes in it, T-shirts, tights, sweaters, that sort of thing, and of course it can't take the strain. Ikea really does puzzle me. I sometimes think that it must be responsible for more failed marriages than money problems or adultery.

You get those so-called instruction leaflets - no words, because that would require a dozen languages - in which it's quite impossible to tell the difference between the 0.75cm grommet and the 0.82cm grommet, so you put the short one in the wrong hole, and the longer one won't go in the right hole, by which time the short ones are stuck and can't be removed, but it doesn't matter because you know that there are exactly 32 Philips screws in the tiny plastic packet. Inevitably, the one that has rolled under the floorboards was vital, and if you want to replace it you have to go back to Ikea, and if you are very very lucky, the spare might arrive in six weeks, during which time piles of flimsy chipboard are spread all over your bedroom. When you finally do get the thing up, it sways in the draught from the window.

Yet Ikea is incredibly popular. My brother lives a mile or so away from the north London branch, and reports that one Saturday the queue to get into the already full car park stretched down the slip road back on to the North Circular - half an hour before the shop opened. (Of course the fact that it's almost impossible to find anything, and even harder to check it out, means that cars have to spend hours there.)

Alan Clark quoted the chief whip's lip-curling remark about Michael Heseltine: "A man who has bought all his own furniture." If the upper classes inherit theirs, and the middle classes buy it, only the wretched of the earth have to assemble it.

#149; I must confess a fondness for Posh 'n' Becks jokes, even though many of them are just Irish jokes or Sun reader jokes with the words "Irish" and "Sun reader" crossed out, and "David Beckham" written in. For example, Becks decides to go riding. Watched by an admiring Posh, he vaults nimbly on to the horse, which suddenly begins to buck alarmingly. She gets more and more anxious as he hangs on for dear life, finally clinging to the horse's neck. Just before it pitches him to the ground, the supermarket manager comes out and switches it off.

Or: Becks puts on a balaclava and goes to rob a bank. "You'll never get away with this, David Beckham," says the clerk. "How did you know who I am?" he asks. "You've sawn the wrong end off your shotgun."

Of course, you have to feel a twinge of sympathy. Being rich is only some consolation for being humiliated day after day. I sometimes wonder why it is. Possibly it's a release; we can tell all the jokes that would be banned if they were about ethnic minorities. Or maybe it's that we think they're a pair of self-obsessed drama queens with far too much money. Or it could be the androgynous air that clings to both of them, and which he has vainly tried to shake off - the sarong is over but the malady lingers on. Meanwhile, what did Becks say when Posh blew lovingly in his ear? "Thanks for the refill, darling."

 Thanks for the many nostalgic letters about the north-west. My favourite came from Peter Johnston of Bolton, who tells me that Wigan folk are alleged to be obsessed by pies. Wigan jokes often concern people who go on holiday with suitcases containing only pies. One chap goes to the Costa Brava and realises he's forgotten the gravy. So he knocks on the next hotel room door and asks: "Hast any Bisto?"

"Clear off, you dago," comes the reply.

But this pie obsession is no myth. Mr Johnston encloses "a sublimely bathetic cutting", as he puts it, from last week's Wigan Observer. It describes the closure of Pooles Pies, "one of Wigan's oldest and best-known pie companies", after the parent company went into liquidation. Poole's had a chain of pie stores in the town. The story continues in heart-breaking vein: "The closure is a huge shock to customers, who continued rattling the doors of the darkened shops in disbelief on Tuesday, as word spread of the firm's demise."

 Have you noticed how every organisation these days has to have its own mini-mission statement, the more banal and meaningless the better? It's as if the Guardian printed a proud slogan on the front page every day, "Bringing articles to Britain."

Alan Cornell of Plymouth points out that they nearly all begin with a present participle. Last week he spotted on the side of a Transco van: "Piping gas for you". "What else should they be doing?" he asks. Often, especially in higher education, they try to whip up a degree of fake excitement for their otherwise staid institution. De Montfort University declares that it is "Setting new challenges, creating new opportunities". (You can always tell how daft they are if the opposite would be self-evidently ridiculous, as in: "Resting on our laurels, closing life's doors".)

And now the department of the environment puts a little wreath at the bottom of all its official statements, bizarrely captioned: "Investor in People". (Why not "Ignoring the public", which might be a little closer?)

All contributions welcome.

webTitle: Livingstone to challenge rules of London mayoral race

fields.headline: Livingstone to challenge rules of London mayoral race
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone was last night preparing a litany of formal challenges to the running of Labour's London mayoral selection contest as speculation grew that his main rival Frank Dobson has narrowly won the nomination to be the party's official candidate on May 4.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone was last night preparing a litany of formal challenges to the running of Labour's London mayoral selection contest as speculation grew that his main rival Frank Dobson has narrowly won the nomination to be the party's official candidate on May 4.

Although Labour and Downing Street officials insisted that even cabinet ministers were being kept in the dark about the result, there were growing signs that Labour's complicated electoral college system may have saved the day for Tony Blair's candidate, even as the ballot results piled up for Mr Livingstone.

With the formal announcement of the winner due early tomorrow afternoon, Labour's Millbank headquarters yesterday contacted the Dobson campaign team to discuss possible joint arrangements for Sunday and Monday, though no such approach was made to the Livingstone camp.

However, returns from affiliated trade unions - the latest being the public services giant, Unison - are still showing commanding majorities for the former Greater London council leader, and there were still doubts among some officials that Mr Dobson had picked up the 36%-plus he needs from individual Labour members to win.

The Labour hierarchy has been taking no chances. It was alleged yesterday that one MP who recently switched support to Mr Dobson had done so after discussions with the prime minister about a possible peerage.

Unison members yesterday delivered a four-to-one majority for Mr Livingstone giving the Brent East MP a 69% share, against 17% for Mr Dobson and 14% for Glenda Jack son - this is worth 6% of the electoral college,

That result reflects the pattern in all the union ballots, where Mr Livingstone has taken between 60% and 90%.

Only two unions, which decided not to ballot, the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union and the ISTC steel union, have backed Mr Dobson. The former health secretary has won two ballots narrowly, held by the Fabian Society and the Labour Zionist group Poale Zion.

In his submission to the Labour party and the scrutineers, Unity Security Balloting, Mr Livingstone will call for the votes of all those affiliated organisations which failed to ballot to be excluded from the count.

fields.headline: The last word on   Hope
fields.standfirst: If it were not for hope, the heart would break - Thomas Fuller
fields.trailText: If it were not for hope, the heart would break - Thomas Fuller
fields.body:
To the people of Northern Ireland, anxiously watching as their tragic past keeps its grip on their future, the saying in Proverbs painfully applies: "Hope deferred maketh the heart sick." For them, as for people seeking asylum in our free rich country so that they can have the life denied them in their unfree and impoverished homelands, hope - for peace, for opportunity, for a new life - is their chief possession. It is hard to bear the thought of their disappointment when their hope is denied at last.

It is taken for a truism that hope is essential to the business of living. What would it be to have no hopes, to believe that things only get worse, to expect failure and anticipate defeat? That is scarcely a life. In good times, say those who approve of optimism, hope is a prompt to yet better things; in bad times it is a comfort, because it sustains the idea of relief or rescue, of reward or at least justice at last. Even at the very worst, when we accept that hopes deceive, we recognise that they nevertheless provide "an agreeable route", as la Rochefoucauld put it, "to the end of our lives".

But there are always those who disagree. History, they say, shows that dark nights have often cost mankind less pain than false dawns. The deceitfulness of hope gives it a bad name; Euripides observed that for 10,000 men there are 10,000 hopes, but very few are realised. It offers lies as truth, and traps people in vain pursuits, which lead them on to greater disillusionments later. "Just as dumb creatures are snared by food, human beings would not be caught unless they had a nibble of hope," Petronius remarked.

Hope - the cynics continue - is distorting; it makes what is genuinely ugly and bad in life appear no more than a temporary screen for what is beautiful and good. It is therefore allied to illusion: "One day everything will be well, that is our hope," said Voltaire; "today everything is fine, that is our illusion."

The fact that hope always applies to the future makes it a cheaply purchased, endlessly renewable commodity - the latter because as old hopes die, new ones can be raised in their place as swiftly and easily as thought. But is a life of false hope, or mere hope, or nothing but hope, a finer and nobler thing than a life squarely based on facing realities, and knowing them for what they are? "Hope is the worst of evils," Nietzsche famously said, "for it prolongs the torment of man."

It might be argued that cynics start from the wrong premise. They observe the human propensity to daydream and fantasise, to cling to vain hopes in the face of overwhelming contrary evidence, to nurture unrealistic expectations and ambitions. They fail to recognise that out of this compost sometimes grows surprising blossoms of novelty and success. Most of what has moved the world onwards began as a hope; all of what has moved it backwards has involved the death of hopes.

On the tough view that interprets hope as a weakness rather than a virtue, what we have to embrace is truth. But the only indisputable truth about the human condition, say hope's defenders, is that we can suffer, and that we shall die. The rest is for us to create.

What would we make of ourselves without hope? We could adopt the posture of nihilism: but that is a life worse than death. For some, indeed, death is hope's only alternative. Albert Camus identified philosophy's central question as: "Shall I commit suicide?" for if the answer is "No", the implication is that there are things worth hoping for.

Cynics object to treating hope as a virtue because it rarely bears fruit. But that, say hope's defenders, is to see things upside down. Hope is a virtue independent of its realisations; it is an intrinsic value, an end in itself, allied to courage and imagination, a positive attitude full of possibility and aspiration. For that reason you discover more about a person when you learn about his hopes than when you count his achievements, for the best of what we are lies in what we hope to be.

fields.headline: Child prodigies
fields.trailText: Hall of infamy
fields.body:
The news this week that a six-year-old, Justin Chapman, had enrolled at the University of Rochester, NY, to study ancient world history makes him the youngest known child to go to university. As ever in precocious genius stories, we are told how Justin can play intellectual ball with the big guys and how his mum has to hold the heavy university doors open for him.

Ruth Lawrence, at 13, got a first in maths at Oxford in the 80s, became Britain's youngest graduate and captured - and swiftly exhausted - the public's attention.Then we had Sufiah Yusof, 12 (maths, Oxford again), a four-year-old data processor from Delhi, a nine-year-old, same city, who corrected his mum's income tax accounts at the age of three and went on to discover (on paper) the smallest atomic particle and predict earthquakes from statistical probability.

While we have to accept that giftedness exists, the matters of a) whether it is to be celebrated or dreaded and b) how much of it is the construct of pushy parents, remain open. What is less debatable is that, whether geniuses by nature or nurture, these children tend to grow from unhappy, frustrated infant to unhappy, frustrated adult. Parents often say it is the child who dictates the pace, but this can merely be exploiting a child's desire to please its mater and pater.

The same parents are always quick to point out how well adjusted and socialised are their home-schooled or hot-housed offspring, that they not only get on with folk of all ages but with their peers. But the real give away is when Justin Chapman goes to a Halloween party in fancy dress. Who does he go as? A Pokémon character? Thomas the Tank Engine? No, Socrates.

That's scary, and not in the Halloween sense, rather because of the fact that his mother must have let him do this. Of course it ended in tears when no one recognised him. He had to go as someone less intellectually rigorous.

What is most depressing about child geniuses is that their precocity is half baked, manifested in mechanistic pursuits: maths, classics and chess. Mathematicians tend to reach a creative peak between the ages of 18 and 21. So it could be argued that being conversant with the subject at 12, when retirement cuts in at 18, is less notable than the headlines make it seem.

It's natural for parents to want their child to do better than they did, but this becomes a middle-class obsession. Playing Mozart to your foetus, tapping out Dickens to it in Morse code and addressing it in French do not suggest fostering of cleverness so much as incubation of stupidity. The desire for five-year-olds to be able to demonstrate Cartesian principles has for many decades led people to enrol at Pennsylvania's institute for the achievement of human potential for its "multiply your baby's intelligence" course, where four-month-old babies are exposed to flash cards of orchids complete with Latin names.

How ironic that people yearning for their children to become clever resort to fatuous exercises, as if nuggets of knowledge will coalesce into the wisdom, perception and emotional focus required to avoid becoming a geeky child genius. Rather than ask if a child is knowledgeable, parents concerned for its future should be asking, "Is my child sufficiently naughty/insolent/ wilful?" To any three-year-old who informs you that the Earth weighs 6.6 sextillion tons, the correct answer should be: "Really, and do you know all the words to 'I'm a Little Teapot?'"

fields.headline: Karsten Solheim
fields.standfirst: The man who put the ping into golf's best-selling club
fields.trailText: Golf's great innovator, Karsten Solheim, who has died aged 88, was the man who invented the Ping putter, the single best-selling club in the history of the game. It was a considerable achievement, but one that was far from the most significant in this remarkable man's career.
fields.body:
Golf's great innovator, Karsten Solheim, who has died aged 88, was the man who invented the Ping putter, the single best-selling club in the history of the game. It was a considerable achievement, but one that was far from the most significant in this remarkable man's career.

Many of the great breakthroughs in sport have come about by accident. Solheim sat down and, having identified the problem, applied logic and technology to it; because he was also a genius in his infinite capacity for taking pains, he solved it.

The putter was the classic example. Although Solheim did not begin playing until he was 45, he quickly became proficient in the long game. But he felt he was being held back by his putting, and that the problem was exacerbated by the putters then in use. Typically, the putter head would twist at impact, particularly if the putt was struck off-centre, sending the ball off-line, despite the best efforts of the player.

So Solheim came up with the concept of heel-and-toe weighting, which reduced twisting and gave his putters a relatively huge "sweet spot"- the area on the club face which gave the best results. The first models made a resounding p-i-n-g when the ball was struck, hence the name of his company.

They were not, at first, successful. Golfers found it difficult to accept that such an odd-looking instrument could be effective. But in 1967, Julius Boros, twice a US Open champion, won the Phoenix Open with a Ping putter and said: "It looks like a bunch of nuts and bolts welded together, but the ball goes into the hole." Since then, more than 1,800 tournaments have been won by a player wielding a Ping putter, and any professional winning a major tour with one receives a gold-plated replica. Severiano Ballesteros has the record, with 45; Nick Faldo has 26.

But the putter was only part of Solheim's story. The son of a Norwegian shoemaker, he trained as a flight research engineer before becoming a mechanical design engineer with General Electric, working on sophisticated radar and guidance systems. It was only natural that he should diversify into making irons, the instruments for golf's guidance systems.

Like his putters, they looked odd at first, but, by creating the concept of perimeter weighting, Solheim again produced a larger sweet spot, and, with it, a club that was much more forgiving of a bad shot. They made the game more fun for almost everyone and, although they sold in their millions, it was the simple fact that they were so obviously a superior product that gave Solheim the most satisfaction. "I only want to make a better golf club," he said.

A modest man, he could be roused to real enthusiasm by anyone approaching him with congratulations on his clubs. He went from a one-man garage industry to an annual place in the Forbes 400 list of the richest companies in America; in 1988, he went to the White House to be presented with the president's "E" award for export expansion by Ronald Reagan.

Through his commercial success, Solheim was able to be active in large-scale charitable works. He was a major sponsor of women's professional golf and created, in 1990, the Solheim Cup, the women's equivalent of the Ryder Cup, the latest edition of which will be played for at Loch Lomond in October.

He died of complications resulting from progressive Parkinson's disease, and is survived by his wife Louise, three sons and a daughter.

Karsten Solheim, engineer and golf patron, born September 15 1911; died February 16 2000

fields.headline: Hsieh Ping-ying
fields.standfirst: A woman's struggle for freedom in China
fields.trailText: Hsieh Ping-ying, who has died in San Francisco aged 93 (or 96 according to other sources), was a Chinese writer whose autobiography, first published in 1936, epitomised the revolutionary changes in her native land and the struggle of Chinese women to break free from the shackles of bound feet, arranged marriages and economic dependence.
fields.body:
Hsieh Ping-ying, who has died in San Francisco aged 93 (or 96 according to other sources), was a Chinese writer whose autobiography, first published in 1936, epitomised the revolutionary changes in her native land and the struggle of Chinese women to break free from the shackles of bound feet, arranged marriages and economic dependence.

The Struggles Of A Girl Soldier was first translated into English in 1943, and reprinted in 1986 as the Autobiography Of A Chinese Girl. Written in a simple and direct style, it briefly evokes a carefree childhood which was suddenly interrupted by Hsieh Ping- ying's first fight with her mother over the awful ritual of foot-binding. As she damped the bandages, her mother explained: "I must bind your feet because I love you. If I do not bind your feet, I shall not be doing the right thing by you. You must realise that a girl with huge feet will never be accepted by a husband."

The story may have helped create some of the outpourings of today's Chinese women writers, such as Adeline Yen Ma or Zhang Rong, but the condition and struggles it describes were infinitely harder for women in the early years of the 20th century.

Hsieh Ping-ying continued to fight against her traditionalist mother and, most unusually for the time, was allowed to go to school, where she immediately unbound her feet. Supported by her brother (who was soon to die of TB), she went on to the famous Hunan Normal School for Girls, where one of her classmates was Ding Ling, later also a prominent writer.

As the great northern expedition, a joint military force formed from the Chinese Communist party and the Kuomintang, led by Chiang Kai-shek, moved northwards through China against the warlords, Hsieh Ping-ying, then threatened by an arranged marriage, volunteered for the Wuchang Central Political and Military School, which offered training for girl propagandists to work with women, peasants and workers in the wake of the military advance.

Yet in 1927, after she had only served a few months, Chiang Kai-shek turned upon his communist allies, killing them in their thousands. Anyone suspected of agitating among workers and peasants, an activity that ran counter to the interests of the Kuomintang's industrialist and land-owner supporters, was in danger of execution.

Forced to return to the parental home, Hsieh Ping-ying once again faced an arranged marriage, but escaped into schoolteaching and, occasionally, suicidal despair. She was arrested, imprisoned and released; the autobiography ends with a description of her arrival in Shanghai, "like a wandering leaf in the autumn".

Hsieh Ping-ying's wanderings did not end there. She studied at Peking university, travelled to Japan - while still pursued by government agents - and in 1949 fled to Taiwan. In the 1970s, she moved to America, where her three surviving children live. She published much besides her autobiography - including short stories, travel prose and her first War Diary (1928) with a subsequent version published in 1937 - but it is as a Chinese girl soldier of the 1920s that she remains best known.

fields.standfirst:
A former British soldier in Belfast puts forward his solution to Ulster's impasse

Northern Ireland: special report

fields.body:
"The kids are clearing, boss," Corporal Lewis shouted at me. I was 50 yards down the road trying to persuade a foreign camera team to get permission from our HQ before filming soldiers on the street corner. I turned my back on the TV crew and ran briskly to my patrol. We had been doing our duty, standing between Protestant and Catholic children on the Crumlin Road as they made their way home after school. These were the "Lollipop" patrols. In this our third day into the new term, the Catholic children had been pelting us with bottles and stones for over half an hour. More than usual, we thought, and this meant they wanted to draw us into the area ready for a gunman. We stood our ground.

"Take cover," I shouted. Moments later the children cleared completely, and we knew something was about to happen. The soldiers pressed themselves more closely into the tarmac. Four shots broke the menacing silence: Corporal Lewis and another soldier were hit, one in the thigh the other in the arm. Just a few inches of body showing around the corner and the gunman had got them.

I remember the blood running down the road; the sense of desperation, calling up the armoured ambulance and having to wait; the shouting and the feverish attempts at stopping the blood pumping out of his main artery. Now there wasn't a child to be seen. They had done their bit. We stopped the bleeding, the crash crew arrived at last. Our mates were sped to the Royal Victoria Hospital to live another day. One lost his leg.

The year was 1972. We had arrived in Belfast with the 1st Battalion the Light Infantry on "Bloody Friday", the IRA's answer to "Bloody Sunday" a few months before: nine civilians killed and 130 injured on one day. Our training had been in riot control but now we were plunged into a vicious shooting war with the Provisional IRA. Two months on, three soldiers had died and 15 had been seriously wounded. Two more were to die before the tour ended.

Standing on the corner after this incident, I struggled to grasp the enormity of what I was witnessing. This was not a street in some foreign land. The houses were similar to those we lived in. The children had been able to swear at us in our own language. This was not a strange enemy neighbourhood, but a war within our own country. Coming from the mainland, I could only wonder what we had done to deserve so much hatred and violence. Civil violence doesn't come from nowhere. It is a last resort by desperate people. Why had the rulers of this land not acted to create reconciliation centuries ago? Why was the British army so hated by the people it had come to protect in 1969?

As we ended our Lollipop patrol that day we crossed the Crumlin Road back into the Shankhill area. We headed back to our company base, three derelict houses in Leopold Street. We were entering an "orange" area. The locals here were friendly, for the moment at least. We could relax our guard.

"Had a bit of trouble with those Fenian bastards today, did yer?" retorted a UDA man on guard outside an illegal bar, dressed in his combat jacket. I wasn't inclined to answer, despite the Union flag flying beside the doorway. I knew, as all the soldiers did, that somehow their claim to be loyal to the crown of England was a little bit hollow. It wasn't quite the same as our loyalty; one day they might be firing at us.

The soldiers in my platoon told stories of a previous tour in 1971, when Protestant machine gun bullets had rained down on them. These people who called themselves loyalists and stood behind the Union Jack were seeking to kill British soldiers. When the Troubles started in 1969, the battalion had been on the streets to protect the mainly Catholic nationalist population from Protestant extremism. They were heralded as saviours. This was the real reason we had been called in to soldier in this strange land. Not, as some imagined, to pick a fight with the IRA. Had we been duped into taking sides and fighting the loyalists' battle for them? What had changed in three years?

Today I see the self-righteousness of the loyalist leadership, claiming British standards and British support. Of course, they seem to say, we have no guns, real democrats don't need guns. When in 1969 we saw the Protestant oppression, the B Specials freely discriminating against Catholics, where was the British moderation and tolerance then? When one side of the political divide has power over a minority, they clearly have no need to resort to weapons.

On the mainland we have a natural suspicion of people who take up arms instead of talking. The unionists play this card for all it is worth. The mainland British have learned to compromise and accommodate opposing views, so that desperation doesn't develop. Somehow in Ulster this wise way of governing by consent has not been followed. Instead over many years the unionist majority has continued to flaunt sectarian dominance and to treat Catholics with disrespect and institutional prejudice.

So now we see the collapse of the Good Friday agreement. Unionists insist they can stand on the moral high ground. They have no arms. They believe they are clean. But are they really? Are Sinn Fein and the IRA in the wrong? Some say the IRA has no more weapons than gangs in any of the large cities in the US. So what's the big deal? You would be forgiven for thinking that, whatever the IRA did, the unionists would continue to view Sinn Fein as not as truly democratic as themselves. Whatever Sinn Fein does, the unionists would probably be unhappy to govern with them.

So what is the solution to this impasse? Being able to say sorry must surely play a part. The British have apologised for their actions in Ireland in the 19th century during the potato famine. When we recognise our own faults, we are more likely to forgive the faults of others. The unionists don't seem to be able to forgive, because they think their own position is blameless. Instinctively we, on this side of the sea, know that this is not the case.

As a former soldier, with several tours under my belt, I have experienced the fear and hatred from both sides. I am convinced that the only way out of the spiral of hatred and revenge between the two communities is forgiveness. Fighting for "our" rights must be replaced by seeking to understand the point of view of others, and acknowledging that one side does not have the monopoly of moral purity. Using religious labels is not the answer, but Christian actions might be.

So is the government being duped again into taking the unionist line? It certainly could be seen that way. The issue is not just guns; it's about giving a minority a proper stake in government and society. If this were done, violence on all sides will probably become irrelevant.

Captain Richard Beath served in Ulster between 1972 and 1977

webTitle: The cold war's tasty legacy - cannelloni and croissants

fields.headline: The cold war's tasty legacy - cannelloni and croissants
fields.trailText: You could almost hear the flourish down the phone line.
fields.body:
You could almost hear the flourish down the phone line.

" Buon giorno, " declared a confident voice. Lovingly stressing the vowels, it went on to name one of Berlin's more fashionable Italian lunch spots.

" Buon giorno, " I replied. " Volevo prenotare per due persone alle dodici quarantacinque. "

There was an appalled silence in response to my request for a table.

" Was ?" came the reply. " Er ... Sprechen Sie Deutsch ?"

In Berlin the demand for Italian waiters long ago outstripped the supply. The only qualifications you now need are olive skin tones and a way with a pepper grinder.

The capital of Germany is awash with French patisseries, Argentine steak houses and Spanish tapas bars. But when I tried to get a taste of wurst in the trendy area round the Hackescher Höfe, the only place I found serving good old German sausage was an Irish pub.

Native cuisine is generally served up only at the extreme ends of the Berlin gastronomic scale. It is either exquisitely presented in £50-a-head restaurants, or found simmering menacingly on fat-drenched hotplates in snack bars.

The same is true in London, of course. If you want a steak and kidney pie, you either go to a greasy spoon or to a top restaurant. But the difference is that Berliners, like other Germans, are heirs to a much richer food culture than the British.

Germany has superb wines and beers, some of the best bread in Europe, and a cuisine with a much wider repertoire than is generally recognised. Yet it seems that restaurant-goers in Berlin want fusilli in a walnut pesto sauce, and nothing else will do.

The central paradox of this city is that, for almost half a century, it was both isolated and cosmopolitan. The western part was marooned in a hostile sea of communism, while the east was treated differently to the rest of the old East Germany. At the same time, the whole city was occupied by foreign troops. As a result, what you get is a familiarity with foreign influences blended with a desire to absorb more.

This desire is not universal. It wears particularly thin in east Berlin, where residents are usually keener to welcome a new trattoria than an incoming immigrant family. Nevertheless, the overall mood of the city is more xenophile than xenophobic.

The explosion in the number of foreign restaurants is one symptom. Another is the fondness for using foreign words and phrases for everything from shop names to advertising. Posters, especially for cultural events featuring foreign artists, often make little or no concession to the fact that most of their readers are German.

It is an odd situation to discover in the capital of a country whose rampant nationalism was the curse of 20th-century Europe. But then that is a ghost which Germans in general, and Berliners in particular, would like to lay to rest forever.

fields.headline: Iran's reformers scent victory
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: Reformist candidates in Iran proclaimed themselves sure of victory over their conservative rivals yesterday in a parliamentary election that could usher in a new era of democracy and change.
fields.body:
Reformist candidates in Iran proclaimed themselves sure of victory over their conservative rivals yesterday in a parliamentary election that could usher in a new era of democracy and change.

Official results are some days away, but large numbers of Iranians cast ballots in favour of President Mohammed Khatami's ticket, which is committed to crafting an Islamic system that is also democratic and could serve as a model for the wider Muslim world.

Due to a heavy turnout, voting was extended for two hours. Some polling stations even ran out of ballot papers.

The reformers had portrayed the contest as a referendum on the Khatami presidency and its ambitious programme to create a true civil society. That strategy has apparently been rewarded.

The president's brother, Mohammed Reza Khatami, who leads the Islamic Iran Participation Front slate, was all smiles as he cast his ballot in central Tehran yesterday. "We predicted before the election that [we] would win a majority of seats, and according to our evidence it seems we will get 60%," he said.

Other supporters of the president said they were confident of victory, based on a survey of 100 polling stations in Tehran and information from campaign workers in other large cities.

Many voters, even those in districts that are traditionally conservative, said they were casting ballots for the first time since the 1979 revolution because they felt, for once, that their voice mattered.

"I have never voted since the revolution and I didn't vote for Khatami when he ran for president," said Mohammed Yusefi, a 37-year-old merchant, casting his ballot in south Tehran, which is mainly conservative. "In previous elections there were no diverse candidates. The conservative establishment chose the candidates and Iranians voted out of obligation, Mr Yusefi said.

"Now, I know Khatami has managed to stop the conservative establishment from always deciding everything for the people," he said, referring to the removal of the right of the guardian council, a body of hardline clerics, to screen election candidates.

Definitive results will not be available for several days, as ballots are counted by hand. But reports from local journalists and campaign workers across the country indicated a high turnout - possibly approaching the 88% of eligible voters who voted in the 1997 presidential race, won by Mr Khatami in a landslide. (The president himself is not up for re-election this poll.)

Enthusiasm for the election stemmed from a desire for change and a determination to tell the clerical establishment that its time is up.

Among the candidates yesterday was Iran's former president, Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, brought out of semi-retirement and tipped by centrists and conservatives to be speaker of parliament.

But women voters wearing the most conservative form of veiling, the full-length black chador, said they had spurned Mr Rafsanjani and his daughter, Faezeh Hashemi. Both ran for seats in Tehran. When voters admitted not voting for the Rafsanjanis, they spoke quietly, as if breaking a taboo.

"He was president for eight years and that was enough," said one government worker, placing her finger over her lips as if she had just revealed a state secret.

If Mr Rafsanjani does poorly it will be a signal that Iranians have left the past, and his conservative social policies, behind.

Conservatives supporting his candidacy and that of other traditionalists tried to alarm voters by warning that a victory for the reformers would bring an end to the principles of the revolution and the legacy of its late leader, Ayatollah Khomeini - in short, an end to Islamic values in Iran. But it was a difficult sell, one that apparently failed.

For one thing, President Khatami is a sayyed, held to denote a descendant of the Prophet Mohammed, and he was once close to Khomeini.

The president's brother, Mohammed Reza Khatami, cast his ballot yesterday, accompanied by his wife, Zahra Eshraqi, Khomeini's granddaughter. When asked if her grandfather would approve of a victory for the reformers, she replied: "My grandfather blessed my marriage into the Khatami family because he liked them so much and I am sure he would have been happy about their victory."

The current 270-seat parliament is controlled by conservatives and has served as a stumbling block to President Khatami's reform agenda. Reformers are now pinning much hope for future change on the new expanded 290-seat parliament.

If Mohammed Reza Khatami places first in the race for Tehran, and reformers win a majority of seats, he would be a strong contender for speaker of parliament. The movement for social and political change might then forge ahead.

Iranians yesterday seemed eager to break with the past.

"I am voting only for women candidates," said a man of 42, Azari Khomeini.

"The men screwed up the country. Now it's time to give women a chance."

fields.headline: Genocide suspect in legal fight
fields.trailText: A former Rwandan army chief accused of genocide during the country's civil war is to mount a legal challenge to his detention in Britain on a warrant from a UN war crimes tribunal.
fields.body:
A former Rwandan army chief accused of genocide during the country's civil war is to mount a legal challenge to his detention in Britain on a warrant from a UN war crimes tribunal.

Tharcisse Muvunyi, who was arrested in London earlier this month, was due to be handed over to the international criminal tribunal for Rwanda, based in Tanzania, next week.

However, his lawyer confirmed yesterday that he is preparing to lodge a writ of habeas corpus at the high court in London, which could delay Mr Muvunyi's transfer by weeks, or even months.

The move sets in train a legal process which could involve the House of Lords and end up on the desk of the home secretary, Jack Straw.

Mr Muvunyi, 46, is implicated in the deaths of 100,000 people - mostly members of Rwanda's Tutsi minority - during the civil war which tore the country apart in 1994. Known as "The Commander", he was the ruling Hutus' military chief in two provinces.

He fled the country at the end of the civil war, and ended up living with his wife and children in Lewisham, south-east London. He was arrested after the UN tribunal indicted him for genocide and crimes against humanity earlier this month.

webTitle: US nets official for spying for Cuba

fields.headline: US nets official for spying for Cuba
fields.trailText: A senior US immigration official with secret security clearance has been charged with spying for Cuba.
fields.body:
A senior US immigration official with secret security clearance has been charged with spying for Cuba.

The FBI said Mariano Faget, 54, originally from Havana, was arrested on Thursday and held overnight in Miami pending a court appearance yesterday.

Authorities said Mr Faget supervised cases for the Immigration and Naturalisation Service (INS), including those involving resident status and political asylum.

Mr Faget had worked for the INS for at least 34 years. The FBI said he had been granted a "secret security clearance" which gave him "access to classified and sensitive INS files relating to confidential law enforcement sources and Cuban defectors".

The bureau's investigation, "Operation False Blue", found that Mr Faget had "unauthorised contacts" with Cuban intelligence officers.

He was charged with violating the Espionage Act and making false statements.

A source close to the investigation told the Washington Post that Cuban intelligence was very effective, and that to "interrupt one of their operations is significant".

In 1998 a group described by authorities as the largest Cuban spy ring in the US in decades was uncovered. At least three people linked to it have been jailed.

The US severed diplomatic ties with Cuba in 1961, and although travel between the two countries has increased, differences were highlighted in the recent custody case involving Elian Gonzalez, the six-year-old Cuban boy who survived a smuggling trip in which his mother and 10 others drowned.

webTitle: Top researcher falsified breast cancer results

fields.headline: Top researcher falsified breast cancer results
fields.trailText: South Africa's leading chemotherapy specialist has admitted falsifying "ground breaking" research into a controversial cure for breast cancer that gave hope to women with advanced cases of the disease but divided the international medical community.
fields.body:
South Africa's leading chemotherapy specialist has admitted falsifying "ground breaking" research into a controversial cure for breast cancer that gave hope to women with advanced cases of the disease but divided the international medical community.

Witwatersrand university in Johannesburg is also investigating suspicions that Professor Werner Bezwoda experimented on dozens of black women for the research without their consent.

The university suspended Dr Bezwoda as head of haematology and clinical oncology after he admitted in writing to "a serious breach of scientific honesty and integrity" by lying about the conduct of experiments which claimed to show that high doses of chemotherapy followed by bone marrow transplants were more effective than existing treatments for breast cancer.

The study was hailed as a "ray of hope" for women with advanced breast cancer when it was presented to an international conference of 12,000 researchers in the US last May. It was approved by some of the doctor's peers but was contradicted by four other studies.

John Durant, vice-president of the US oncology society which hosted the conference, said the research was worthless. "I'm very angry at Bezwoda personally. He misled his patients, he misled us, he misled women who had hope," he said. "When it was learned that his research wasn't credible it put an end to any research in the same the area... He has done a lot of damage to clinical trials of all sorts."

US cancer researchers had already begun trials on the basis of Dr Bezwoda's claim that his treatment increased the survival rate and reduced relapses, when his research was exposed as a fraud after US experts visited Witwatersrand university last month.

webTitle: Security lapses in Brussels HQ cast doubt on EU defence plans

fields.headline: Security lapses in Brussels HQ cast doubt on EU defence plans
fields.trailText: Hopes that the European Union can develop its own military forces have been dealt an early blow by the embarrassing realisation that the headquarters of its brand new planning bodies have almost no security.
fields.body:
Hopes that the European Union can develop its own military forces have been dealt an early blow by the embarrassing realisation that the headquarters of its brand new planning bodies have almost no security.

Officials last night admitted to grave concerns about lapses involving the Justus Lipsius building, home to the council of ministers, but a place more used to holding talks about agriculture and the environment than sensitive defence issues.

Justus Lipsius, built of polished pink granite, is one of the grandest edifices in the EU quarter of central Brussels but a nightmare for anyone worried about spies or terrorists.

Two cleaning workers, on contract to the council, were found to have criminal records, while US intelligence agencies discovered during apparently routine eavesdropping that EU employees were using office phones to make private calls, diplomats said.

Late one night, Javier Solana, the EU's new foreign and security policy chief, encountered a crowd of complete strangers milling around outside his fifth-floor private office, and later complained that the building has "as many holes as Swiss cheese".

Mr Solana, a former Spanish foreign minister who was secretary general of Nato until moving across town last October, does not even have a secure phone in his office and is now lobbying hard for leak-proof premises.

It is extremely urgent. Earlier this week the EU took the historic step of setting up a political and security committee and a parallel military staff body to advance the European security and defence identity - of which Mr Solana is the keeper.

Its most ambitious goal is for the EU to launch its own 60,000-strong rapid reaction force by 2003. The idea is that in a future crisis, EU forces could act without relying on the US, as they did in Kosovo, but would borrow Nato transport planes and satellite intelligence.

Nato, not surprisingly, insists that the Europeans improve their virtually non-existent security if they want to share the alliance's secrets.

"Frankly, at the moment, if you give the council a document you might as well just give it straight to CNN," complained one exasperated official. "They just have no culture of being security conscious - and there's no quick fix for that."

EU sources deny that a concealed microphone was found in an interpreters' booth, but horrified security consultants discovered during a rare debugging sweep several weeks ago that the facilities for allowing officials to listen in on ministerial meetings could be easily monitored.

Computer networks are also far too insecure to handle classified material, so the EU's 15 member states, especially big military players such as Britain, are refusing point blank to allow their own secret documents into the building.

Justus Lipsius - which has a vast and potentially dangerous underground car park - houses hundreds of translators and clerical staff, and up to 1,200 people come in though half a dozen separate entrances every day.

It was hoped that a secure area could be created inside the building, but it is now almost certain that the new committees - starting work on March 1 and eventually likely to comprise 100 military and civilian personnel - will have to find a home elsewhere.

The most obvious site for a custom-built EU defence headquarters is an adjacent lot, but that was sold recently by the Belgian government and is now a car park. Rental is the next best option.

"We have got to move out for reasons of space and security," said one official. "If we cannot guarantee confidentiality, the Americans and Nato are never going to let us have the information we will need to manage a crisis."

British sources say an EU version of the official secrets act may be needed, but senior council staff protest that they are vetted by their own governments and the Belgian authorities, as well as signing confidentiality agreements.

webTitle: UK helicopter to help re-create Waco's last days

fields.headline: UK helicopter to help re-create Waco's last days
fields.standfirst: Hi-tech key to finding out whether FBI fired shots that started fatal fire
fields.trailText: A Royal Navy Lynx surveillance helicopter is to play a key role in next month's re-enactment of the end of the Branch Davidian siege at Waco, Texas, in 1993 where 74 people died.
fields.body:
A Royal Navy Lynx surveillance helicopter is to play a key role in next month's re-enactment of the end of the Branch Davidian siege at Waco, Texas, in 1993 where 74 people died.

The re-enactment is being organised by Peterborough-based Vector Data Systems, a British arm of an American hi-tech defence contractor.

The exercise, to recreate the dramatic climax of the Waco siege, will be conducted at Fort Hood, a US military base near Waco, and is intended to provide the answers to a series of passionately contested questions concerning the role of the FBI in the conclusion of the 51-day siege.

The field test using the Lynx will be crucial in two investigations into the end of the siege and could make or break dozens of US justice department and FBI careers.

The test will also determine whether relatives of the Waco victims receive millions of dollars in compensation from the US government.

The Lynx is equipped with infra-red surveillance cameras manufactured by BAE Systems similar to one used by the bureau at the time of the Waco siege.

Videos taken by the FBI on the day that the siege ended, April 19, 1993, are at the heart of the argument over whether the bureau fired shots or launched grenades that contributed to the deaths of the Davidians, including many children.

For nearly seven years, families of the Davidians killed during the siege have been trying to mount a wrongful killing lawsuit against the US federal government.

They allege that the FBI - either on the orders of the attorney general Janet Reno or not - deliberately began the fire that engulfed the Davidian compound and fired on the cult members inside.

The official verdict on Waco has always been that the fire was started by the Davidians themselves, acting on the orders of the cult's leader, David Koresh.

The issue has become a cause celebre among US conspiracy theorists and rightwing anti-government groups, which believe that Waco is proof that Washington is committed to a military-style repression of people who sometimes see themselves as armed freedom fighters.

Last year the FBI discovered a previously unacknowledged videotape of the siege at the Davidian compound which contained evidence that the FBI had fired at least two tear-gas grenades during the fire - something which Ms Reno and the bureau had always denied.

News of the discovery was the biggest breakthrough so far for the relatives, and led to an official re-investigation of the end of the siege, conducted by former Republican Senator John Danforth.

One of the key unanswered questions arising from the video is whether a series of flashes which are visible on the tape show gunfire, as the plaintiffs claim

Until now, the FBI has opposed any moves for a recreation of the final hours of the siege, arguing that revealing any information about the surveillance camera, including even the name of its manufacturer, would jeopardise law enforcement secrets and national security.

However both Mr Danforth and US District Judge Walter Smith, the Waco judge who is hearing the relatives' civil suit, have approved a restaging next month, and this week an unidentified British scientist working on the project told the court than none of the information that would be revealed was considered sensitive or secret in the UK.

"The British military representatives said the only thing that's classified is if someone goes in and takes video footage inside the aircraft," Edward Allard, a representative of the Davidian relatives' legal team, said.

British diplomatic sources in Washington confirmed that a single Royal Navy Lynx, along with its nine-member crew, is being loaned by the Ministry of Defence at the request of Mr Danforth. The cost of transporting the British equipment and personnel across the Atlantic to Texas has been estimated at about $300,000 (£187,000).

The managing director of Vector Data Systems, John Barry, refused to comment on his company's precise role in the exercise yesterday.

Vector Data Systems is owned by the US-based Antion corporation and specialises in the military application of hi-tech imaging systems.

Its systems have been used to train pilots on low-flying missions in Kosovo and Bosnia.
