webTitle: Green shoots appear in France's desert

fields.headline: Green shoots appear in France's desert
fields.standfirst: Newcomers bring hope to the countryside after a century of decline
fields.trailText: Outside wild and wooded Lozère, the news was not exactly earth shattering: between 1990 and 1999, the population of France's least-inhabited department, or administrative division, rose by 1% to 73,509 - not enough to fill the Stade de France.
fields.body:
Outside wild and wooded Lozère, the news was not exactly earth shattering: between 1990 and 1999, the population of France's least-inhabited department, or administrative division, rose by 1% to 73,509 - not enough to fill the Stade de France.

But for this beautiful, isolated pocket of rural France tucked away in the foothills of the Massif Central, the census results were cause for cautious celebration. They represented the first recorded increase in Lozère's population since 1881.

"We're not out of trouble yet," said the president of the district council, Jean-Paul Pottier. "But in its way, this is a triumph. In its way, it's historic. It's not an accident, it's the result of 20 years of hard work and a lot of money. And it's proof that this corner of France is not, as Paris likes to think, lost for ever."

Rural depopulation has been a fact of life in France for more than a century. Schools, shops and cafes have closed, and villages have been dying away as young people decide that the city lights are brighter than the prospect of eking out an existence in the countryside, which the French have come to term "the green desert".

In 1929 France had 4m farms; it now has fewer than 750,000. More than 1m agricultural jobs have gone since 1970 alone, and over the same period 50,000 small rural businesses have disappeared. Rural departments such as Lozère, which back in 1881 boasted 143,565 inhabitants, have seen their populations more than halve.

Lozère is saddled, too, with an unfortunate reputation as the most backward of all France's departments. So all in all, in the bars of Mende, its pretty county town, those extra 684 inhabitants are a reason for solid satisfaction.

Some of the reasons for this windfall are, of course, part of a bigger story. There is the gradual recent drift away from the vast urban sprawl of Paris, which has lost 500,000 of its 10m inhabitants in a decade to cities such as Toulouse, Rouen, Nantes and Lille.

There is also the new motorway that winds carefully around the department's spectacular crags and gorges to bring Clermont-Ferrand, Lyon and Montpellier within a couple of hours' drive. And there's the e-revolution that has allowed a few entrepreneurs to open profitable businesses in what remains to many people the back of beyond.

But Lozère has worked hard to bring in newcomers. There remains, after all, a big difference between setting up shop in a thriving provincial hub and moving to the exposed sweep of the Aubrac plateau some 2,400ft up in the Cévennes, which is what two of Lozère's new arrivals, Casimir Cerle and Emmanuelle Appriou, did last June.

They were clients of the department's business development mission run by one man, whose job it is to find suitable small-scale firms and then to put together a package including everything from business premises to a home for the managing director and school places for the children.

In two years that one-man band - Pierre Pagès - has helped five companies relocate to Lozère and has seen three new businesses launch in the department. Nearly 500 jobs were created here last year, a 16% increase that was the highest in France.

The company run by Mr Cerle and Ms Appriou is France's market leader in software for libraries. After 20 years in the capital, Mr Cerle wanted to get back to his rural roots. The firm has trained four local youths as software developers, and is growing at a faster rate than it could have afforded in Paris.

Lozère's growth does not yet herald the salvation of rural France. Several other rural departments, including two of Lozère's neighbours, are still losing inhabitants, although the rate of depopulation has slowed significantly.

But the success of Lozère in turning the tide has been greeted as a sign that rural regeneration is possible. It is also indicative of a clear drift back from Paris to a quieter way of life. The last census showed that provincial cities such as Nantes and Rouen had grown by as much as 10% in 10 years.

"It is inevitable," said Mr Cerle. "The country can't continue with a quarter of the population in and around Paris. As conditions and communications improve, more and more will come back."

In the battle for new jobs, mayors are also becoming entrepreneurs. In one Lozère village, the council ploughed £450,000 into a small business complex, and followed it up with a council-owned retirement home. Le Collet-de-Dèze, population 718, boasts 21 new jobs, 60 new inhabitants, a garage and a cafe.

With the department's encouragement, several newcomers have invested in green tourism, opening self-catering gites and small wilderness hotels. The sector now provides jobs for some 3,000 people but, says the head of the local tourist board, Pierre Spirito, it also keeps other local businesses going.

"In this kind of landscape, beautiful but tough, everything is interdependent," he said. "Tourists need village shopkeepers, and village shopkeepers need tourists, and villages need shops. This population increase is a symbolic success, but we're still in a struggle for life. The battle's not won."

Lionel Boudoussier moved to Lozère from near Paris two years ago, and runs a young company that provides centralised accounting for some 650 French firms. He says the biggest difference in his life is that he can now walk his son to school in the morning and back again at lunchtime.

But not all newcomers to Lozère are hi-tech wizards. Up on the high, deserted scarp of the Causse Méjean, Florence Pratlong manages a fast-growing firm making cheese from ewe's milk. She employs 19 staff and keeps 14 Lozère shepherds in business.

"We're on a tightrope, I realise that," she said. "But there's hope here now, a will to construct something in this community. People are no longer ashamed to be here, and that's important."

webTitle: Young Buddhist leader on stage with Dalai Lama

fields.headline: Young Buddhist leader on stage with Dalai Lama
fields.trailText: Tibetan Buddhism's two most important figures made their first joint appearance yesterday. The Dalai Lama was joined at celebrations - marking the 60th anniversary of his enthronement - by the young Buddhist leader, the Karmapa, who recently fled Chinese-controlled Tibet.
fields.body:
Tibetan Buddhism's two most important figures made their first joint appearance yesterday. The Dalai Lama was joined at celebrations - marking the 60th anniversary of his enthronement - by the young Buddhist leader, the Karmapa, who recently fled Chinese-controlled Tibet.

There was little interaction between the two at the festivities in Dharamsala, the town in northern India where the exiled Dalai Lama is based. But aides say they have formed a strong bond in recent weeks.

The Karmapa crossed secretly into India with a small entourage on January 5. He was said to be seeking religious instruction denied to him by Chinese authorities.

The 14-year-old lama was among four senior religious figures on the upper pavilion of the Namgyal monastery in Dharmsala yesterday.

The Dalai Lama smiled and laughed through much of the four-hour ceremony and he tapped the Karmapa's hand as he blessed the monks and lamas.

The Tibetan spiritual leader is reported to have held five meetings with the Karmapa since his arrival in India, including dress rehearsals on Thursday and a special blessing audience on Tibetan new year's day.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Peacekeeper faces trial
fields.body:
Peacekeeper faces trial

A Nato peacekeeping soldier told a military court yesterday how a trail of blood in the snow in Kosovo led to the body of an 11-year-old ethnic Albanian girl, allegedly raped and killed last month by another US soldier.

The hearing aimed to determine whether Staff Sergeant Frank J Ronghi, 35, from Ohio, should be court-martialled on charges of murder and indecent acts with a child. Sgt Ronghi, who faces the death sentence if found guilty, is being detained at a US base in Germany. AP, Urosevac, Yugoslavia

Tourists killed in Egyptian crash

Two German tourists were killed and 10 Germans and an Egyptian driver and tour guide were injured yesterday when their bus overturned in Egypt's Sinai peninsula, police said.

Most of the injured passengers, including three children, were taken to a hospital in the Egyptian Red sea port of Nuweiba, about 250 miles south-east of Cairo. AP, Cairo

Kosovan rebels jailed in Serbia

A Serbian court yesterday sentenced six Kosovan Albanians to up to 10 years each in prison for helping Kosovo Liberation Army guerrillas.

The prosecution in Nis alleged that the six had organised a unit of the rebels in Gracanica, and had collected money and weapons for them. Reuters, Belgrade

Alcohol death on skiing trip

An Irish teenager on a family ski trip froze to death after sneaking out of his hotel, getting drunk and spending a night barefoot and unconscious in the snow, police said yesterday.

David Noonan, 16, was found outside wearing a short-sleeved shirt and no shoes in the principality of Andorra in the Pyrenees, where it had snowed heavily during the night. AP, Canillo, Andorra

webTitle: MPs accuse IMF of hypocrisy and call for reforms

fields.headline: MPs accuse IMF of hypocrisy and call for reforms
fields.standfirst:
Debt relief: special report
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: MPs accused the International Monetary Fund of hypocrisy yesterday, saying it was unacceptable for the IMF to demand more openness and transparency from developing countries without undertaking similar reforms itself.
fields.body:
MPs accused the International Monetary Fund of hypocrisy yesterday, saying it was unacceptable for the IMF to demand more openness and transparency from developing countries without undertaking similar reforms itself.

Calling on the IMF to publish the agenda and minutes of executive board meetings, MPs on the treasury committee said: "The IMF must be more open about its proceedings and give a greater voice to developing countries when discussing issues of direct relevance to their economic well-being."

The committee challenged Gordon Brown, who chairs the IMF's policy-making committee, to set a good example by publishing Britain's voting record at IMF board meetings.

Without unilateral action on that front, parliamentary scrutiny of British policy decisions and the performance of its representative, Stephen Pickford, would continue to be "severely constrained", said the treasury committee in a report.

Mr Brown has already indicated that he is unlikely to alter the practice of not publishing Britain's voting record. He told the committee last year similar action by the US had made no difference to the secrecy of other countries.

Most IMF board decisions are taken by consensus and the treasury committee is aware that a move towards a more formal voting system would require reforms, which could inhibit discussion. But it believes that the benefits of more openness and transparency outweigh the drawbacks.

Endorsing the complaints of non-governmental organisations, the committee said the secretive process of selecting the managing director - controlled by the Group of Seven - should be open to greater public scrutiny.

It also recommended that the IMF pull back from long-term poverty reduction programmes, which should be the responsibility of the World Bank, and concentrate on policing the financial system.

Angela Wood, of the Bretton Woods Project, an IMF watchdog, said: "We would like to see the UK make its voting record public. To make this effective, there should be a formal voting procedure for every decision and how each country voted should be made public. Otherwise, smaller and developing countries will continue to be marginalised."

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Yorkshire Dales
fields.trailText: The snows came overnight. Not a great deal, only an inch or two really, but it was enough to remind everyone that it is still winter, and will be in the Dales for another month or so.
fields.body:
The snows came overnight. Not a great deal, only an inch or two really, but it was enough to remind everyone that it is still winter, and will be in the Dales for another month or so.

While traffic in Bradford and Sheffield slows to a crawl in the intermittent snow storms and everyone moans about the lack of gritting or salting, the Dales carries on as usual. An ancient little red Massey Ferguson tractor trundles up the Conistone road out of Grassington, a bale of hay in the rear skip for stock further up the dale. A contractor, hired to fell alien conifers from the nearby woodland nature reserve, turns up on time and quickly puts his chain saw to work. Like the farmer, there is no one else to do the job and if the contractor doesn't work, there is no pay.

In between the snow showers the Dales gleam in sunshine. There is even blue sky and the highest hills take on a picture postcard appearance, until the next wave of storm clouds shroud them in gloomy mist again.

From beneath the roadside dry-stone wall a stoat dances out into the field below us, prancing, pirouetting, almost gambolling in the grass. Despite the latitude and altitude, it is still a uniform brown with a black tail tip. There is no white of ermine. This is odd because stoats certainly change at least to piebald as far south and low down as Doncaster. Maybe the mild winter is responsible. Our stoat leaps around in circles, pouncing, springing in an apparently motiveless dance. You hear tales of them dancing to hypnotise prey such as rabbits, but none are to be seen here. Eventually, perhaps tiring of its play, it wriggles through the stones at the wall's base, crosses the road and disappears among the long grass.

The farmers have no time for dancing. Back comes the old Massey Ferguson, now unladen, to return 10 minutes later with another hay bale. This apparent inefficiency is typical of small-scale hill farming in the Dales, but bigger machines would be too large for the narrow lanes and trackways anyway.

fields.headline: Cooked to a turning point
fields.standfirst: Sara Lee
fields.trailText: As claims to fame go, Sara Lee Lubin's is an unusual one. First her father, Chicago baker Charles Lubin, named a cheesecake after her. Then he named his business after her - Kitchens of Sara Lee.
fields.body:
As claims to fame go, Sara Lee Lubin's is an unusual one. First her father, Chicago baker Charles Lubin, named a cheesecake after her. Then he named his business after her - Kitchens of Sara Lee.

Consolidated Foods Corporation, founded by a Canadian in 1939, acquired Mr Lubin's business in 1956. Twenty-nine years later the group wanted a more consumer friendly name for itself. It chose Sara Lee Corporation.

Earlier this week the food and clothing group carrying Sara Lee's name bid £104m for Courtaulds Textiles, once a key player in Britain's clothing industry but more recently fallen on hard times.

The move would not have surprised Mr Lubin, who was always an entrepreneur at heart. But his expertise lay in food.

He started out in business in 1935, when he and his brother-in-law bought a small chain of local bakers shops called Community Bake Shops. But 14 years later he parted company with his relative to set up his own business in Chicago.

He developed a range of new products. They caught the attention of a buyer from Texas who wanted them sent to him.

The problem was that fresh goods did not travel well, and Sara Lee's product range was not suitable for freezing. But Lubin was not one to turn down opportunities. He changed the products' ingredients so that they would freeze well and by 1953 he had developed his own process for freezing baked food.

It was a turning point. Frozen foods enabled the company to expand from a local into a national business.

It used the new medium of television to advertise its goods. Mitch Leigh, the creator of the musical, Man of La Mancha, was drafted in to write the company's advertising jingle in 1968. The scale of the change in the firm's fortunes was reflected by the building of an ultra-modern plant with extensive research and development facilities.

Lubin retired in 1965 but soon Sara Lee, backed by new owners, Consolidated Foods Corporation, was reaching abroad, opening plants in Canada and Australia. It moved into the UK in 1977, with a plant in Bridlington, Yorkshire.

Despite the success of the Sara Lee food business the group was diversifying into new areas, including clothing and household goods, through acquisitions.

The group's global brands now include Kiwi shoe polish, Badedas and Radox bath salts, Bali lingerie, Coach leathergoods, Douwe Egbert coffee, Hanes hosiery and casual clothing, Brylcreem hair products, Ambi-Pur air fresheners, Pretty Polly tights, Playtex and Wonderbra underwear.

It is the latter which has led to the bid for Courtaulds Textiles being dubbed "the battle of the bras". Courtaulds is the manufacturer of the Berlei bra range and the Gossard Ultrabra.

Much of the diversification and the recent restructuring have been overseen by chairman and chief executive, John Bryan, who last month announced he was giving up the chief executive's role.

Industry experts thought Mr Bryan would begin to ease himself out after a long time at the top when he announced in June last year that the group would give away the cream of its $100m collection of paintings.

Over 50 pieces, including works by Monet, Pissarro, Gaugin and Picasso, are being donated to 40 museums throughout the world. The National Gallery in Britain is to receive Degas's 1899 work, The Russian Dancers.

Mr Bryan has a reputation in the United States for campaigning for women's rights and encouraging his senior executives to take part in local community ventures.

Failure to do so can slow a career within the company.

But what happened to Sara Lee herself? She is married, has had a family and is living on the American east coast. But until five years ago, she was still doing her bit for the business - by appearing in the company's commercials.

fields.headline: Brewers facing overseas takeovers
fields.trailText: Two of the three largest brewers in Britain may end up in foreign hands following takeover approaches to both Bass and Whitbread from overseas beer groups.
fields.body:
Two of the three largest brewers in Britain may end up in foreign hands following takeover approaches to both Bass and Whitbread from overseas beer groups.

The hotels, pubs and brewing group, Bass, yesterday said it was looking at all the options for the future of its brewery business, which is the second largest in the country and produces brands such as Carling lager, Worthington, Hooper's Hooch and Caffrey's.

It is understood that Bass has received several offers for the business, which employs 4,000 people, including approaches from Heineken and South African Breweries. Regarded as one of the most efficient brewing operations in Britain, Bass sells one in every four pints and is expected to command a price of up to £2bn.

Whitbread, which axed plans to float its beer company after failing to buy Allied Domecq's large stable of pubs, is also understood to be exploring possible offers from foreign buyers. Heineken - whose lager Whitbread brews under licence in the UK - is believed to have expressed interest as has Interbrew, the European group whose Stella brand is also produced under licence in Britain by Whitbread.

The group declined to comment on any approaches but a spokesman said: "Brewing is not central to our business so there is the expectation that we will exit from this at some time when conditions are right. It would be correct to say we are reviewing our options." Insiders, however, admitted that overtures have been made.

Like Bass, which has been concentrating on its higher return businesses such as hotels and leisure retailing, Whitbread is keen to focus on the more exciting operations in its portfolio such as hotels, restaurants, pubs and the David Lloyd leisure clubs.

If both companies secure buyers for their brewing businesses that will leave Scottish & Newcastle as the only large, domestically owned brewer, but even then half a dozen of the group's leading brands, including Kronenbourg 1664, Miller and Beck's, are not owned but simply brewed under licence. Following the acquisition of Allied Domecq's beer operations, the Danish Carlsberg group is the fourth biggest player in the British market.

Shares in Bass and Whitbread frothed up strongly early yesterday as the possibility of deals spread into the market. But some of the excitement surrounding Whitbread evaporated as traders realised that a transaction between Bass and Heineken could be fatal for the smaller group.

Heineken is one of the most important brands for Whitbread's beer company and the contract would almost certainly be lost if Heineken acquired its own brewing capacity in the UK.

There was also some scepticism that market traders might be exaggerating the possibility of big ticket takeovers in an effort to drive up the share prices of the major companies, helping Whitbread and Scottish & Newcastle retain their place in the FTSE 100 at next month's review.

webTitle: Jobs at risk in milk merger

fields.headline: Jobs at risk in milk merger
fields.trailText: The shake-out of the hard-pressed dairy industry began yesterday as Dairy Crest announced plans to merge its business with the milk and cheese operations of Unigate.
fields.body:
The shake-out of the hard-pressed dairy industry began yesterday as Dairy Crest announced plans to merge its business with the milk and cheese operations of Unigate.

The move, designed to improve returns from the commodity milk and unbranded cheese businesses, is expected to mean the loss of hundreds of jobs as the group attempts to cut costs by £25m a year.

It is also expected to kick-start much wider rationalisation in an industry which has too many operators and is being squeezed by the mighty supermarket groups.

John Worby, the finance director of Unigate, said his company had "talked long and hard with lots of people" in the industry and that the merger with Dairy Crest offered the best potential.

But he accepted that the deal was likely to trigger consolidation among the industry's weaker players, some of which might withdraw altogether.

"The industry has needed consolidation... the parts of the industry which are relatively undifferentiated have found things hard going, and this is the area in which you have to be as efficient as possible and that means being larger rather than smaller. This deal goes to the heart of that."

Dairy Crest, whose brands include Cathedral City, Clover and Yoplait, has a workforce of about 3800 people - including 900 milkmen - and that will more than double once employees from Unigate have transferred over.

The company had sales of nearly £775m in its last financial year and profits of about £45m. The business it is acquiring is almost exactly the same size - with a turnover of nearly £750m and profits of some £51.5m.

Under the terms of the transaction Dairy Crest will issue 75.7m new shares in exchange for Unigate's dairy and cheese businesses, which will transfer with £100m of debt.

Once the deal is complete, Dairy Crest shareholders will control 60% of the enlarged group while Unigate investors will have a 40% stake.

Unigate says it now intends to focus strongly on convenience foods and logistics, and is already looking around for acquisitions in the UK and on the European mainland.

The group recently acquired Terranova, the chilled food business formerly owned by Hillsdown, and took over another convenience operation, Marie, from Danone of France.

The enlarged convenience food operation has sales of about £1.1bn a year - two-thirds of Unigate's entire income - and a quarter of food income is now generated on the European mainland.

Shares in Unigate shed 12.75p to close at 246.25p, while Dairy Crest edged 1p higher to 158.5p as the group expects to have to spend £30m in one-off cash costs plus £35m of capital spending to reconfigure facilities and achieve savings. The group declined to comment on job losses or where they would occur.

webTitle: Crunch time for the car makers

fields.headline: Crunch time for the car makers
fields.trailText:
Industry faces up to its excesses
The grim news of 1,500 job losses at Ford's Dagenham plant, which employs 8,000 people, is evidence that car makers are finally tackling production over capacity in Europe. No site, least of all Rover's Longbridge, is safe.
fields.body:
Industry faces up to its excesses
The grim news of 1,500 job losses at Ford's Dagenham plant, which employs 8,000 people, is evidence that car makers are finally tackling production over capacity in Europe. No site, least of all Rover's Longbridge, is safe.

Yesterday's announcement by Nick Scheele, Ford of Europe chairman, coincided with a new spate of rumours that the world's No 2 carmaker has set its sights on acquiring BMW, Rover's German owner. This and news of Ford's (entirely unrelated) press conference in London, were enough to send BMW's stock up 13% at one stage.

There is a febrile atmosphere around Europe's car industry these days, with the three medium-size independents - BMW, Fiat and Peugeot - regularly the target of speculation about bids from General Motors, Ford, DaimlerChrysler and/or Volkswagen. The facts that these three are largely family-controlled - by the Quandts, Agnellis and Peugeots respectively - and these tightly banded dynasties repeatedly deny they want to sell their holdings make not a jot of difference to the speculators.

Market over-excitement aside, there is little doubt that sooner or later one or all three will fall into new hands as the family owners give up the ghost on their low-yield investments - and a new wave of consolidation engulfs an industry that has the capacity to produce 1.7m more cars than Europeans want to buy, according to Mr Scheele. Equally, there is little doubt that BMW and its loss-making UK offshoot, Rover, which is likely to declare 1999 losses of around DM2.5bn (£780m) next month, are the most vulnerable. Continuing doubts about whether Brussels will approve government aid of £151m for Longbridge to produce a new medium-sized car hardly helps.

The car majors, including Ford, are adept at playing plants - and governments - off against each other and the Dagenham employees have good grounds for feeling aggrieved about their fate. The Essex plant, racked by a spate of racist incidents, is the victim of the declining appeal of the old Fiesta and yet has vastly improved its productivity record.

Tony Woodley, chief union negotiator for the car industry and architect of the 1998 deal to save Longbridge, has every right to pinpoint the soaring pound and "the fact that it is cheaper, easier and quicker to sack UK workers than anywhere else in Europe" as factors behind Ford's decision yesterday.

But the unions, planning a further series of strikes by 3,000 white-collar Ford staff from Monday over pensions, must realise that tens of thousands of their members in Europe could lose their jobs in the next few months - and their employers will be reduced in number to four or five, at most.

Small beer

Ten years ago there were six big brewers in the UK and only two were foreign. Within the next few months we could be down to four big operators, with only one British-owned and even that one - Scottish & Newcastle - is heavily reliant on brewing overseas mega-brands under licence.

Bass, which only a couple of years ago tried to move into pole position in the beer business with the purchase of Carlsberg Tetley (stalled by the department of trade and industry), yesterday admitted a volte-face and said it was considering offers for its beer business. Whitbread, which called off flotation of its beer company after failing to buy Allied Domecq's pub chain last summer, now admits beer is not central to its future and is discussing an exit route.

It is astonishing that two companies whose names are synonymous with beer should consider severing all ties with the business their empires were built on. While it is hard to argue that emotional ties hold sway over shareholder value, it has to be said that beer as a business is still growing, is very profitable and employs thousands.

So what has taken the sparkle out of brewing? There are two guilty parties. Step forward first the last government, which dreamed up one of the most ill- conceived pieces of industry legislation in the name of consumer choice.

The so-called beer orders - for which we have to thank Lord Young - have resulted in the price of a pint rising more quickly than inflation, less choice, and the transference of pub market dominance from the brewers to a new generation of nouveau pub-owners such as Hugh Osmond's Punch Taverns. Then there is the City, which has allowed the sector to sink to the bottom of the stock market's slops tray. Beer does not travel well in the e-world, whatever the bandwidth, and both Whitbread and Scottish & Newcastle look sure to drop out of the FTSE 100 next month.

Last week a solid engineering group called Finelist submitted to overseas overtures and blamed e-frenzy for its predicament - and that of the entire engineering sector. Now it seems we must just sit back and watch the colonisation of the British brewing industry.

fields.headline: Pru finance chief resigns
fields.trailText: The finance director of the Prudential insurance group is to leave the company - after just five months in the job.
fields.body:
The finance director of the Prudential insurance group is to leave the company - after just five months in the job.

The departure of Les Cullen, who joined from Black & Decker last year, was unexpected and last night remained unexplained.

The Pru said Mr Cullen had resigned and it would look to recruit a new finance director from within the insurance or financial services industries.

The company insisted it was an "amicable" parting and that Mr Cullen would stay with the company until the end of next month, presenting its annual results next week.

However, there was speculation that Mr Cullen, 48, had clashed with the new chief executive, Jonathan Bloomer, whose promotion to the top job was announced a month ago.

Mr Bloomer, who was finance director, does not move into the chief executive's office until March 1. But some sector watchers believe he has made it clear he expects to remain at the centre of the finance side of the business.

In a statement, Mr Bloomer said: "This is Les's first experience in the financial services industry and he has decided that his future lies elsewhere.

"Les will be staying with us for the next couple of months to help us through our year-end work. He leaves us with our best wishes."

The company refused to say whether Mr Cullen would receive a pay-off or had resigned without compensation. A spokesman said the details were "not yet finalised".

If he is entitled to a pay-off it is likely to be some £300,000. He had a one-year contract and, although his salary has not been made public, Mr Bloomer received a basic salary of £347,000 last year in that role.

The Pru's shares fell 33p as Mr Cullen's resignation was announced but closed down only 9p at 981p.

His abrupt departure means that the senior echelons of the Pru's management have been almost completely changed in recent months.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.body:
Leading blue chips ended a volatile week on a subdued note, hit hard late in the day by a slide on Wall Street which after London closed stretched to 2.3% on the Dow Jones index.

The FTSE 100 itself ended the session down 44.3 points at 6,165 - above its 6,151.4 low of the day but well below the 6,264.1 high seen early in trading.

But the selling was confined to the blue chips, with both the Mid 250 and Small Cap indicators closing in positive territory.

Halifax retained pole position among the leaders - up another 13% or 73p to 625p - as investors continued to warm to the bank's move to business on the internet.

Woolwich added 20p to 306p in sympathy and Abbey National - which launched its own internet bank, Cahoot, on Thursday - firmed 13p to 726p.

Norwich Union , tipped by Goldman Sachs as a "market outperformer", also attracted fresh buying as vague bid rumours once again did the rounds. The shares closed 26p higher at 435p.

Away from the e-economy, Bass was made some progress, adding 6p to 701p after confirming that it is reviewing strategic options for its brewing arm. Dutch brewing group Heineken has already signalled its interest in the division, which brews Caffrey's and Carlsberg lager, with South African Breweries also mooted as a possible buyer.

Scottish & Newcastle firmed 7p to 397p, while Whitbread gave up early strength to finish the day 10p lower at 488p.

Over in the insurance sector Prudential saw its shares slump after the sudden departure of its finance director, Les Cullen, after only 5 months in the job and a month after the appointment of Jonathan Bloomer as chief executive designate. The stock finished above its worst, down 9p at 981p.

Chip designer ARM Holdings came under pressure, down 79p at £43.28 as a few investors locked in some profits. There was also some more profit-taking in recent high flyer WPP , which closed 25p lower at £10.03 after this week's solid figures. Most big brokers remain very positive on the advertising group.

Elsewhere, there was further demand for biotech stocks. Celltech stood out with a 100p gain to £10.02.

fields.headline: Unions pledge to save Dagenham
fields.standfirst: www.ford.co.uk
fields.trailText: Union leaders said yesterday they would fight any attempt by Ford to close its car plant at Dagenham where 1,500 jobs are scheduled to go in August.
fields.body:
Union leaders said yesterday they would fight any attempt by Ford to close its car plant at Dagenham where 1,500 jobs are scheduled to go in August.

Nick Scheele, head of Ford Europe, said the immediate job cuts were the result of overcapacity. But he said the whole plant could be closed unless industrial relations and productivity were improved.

The plant, which employs 8,000, is the last making Ford cars in Britain since Halewood switched to making Jaguars.

Tony Woodley, motor industry negotiator for the Transport and General Workers' Union, said his members would fight any move to close Dagenham. "If this is a slow closure of Dagenham, we will have to put up or shut up," he said.

He accused Ford of going back on an agreement - made when Halewood production ended in 1997 - to build the replacement Fiesta at Dagenham. The new car is now due to start production at Ford's Cologne plant in Germany late next year.

"This is a classic case, once again, of Britain being treated unreasonably and unfairly," Mr Woodley said. Low costs and the speed with which workers could be sacked in Britain made the country "a soft touch" for European employers, he added.

"At Cologne, they continue to maintain jobs and we have to ask ourselves why," he said.

The TGWU official said Britain had already borne the brunt of Ford's overcapacity in Europe.

"Two years ago we assisted Ford by, if you like, closing the Ford Halewood plant on Merseyside for Ford production. That allowed them to spread their production costs across the rest of Europe, and under those arrangements it was made clear that this plant [Dagenham] would have a new model and a future.

"We intend to make sure that Ford honours those commitments," he said.

Duncan Simpson, the AEEU engineering union's national officer for the motor industry, said: "This will have a knock-on effect on component suppliers, affecting up to 3,000 jobs. The whole area depends on the plant for work."

The Dagenham plant, which makes the Fiesta, has been on an effective four day week for more than a year because of surplus capacity in Europe.

The switch from two to just one shift a day, announced yesterday, will reduce the plant's production of Fiestas from 1,200 to 560 a day.

Engine production, which includes making diesels for Ford plants elsewhere, will not be affected.

Mr Scheele said the main cause for the cut was the supply and demand for vehicles.

But he added that it would be foolish to deny that the plant's industrial relations problems and a series of one-day strikes planned by its white-collar staff had not played a part in the decision. He said that the strength of sterling had been a secondary consideration.

"This move is a significant step towards resolving our capacity imbalance but we will continue to look at all aspects of our European operations," he said.

He added that the short-time working at Dagenham had cost the company £20m last year and would cost a further £22.5m this year unless action was taken.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Ghana steers clear of Ashanti
Ghana's government said yesterday that it would not interfere with the running of Ashanti Goldfields and might sell its golden share following a deal on board reforms which saved the mining firm from collapse. At the same time Ashanti won an open-ended reprieve on payment of margin calls due to counterparties with which it conducts gold derivatives business. A previous short-term agreement freezing margin demands ran out this week. The moves come after Ashanti clinched a rescue deal with key shareholders paving the way for it to secure a badly needed $100m (£63m) loan.

Ghana steers clear of Ashanti
Ghana's government said yesterday that it would not interfere with the running of Ashanti Goldfields and might sell its golden share following a deal on board reforms which saved the mining firm from collapse. At the same time Ashanti won an open-ended reprieve on payment of margin calls due to counterparties with which it conducts gold derivatives business. A previous short-term agreement freezing margin demands ran out this week. The moves come after Ashanti clinched a rescue deal with key shareholders paving the way for it to secure a badly needed $100m (£63m) loan.

Record profit for Hugo Boss
Leading German fashion group Hugo Boss said yesterday it had achieved its ninth consecutive record result in 1999, driven by global expansion and strong growth in its core US and European markets.

The company, whose founder Hugo Boss tailored Nazi uniforms, said 1999 sales rose 10% year-on-year to DM1.47bn (£462m) and net profit grew 14% to DM110.5m.

Boss said in a statement it plans to pay a 1999 dividend of 4 euros (£2.47) per ordinary share, up from 3.49 euros in 1998.

ITT contract to create 500 jobs
Up to 500 jobs will be created or secured following yesterday's decision to award US group ITT a £200m contract to supply 55,000 digital military mobile phones for Britain's armed forces.

ITT, which won the contract to provide VHF radios for armed units and individual soldiers on the battlefield under the £2.8bn Bowman programme against Racal, said it would create 90 new jobs in Basingstoke.

Baroness Symons, the defence procurement minister, said the contract - awarded by the Archer Communications consortium - would help secure 500 skilled jobs and involve a significant degree of technology transfer from the US to Britain.

Flat fee ISP suffers setback
Britain's first flat fee internet service provider has suffered a setback in its launch week, with operator Telewest blaming the collapse of its email system on overwhelming demand for the £10 a month deal.

Users of its Cable Internet service were unable to receive email from late on Thursday until yesterday morning, Telewest said on its website.

It blamed a storage problem triggered by the success of the deal launched on Monday, which it trumpeted as an example of the cheap internet services promised by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, on Wednesday.

Baltic appeal to stop tower
The Baltic Exchange yesterday announced plans for a high court challenge and appealed to government ministers to halt planning permission for Norman Foster's proposed 41-storey Swiss Re Tower in the City.

The move follows revelations that City of London officers would recommend a go-ahead for the controversial structure.

fields.headline: Five delicious freezer recipes
fields.standfirst: A parfait of pear, walnut praline ice cream, blood orange granita, melon and ginger sorbet, and baked Alaska. Jeremy Lee shares some of his favourite recipes
fields.trailText: A parfait of pear, walnut praline ice cream, blood orange granita, melon and ginger sorbet, and baked Alaska. Jeremy Lee shares some of his favourite recipes
fields.body:
All recipes serve six.

A parfait of pear

Jane Grigson describes this dessert as a poetic finish to a special meal. It is.

250g caster sugar

125ml water

4 very fresh, large egg whites

750g Williams pears

1 lemon, juiced

300ml double cream

4 tbsp pear eau de vie

In a pan, dissolve the sugar in the water over a low heat until the liquid is clear. Bring up to boil, and maintain the pace until the syrup reaches 120C (you can be precise if you have a kitchen thermometer; otherwise, just make sure it's very hot). Should the sugar crystallise on the sides of the pan, wash it down with a brush dipped in cold water.

In a scrupulously cleaned bowl, whisk the egg whites into stiff peaks, then pour in the hot syrup and beat until the meringue stiffens into a great white mass. Peel and core the pears, and chop their flesh. Place the pear pieces in a pan, along with the lemon juice, and cook gently until the fruit has softened. Process into a purée.

Lightly whip the cream, then fold it carefully into the meringue mix. Now fold in the eau de vie and the purée. Spoon into a 1-litre terrine or mould, cover and freeze, preferably overnight. To serve, unmould, cut into slices with a heated knife and dish up with some almond or vanilla thins.

Walnut praline ice cream

This will feed more than six, so there's plenty for second helpings.

250g shelled walnuts

142ml water

320g sugar

142ml milk

4 egg yolks

3 tbsp dark rum

284ml double cream

You can freeze this either in individual ramekins or somesuch or, as I do, in a lovely big bowl. Pre-heat the oven to 190C/375F/gas mark 5. Put the walnuts on a flat tray and roast until quite brown - do not scorch.

Put the water in a heavy-bottomed, stainless-steel pan and place over a medium heat. Pour in the sugar, and stir until dissolved. The syrup will start to colour after a couple of minutes and then darken; you're after a caramel that is dark but not burnt. Once the caramel is right, remove from the heat, tip in the roasted walnuts and stir very carefully - a caramel burn is pain beyond endurance. Lightly oil a tray, spread out the mixture on it, and leave to cool and set.

Set the cooking pan to one side, as any caramel stuck to the bottom will be used up later. Once cooled, break up the now-brittle praline into a bowl, then grind into a rough-cut powder with large chunks within. Put the milk in the caramel pan, set it over a medium heat and stir until the caramel has dissolved.

In a mixing bowl, beat the yolks until pale and grown in volume, then add a third of the praline powder, and beat until thick and tacky. Pour the heated milk in a thin, steady stream over this, return the whole lot to the pan and stir over a medium heat until it has thickened and bubbles have ceased to appear on the surface.

Remove from the heat, stir in another third of the praline mix and stir until cooled. Transfer to a bowl suitable for an electric beater, and whisk at high speed until the custard thickens. Add the rum and, when the mix is quite cool, the rest of the praline. Whip the cream until it begins to hold a shape, fold into the custard and then transfer the ice cream into your vessel(s) of choice. Freeze, preferably overnight. Transfer from freezer to fridge an hour before eating .

Blood orange granita

I know all is meant to be metric these days, but sugar-to-water measures seem only to work in imperial, so there.

1 pint water

1lb sugar

2 pints blood orange juice

1 small lemon, juiced

In a pan, dissolve the sugar and water, bring to a boil and remove from the heat. Once it has cooled completely, sieve the orange and lemon juices, and pour into the syrup. Tip into a freezing tray and freeze. As the granita freezes, break it up every 30 minutes or so with a fork, until you have a great pile of crystals. Transfer to a container with a secure lid, and keep in the freezer, where it will last for at least a week. Serve in frozen glasses .

Melon and ginger sorbet

Use Charentais, if you can, but the main rule is that the melon is sweet and ripe.

1 kg ripe melon flesh and juice

115g caster sugar

3cm piece fresh ginger

Juice of 1 small lemon

Peel and grate the ginger over a plate, to keep as much juice as possible. Put all the ingredients into a liquidiser and purée until very smooth. Pass through a fine sieve, then churn in an ice cream machine.

Baked Alaska

The ice cream and sponge can be bought, but homemade elevates what is a good dessert into a very good one indeed. Both can be frozen until required, as can the finished dish.

For the sponge

170g unsalted butter, softened

170g caster sugar

3 very fresh, large eggs

Zest and juice of 1 lemon

170g self-raising flour, sifted

For the vanilla ice cream

1 vanilla pod

60Oml milk

7 egg yolks

250g caster sugar

750ml double cream

For the meringue

4 egg whites

85g caster sugar

4 tbsp apricot jam

You'll need three roughly equal-sized rectangular vessels for this: a baking tin, for the sponge; a freezer container, for the ice cream; and a dish for the end-result. Make the sponge first. Pre-heat the oven to 190C/375F/gas mark 5. Lightly butter a sponge tin. Beat together the sugar and butter until pale. Crack the eggs into a jug, beat, and add in a slow stream to the butter/sugar mix. Beat in the lemon juice and rind, then fold in the flour. Put the batter in the tin, and bake for 25 minutes.

Next, make the ice cream. Split the vanilla pod, scrape out the seeds into a heavy-bottomed pan, drop in the pod and then pour in the milk. Place over a medium heat, and leave gently to infuse. In a large bowl, beat together the egg yolks and sugar, and, once the milk is scalded, pour it over this eggy mixture, stirring all the while. Pour back into the pot, return to the heat and stir constantly until the custard thickens and the bubbles on the surface disappear. Still stirring, pour in the cream, then leave to stand for an hour, so the vanilla flavour can fully permeate the cream. Strain and churn in an ice-cream machine. Scoop into the rectangular mould, and freeze.

Now you're ready to assemble the baked Alaska. First, choose a suitable dish that will go happily from freezer to oven to table. Now make the meringue: beat in the egg whites until they are stiff but not dry, beat in half the sugar until stiff peaks are regained, then fold in the rest of the sugar. Spread a not-too-deep layer of meringue at the base of the dish. Cut the sponge in half horizontally, and spread apricot jam over one side of each piece. Lay a slice of sponge, jam-side up, on top of the meringue. Unmould the ice cream and place it as a block on top of the sponge. Place the second piece of sponge, jam-side down, on the ice cream, and then cover with meringue, making sure that it completely seals the cake.

The Alaska will stay happily in the freezer until required. To cook, bake for six to eight minutes in a pre-heated oven at 230C/450F/gas mark 8, until golden in colour and flecked with little dark spots. Eat there and then

 Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, London SE1.

fields.headline: Home is the hunter
fields.standfirst: This great American playwright has been accused of misogyny and pessimism, and in his latest books he reveals his technophobia. But  Stephen Moss finds that his young family, community and religion have given him a new sense of belonging
fields.trailText: This great American playwright has been accused of misogyny and pessimism, and in his latest books he reveals his technophobia. But Stephen Moss finds that his young family, community and religion have given him a new sense of belonging
fields.body:
David Mamet's reputations precede him. There's the reluctant interviewee - tough, prickly, hates small talk, doesn't suffer fools gladly, doesn't suffer them at all. And there's the great writer - "With Sam Shepard and Arthur Miller, he is one of the three greatest living American playwrights," says Patrick Marber, who directed The Old Neighborhood at the Royal Court in 1998 and is currently on tour in Mamet's Speed-the-Plow, written in the late 80s. "Mamet brought a language to the stage that hadn't quite been there before, but he also brought with that language the classical beauty in his work. He's a classical writer."

"Everyone knows he's a great writer, but he's a great storyteller too," says William H Macy, who is playing Teach in the current Donmar Warehouse production of American Buffalo. "When he first wrote Buffalo, what made me feel so proud was that he was writing in an American idiom and had found the beauty in it; it's just gorgeous - the metre and the rhythm, the music in this stuff - and he was the first writer who captured it."

Over the past quarter-century, since American Buffalo made Mamet famous at the age of 28, the torrent of plays and - since the early 80s - movies, has been unstoppable. "He goes into the men's room and comes out with a script," as one of his film collaborators puts it.

The plays Glengarry Glen Ross, which won him a Pulitzer prize, Edmond, Speed-the-Plow, the controversial Oleanna, The Cryptogram (a highly personal play about a young boy losing his innocence in the face of domestic trauma) and The Old Neighborhood have made him the hottest ticket on Broadway and in London's West End. Screenplays for The Postman Always Rings Twice, The Verdict, The Untouchables, Hoffa, The Edge and Wag The Dog have established him as an A-list Hollywood screenwriter, and he has had success as a writer-director with House of Games, Homicide, The Spanish Prisoner and, last year, The Winslow Boy.

His productivity is extraordinary: plays, movies, five collections of essays, books on acting and directing, poetry, children's books. Monday sees the publication of a new novel, Wilson, and his latest book of essays, Jafsie And John Henry; Mamet recently did a screenplay for the film of Thomas Harris's Hannibal ("it was pretty good but the studio didn't think so and fired me"); a new movie of his own called State And Main is in post-production; and he has finished the script for another movie to be shot in the autumn. How many Mamets are there?

We have breakfast at Henrietta's Table near Harvard Square, close to his office in Cambridge, Massachusetts. The restaurant's motto is "fresh and honest", which might serve for Mamet too. For the photograph, he sets his jaw and adopts what looks like a grimace. "Smile", says the photographer, "this is a happy occasion."

"I am smiling," says Mamet.

The journalist Minty Clinch once described Mamet as looking like a bulldog guarding its gate: you approach at your peril. The late Michael VerMeulen, former editor of GQ - a friend from Mamet's early theatre days in Chicago in the mid-70s - called him the "Great Satan" of the interview, and truly he despises the form. "It's inherently a corrupt transaction," he says.

Mamet will pronounce in general terms on art - he argues that the artist is responding to repression in society but, unlike the propagandist, expounds no theory, offers no solution. What he will not do is attempt to examine his own work. "I'm paid to write things, not read them," he says pithily.

He is not rude; indeed he is quite formal and punctilious in observing the pleasantries. But he is contemptuous of "the interview", the journalistic attempt to corner the artistic impulse. He is also averse to talking about his private life. "I don't think your readers will want to know about my private life. That's just gossip." (This in response to an innocent question about whether he spends more time at his lovely house in a suburb of Boston or his even lovelier 100-acre farm in Vermont.)

His new novel, said his wife, the Scottish actress Rebecca Pidgeon, was impenetrable; his agent, Andrew Wylie, said it was unpublishable. It is set hundreds of years into the future, when mankind has decamped to Mars. A computer crash has wiped out all knowledge of the past and a smug academic is trying to recreate it from fragmented sources, adding dodgy hypotheses to others' doctored histories. It is tragedy rendered as comedy, a very Mametian device; it is funny, provocative, and rather too self-conscious, the batteries of footnotes enumerating cod sources dimming after a while.

Look for logic in the book and you are doomed to disappointment. "Treat it as a modern-day Tristram Shandy," says his editor at Faber hopefully. "His plays and films are accessible but in fiction he is a hardline modernist." The point of the book seems to be that scholarship is limited, truth partial and the past a barely audible Chinese whisper.

The threat posed by the "information age" is a theme that surfaces repeatedly in his new collection of essays. "I can envision no device more capable of spreading ignorance and illiteracy than the computer," he writes. "It is, I think, like the atom bomb, a naturally evolved engine of oblivion, a sign, like the Tower of Babel, that civilisation has run its course." (Mamet continues to write on a typewriter; his office does not have e-mail; "it's Victorian here", says his assistant.)

Mamet is, however, loath to agree that the arguments forcefully put in the essays are given fictional flesh in Wilson: "It's just a bunch of stuff that I think is funny", is his summing up of the novel. "James Joyce," he adds, "when asked what Finnegans Wake was about, said it's just about a bunch of Micks. I don't want to look for themes. It's like saying to Mark Rothko, 'I get it, you're trying to make a paint chart - a little bit of orange, a little bit of yellow...' "

There is a good deal of pessimism in the essays: in "LA Homes" he refers to "the roadside crash which is our culture"; in "Why Don't You Write With A Computer" he says "television's mindless and interminable banality has made us stupid - unable to recognise, let alone understand, the simplest human interactions". He comes on as grouchy, preachy, sometimes fogeyish in his dismissal of our foolishness and triviality.

Is he happy? "It's in my nature to be weak and complaining once in a while, and when that happens I try to remember to kick myself, or my wife remembers to kick me and says 'what, are you crazy?' Writing is so much better than working for a living, better than scrubbing floors."

And he should know: when he was struggling to build a theatrical career in his early twenties, he took cleaning jobs, was a waiter, drove a taxi, worked in a junk shop (cue American Buffalo) and a real estate office (ditto Glengarry Glen Ross). Those plays depict masculine, intensely competitive worlds and the marginalisation of women in his plays has not been lost on critics. In Sexual Perversity In Chicago, men and women engage in mutually uncomprehending warfare, power games fuelled by fear and fast talk. In Speed-the-Plow, a close, joshing male friendship is threatened by the arrival of a strange, idealistic, faintly sinister woman.

"Men have a lot to learn from women," Mamet says in an essay called, simply, "Women" (which he says he wrote "for a dare"). Men are the puppydogs of the universe. Men will waste their time in pursuit of the utterly useless simply because their peers are all doing it. Women will not. They are legitimately goal-oriented, and their goals, for the most part, are simple: love, security, money, prestige. These are good, direct, meaningful goals, especially as opposed to the more male objectives of glory, acceptance, and being well-liked. Women don't give a tinker's damn about being well-liked, which means they don't know how to compromise."

There are some dangerous sallies on the sex war in Mamet's essays. "In husband-and-wife arguments, or, as they are generally known, 'marriage', the ultimate response the man feels is, of course, physical violence," he says in "True Stories of Bitches". (Bitchiness, which he raises to the status of an art form, is not gender-specific.)

When Oleanna was premiered, sensationally, in 1992 at Harvard University - the home of American liberalism - Mamet admitted, it was "like doing The Diary Of Anne Frank at Dachau". The play concerns a young female student who, by falsely accusing her tutor of rape, destroys his career. The play hit every hot button - gender wars, political correctness, patriarchal power, academic freedom, male violence, feminist myopia - and audience reactions were almost unprecedented. Men tended to side with the tutor, women with the student.

Mamet, true to form, refused to explain the play, though he did insist it was not inspired by the contemporaneous Clarence Thomas-Anita Hill sexual harassment case. Some refused to accept his claimed neutrality. "Mr Mamet has never been known for being particularly sensitive to women's issues," wrote one American critic. "Nor does he write particularly sympathetic female characters. But with Oleanna he has surely written his most misogynistic script yet."

Mary McCann, who played the part of Carol in New York, defends him from feminist obloquy. "The play isn't about a woman who's a villain and sets a man up. David thinks both characters are absolutely honest. We are so conditioned to having things neatly wrapped up that when it doesn't happen, people are outraged. Doing Oleanna, I was amazed at how different people's interpretations of what they saw were. There was outrage on all sides."

It is true that Mamet's world - with its late-night poker, guns, knives, games-playing, japes and quotidian male stupidities - is fuelled by testosterone. "Mamet's is a man's world and any woman in it has to recognise that," says Macy, referring principally to his fictional world. That doesn't mean that he automatically sides with men; he simply knows them and feels for their impotent swagger.

Mamet likes to cast himself as undisciplined - he says he writes across so many genres because he is easily bored - but that may be dissimulation. His five-year-old daughter Clara is learning the violin by the Suzuki method, and he subscribes to Shinichi Suzuki's singlemindedness. "If we get used to acting on every idea we have, our life becomes extremely full," Mamet says. "If we replace the thought with the action, there's a recognition that the thought is meritless."

He loves to work - "he has to be building something", says Macy. He adores the camaraderie and collective effort of the theatre and the film set. "He walks in on the first day and knows everyone's name on the set," says film editor Barbara Tulliver. "He appreciates people who do their job well."

"He's a master storyteller," she says. "When he writes something he edits it down so there is no fat." He adopts the same approach with actors. "He's a bit like Mussolini as a director," says Macy, who has known Mamet since Goddard College in the late 60s, where Mamet studied and later taught acting. "His phrase is 'take it easy, you don't gotta do that', and it's frustrating sometimes, sometimes enraging. David will take away and take away, and what happens with many actors is that they basically give up. You've got to do what he says, but you can't give up.

"His view is that everything you need is on the page. A writer is not trying to trick his actors, he's not keeping back any vital information. So many actors have this attitude; 'it's a puzzle and we must solve this puzzle'. Dave's attitude is; 'this is not a puzzle, I'm telling you everything I know'."

There is something rabbinical about Mamet, especially now that his beard is flecked with grey. The young foursquare theatrical lion of countless 80s photographs is being replaced by an older, more reflec tive figure. The temperature is around zero on this day in Boston, and he keeps his black beret on and the collar of his polo-neck sweater well up; he seems to have a slight crick in the neck.

At 52, he is not old - still moves fast, still devours work and hearty breakfasts, can go 10 rounds with anyone - but the process of ageing seems to fascinate him. "Looking At Fifty" is the title of the first essay in the new collection, and the theme runs through the entire book. Essays, especially when they have previously appeared in magazines, can have a disparate feel to them, but this really is a book, given unity by the fact that they have all been written in the past five years, when Mamet has been making a mid-life reckoning, searching, as he says in the introduction, for a "new model".

The essays are charming, wistful, funny, wise, the reflections of a man who has both read and lived, who can manage Homer and Hollywood. He writes plainly yet philosophically; his vision is both deep and wide; he makes you laugh hard and think harder. If Mamet in person is a studied act in negation, Mamet in his essays is a delightful and instructive read.

He is master storyteller, able to pace a narrative to perfection; a lyrical writer too, capable of simple, direct, lovely prose; a careful observer;. a lover of language; a terrific wit: "They say the definition of ambivalence is watching your mother-in-law drive over a cliff in your new Cadillac"; and a master of the bitter Jewish joke: "My people don't travel well - for the past thousand years we usually moved only because someone was trying to kill us." He is an object fetishist too - the Karmann Ghia sports car, the IBM Selectric typewriter, turtle-neck sweaters, guns, knives, caps, even that famously functional, sharply defining crew-cut - and an obsessive collector of most of the above.

Above all, he is what all great writers are - a searcher for the real, an exposer of the artificial or corrupt, a truth-teller. The closing words of his pithy and provocative book on acting, True And False: Heresy And Common Sense For The Actor, could be taken as an epigraph for his entire literary under taking: "What is true, what is false, what is finally important? It is not a sign of ignorance not to know the answers. But there is great merit in facing the questions."

Mamet loathes artifice and is constantly comparing the earthy reality of Chicago with the Hollywood dreamworld. He venerates "outdoors people" - he is a keen hunter, but says his eyesight is too bad ever to hit anything - and hymns "their reverence for knowledge and their understanding that knowledge lies not in the self but in the world around them". He is simultaneously in awe of the world and fearful for its future: that produces a jangling tension in his writing. He unites opposites: then and now, optimism and pessimism, lyricism and aggression, beauty and ugliness. The way he writes about crooks and shysters is tinged with sympathy, finding music in the language of the streets.

Macy puts this perfectly: "He brought the language of the street on to the stage and on to film, but he didn't bring it in its ugliness, he brought it in its beauty. It is a thrill to speak because of the music." "He's writing disjointed vernacular and you have to dig deep in order to learn it," says Mark Strong, who is appearing in Speed-The-Plow. Marber is keen to free Mamet from his public persona - as a streetwise writer producing fast, hard-boiled dialogue laced with four-letter words. "He writes beautiful, lyrical speeches as well. He can write lyrical, poetic plays as well as the more regular, streety, vernacular plays, and I think Speed-the-Plow is a bit of both."

Beauty and aggression characterise Mamet's work, just as they characterised his childhood in Chicago in the 50s. "My childhood, like many people's, was not a bundle of laughs. So what? I always skip that part of the biography," he told John Lahr in 1997.

Not quite always: the essay "Five Mile Walk" in Jafsie And John Henry, is wonderfully evocative of a wayward, romantic, innocent childhood: "Now and then we would take the train into the city. We were interested in climbing and trespassing. We would climb the girders of a bridge. We would break into a building under construction and explore. We went to the museum, and spent a day walking the pediments, among the caryatids, 30 feet off the ground. When I was by myself I would spend the day in the city shoplifting."

As a boy, Mamet was lonely, self-aware, alienated; he did poorly at school - he was endlessly told that he was not "living up to his potential" - and rebelled against the system, but he still read avidly, on his own terms. "I would haunt the library. I'd walk the stacks - the floor was made of glass bricks, and they fascinated me. I'd find a likely-looking novel and read it in the big room, and find another, and read that, until it was time to return home."

His parents divorced when he was 11 - "we lived", his sister Lynn told Lahr, "in an emotional hurricane" - and his mother quickly remarried. Mamet was very close to his father, Bernie, a quick-witted lawyer, whose linguistic exactitude his son inherited, but he disliked his stepfather, who had a violent temper. The aggression, verbal and physical, that punctuated his upbringing is echoed throughout Mamet's work: close relationships are war zones, words artillery shells, life a battle. Occasionally, the smoke clears to give moments of peace, epiphanies when all things seem possible.

In his essay "The Rake", which appears in the collection The Cabin, Mamet lays bare the pain of his teenage years: his stepfather shattering a glass table in a fit of temper and blaming the children; his mother cutting her hands collecting the shards; an occasion when his sister was kept home from a school play - in which she had the lead role - because she was too excited to eat her meal; worst of all, a terrible incident where Mamet, in a fit of rage, threw a rake at his sister and badly cut her lip. His mother demanded to know what had happened and refused to take her to hospital until they had told her. "So the family sat down to dinner, where my sister clutched a napkin to her face and the blood soaked the napkin and ran down on to her food, which she had to eat."

At 15, Mamet grew tired of the war and went back to live with his father - "the intense relationship of David's life", according to the director Gregory Mosher, who directed many Mamet premieres. Lahr tells how at Bernie's funeral in 1991, Mamet insisted on burying his father himself, taking 40 minutes on a hot summer's day to finish the task.

Mamet got involved with a theatre group in Chicago, then a centre of vibrant, pioneering drama, and immediately fell in love with the world. At 18, he went to Goddard College in Vermont, "a hippy school where you got credits for taking drugs", according to his close friend Jonathan Katz. "He was there to get an education, so the rest of us found him a little disturbing."

Mamet studied theatre and creative writing and, after graduating in 1969, taught acting in Vermont, co-founded the St Nicholas Theater Company in Chicago, and wrote Pinteresque sketches, the electrifying Sexual Perversity in Chicago (1974) and American Buffalo (1975), which proved his breakthrough play and led him to leave for New York the following year.

Sexual Perversity in Chicago was later made into a movie, called About Last Night. Mamet's screenplay was butchered and what eventually emerged was dross that left him feeling embittered. Speed-the-Plow can in part be read as an act of revenge. His dealings with Hollywood have always been slightly arm's length; he has no home on the west coast and pokes fun at it in the essay LA Homes, as well as in his new movie State And Main, where a film crew takes over a US town.

How do the occupants of those lavish LA homes feel about this hi-falutin' easterner's jibes? "Hollywood is uninsultable," says producer Art Linson, who worked with Mamet on The Untouchables. "It's all about money. Hollywood will not feel insulted by him as long as he makes money. If you stop making money and then insult them, it can be very thin-skinned. If Tom Hanks had a few harsh words to say about Hollywood, they'd live with it. Mamet is still in credit, though not as much as Tom Hanks, naturally."

Linson says Mamet "has tended to write big movies and direct small ones. He has done mainstream movies and maverick projects - films that have made money and films that haven't made money. He hasn't directed a blockbuster yet, but then he hasn't had any blockbuster budgets."

Michael Hausman, who produced House Of Games, Things Change, and Homicide, makes a similar point: "He gets his price as a screenwriter but he doesn't get his price as a screenwriter-director. His subject matter is not really Hollywood material when he's writing for himself. People would probably only risk $10m-$20m on one of his films - a crazy amount in any other business but not in Hollywood - but for other people he can write big."

Hausman offers a character assessment that is common among those who have worked with him: "He knows what he wants and he gets what he wants. He's very good with actors and with crew members; he's loyal to people and trusts you if you do your job. When you buy David, you buy his mouth, you buy his words. He's not easy but he's worth it - that's how I would sum him up."

Mamet married Rebecca Pidgeon in 1991. They had met when she appeared in Speed-The-Plow at the National Theatre in 1989. Mamet's first marriage, to the feisty New York actress Lindsay Crouse, with whom he had two daughters, had broken down, and the relationship with Pidgeon has given him what Lahr called "a new mellowness".

"She had a tremendous effect in anchoring him, in calming him down, in making him feel it's OK to be scared, it's OK to be upset, it's OK to fail," his sister Lynn has said. "I think she has allowed my brother to exhale for the first time in his life."

"When I first saw Dave, when he came over to England to direct Speed-the-Plow, it was quite a shock for me," Pidgeon said last year. "I was expecting an Arthur Miller, and there he was, with his little scarf tied nattily around his neck like some Parisian mime artist. He looked younger than I thought he was going to, and I couldn't understand how such a young person could have written all this work. He is approachable, but a little intimidating at first. He has a reputation for being tough, but not with actors - with producers.

"When he is working at home, he has to have a lot of time alone, a lot of dreaming time. He is supportive, though. When I joined him there [in the US], I had to start all over again. That was scary, because I had left a thriving career. Being married to Dave turned out to be quite damaging to my career. People thought of me as some wife; my acting credits did not mean anything. But Dave really loves my acting, God bless him, and that helped." Mamet and Pidgeon have two children - Clara and one-year-old Noah.

Mamet, in a rare excursion into personal territory, said: "Rebecca is a very honest and straightforward and self-confident actress. It is not that I am particularly idealistic about women, but Rebecca happens to be as admirable a person on stage as she is in life. My sister has said that my writing for women characters has improved, or changed, since I have been close to Rebecca, but you should remember that my sister also said President Roosevelt is alive and well and living in Argentina. I think the only thing that has changed about my writing over the years is my typing, which has got a lot worse."

His refusal to align life with art is typical, and legitimate - artists reject such crude reductionism. But it is tempting to see his marriage to Pidgeon in 1991 and the death of his father in the same year as turning points. His latest essays are reflective and very personal; he turned to novel-writing - The Village (1994), The Old Religion (1997) and now Wilson; he has become both more religious and more overtly Jewish in outlook.

"He is deeply religious," says Macy, "and his rabbi is one of his closest friends." He lives in Newton, a suburb of Boston which has a large Jewish community. "I notice that the Boston Globe refers to him these days as the Newton writer," says his friend Jonathan Wilson. "He seems to enjoy the sense of community. He has been happier in the past 10 years than previously."

In an essay 15 years ago, Mamet wrote: "I have always felt that people look on me as an outcast. I have always felt like an outsider; and I am sure that the suspicion that I perceive is the suspicion that I provoke by my great longing to belong [his emphasis].

"As the children of immigrant Jews, we are spurred in our need to observe by the memory of old humiliations, of old indignities_ Trained not to assimilate, we have found useless the virtues of compromise with our environment... True to our past, we live and work with an inherited, observed, and accepted vision of personal futility, and of the beauty of the world."

As a young man, Mamet tried - shades of Melville - to get a berth on a ship. His attempt to escape failed and he took shelter in the theatre, a surrogate home. Now he has a real home, an adored family, a close-knit community; perhaps at last he feels he belongs. Much of what he writes is deeply pessimistic - in Wilson he envisages a world without knowledge or wonder or truth - but his warnings show that he cares passionately. He chides us not from rage, but from love.

Education: Goddard College, Vermont (BA Eng lit 1969).
