fields.bodyText: David Mamet's reputations precede him. There's the reluctant interviewee - tough, prickly, hates small talk, doesn't suffer fools gladly, doesn't suffer them at all. And there's the great writer - "With Sam Shepard and Arthur Miller, he is one of the three greatest living American playwrights," says Patrick Marber, who directed The Old Neighborhood at the Royal Court in 1998 and is currently on tour in Mamet's Speed-the-Plow, written in the late 80s. "Mamet brought a language to the stage that hadn't quite been there before, but he also brought with that language the classical beauty in his work. He's a classical writer." "Everyone knows he's a great writer, but he's a great storyteller too," says William H Macy, who is playing Teach in the current Donmar Warehouse production of American Buffalo. "When he first wrote Buffalo, what made me feel so proud was that he was writing in an American idiom and had found the beauty in it; it's just gorgeous - the metre and the rhythm, the music in this stuff - and he was the first writer who captured it." Over the past quarter-century, since American Buffalo made Mamet famous at the age of 28, the torrent of plays and - since the early 80s - movies, has been unstoppable. "He goes into the men's room and comes out with a script," as one of his film collaborators puts it. The plays Glengarry Glen Ross, which won him a Pulitzer prize, Edmond, Speed-the-Plow, the controversial Oleanna, The Cryptogram (a highly personal play about a young boy losing his innocence in the face of domestic trauma) and The Old Neighborhood have made him the hottest ticket on Broadway and in London's West End. Screenplays for The Postman Always Rings Twice, The Verdict, The Untouchables, Hoffa, The Edge and Wag The Dog have established him as an A-list Hollywood screenwriter, and he has had success as a writer-director with House of Games, Homicide, The Spanish Prisoner and, last year, The Winslow Boy. His productivity is extraordinary: plays, movies, five collections of essays, books on acting and directing, poetry, children's books. Monday sees the publication of a new novel, Wilson, and his latest book of essays, Jafsie And John Henry; Mamet recently did a screenplay for the film of Thomas Harris's Hannibal ("it was pretty good but the studio didn't think so and fired me"); a new movie of his own called State And Main is in post-production; and he has finished the script for another movie to be shot in the autumn. How many Mamets are there? We have breakfast at Henrietta's Table near Harvard Square, close to his office in Cambridge, Massachusetts. The restaurant's motto is "fresh and honest", which might serve for Mamet too. For the photograph, he sets his jaw and adopts what looks like a grimace. "Smile", says the photographer, "this is a happy occasion." "I am smiling," says Mamet. The journalist Minty Clinch once described Mamet as looking like a bulldog guarding its gate: you approach at your peril. The late Michael VerMeulen, former editor of GQ - a friend from Mamet's early theatre days in Chicago in the mid-70s - called him the "Great Satan" of the interview, and truly he despises the form. "It's inherently a corrupt transaction," he says. Mamet will pronounce in general terms on art - he argues that the artist is responding to repression in society but, unlike the propagandist, expounds no theory, offers no solution. What he will not do is attempt to examine his own work. "I'm paid to write things, not read them," he says pithily. He is not rude; indeed he is quite formal and punctilious in observing the pleasantries. But he is contemptuous of "the interview", the journalistic attempt to corner the artistic impulse. He is also averse to talking about his private life. "I don't think your readers will want to know about my private life. That's just gossip." (This in response to an innocent question about whether he spends more time at his lovely house in a suburb of Boston or his even lovelier 100-acre farm in Vermont.) His new novel, said his wife, the Scottish actress Rebecca Pidgeon, was impenetrable; his agent, Andrew Wylie, said it was unpublishable. It is set hundreds of years into the future, when mankind has decamped to Mars. A computer crash has wiped out all knowledge of the past and a smug academic is trying to recreate it from fragmented sources, adding dodgy hypotheses to others' doctored histories. It is tragedy rendered as comedy, a very Mametian device; it is funny, provocative, and rather too self-conscious, the batteries of footnotes enumerating cod sources dimming after a while. Look for logic in the book and you are doomed to disappointment. "Treat it as a modern-day Tristram Shandy," says his editor at Faber hopefully. "His plays and films are accessible but in fiction he is a hardline modernist." The point of the book seems to be that scholarship is limited, truth partial and the past a barely audible Chinese whisper. The threat posed by the "information age" is a theme that surfaces repeatedly in his new collection of essays. "I can envision no device more capable of spreading ignorance and illiteracy than the computer," he writes. "It is, I think, like the atom bomb, a naturally evolved engine of oblivion, a sign, like the Tower of Babel, that civilisation has run its course." (Mamet continues to write on a typewriter; his office does not have e-mail; "it's Victorian here", says his assistant.) Mamet is, however, loath to agree that the arguments forcefully put in the essays are given fictional flesh in Wilson: "It's just a bunch of stuff that I think is funny", is his summing up of the novel. "James Joyce," he adds, "when asked what Finnegans Wake was about, said it's just about a bunch of Micks. I don't want to look for themes. It's like saying to Mark Rothko, 'I get it, you're trying to make a paint chart - a little bit of orange, a little bit of yellow...' " There is a good deal of pessimism in the essays: in "LA Homes" he refers to "the roadside crash which is our culture"; in "Why Don't You Write With A Computer" he says "television's mindless and interminable banality has made us stupid - unable to recognise, let alone understand, the simplest human interactions". He comes on as grouchy, preachy, sometimes fogeyish in his dismissal of our foolishness and triviality. Is he happy? "It's in my nature to be weak and complaining once in a while, and when that happens I try to remember to kick myself, or my wife remembers to kick me and says 'what, are you crazy?' Writing is so much better than working for a living, better than scrubbing floors." And he should know: when he was struggling to build a theatrical career in his early twenties, he took cleaning jobs, was a waiter, drove a taxi, worked in a junk shop (cue American Buffalo) and a real estate office (ditto Glengarry Glen Ross). Those plays depict masculine, intensely competitive worlds and the marginalisation of women in his plays has not been lost on critics. In Sexual Perversity In Chicago, men and women engage in mutually uncomprehending warfare, power games fuelled by fear and fast talk. In Speed-the-Plow, a close, joshing male friendship is threatened by the arrival of a strange, idealistic, faintly sinister woman. "Men have a lot to learn from women," Mamet says in an essay called, simply, "Women" (which he says he wrote "for a dare"). Men are the puppydogs of the universe. Men will waste their time in pursuit of the utterly useless simply because their peers are all doing it. Women will not. They are legitimately goal-oriented, and their goals, for the most part, are simple: love, security, money, prestige. These are good, direct, meaningful goals, especially as opposed to the more male objectives of glory, acceptance, and being well-liked. Women don't give a tinker's damn about being well-liked, which means they don't know how to compromise." There are some dangerous sallies on the sex war in Mamet's essays. "In husband-and-wife arguments, or, as they are generally known, 'marriage', the ultimate response the man feels is, of course, physical violence," he says in "True Stories of Bitches". (Bitchiness, which he raises to the status of an art form, is not gender-specific.) When Oleanna was premiered, sensationally, in 1992 at Harvard University - the home of American liberalism - Mamet admitted, it was "like doing The Diary Of Anne Frank at Dachau". The play concerns a young female student who, by falsely accusing her tutor of rape, destroys his career. The play hit every hot button - gender wars, political correctness, patriarchal power, academic freedom, male violence, feminist myopia - and audience reactions were almost unprecedented. Men tended to side with the tutor, women with the student. Mamet, true to form, refused to explain the play, though he did insist it was not inspired by the contemporaneous Clarence Thomas-Anita Hill sexual harassment case. Some refused to accept his claimed neutrality. "Mr Mamet has never been known for being particularly sensitive to women's issues," wrote one American critic. "Nor does he write particularly sympathetic female characters. But with Oleanna he has surely written his most misogynistic script yet." Mary McCann, who played the part of Carol in New York, defends him from feminist obloquy. "The play isn't about a woman who's a villain and sets a man up. David thinks both characters are absolutely honest. We are so conditioned to having things neatly wrapped up that when it doesn't happen, people are outraged. Doing Oleanna, I was amazed at how different people's interpretations of what they saw were. There was outrage on all sides." It is true that Mamet's world - with its late-night poker, guns, knives, games-playing, japes and quotidian male stupidities - is fuelled by testosterone. "Mamet's is a man's world and any woman in it has to recognise that," says Macy, referring principally to his fictional world. That doesn't mean that he automatically sides with men; he simply knows them and feels for their impotent swagger. Mamet likes to cast himself as undisciplined - he says he writes across so many genres because he is easily bored - but that may be dissimulation. His five-year-old daughter Clara is learning the violin by the Suzuki method, and he subscribes to Shinichi Suzuki's singlemindedness. "If we get used to acting on every idea we have, our life becomes extremely full," Mamet says. "If we replace the thought with the action, there's a recognition that the thought is meritless." He loves to work - "he has to be building something", says Macy. He adores the camaraderie and collective effort of the theatre and the film set. "He walks in on the first day and knows everyone's name on the set," says film editor Barbara Tulliver. "He appreciates people who do their job well." "He's a master storyteller," she says. "When he writes something he edits it down so there is no fat." He adopts the same approach with actors. "He's a bit like Mussolini as a director," says Macy, who has known Mamet since Goddard College in the late 60s, where Mamet studied and later taught acting. "His phrase is 'take it easy, you don't gotta do that', and it's frustrating sometimes, sometimes enraging. David will take away and take away, and what happens with many actors is that they basically give up. You've got to do what he says, but you can't give up. "His view is that everything you need is on the page. A writer is not trying to trick his actors, he's not keeping back any vital information. So many actors have this attitude; 'it's a puzzle and we must solve this puzzle'. Dave's attitude is; 'this is not a puzzle, I'm telling you everything I know'." There is something rabbinical about Mamet, especially now that his beard is flecked with grey. The young foursquare theatrical lion of countless 80s photographs is being replaced by an older, more reflec tive figure. The temperature is around zero on this day in Boston, and he keeps his black beret on and the collar of his polo-neck sweater well up; he seems to have a slight crick in the neck. At 52, he is not old - still moves fast, still devours work and hearty breakfasts, can go 10 rounds with anyone - but the process of ageing seems to fascinate him. "Looking At Fifty" is the title of the first essay in the new collection, and the theme runs through the entire book. Essays, especially when they have previously appeared in magazines, can have a disparate feel to them, but this really is a book, given unity by the fact that they have all been written in the past five years, when Mamet has been making a mid-life reckoning, searching, as he says in the introduction, for a "new model". The essays are charming, wistful, funny, wise, the reflections of a man who has both read and lived, who can manage Homer and Hollywood. He writes plainly yet philosophically; his vision is both deep and wide; he makes you laugh hard and think harder. If Mamet in person is a studied act in negation, Mamet in his essays is a delightful and instructive read. He is master storyteller, able to pace a narrative to perfection; a lyrical writer too, capable of simple, direct, lovely prose; a careful observer;. a lover of language; a terrific wit: "They say the definition of ambivalence is watching your mother-in-law drive over a cliff in your new Cadillac"; and a master of the bitter Jewish joke: "My people don't travel well - for the past thousand years we usually moved only because someone was trying to kill us." He is an object fetishist too - the Karmann Ghia sports car, the IBM Selectric typewriter, turtle-neck sweaters, guns, knives, caps, even that famously functional, sharply defining crew-cut - and an obsessive collector of most of the above. Above all, he is what all great writers are - a searcher for the real, an exposer of the artificial or corrupt, a truth-teller. The closing words of his pithy and provocative book on acting, True And False: Heresy And Common Sense For The Actor, could be taken as an epigraph for his entire literary under taking: "What is true, what is false, what is finally important? It is not a sign of ignorance not to know the answers. But there is great merit in facing the questions." Mamet loathes artifice and is constantly comparing the earthy reality of Chicago with the Hollywood dreamworld. He venerates "outdoors people" - he is a keen hunter, but says his eyesight is too bad ever to hit anything - and hymns "their reverence for knowledge and their understanding that knowledge lies not in the self but in the world around them". He is simultaneously in awe of the world and fearful for its future: that produces a jangling tension in his writing. He unites opposites: then and now, optimism and pessimism, lyricism and aggression, beauty and ugliness. The way he writes about crooks and shysters is tinged with sympathy, finding music in the language of the streets. Macy puts this perfectly: "He brought the language of the street on to the stage and on to film, but he didn't bring it in its ugliness, he brought it in its beauty. It is a thrill to speak because of the music." "He's writing disjointed vernacular and you have to dig deep in order to learn it," says Mark Strong, who is appearing in Speed-The-Plow. Marber is keen to free Mamet from his public persona - as a streetwise writer producing fast, hard-boiled dialogue laced with four-letter words. "He writes beautiful, lyrical speeches as well. He can write lyrical, poetic plays as well as the more regular, streety, vernacular plays, and I think Speed-the-Plow is a bit of both." Beauty and aggression characterise Mamet's work, just as they characterised his childhood in Chicago in the 50s. "My childhood, like many people's, was not a bundle of laughs. So what? I always skip that part of the biography," he told John Lahr in 1997. Not quite always: the essay "Five Mile Walk" in Jafsie And John Henry, is wonderfully evocative of a wayward, romantic, innocent childhood: "Now and then we would take the train into the city. We were interested in climbing and trespassing. We would climb the girders of a bridge. We would break into a building under construction and explore. We went to the museum, and spent a day walking the pediments, among the caryatids, 30 feet off the ground. When I was by myself I would spend the day in the city shoplifting." As a boy, Mamet was lonely, self-aware, alienated; he did poorly at school - he was endlessly told that he was not "living up to his potential" - and rebelled against the system, but he still read avidly, on his own terms. "I would haunt the library. I'd walk the stacks - the floor was made of glass bricks, and they fascinated me. I'd find a likely-looking novel and read it in the big room, and find another, and read that, until it was time to return home." His parents divorced when he was 11 - "we lived", his sister Lynn told Lahr, "in an emotional hurricane" - and his mother quickly remarried. Mamet was very close to his father, Bernie, a quick-witted lawyer, whose linguistic exactitude his son inherited, but he disliked his stepfather, who had a violent temper. The aggression, verbal and physical, that punctuated his upbringing is echoed throughout Mamet's work: close relationships are war zones, words artillery shells, life a battle. Occasionally, the smoke clears to give moments of peace, epiphanies when all things seem possible. In his essay "The Rake", which appears in the collection The Cabin, Mamet lays bare the pain of his teenage years: his stepfather shattering a glass table in a fit of temper and blaming the children; his mother cutting her hands collecting the shards; an occasion when his sister was kept home from a school play - in which she had the lead role - because she was too excited to eat her meal; worst of all, a terrible incident where Mamet, in a fit of rage, threw a rake at his sister and badly cut her lip. His mother demanded to know what had happened and refused to take her to hospital until they had told her. "So the family sat down to dinner, where my sister clutched a napkin to her face and the blood soaked the napkin and ran down on to her food, which she had to eat." At 15, Mamet grew tired of the war and went back to live with his father - "the intense relationship of David's life", according to the director Gregory Mosher, who directed many Mamet premieres. Lahr tells how at Bernie's funeral in 1991, Mamet insisted on burying his father himself, taking 40 minutes on a hot summer's day to finish the task. Mamet got involved with a theatre group in Chicago, then a centre of vibrant, pioneering drama, and immediately fell in love with the world. At 18, he went to Goddard College in Vermont, "a hippy school where you got credits for taking drugs", according to his close friend Jonathan Katz. "He was there to get an education, so the rest of us found him a little disturbing." Mamet studied theatre and creative writing and, after graduating in 1969, taught acting in Vermont, co-founded the St Nicholas Theater Company in Chicago, and wrote Pinteresque sketches, the electrifying Sexual Perversity in Chicago (1974) and American Buffalo (1975), which proved his breakthrough play and led him to leave for New York the following year. Sexual Perversity in Chicago was later made into a movie, called About Last Night. Mamet's screenplay was butchered and what eventually emerged was dross that left him feeling embittered. Speed-the-Plow can in part be read as an act of revenge. His dealings with Hollywood have always been slightly arm's length; he has no home on the west coast and pokes fun at it in the essay LA Homes, as well as in his new movie State And Main, where a film crew takes over a US town. How do the occupants of those lavish LA homes feel about this hi-falutin' easterner's jibes? "Hollywood is uninsultable," says producer Art Linson, who worked with Mamet on The Untouchables. "It's all about money. Hollywood will not feel insulted by him as long as he makes money. If you stop making money and then insult them, it can be very thin-skinned. If Tom Hanks had a few harsh words to say about Hollywood, they'd live with it. Mamet is still in credit, though not as much as Tom Hanks, naturally." Linson says Mamet "has tended to write big movies and direct small ones. He has done mainstream movies and maverick projects - films that have made money and films that haven't made money. He hasn't directed a blockbuster yet, but then he hasn't had any blockbuster budgets." Michael Hausman, who produced House Of Games, Things Change, and Homicide, makes a similar point: "He gets his price as a screenwriter but he doesn't get his price as a screenwriter-director. His subject matter is not really Hollywood material when he's writing for himself. People would probably only risk $10m-$20m on one of his films - a crazy amount in any other business but not in Hollywood - but for other people he can write big." Hausman offers a character assessment that is common among those who have worked with him: "He knows what he wants and he gets what he wants. He's not easy but he's worth it - that's how I would sum him up." Mamet married Rebecca Pidgeon in 1991. They had met when she appeared in Speed-The-Plow at the National Theatre in 1989. Mamet's first marriage, to the feisty New York actress Lindsay Crouse, with whom he had two daughters, had broken down, and the relationship with Pidgeon has given him what Lahr called "a new mellowness". "She had a tremendous effect in anchoring him, in calming him down, in making him feel it's OK to be scared, it's OK to be upset, it's OK to fail," his sister Lynn has said. "I think she has allowed my brother to exhale for the first time in his life." People thought of me as some wife; my acting credits did not mean anything. But Dave really loves my acting, God bless him, and that helped." webTitle: The science of freezing food... and why you should do it more

fields.headline: The science of freezing food... and why you should do it more
fields.standfirst: Chill out, says Peter Barham and Len Fisher, and give your freezer the same respect as the cooker
fields.trailText: There is a strong case for regarding freezing as one of the principal methods of cooking, which may be news to those who view the freezer only as a repository for their bottle of gin. Cooking is, after all, the process of using heat to make food more palatable. Most of the time we add heat to the food, but there are also occasions when we subtract it - why not call that cooking, too?
fields.body:
There is a strong case for regarding freezing as one of the principal methods of cooking, which may be news to those who view the freezer only as a repository for their bottle of gin. Cooking is, after all, the process of using heat to make food more palatable. Most of the time we add heat to the food, but there are also occasions when we subtract it - why not call that cooking, too?

The classic example of this form of cooking is the frozen dessert, such as sorbet and ice cream, both of which begin life as a flavoured liquid. In sorbets, the flavour is dissolved in water; ice creams, meanwhile, also have droplets of milk fat present, and some of the flavour is dissolved in these. Both contain sugar, and sometimes alcohol, too.

The presence of these additives is not incidental; it is essential. When we freeze a sorbet or ice cream, ice crystals grow from the water inside. These crystals are absolutely pure, frozen water. The sugar, flavourings and other water-soluble ingredients, such as alcohol, remain dissolved in what liquid is left, forming a more and more concentrated solution as more of the water turns to ice. Eventually, you end up with a slush of pure ice crystals in a very concentrated, flavoured sugar solution.

This is where the sugar and other water-soluble ingredients play their vital role. The more concentrated the solution gets, the lower its freezing point becomes. In fact, the solution becomes unfreezeable at domestic freezer temperatures (just as gin does, because of its high concentration of alcohol), and serves as a liquid lubricant that stops the ice crystals from sticking together.

Sorbets tend to be slightly acidic, usually from added fruit juices, and so are often used to clear the palate between courses, though scientifically there is still some way to go before we fully understand why that is. Ice creams, however, are generally sweeter, and have a very different texture due to the presence of milk fats and air bubbles, along with the ice crystals. The texture of an ice cream will depend particularly on the size of these crystals - the larger they are, the grittier the ice cream will feel to the tongue. And the size of the crystals is determined by the speed at which they are formed - the faster they are formed, the smaller they are and the smoother the ice cream becomes.

The ultimate ice cream can be made by freezing a basic ice-cream mixture not in a freezer but by pouring liquid nitrogen into it. This is because liquid nitrogen has a temperature of less than -180C, whereas domestic freezers can manage only -18C - of course, we would not recommend trying this outside a proper laboratory, but it does make the most deliciously smooth ice cream, and also provides a spectacular display of white clouds billowing over the table, to boot.

Frozen desserts are not the only way in which freezing is used in food preparation. Many foods are frozen for long-term storage, for example, where the freezing process is used to slow down or even stop bacterial growth, and some are frozen to make them easier to handle. Bacon, for one, is far easier to slice when frozen that at room temperature; and the American chef Fritz Blank has even been known to freeze a fillet steak, go over it with a blowtorch, leave it to thaw and then cook it in the normal way. The result is juicily delicious.

Primarily, though, we use freezing to create ice crystals that add to the impact of a food or drink. This is one reason why the frozen margarita is so popular, for the alcohol ensures that part of the drink remains unfrozen, which means the concentrated alcohol solution blends pleasantly with the melting ice crystals in the mouth. As with sorbets and ice creams, there is enough unfrozen liquid to let the ice crystals slide past each other and not stick together in a lump. They can be made to stick together, however, so producing the harder frozen confections that some prefer, by lowering the temperature further, or by reducing the sugar or alcohol content. Whatever your pref erence, there is no doubt that freezing is a cooking method that's here to stay.

fields.headline: Frighteningly clever
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  is bombarded by scary songs and jokes about fruit in Marina Warner's No Go The Bogeyman
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard is bombarded by scary songs and jokes about fruit in Marina Warner's No Go The Bogeyman
fields.body:
No Go The Bogeyman
Marina Warner
Vintage, £10.99
Buy it at BOL

Massive, monumental even - and not just because of the way Vintage has decided to print this book on paper as dense as lead. (This is more than just annoying: read the book without a lectern or a flat surface for more than 10 minutes and you'll think you have arthritis in your fingers.) This is a long, hard look at what is really going on when we are trying to scare ourselves with ogres, monsters, bogeymen, cyclops, giants, and so on.

Consider the ambiguous nature of lullabies, such as those which threatened the sleepy child with abduction by boo-baggers nameless and specific - Napoleon, Cromwell, or, in Brittany, "le grand Lustucru", who makes a noise like chains dragging on the pebbles. We particularly like the "grim" (Warner's word) cradle songs from Germany collected by Hans Magnus Enzensburger in the 1960s: "Sweet little babykin, what are you whispering in the straw? / Your mother is dead, your father is happy, / If he marries a new young wife / Then the children will get a beating."

Warner points out: "Such verses should be viewed with more sympathy than a first glance inspires... the songs are filled with the difficulties of mothering, and far from diffusing a sentimental ideology of blissful union, they catch the tension and the exhaustion of dependency - maternal ambivalence." That, I think, works as an explanation, although she slightly undermines the implications of her argument by recalling the terror induced in her by the family copy of Struwwelpeter, which she asked her father to put on the bonfire.

The book is itself an entire digression. If it has an argument, it seems to be nothing more groundbreaking or astonishing than that we create terrors in order to conquer them. While this is hardly startling, the book is made wonderful by its breadth of reference, the sagacity of Warner's comments, and the justness of the connections she makes.

One braces oneself for off-key registers when a scholar starts talking about popular culture; but when Warner talks about, say, Men in Black, you are relieved to find that she gets the point of that film as much as she gets the point of The Odyssey. The book is like a core sample taken through all the layers of human experience and artistic expression: laid out and explained in the way she does, it offers the promise of coherence, and the satisfaction of being bombarded with masses of fascinating information.

What comes across best is a pleasant, ludic tone, a benign acceptance of the strange muddle of humanity's attempts to place themselves in the world. One might not have suspected that a book which begins with cannibalistic monsters - Saturn devouring his children, and the monstrosity of anthropophagy - would end with a chapter on the comedy of bananas. This in itself suggests that Warner's muse is more approachably scatty than most reviewers, understandably in awe of her learning, might care to acknowledge.

Elsewhere, in chapters on Circe, mockery and song, the book seems to be turning into a treatise on something else altogether - on the nature of amusement, perhaps - but it is nice that a work which began by scaring the bejesus out of us ends with a picture of Viz 's Tommy "Banana" Johnson impaled, as he is at the end of each of his adventures, on his own fruit. Did you know, incidentally, that Tommy Johnson is named after the 17th-century apothecary who displayed the first banana ever seen in this country? There you go. I think we should be impressed.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.standfirst: The painfully surreal journal of John Rabe during the Japanese occupation, plus The Godfather Trilogy and Shakespeare in the Theatre
fields.trailText: The painfully surreal journal of John Rabe during the Japanese occupation, plus The Godfather Trilogy and Shakespeare in the Theatre
fields.body:
The Good German of Nanking
John Rabe
Abacus, £9.99

Buy it at BOL

Rabe was an old China hand, business not diplomacy, who kept this diary of the Japanese occupation of the Chinese city in 1937-38: it was his witness and therapy as he improbably sheltered 600 refugees in his garden and saved the lives of 30,000 more by never ceasing to protest and protect when the invaders murdered and burnt at whim. He simply noted everything with equal weight: massacre, rape, the Blue Danube Waltz played by the military band, and the day the burnt corpse at his door was finally buried. The surreality of his description is therefore very real, and the ambiguity of all he could manage to do is fully accepted.

The Godfather Trilogy
edited by Nick Browne
Cambridge, £10.95
Buy it at BOL

Collected film studies on the Coppola movies written in that dreary academic para-language ("recontextualised auteurism", "representation of ethnicity", "in my analysis") which is supposed to make opinion, speculation and retelling the plots - guys, we saw these pictures - sound not merely authoritative but like unarguable fact. Though we'll exempt from that Jon Lewis investigating the productions' bottom line, which is newly informative: gangster money may have made these movies possible. Neat. Otherwise, we'll stick with the in-the-know judgment of Mrs Carmela Soprano - I is terrific, II is great, and III? Forgetaboutit.

Shakespeare in the Theatre
Stanley Wells
OUP, £12.99

Buy it at BOL

Contemporary criticism is the only way to preserve the experience of live theatre, for even if there were video of Garrick, what would it mean now? Here is Keats on Kean's Richard III, amazed that the actor never calculates in advance where the character is going; Tynan on Olivier's Hotspur, stammering on the "w" in the word "worms" even as he dies, catching the man's "flavour of sharp masculine kindness". Newer pieces explain the latest settings - Crimean war, white box - as these too are now as ephemeral as speech delivery; where has the RSC own-brand rising pitch at the line-end gone?

fields.headline: Digging for story bones
fields.standfirst: Masterpiece or masturbation?  Nicholas Lezard  is hideously confused by David Foster Wallace's Brief Interviews With Hideous Men
fields.trailText: Masterpiece or masturbation? Nicholas Lezard is hideously confused by David Foster Wallace's Brief Interviews With Hideous Men
fields.body:
Brief Interviews With Hideous Men by David Foster Wallace 273pp, Abacus, £9.99
Buy it at BOL

Begin by outlining one facet of David Foster Wallace's dilemma: the perceived impossibility of fictional honesty with regard to - w/r/t, to adopt his shorthand - inner states, literary history, acute self-consciousness (not so acute as to prevent him from writing reams and reams of prose), leading to highly problematic relationship with presentation/style if one is both conscientious and talented writer, which DFW clearly is.

Add, by way of cheap laugh masquerading as substantiation, how cosy notion of standard short story form, as typified by countless hackneyed examples in, eg, The New Yorker, has become unworkable, not to mention downright pain in neck, leading to sterility/impasse or, for whatever reasons (sheer old-fashioned but none the less urgent need to express?), stylistic games, eg pretending that story has broken down and so offering up what profess to be the writer's raw unmediated notes instead of a conclusion.

Note one "story" in Brief Interviews going so far as to posit dilemma of writer embarked on said story but now hopelessly bogged down and so, with characteristic footnotes so audaciously prolix that at times the narrative itself exists on the page merely as a thin crust over a massive block of small print, asking reader straight out if this is really the way to go about things. (Nb rewrite lame phrase "go about things", perhaps by quoting DFW himself, who sees such jiggery-pokery as an attempt to "salvage the aesthetic disaster".)

Toy with notion of writing review in same fashion.

Wonder aloud whether DFW's methods are more than just an attempt to avoid becoming trapped in his very idiosyncratic - not to mention horribly infectious - style. Wonder too whether writing things up as notes, overheard transcripts, etc, reflects and tacitly comments on the fractured state of the restless Western mind and the tendency of depressed people's thought processes to move endlessly but fruitlessly in paranoid, self-fulfilling circularity. Not to mention whether we should worry about these things as much as he clearly does, or pretends to.

Do lit. name drop, eg John Barth, Calvino, Gaddis etc, not so much for purposes of serious comparison as to assure anyone who has got this far that, yes, reviewer is aware of such influences/reference points, but shy away from question as to whether DFW is in fact doing anything so radically different after all. Imply that cursory nature of lit. name dropping is not laziness but a matter of space and the desire to avoid an extremely tedious debate best left to teachers of creative writing and their students.

Cite the story "Adult World", divided into parts I and II, I being a reasonably straightforward tale of a newlywed woman's insecurities w/r/t her love life, II being DFW's own notes for its conclusion. Wife comes to realise that husband is chronic compulsive masturbator, and wonders whether there is a support group for wives of CCMs. Text reads: "'MastAnon?' 'Co-Jack?' (Nb avoid easy gags.)" Thereby DFW makes easy gag while at same time deferring responsibility for it, ie has metafictional cake and eats it, hoping actual comedy of intranarrative acknowledgment, much like screen comedian turning helplessly to camera, will save bacon.

Mention curious fact that one can't read DFW's work when stoned, despite not only author's resemblance to pothead (unshaven, Axl Rose-style bandanna, numerous refs in fiction to dope or "pot" as Americans still call it) but also the huge spiralling sentences which superficially mimic the endlessly qualified meanderings of a marijuana-saturated brain. In this respect DFW sometimes seems like a very, very intelligent person who, under chemical influence, has slipped a notch, and is now merely a very intelligent writer.

In fact, could this style be called the mock-intelligent, long-windedness for comic effect, cf the mock-heroic? But isn't there a danger that this is the kind of joke which posterity will treat harshly, cf the 1,000+ page-long Infinite Jest, whose imposing length might be, if not the point, at least part of the joke, yet which does not stop the book from being simply too long?)

Conclude by saying that for all DFW's assumed tricksiness and game-playing, we still react to his stories, or to the bones of them, as though they were ordinarily told fictions, DFW's style being among other things a shorthand that we revel in decoding as much as he relishes using it.

Stress that although by no means all of these pieces, for want of a better word, work, we should be grateful for DFW's originality, wit, fine attention to the details of internal processes (viz his agonising over whether to use "palpate", "limn" or just "demonstrate" when wondering what word to use for the thing that his fiction does).

Leave aside the question of whether the ease w/which he can be pastiched is a good or a bad sign.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: There is no substitute to hearing Bennett tell all in his own Eeyore tones.
fields.body:
The Lady in the Van
written and read by Alan Bennett
BBC Radio, £8.99, 100 mn
Buy it at BOL

Bennett is blessed with razor antennae for eccentrics, and they seem drawn to him. He chronicles the 15 years, until her death, that a dotty, elderly vagabond, Mary Shepherd, lived in a van in his front yard. God bless him for his great kindness, and for recording their interchanges with his customary ear.

Bennett, by his own admission, can be a bit prickly - but even he wasn't a patch on her. Shepherd, poor soul, was difficult to help, short on showing gratitude and sometimes very demanding. He could never even get enough sherbert lemons for her.

But through Bennett's very funny account peeps her indebtedness and his compassion. No doubt Maggie Smith plays a superb Miss Shepherd in the current West End production, but there is no substitute to hearing Bennett tell it in his own Eeyore tones.

fields.headline: The Saturday Poems
fields.trailText:
It's brilliant. It's a tear you can stand a car

on, the hard eye of a chandelier
ready to break down and cry like a baby, a rare
birth, cooled before its time.
fields.body:
Prince Rupert's Drop

the rapid cooling of this extraordinary glass drop leaves it in a state of enormous tension...

It's brilliant. It's a tear you can stand a car

on, the hard eye of a chandelier
ready to break down and cry like a baby, a rare
birth, cooled before its time. It's an ear
of glass accidentally sown in the coldest of water,
that sheer drop, rock solid except for the tail
or neck which will snap like sugar, kick like a mortar
under the surefire touch of your fingernail.

It's the pearl in a will-o'-the-wisp, the lantern asleep
in the ice, the light of St Elmo's fire in your eyes.
It's the roulette burst of a necklace, the snap
of bones in an icicle's finger, the snip of your pliers
at the neck of my heart, the fingertip working the spot
which says 'you are here' until you are suddenly not.

Wedding Breakfast

High
on the high table
the leaves are out
and all our fingers blossoming

with glass. The tablecloth's
a lawn, a linen bedsheet
where we lay our limbs to grass
amidst the carnival,
the cavalcade,

the mardi gras.

Your eye's a sunglass
or a solitaire, your mouth
a cave to drink the melt
which falls from my rich table.
Our lips cast burning sugar
to polish on the wind
and the table turns.

 Jane Draycott's collection, Prince Rupert's Drop, is published by Carcanet/Oxford Poets, £6.65.

It's an ear of glass accidentally sown in the coldest of water, that sheer drop, rock solid except for the tail or neck which will snap like sugar, kick like a mortar under the surefire touch of your fingernail. It's the pearl in a will-o'-the-wisp, the lantern asleep in the ice, the light of St Elmo's fire in your eyes. It's the roulette burst of a necklace, the snap of bones in an icicle's finger, the snip of your pliers at the neck of my heart, the fingertip working the spot which says 'you are here' until you are suddenly not. Wedding Breakfast High on the high table the leaves are out and all our fingers blossoming with glass. The tablecloth's a lawn, a linen bedsheet where we lay our limbs to grass amidst the carnival, the cavalcade, the mardi gras. Your eye's a sunglass or a solitaire, your mouth a cave to drink the melt which falls from my rich table. Our lips cast burning sugar to polish on the wind and the table turns.  Jane Draycott's collection, Prince Rupert's Drop, is published by Carcanet/Oxford Poets, £6.65.

webTitle: The king of blood and mischief

fields.headline: The king of blood and mischief
fields.standfirst: Gary Indiana tells Garth Cartwright why he likes to shock middle America
fields.trailText: Gary Indiana tells Garth Cartwright why he likes to shock middle America
fields.body:
Another day, another sensational murder trial. At least, that is how it seems for Gary Indiana. As New York settles into the trial of the year - that of a mother and son allegedly responsible for a coast-to-coast trail of arson, fraud and murder culminating in the disappearance of a rich Manhattan widow - Indiana is settling down to write about it. The court case hadn't even started when he was signed up by HarperCollins for a six-figure sum to produce a novel based on the Oedipal adventures unravelling across Manhattan.

The case of Sante Kimes and her son Kenneth is so surreal in its subversion of the American Dream - even former President Gerald Ford has a cameo in it - that it appears perfectly tailored for Indiana. He was initially located alongside Dennis Cooper and Kathy Acker as an author whose appeal was limited to connoisseurs of underground Americana, but his last two novels, Resentment and Three Month Fever, have found him moving towards mainstream literary fame. Over the last decade he has shaped up as one of America's darkest and funniest chroniclers. Even the New York Times - which previously damned all he wrote - described him as "a huge satirical talent".

That he has received more recognition for these novels than for all his previous work (three novels, two short story collections, several plays, much journalism) is unsurprising. Dealing with cause célèbre murders while satirising the public's insatiable appetite for media-fed gore, the novels offer a particularly skewed take on the crimes and their perpetrators.

The poisonously funny Resentment tracks the obsession of a wayward journalist with the trial of Carlos and Felix Martinez, who gunned down their wealthy parents. It ends up finding everyone in Los Angeles morally corrupt. Three Month Fever, meanwhile, is an iconoclastic attempt to weave a fact'n'fiction biography of Andrew Cunanan, killer of the fashion designer Versace.

"I'm kinda mired in crime, but so was Dostoevsky," drawls Indiana. "With Resentment, what attracted me to it was the family story and the distinct possibility that, as the kids had killed their parents, the state would kill the kids. That seemed a perfect metaphor for patriarchal society. And the fact that the trial permeated everywhere - it was like water, it filled everything."

What is perhaps most striking about both that novel and Three Month Fever is Indiana's attempt to humanise - even empathise with - the murderers. "Andrew Cunanan was not someone I'd want to be best friends with, but he's an interesting individual and sociopaths interest me. Anyway, Versace struck me as a much worse individual than Andrew." He laughs loudly at his suggestion.

Underlying that sympathy is an awareness of the media's capacity for making monsters. "People discuss these cases in a manner which is so Victorian, yet life is not so black and white, good versus evil," he argues. "There's a saying that describes Cunanan well - 'Some people are just not ready for disappointment.' "

Which brings Indiana back again to the dangers of dreaming the American dream. "Andrew was very much a pure product of American culture - a culture which has defined ontological existence as fame. Outside of this lust for fame, what excuse is there for the cavalcade of nastiness on TV we get every afternoon?"

Indiana came originally from New Hampshire, but fled to Berkeley in the late 1960s and assumed the name Gary Indiana. By the mid-70s he was writing and directing plays in the artistic ferment of New York's East Village. The 1980s found him writing art criticism for the Village Voice and acting in low-budget films - even performing in a scene with Rainer Fassbinder. Limited-edition collections of short stories followed before his 1989 novel Horse Crazy.

Each of his novels travels a radically different path from the previous one - Horse Crazy is a beautifully crafted tale of obsession while 1994's Rent Boy overloads with porn and satire. If his style changes, his themes remain the same, along with constant graphic descriptions of gay sex. Indeed, I suggest to Indiana, no writer since William Burroughs has shown such affection for sodomy and shit.

"I like to put things in my books that people avoid, that even novelists avoid or put in flowery language. So I insert things in a very blatant way that people will have problems with. My editor at Doubleday, she was desperate to get the shit out and wrote me notes like 'If you take "shit" out of page 101, you can keep the turd on page 103' ! "

Indiana confesses that "payback is a very bad motive for writing a novel - but it is one of the perks", and Resentment's treatment of such high-profile American figures as Vanity Fair's crime reporter Dominick Dunne also made Doubleday sweat.

"It's not so much the publishers but the corporations that own them," says Indiana. "They're so scared of stepping on anyone's toes. I happen to have the best First Amendment lawyer in the US as a close friend, so he cleared the way for it to go ahead. We inserted an Author's Note that's as good as the Psychiatrist's Note in Lolita."

Again, that laugh. Gary Indiana: a shark in US literature's calm waters.

fields.headline: E-laureate announced
fields.trailText: • To the Voice Box on the South Bank to hear Peter Parker (currently engaged on a mammoth biography of Christopher Isherwood) interview the 96-year-old novelist, short story writer, and sometime Communist and CND member Edward Upward. The march of time has not diminished Upward's enthusiasm for work, and his output of late would shame authors a quarter his age.
fields.body:
 To the Voice Box on the South Bank to hear Peter Parker (currently engaged on a mammoth biography of Christopher Isherwood) interview the 96-year-old novelist, short story writer, and sometime Communist and CND member Edward Upward. The march of time has not diminished Upward's enthusiasm for work, and his output of late would shame authors a quarter his age.

Since 1990, from his home on the Isle of Wight, Upward has produced six books, including three volumes of short stories, memoirs of Auden and Isherwood, and a revision of his novel Journey to the Border, first published in 1938. One purpose of the revision was to excise the word "queer", used throughout, shall we say, in its old-fashioned sense. This March sees the publication of another set of stories, The Coming Day. On the night in question, the author read and spoke for an hour, answered questions from the packed floor (tickets were sold out four weeks in advance) and signed books for three quarters of an hour. Not bad going.

 The latest from the world of e-literature comes with an endorsement from none other than Andrew Motion. BT has anointed its first "e-poet laureate", Scottish writer Kyle MacRae, whose poem "The Coolest Den in Cyberspace" tells the story of a web-crazed schoolboy. Said Motion: "The net is a natural and exciting outlet for poetry: at once intimate and large-scale." Can't quite see a million hits a day for www.sonnets.com, but you never know.

 The evenings can really drag in February, especially once the thrill or horror of Valentine's Day is behind us. Never fear! There are hours of innocent fun to be had from filling in the London Review of Books's new reader survey, designed to help the eggheads' version of the Dandy know their clientele even better.

How many hardback books do you buy every year? More than 200 - or none? Tick the appropriate box. Do you use the LRB for the purposes of pleasure, or "to help you form your opinions"? And do you drink French Cognac, Armagnac - or, you cheapskate, you - "other brandy"? Tempting as it is to style oneself a vintage port-swilling poet who listens to Melody radio on a salary of £200k, please take this seriously: your entry to the grand draw (first prize: a copy of Alan Bennett's The Clothes They Stood Up In) depends on it.

fields.headline: Fevered pitch
fields.standfirst: Peter Bradshaw  sees a novel unfold with one eye on the movie in James Hawes' Dead Long Enough
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw sees a novel unfold with one eye on the movie in James Hawes' Dead Long Enough
fields.body:
Dead Long Enough
James Hawes 288pp, Cape, £10
Buy it at BOL

James Hawes belongs to a new generation of fast, funky, streetwise British male novelists: the one that has stopped sounding like Martin Amis and started sounding like Helen Fielding, moving away from the literary pyrotechnics of the New Statesman 70s crowd and repositioning itself in the more lenient and less vinegary arena of relationships and blokeish self-awareness. Its printed voice has absorbed the locutions of magazine article, stand-up comedy and, inevitably, film screenplay.

All these traces are visible in Dead Long Enough, the story of a group of college contemporaries in their late 30s who go on annual reunion binges organised by their mate Harry MacDonald, who has become a famous TV personality. Then one year he leads them to Ireland and to a terrible and violent reckoning with his past.

Hawes is a former university lecturer, but his prose only occasionally signals his cerebral past. Like Nick Hornby - whose first published work was not Fever Pitch, but an academic study of American literature - he has found himself a radically different voice: populist, punchy and muscular. He is one of those writers routinely celebrated for having found readers who would never before have dreamt of spending £10 on new literary fiction.

His latest book is tough and shrewd and often very funny, crammed with brutal and tactless insights into the sadness of middle youth: what it's like to be approaching 40, yet equipped with the wised-up sensibility, health and spending power to enjoy the twentysomethings' hedonistic party - and do it properly this time. But he also conveys the shallowness and emptiness of this determination. Hawes persuasively imagines the cultural and spiritual crisis of a generation approaching middle age, resentful and anxious about the compromises they have made for their kids and mortgages and having no very commanding beliefs with which to make sense of their own mortality.

There's a very funny passage about the ghastly suburban Siberias where the endowment mortgagees have to live: "wherever the hell it is, double-digit NE whatever, you know, some place no one has ever been to and returned, some region beyond all hope, up near where the Central Line, we assume, finally plunges gratefully into the North Sea".

The price Hawes pays for this risky, laugh-driven style is an occasional jarring maladroitness. The other problem is that the narration often sounds like the voiceover in a very bad Lottery-funded British film. All of his novels have made or are making the leap to film - and the prose style shows him already flexing to make that jump.

Rancid Aluminium, the only release so far, was an embarrassing disaster, having jettisoned everything intelligent in Hawes's writing to create a crass wannabe thriller. My heart sank at this description of the cast of Dead Long Enough hanging out together in a pub: "I want to freeze us for a second, Harry, spieling away and all of us grinning like teenagers." I really hope that this tired Trainspotting-Lock, Stock moment does not make it into the finished movie. Dead Long Enough is an expert and enjoyable read, but I look ahead to the film version with a heavy heart.

fields.headline: Is it ;-) or :-( ?
fields.standfirst: Naomi S Baron on what email will do to the English language in Alphabet to Email
fields.trailText: Naomi S Baron on what email will do to the English language in Alphabet to Email
fields.body:
Alphabet to Email: How Written English Evolved and Where It's Heading
Naomi S Baron
Routledge, £15.99, 336pp
Buy it at BOL

In Beckett at Reading, the magnificent catalogue of the Beckett Manuscript Collection at the University of Reading, the editors describe the 36 scraps of paper that go to make up Beckett's Mirlitonnades, first published by Editions Minuit in 1978: "These brief poems are written in black ink, with some in pencil and red felt-tip. The manuscripts are a wide variety of sizes and shapes. Types of paper used include pieces of card, variously coloured pieces of notepad paper, diary pages, the backs of letters to Beckett which he has torn into small squares, cheroot packets, part of a cardboard box which contained a bottle of whiskey, squared exercise-book paper and an airmail envelope."

Now imagine the bibliographical description of an author's complete works composed after about 1991: '4 3M 3.5" diskettes, double-sided, high-density, formatted for use with IBM PS/2 (models 30, 286, 50, 60, 70, 80) and compatible systems using DOS 3.3 and higher.' Not quite the same, is it. But does it matter?

This is the kind of question that occurs while reading Naomi S Baron's book about the past and possible futures of written English. Baron's own written English, it should be said, is classic easy-fit American academic, a combination of the bold and the flaringly obvious with the odd quirky personal pleat and cable-knit scholarly. Her argument on the page is at times impossible to follow, being disfigured by the livid scar tissue of headings, subheadings, and sub-subheadings.

Persevering, however, one finds Baron's argument eventually emerging through the deep fog of historical example into clear summary and bullet points in the book's conclusion and epilogue.

According to Baron, the gradual blurring of distinctions between writing and speech effected by the widespread use of email means that authors and texts and their readers behave differently now from how they did 50 or 100 or 1,000 years ago.

Baron regards email as an influential and distinct language style like a creole, characterised by its informality and lack of standardisation in usage, by a higher level of self-disclosure than in either speech or writing, and as creating new venues and opportunities for communication.

None of this is exactly news. What is remarkable about Alphabet to Email is Baron's grounding in and grinding through the history of language and literacy, which enables her to approach the implications and identify the bigger questions: "Is there any point in teaching prescriptive grammar and punctuation?" "Should one standard English serve as a norm worldwide?" "Does reading and writing texts on-line yield the same outcomes... as more traditional forms of producing and consuming written works?"

Her answers to these questions seem to be, respectively, Yes, No, and Don't Know. To clarify the last, you might like to ask yourself whether you have ever received an email which is alive to the kind of metaphysical distinctions, subtleties and gravities that are commonly conveyed in a book, a letter, or in conversation. Hey, let me know. Mail me.

fields.headline: 1700 and all that
fields.standfirst: John Mullan finds many vivid details but little narrative cohesion in Maureen Waller's 1700
fields.trailText: John Mullan finds many vivid details but little narrative cohesion in Maureen Waller's 1700
fields.body:
1700: Scenes from London Life
Maureen Waller
Hodder & Stoughton, £20, 388pp
Buy it at BOL

At the beginning of the 18th century, Londoners were learning to be proud of their modern city, much rebuilt after the Great Fire of 1666 and thriving as a centre of commerce and capital. "A prodigy of buildings" equalled only by "old Rome in Trajan's time", marvelled Daniel Defoe.

Pleased by the grandeur and "Protestant plainness" of St Paul's, now dominating the London skyline, he took delight in every "improvement". "Among other public edifices, that of the hospital of Bethlehem, or Bedlam, should not be forgot, which is at the very time of writing this appointed to be enlarged with two new wings, and will then be the most magnificent thing of its kind in the world."

The greatest metropolis should of course have the greatest lunatic asylum. Defoe seems witness to an age and a city of sometimes ludicrous self-confidence. Yet the London of his novels was different: a place of alleys and prisons, whose inhabitants were turned by commerce into predators.

Maureen Waller relies a good deal on Defoe's testimonies, and never quite knows what to do with the contradiction between the vaunting and the fearful accounts he offers of urban existence. In the end, the sense of London at this time as a city of urbanity and modernity - prominent in the recent work of historians such as Roy Porter and John Brewer - is relinquished.

Waller talks of the age's "optimism and ebullience", but she has a greater feel for the grimness of life. Partly this is because her book is dedicated to the details of everyday existence. 1700 is unreliable when it considers larger patterns of religious or intellectual history, but on the minutiae it is often compelling.

These most come to life when Waller finds new material in the archive. Her chapter on marriage is illustrated by vividly desperate wrangles over marriage settlements that she has found among Consistory Court depositions. Her discussion of "Crime and Punishment" recovers contemporary accounts in which absurdity vies with horror. The Ordinary (chaplain) of Newgate narrates the demise of legendary pirate "Captain" Kidd: he is drunk and roaringly unrepentant when brought to Tyburn, but the rope breaks, and when the scaffold is ready once again the swashbuckler is sober and terrified, begging the gratified clergyman for God's forgiveness.

Elsewhere Waller has found good material in the burgeoning newspapers of the period. Their news columns give poignant or mysterious accounts of suicides and murders; their advertisements provide a rich new index to a culture's preoccupations - whether trumpeting the varieties of human and animal monstrosity to be seen at Bartholomew Fair or searching for stolen goods or missing persons. She is perhaps too reliant for her illustrations on the work of others, yet she does concentrate details often scattered through the pages of academic histories, drawn as she is to the quotidian pains and preoccupations of life.

We find out about the business of the nightsoil men, and the difficulties of storing the household's ordure until their arrival. We are told of the importance and expense of men's wigs, and of the strange trade in human hair. (One John Matthews, executed at Tyburn, had made a profession of stealing hair from barbers' shops.) We sample an apparently fevered debate about the good or harm done by drinking coffee, which includes a dispute about its effects on men's sexual performance. It "assists us for your nocturnal benevolencies" a male enthusiast told women, "by drying up those crude flatulent humours, which otherwise would make us only flash in the pan."

One quite typical section of about 10 pages covers coffee houses, the stock market, the growth of auctioneering, the postal system, the development of London newspapers, gambling-mania and drinking. fields.headline: The cauterised heart
fields.standfirst: Maya Jaggi  on Chang-rae Lee's fine exploration of loss in the Japanese-American experience, A Gesture Life
fields.trailText: Maya Jaggi on Chang-rae Lee's fine exploration of loss in the Japanese-American experience, A Gesture Life
fields.body:
A Gesture Life
Chang-rae Lee
Granta, £16.99
Buy it at BOL

The breach of a 50-year silence over the estimated 200,000 Asian - mainly Korean - women and girls forced into sexual service as "comfort women" for Japanese troops in the second world war has gripped the imagination of a young generation of Asian-American writers. Among the fiction inspired by survivors' stories is Nora Okja Keller's Comfort Woman (1998), longlisted for last year's Orange Prize, and Chang-rae Lee's A Gesture Life.

Lee, whose garlanded debut, Native Speaker (1995), announced a writer of immense subtlety and craft, probes the onerous and debilitating silence not of women's "shame" but of a man's guilt. Splicing haunting wartime remembrance into a first-person narrative of present-day American suburbia, he builds a memorably disquieting portrait of a man dislocated from himself and from life.

Franklin Hata, a Japanese resident of the affluent New York suburb of Bedley Run, is a model citizen in his 70s. Still known as "Doc Hata" for the Sunny Medical Supply store he ran before his retirement, he tends his lawn, swims in his pool and makes amiable small talk with a network of acquaintances. "People know me here," he reflects with satisfaction.

Yet the wellbeing is surface-deep. Amid the impeccable politeness and decorum are hints of self-destruction; Hata nearly chokes in his pool and suffers smoke inhalation from a fire he lets spill from the grate. He is estranged from his adopted Korean daughter Sunny, with her "flinty, coal-like hardness", and has failed in his relationship with a neighbouring widow, Mary Burns, who died of cancer without his having visited her.

Gradually, chilling memories seep in from a time when, as a paramedic in an army camp in the final days of the Pacific war, he was required to examine the five "female volunteers" servicing 200 officers and men in the "comfort house" stalls; VD was known to deplete whole battalions. Sunny's adolescent sexuality brings disturbing echoes of K, the comfort woman with whom the callow Hata had fallen in love; his relationship with his daughter is distorted by guilt, "the soiling, resident sickness" that stems from the "wish for a penance that would likely never come".

He also has an earlier trauma to contend with. A member of Japan's despised ethnic Korean minority, as a child Hata escaped from a ghetto of hide tanners via a scholarship and adoption by a Japanese family; wrested from his childhood language, he was renamed and indoctrinated amid schoolmates who treated him "like a stray dog". His current sense of racial isolation in the US suburbs ("a minor but uncomfortable feeling, like the digging edge of an overstarched collar") is a reprise of this earlier pain and impulse to disappear.

Hata suffers a foreigner's fear of overstepping his welcome while retaining the gratitude of the orphan; his stance is simultaneously one of ingratiation and appeasement. When it comes to feeling at home, he reflects: "I've always believed that the predominant burden is mine."

"You make a whole life out of gestures and politeness," Sunny says to her father, who has indeed spent a lifetime striving to belong through a social web of obligation, treating love as a "sworn duty" while avoiding the warmth of intimacy. As his tightly controlled narrative suppresses a grief that makes him a stranger even to himself, his dread of the vulnerability of attachment gives his life an etiolated quality, as though it were being lived underwater in his stone-coloured pool, in muted slow motion.

The limpid simplicity and restraint of the prose matches this dislocation. Emotion is avoided by understatement, as when Hata describes merely as "most unreal" a brutal wartime episode in which the sadistic Captain Ono practises open-heart resuscitation on a semiconscious Burmese petty thief. Lee makes deft use of bodily metaphor throughout the book: when a young boy stunted by congenital heart disease awaits a transplant in hospital, Hata notes "the sad and peculiar notion of waiting for a heart". His own full name, Kurohata, means "black flag" - a traditional warning against contagion within.

The author's remarkable gift for the precise, delicate delineation of relationships emerges in the description of Hata's fatherhood and his blighted affair with Mary Burns, his reserve finally preventing him freeing her from her own well-bred restraint - "the thick jacket of her grace". Yet the novel signals a gentle redemption through Hata's love for his young grandson. With slowly accruing knowledge comes self-realisation, including recognition of his complicity in the logic that made women objects for raising army morale and acceptance that the yearning to find one's "own place in the accepted order of things" helped to make him unquestioning war-machine fodder.

Lee skilfully extends the terrain he mapped in Native Speaker, in which an undercover detective uses the watchful vigilance and secretiveness natural to the outsider in his profession as a spy. Hata's state of being is also liminal - "the sensation of near-perfect lightness, of being in a place and not being there". A Gesture Life vivisects US suburbia, weighing the costs of social conformity and assimilation, the violence done to the self in an impossible attempt to "fit in". It commands a place alongside another classic novel on the submerged desperation of cauterised hearts, Kazuo Ishiguro's The Remains of the Day, in whose starched and stranded butler Doc Hata would no doubt find a kindred soul.

fields.headline: A devil in the details
fields.standfirst: He wrote Faust and found sexual bliss - so what exactly did Goethe renounce? TJ Reed finds out in the second volume of Nicholas Boyle's biography
fields.trailText: He wrote Faust and found sexual bliss - so what exactly did Goethe renounce? TJ Reed finds out in the second volume of Nicholas Boyle's biography
fields.body:
Goethe: The Poet and the Age Vol 2 - Revolution and Renunciation 1790-1803
Nicholas Boyle Oxford, £30, 949pp
Buy it at BOL

The first volume of Nicholas Boyle's Goethe eight years ago helped to put Goethe back on the map in the English-speaking world, and the second volume was eagerly awaited as a major event of Goethe's 250th anniversary year. In today's context of short-term scholarship, this is work of exemplary stature, to be criticised strictly with one's hat off.

And the project is growing ever larger. Where Goethe's Wilhelm Meister meets with mysterious figures who warn him off his chosen course, Dr Boyle met an unknown American on the stairs of a Berlin institute who positively egged him on: "Make it three volumes! Goethe deserves it." Momentous advice, since, at this tempo, three seem unlikely to be enough. The first volume covered 40 years; this one 13. There are 29 still to go.

Whether as cause or effect of that strategic decision, space is given to an encyclopedic knowledge that reaches deep into all Goethe's involvements: administration, architecture, colour theory, mine technology, university and theatre intrigues, politics large and small, literary relationships, cultural polemics, military campaigns - all are presented with total grasp of detail, to the point of self-parody. Works, not only Goethe's, are renarrated at a length specialists do not need and general readers may find obstructive to the biographical line; the narrative is often day-to-day chronicle.

With no foreshortening, a whole phase of life can seem arid which, in the longer rhythms of creativity, is a mere trough between crests. Yet against this, there are thought-provoking speculations on the direction of literature and on writers' allegiances and ambitions in the dying years of the Holy Roman Empire. An outstanding chapter on the German invasion of France in 1792 captures the misery of that mud-drowned campaign with positively Tolstoyan force.

Such episodes in the revolutionary wars apart, this phase of Goethe's life is uneventful. The shift of emphasis to events outside his control is central to the book's conception: "the Age" now dominates "the Poet". Goethe hardly gets a mention in the first 70 pages, which are half on the French Revolution and half on Kant's philosophical revolution in Germany. Neither is neutral background: they are the forces which, it is argued, upset Goethe's poetic and intellectual applecart, compelling the renunciation of the subtitle. But renunciation of what? With what result? And why?

Goethe had come back from Italy in 1788 after two years of intense seeing and reflecting, reinvigorated and restored after his previous decade of Weimar drudgery, sensitised again to the beauty and vitality of physical forms, confident of his ability to grasp them with enthusiasm and understanding, aesthetic or scientific. Also erotic: he now took a resident mistress, a finishing touch to the restorative of Italy.

In his first volume Boyle was mistrustful of Italy and all its works, overlooked Goethe's metaphors of long-term investment and initiation, and judged by short-term returns: why did he write hardly any poetry there? Here he resumes that attack. Unable to ignore the first fine fruits of Italy, the "Roman Elegies" written immediately after Goethe's return, he asserts against the clear run of the text that "present love cannot be shown", that belief in a "poetry of possession" is an illusion.

Yet no love poems were ever less illusory, or more convincingly in possession of objects and locations that make love real. The idea that Goethe's poetry was "paralysed by the disappointments of fulfilled desire" - that he was caught in "the prison of sated appetite" - is a moralistic misreading that sees spiritual sloth and inertia where there was balance and stasis in a present moment. Goethe at his best is the poet of all our todays:

"How do you live, say? I live! And were hundreds of years to be granted, / Hundreds, still I should wish each day to be like today."

The Italian experience that lay behind this reprehensible contentment is written off as something "lost and not quite definable". This again involves unashamedly facing down great and zestful texts, the Italian diary and the letters full of overflowing delight that Goethe is finally dwelling among realities that dissolve the mists of old yearnings, in what came to seem an earthly paradise.

The issue is not just ethics but poetics: Goethe "had not yet realised that the classical objectivity of 'style' was a chimera". The biographical plot consists in showing how, battered from without by revolution and subverted from within by Kant's analysis of human perception, Goethe consciously "renounced" his premature synthesis: idyll and objectivity were equally impossible. The first recognition made him come to terms with a new age, the second restored the true direction of his poetry and also his finer humanity.

Dr Boyle's take on "objectivity" is surely mistaken about what that word means in literature. In a hierarchy of rigour that rises via science to philosophy, the objectivity of poetry is on the bottom step: a fitting of subject to object and of both of them to words that makes no strict epistemological claim. The scientist has set procedures, and will be satisfied if he can replicate results; the purist philosopher may query these and their objects at every step.

That is a long way from literature's modest pretensions. Goethe was no philosopher; his copies of Kant do not suggest intensive use. He was, however, alert to his intellectual surroundings; he knew from informed conversations what Kant's drift was and what it implied for non-philosophers.

The passages of Goethe's Italian diary that ruthlessly replace self-indulgent emotionalism with solid objects and presences are close kin to Kant's trashing of the old speculative metaphysics, a clearing of ground for new, firmer structures. But Goethe never claimed an absolute objective vision.

Barely back from Italy, he writes: "Style rests on the deepest foundations of knowledge, on the essence of things insofar as it is permitted to us to know them in visible and graspable shapes." That echoes the splendid line in the "Roman Elegies" where the "visible and graspable shapes" of classical statuary and loved flesh are joined in the poet's delight, so that he now "sees with an eye that can feel, feels with a hand that can see".

Nothing in all this needed to be "renounced", and there is nothing in Goethe's later writing, with its firm grasp on phenomena, to suggest it ever was. Four decades on he still speaks of his "object-related [gegenständlich] thinking and writing". It is seen at work in the equally late account Dr Boyle quotes of what it felt like to be under fire during the French campaign:

"The sound of cannonballs is strange enough, as if it were composed of the humming of a top, the bubbling of boiling water and the whistling of a bird. They were less dangerous because of the wet ground, where one of them hit it stuck, and so my foolish self-exposure was at least safe from the peril of ricochets...

"I could soon notice something unusual was going on inside me. I paid close attention and yet the sensation could only be communicated by a simile. It seemed as if you were in a very hot place and at the same time completely penetrated by the same heat, so that you feel completely at one with the element you find yourself in. Your eyes lose nothing of their power or clear vision, but yet it is as if the world had a certain reddish-brown tinge which makes the situation as well as the objects even more fearful. I could not observe any excitement of the blood, rather everything seemed to be swallowed up in that intense heat.

"It's clear why this condition is called cannon-fever. It remains remarkable that this horrible disquiet reaches us only through the ears: for the thunder of the guns, the wailing, whistling, and crashing of the balls through the air, is really the cause of these sensations."

Cool, detached, matter-of-fact, this passage is on the high road to realism, to Stendhal's Fabrice at Waterloo and Tolstoy's Andrey at Austerlitz.

Which brings us back to that other revolution. Certainly it threatened lives, unsettled thinking and writing, made a way of life harder to sustain. That does not mean it had to be renounced, its value denied. If fulfilment were possible only in the idyllic lulls of history, humanity and poetry would have a long wait. Precisely how events affected Goethe - relatively sheltered in a Weimar that for a decade enjoyed a separate peace - is not made clear until we reach 1797, when a planned new Italian journey is aborted because Napoleon is rampaging down that way.

By a strange disproportion in the handling of evidence, this non-event is given more significance than the two years actually spent in Italy in 1786. Indeed, when that experience has been so consistently belittled, it is hard to see how renouncing it can be so major a turning point, or why is it now right for Goethe to return to home and "marriage" because (we are told) he "needed the sex", when sexual fulfilment was earlier the "prison of sated appetite" and part of an illusory objectivity.

The argument begins to blur. Renunciation means too many things - being a realist not an escapist, living with life's normal disappointments, not spreading himself too far, writing Faust rather than a book on Italy, not travelling so as to stay with his wife in Weimar (in fact he doesn't). None of this seems anywhere near the quick of creative work or poetic texture. Renunciation, reasserted to the point of tedium and often entwined with religious language, seems more and more an idealistic tic of the critic's, not the mainspring of Goethe's motivation.

How could it be, in this of all writers? Poetry is made from loss and deprivation as well as fulfilment, but not from gestures of denial, turning away from experience. Renunciation is too negative a thing, ridiculed in Wilhelm Busch's aphorism "Abstinence we call the fun / We get from things we haven't done". More seriously, it is the twisted spirituality of Nietzsche's ascetic priest, the philosophy of the sour grape from which not much lyrical juice can be squeezed. It is sad that so monumental a work of scholarship has focused on a notion so alien to Goethe and to the art he practised.

 TJ Reed is Professor of Modern German at Oxford.
