The biographical plot consists in showing how, battered from without by revolution and subverted from within by Kant's analysis of human perception, Goethe consciously "renounced" his premature synthesis: idyll and objectivity were equally impossible. The first recognition made him come to terms with a new age, the second restored the true direction of his poetry and also his finer humanity. Dr Boyle's take on "objectivity" is surely mistaken about what that word means in literature. In a hierarchy of rigour that rises via science to philosophy, the objectivity of poetry is on the bottom step: a fitting of subject to object and of both of them to words that makes no strict epistemological claim. The scientist has set procedures, and will be satisfied if he can replicate results; the purist philosopher may query these and their objects at every step. That is a long way from literature's modest pretensions. Goethe was no philosopher; his copies of Kant do not suggest intensive use. He was, however, alert to his intellectual surroundings; he knew from informed conversations what Kant's drift was and what it implied for non-philosophers. The passages of Goethe's Italian diary that ruthlessly replace self-indulgent emotionalism with solid objects and presences are close kin to Kant's trashing of the old speculative metaphysics, a clearing of ground for new, firmer structures. But Goethe never claimed an absolute objective vision. Barely back from Italy, he writes: "Style rests on the deepest foundations of knowledge, on the essence of things insofar as it is permitted to us to know them in visible and graspable shapes." That echoes the splendid line in the "Roman Elegies" where the "visible and graspable shapes" of classical statuary and loved flesh are joined in the poet's delight, so that he now "sees with an eye that can feel, feels with a hand that can see". Nothing in all this needed to be "renounced", and there is nothing in Goethe's later writing, with its firm grasp on phenomena, to suggest it ever was. Four decades on he still speaks of his "object-related [gegenständlich] thinking and writing". It is seen at work in the equally late account Dr Boyle quotes of what it felt like to be under fire during the French campaign: "The sound of cannonballs is strange enough, as if it were composed of the humming of a top, the bubbling of boiling water and the whistling of a bird. They were less dangerous because of the wet ground, where one of them hit it stuck, and so my foolish self-exposure was at least safe from the peril of ricochets... "I could soon notice something unusual was going on inside me. I paid close attention and yet the sensation could only be communicated by a simile. It seemed as if you were in a very hot place and at the same time completely penetrated by the same heat, so that you feel completely at one with the element you find yourself in. Your eyes lose nothing of their power or clear vision, but yet it is as if the world had a certain reddish-brown tinge which makes the situation as well as the objects even more fearful. I could not observe any excitement of the blood, rather everything seemed to be swallowed up in that intense heat. "It's clear why this condition is called cannon-fever. It remains remarkable that this horrible disquiet reaches us only through the ears: for the thunder of the guns, the wailing, whistling, and crashing of the balls through the air, is really the cause of these sensations." Cool, detached, matter-of-fact, this passage is on the high road to realism, to Stendhal's Fabrice at Waterloo and Tolstoy's Andrey at Austerlitz. Which brings us back to that other revolution. Certainly it threatened lives, unsettled thinking and writing, made a way of life harder to sustain. That does not mean it had to be renounced, its value denied. If fulfilment were possible only in the idyllic lulls of history, humanity and poetry would have a long wait. Precisely how events affected Goethe - relatively sheltered in a Weimar that for a decade enjoyed a separate peace - is not made clear until we reach 1797, when a planned new Italian journey is aborted because Napoleon is rampaging down that way. By a strange disproportion in the handling of evidence, this non-event is given more significance than the two years actually spent in Italy in 1786. Indeed, when that experience has been so consistently belittled, it is hard to see how renouncing it can be so major a turning point, or why is it now right for Goethe to return to home and "marriage" because (we are told) he "needed the sex", when sexual fulfilment was earlier the "prison of sated appetite" and part of an illusory objectivity. The argument begins to blur. Renunciation means too many things - being a realist not an escapist, living with life's normal disappointments, not spreading himself too far, writing Faust rather than a book on Italy, not travelling so as to stay with his wife in Weimar (in fact he doesn't). None of this seems anywhere near the quick of creative work or poetic texture. Renunciation, reasserted to the point of tedium and often entwined with religious language, seems more and more an idealistic tic of the critic's, not the mainspring of Goethe's motivation. How could it be, in this of all writers? Poetry is made from loss and deprivation as well as fulfilment, but not from gestures of denial, turning away from experience. Renunciation is too negative a thing, ridiculed in Wilhelm Busch's aphorism "Abstinence we call the fun / We get from things we haven't done". More seriously, it is the twisted spirituality of Nietzsche's ascetic priest, the philosophy of the sour grape from which not much lyrical juice can be squeezed. It is sad that so monumental a work of scholarship has focused on a notion so alien to Goethe and to the art he practised.  TJ Reed is Professor of Modern German at Oxford.

fields.headline: The secret sharer
fields.standfirst: Giles Foden  follows Paul Theroux's witty wanderings in Fresh-Air Fiend
fields.trailText: Giles Foden follows Paul Theroux's witty wanderings in Fresh-Air Fiend
fields.body:
Fresh-Air Fiend: Travel Writings 1985-2000
Paul Theroux
Hamish Hamilton, £20, 425pp
Buy it at BOL

For Paul Theroux, travel began with what he calls "expatriation" from the slightly crushing atmosphere of his native Massachusetts in 1963. Ever since, in an attempt to counterbalance years "thrashing around in inspissated darkness" (his metaphor for the writing life), he has tried to get out and about.

He first headed for Malawi as a Peace Corps volunteer, and there ("nuns, lepers, guerrillas and runaways") he stayed for five years, until he was chucked out by President Banda's goons for fomenting rebellion. The experience produced a novel, Jungle Lovers, and much of his previous, 1985 collection of travel pieces, Sunrise with Seamonsters.

In Africa Theroux was a muzungu, a word for white man which also implies spirit or ghost figure. Elsewhere, travelling in China and Hong Kong, he is a gweilo, which has similar connotations in Chinese. This sense of the shadow self is important to him: just one of several attempts to define travel and travel writing in the course of his new book Fresh-Air Fiend, which covers some 50 journeys in every continent, throwing in essays and introductions to the work of kindred spirits: Joseph Conrad, V S Pritchett, Henry Thoreau, Graham Greene.

Greene it is, in conversation, who offers one definition of travel for Theroux: "the saddest pleasure". Others include self-dramatisation, liberation, trespass, risk - though the "so called adventure travellers" bungee-jumping at Victoria Falls are subject to his disapprobation. Getting off easier, at least with more humour, are the multimillionaires whom he joins for a jaunt down the Yangtze: "At the Wuhan Conservatory, Mr Jones asked, 'What is the name of this instrument?' He was told it was a harp, but he wanted its Chinese name. The musician looked at him and said loudly, 'Zhong!' "

One of the many pleasures of this book is getting to know the American Theroux, skiing in the woods of Maine or kayaking round Cape Cod. This last he does in a folding kayak that he now seems to take everywhere with him - unlike the satphone whose batteries run out on a remote Pacific island. So much, he says, for the "secure uplink" of Steven Seagal in Under Siege.

Another film star provides entertaining material when spotted emerging from "Lucky Sauna" in Kowloon. The establishment is "a gai dao, or 'chicken house', famous for its cheap rates for buccal coition".

But if Theroux has an eye for the seamy side, he can deal with pathos too - as when he interviews a survivor of the Christmas Island H-bomb tests: " 'Like a big flower opening,' Ambo thought, 'the colour of clouds, with flames inside.' "

It takes some range to move between such different orders, and it takes some judgment too. In Fresh-Air Fiend, there is plenty of both those qualities, and lots of mischief as well. Theroux is 60 next year, and I wanted to say: "This is an author at the height of his powers." But I suspect there is better still to come.

fields.headline: Travel hardbacks
fields.trailText: As Paul Theroux's latest collection of travel writing shows, it's a genre that is far from exhausted. Theroux's book will no doubt soon head this list. For now, the top slot is occupied by Miles Bredin's tale of James Bruce, the 18th-century explorer who fought, slept and cajoled his way across Ethiopia.
fields.body:
As Paul Theroux's latest collection of travel writing shows, it's a genre that is far from exhausted. Theroux's book will no doubt soon head this list. For now, the top slot is occupied by Miles Bredin's tale of James Bruce, the 18th-century explorer who fought, slept and cajoled his way across Ethiopia.

It's a good example of the way travel writing cross-fertilises with other modes. History, says James Daunt of travel specialist Daunt Books, "has provided the real successes of recent years" . Next on the list is Martin Buckley's Grains of Sand, an account of trying to cross the globe by desert only. (Look out, later, for William Least Heat Moon's attempt to cross the US by water only.)

In the meantime, hunt sharks with Edward Marriott, get cold with Colin Thubron, or (another desert book) check out casinos and cacti with David Thomson in Nevada. Church-going with Simon Jenkins might seem tame by comparison, but it's selling well for all that.

fields.headline: Generation vexed
fields.standfirst: Douglas Coupland manipulates the narratives with devilish mastery in Miss Wyoming
fields.trailText: Douglas Coupland manipulates the narratives with devilish mastery in Miss Wyoming
fields.body:
Miss Wyoming
Douglas Coupland
Flamingo, £9.99, 311pp

Buy it at BOL

Douglas Coupland espouses the lives of the young and disenfranchised, the crazier the better. His kooky characters struggle to abandon the traditional structures of family, religion and convention, while giving the finger to north America's spiritless consumerism; they may not always triumph, but they usually sample enough gritty freedoms to give them (and the reader) more than a glimpse of an alternative way of being.

Coupland's latest, Miss Wyoming, approaches the same paradigm from a different angle. What happens when you tire of reinventing yourself? Where do you go? And, perhaps more importantly, who do you take with you?

Susan Colgate is an American beauty. She's been a beauty queen since the age of four, a child TV star, a rock 'n' roll bride and, finally, a disenchanted ex-celeb. When her plane crashes and everyone thinks she's dead, she decides to ditch her "variety pack" of identities and go in search of a more lasting self.

Before long she's raiding the bins at McDonald's and getting scooped up by a garbage truck. "In her new life she'd have to start at the bottom." Coupland splices Colgate's freakish odyssey with episodes from her previous incarnations; in the process he savages America's dependence on success.

The other narrative strand follows the bizarre quest undertaken by 37-year-old John Johnson. This affluent "semi-sleazebag movie producer" is fed up with his life of hookers, drink and drugs: he also becomes a highway-walking hobo, assuming each new identity as quickly as a change in clothes. And he too has come through a near-death experience, flatlining for a few moments with a vision of Susan Colgate (another recurring motif from Coupland's brand of bourbon-fuelled romanticism).

Coupland manipulates the two narratives with devilish mastery: their stories mirror each other, almost touch, then move away. The structure can confuse: it is like watching a TV series in which the episodes have been shuffled. The author's point is that we're living in an age in which time seems to pass more quickly; his twisted chronology is a way of slowing things down, sustaining the narrative's awkward energies and deferring the inevitable outcome.

As Johnson notes, you reach a moment in life when thereafter "it's reruns". For Coupland, soothsayer of the anxious generation, the only way to break the loop is with love, and that's exactly what his characters are holding out for. There is more than enough fret and fizz here to keep you simmering, and even if Coupland can't resist the gawky, lyrical ending, for this he can easily be forgiven.

webTitle: Fight on to stamp out dissent

fields.headline: Fight on to stamp out dissent
fields.standfirst: Football Association will seek today to introduce 10-yard punishment in the Premiership next season
fields.trailText: Football Association will seek today to introduce 10-yard punishment in the Premiership next season as Fifa is about to rule on the issue.
fields.body:
The Football Association will be looking for no dissent from Fifa today when the world game's governing body meets to decide on the introduction of the 10-yard rule in the Premiership next season.

Fifa's law-making International Board is expected to sanction the worldwide recognition of a new ruling whereby free-kicks are moved forward if referees' decisions are disputed.

But even if the decision is to delay implementation, the FA plans to seek special permis sion to introduce it to the Premiership from August.

The FA has been looking to employ the new measure for some time, but the recent incidents of players haranguing referees - most notably in games involving Manchester United - has made the call for a rule change more pressing.

The rule, which has long been applied successfully in both codes of rugby, was given a trial run in Jersey for 18 months and was credited with a 40% drop in cautions for dissent as well as, apparently, persuading many referees to continue in the game.

This season the trial has been extended to the Auto Windscreens Shield and Fifa are pleased with the results to date. "It has seriously cut down dissent and time wasting at free-kicks, allowed the game to flow more and improved sportsmanship," said a spokesman.

Under the proposed new rule, the referee is allowed to move the ball forward 10 yards for an offence committed after the award of a free-kick.

The four offences are: failing to retreat 10 yards at a free-kick; delaying the free-kick by carrying, throwing or kicking the ball away; dissent; and unsporting behaviour. The player causing the advancement must be cautioned, and if booked for the original offence, a dismissal would follow.

If the extra 10 yards takes the ball into the penalty area, the kick remains direct or indirect; no penalty is given. This could lead to the spectacle of the defending team lined up on the goal-line while a member of the opposition enjoys a clear shot at goal.

Today's meeting is being held at Cliveden, the former stately home, now a hotel, where Christine Keeler met the minister of war John Profumo and precipitated the biggest sex scandal of the 60s.

Less explosive issues being discussed by Fifa today include continuing the experiment of using two referees per game, introducing sanctions against players using arms or holding to gain unfair advantage, the possible use of goal-line technology, allowing the fourth official a more active role, speeding up the goalkeeper's distribution and banning on-pitch advertising.

England's Under-21s will face Italy, the hosts Slovakia and Turkey in the European Championships in May should they defeat Yugoslavia in their play-off next month. Spain, Holland, the Czech Republic and Croatia make up Group A. The top-four teams will qualify for the Olympics - but not England as they are not a separate member of the IOC.

Ten of Argentina's team which beat England in the 1998 World Cup quarter-final have been named in the squad for Wednesday's friendly between the sides at Wembley.

webTitle: Don't be a part of the net shake-out

fields.headline: Don't be a part of the net shake-out
fields.standfirst:
It's a bubble which at some stage will burst leaving casualties, especially among employees. The trick is to find the right niche.

E-finance: special report

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The debate over the risks of investing in internet-related companies rolls on. As with any bubble, there are those who see nothing but doom and those that see nothing but pound signs and, eventually, the strong will survive and the weak die.
fields.body:
The debate over the risks of investing in internet-related companies rolls on. As with any bubble, there are those who see nothing but doom and those that see nothing but pound signs and, eventually, the strong will survive and the weak die.

Investors who pumped money into high-risk internet stocks and lost it all will be unhappy. But there are others who invest more than just their cash in the internet - the hundreds of thousands who have found employment in the sector.

Reliable statistics are hard to come by. The last time the Employment Service reviewed the way it categorises jobs was in 1992. This pre-dates real net development, so it is impossible to strip out which jobs are specifically net-related from any others in the IT field.

Despite this it is impossible to ignore the fact that the internet is creating thousands of new jobs. In sectors such as banking, most news seems to be bad news. The growth of internet banking reduces the need for high street branches, so many traditional banking jobs are gone. But even banks such as Barclays - the largest online bank with 600,000 customers - and Lloyds TSB, where jobs have been drastically cut, argue that at least as many jobs are created by the new services.

Across the economy as a whole the result of internet-based job creation appears to be an increase in opportunities. Jobless figures are at a 20-year low. The latest figures showed the number of unemployed down to 1,158,000. Recruitment agencies report that the number of internet-related jobs on offer is growing at a phenomenal rate. Christine Little, a director at the Recruitment & Employment Confederation, the industry body for recruitment consultants, says this is illustrated by the demand for people with net-related technical skills such as programmers and website designers.

Tesco recently announced that it will create 7,000 jobs by tripling the number of stores that offer its web-based home shopping service. Sifam Fibre Optics is to take on 1,000 people to cope with new business arising from the internet boom. The company is to invest £5m, which will include building a new factory.

So it is important to ask questions about the longevity of the new jobs. If it is risky to invest in an internet company it must be all the more risky to work for one since it is your livelihood is at stake.

Richard Downs is managing director and founder of Iglu.com, which sells winter sports holidays. Mr Downs now employs 40 people and agrees that internet jobs are risky, but not entirely. He says it is true on a "micro" level: that there is a good chance that many who have gained jobs in the internet boom will lose them when companies go to the wall. But it is not true on a "macro" level: the internet will continue to be a sector with a wealth of employment opportunities. His view is: "It all depends on the switching costs for employees. If their jobs go in the company, how long will it be before they find another job with another company?" But as he acknowledges, this analysis is all very well if you are an economist, but irrelevant if you suddenly find yourself without a salary.

Mr Downs says the best course to take its to ensure that your skills are applicable elsewhere. Ideally your "skills set" will not be internet-specific, he says, but will be such that you would be a useful asset to any company in your field. Ms Little supports this. This week Amaze, a company that sets up internet operations for other businesses, announced it is to recruit 50 people over the next two months. These will not only be technical specialists but also journalists and academics not necessarily identified with the net.

Mr Downs says: "Individuals need to build downside risk into their personal skill set acquisition," as if reading from an MBA textbook. But he does raise a key point. Those who depend on the internet alone are most vulnerable when the boom times fade. This is not only true of the employees but of the companies. Gillian Miller is the home shopping manager for Tesco Online in Kent and one of the beneficiaries of the internet jobs boom, but she does not see it that way. As far as Ms Miller is concerned it is just another managerial position within Tesco.

It is common for small start-up internet companies to invite their employees to share ownership. Joining a new, small company dependent on unproven technology is risky and deserves to be rewarded. If it is not, employees will be few and far between. And most new companies are not cash-rich and the best they can offer is a stake in the future of the company. At Tesco neither of these rules apply. Ms Miller was given no extra equity in the company and did not even get a pay rise. But with more orders coming in than the department can cope with, she says it is obvious that her job is not likely to be on the line. As long as people want to shop at Tesco on the net Ms Miller is in a job.

Tesco is what Mr Downs calls "a high-profile value company" and it is in such firms that secure net jobs can be found. But Ms Miller, on a salary of £14,000 with no extra benefits, is not likely to be joining the swelling ranks of e-millionaires. On the other hand her job is pretty secure - and therein lies the pay-off.
fields.bodyText: The debate over the risks of investing in internet-related companies rolls on. As with any bubble, there are those who see nothing but doom and those that see nothing but pound signs and, eventually, the strong will survive and the weak die. Investors who pumped money into high-risk internet stocks and lost it all will be unhappy. But there are others who invest more than just their cash in the internet - the hundreds of thousands who have found employment in the sector. Reliable statistics are hard to come by. The last time the Employment Service reviewed the way it categorises jobs was in 1992. This pre-dates real net development, so it is impossible to strip out which jobs are specifically net-related from any others in the IT field. Despite this it is impossible to ignore the fact that the internet is creating thousands of new jobs. In sectors such as banking, most news seems to be bad news. The growth of internet banking reduces the need for high street branches, so many traditional banking jobs are gone. But even banks such as Barclays - the largest online bank with 600,000 customers - and Lloyds TSB, where jobs have been drastically cut, argue that at least as many jobs are created by the new services. Across the economy as a whole the result of internet-based job creation appears to be an increase in opportunities. Jobless figures are at a 20-year low. The latest figures showed the number of unemployed down to 1,158,000. Recruitment agencies report that the number of internet-related jobs on offer is growing at a phenomenal rate. Christine Little, a director at the Recruitment & Employment Confederation, the industry body for recruitment consultants, says this is illustrated by the demand for people with net-related technical skills such as programmers and website designers. Tesco recently announced that it will create 7,000 jobs by tripling the number of stores that offer its web-based home shopping service. Sifam Fibre Optics is to take on 1,000 people to cope with new business arising from the internet boom. The company is to invest £5m, which will include building a new factory. So it is important to ask questions about the longevity of the new jobs. If it is risky to invest in an internet company it must be all the more risky to work for one since it is your livelihood is at stake. Richard Downs is managing director and founder of Iglu.com, which sells winter sports holidays. Mr Downs now employs 40 people and agrees that internet jobs are risky, but not entirely. He says it is true on a "micro" level: that there is a good chance that many who have gained jobs in the internet boom will lose them when companies go to the wall. But it is not true on a "macro" level: the internet will continue to be a sector with a wealth of employment opportunities. His view is: "It all depends on the switching costs for employees. If their jobs go in the company, how long will it be before they find another job with another company?" But as he acknowledges, this analysis is all very well if you are an economist, but irrelevant if you suddenly find yourself without a salary. Mr Downs says the best course to take its to ensure that your skills are applicable elsewhere. Ideally your "skills set" will not be internet-specific, he says, but will be such that you would be a useful asset to any company in your field. Ms Little supports this. And most new companies are not cash-rich and the best they can offer is a stake in the future of the company. At Tesco neither of these rules apply. Ms Miller was given no extra equity in the company and did not even get a pay rise. But with more orders coming in than the department can cope with, she says it is obvious that her job is not likely to be on the line. As long as people want to shop at Tesco on the net Ms Miller is in a job. Tesco is what Mr Downs calls "a high-profile value company" and it is in such firms that secure net jobs can be found. But Ms Miller, on a salary of £14,000 with no extra benefits, is not likely to be joining the swelling ranks of e-millionaires. On the other hand her job is pretty secure - and therein lies the pay-off.

fields.headline: Share trading
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Instead of frittering away his money on beer or CDs, one Loughborough University student turned £5,800 saved from student loans into £12,000 in just eight weeks after clambering on the net share-trading bandwagon.
fields.body:
Instead of frittering away his money on beer or CDs, one Loughborough University student turned £5,800 saved from student loans into £12,000 in just eight weeks after clambering on the net share-trading bandwagon.

Paul McLernon, a final year engineering student, says he has made enough money from buying and selling hi-tech stocks to more than pay off all his student debts and that his worry now is capital gains tax. He's part of the astonishing wave of small investors who are jamming cheap internet-based dealing services in the frenzy of technology share trading that took off in September last year.

This week it reached new peaks with the flotation of Interactive Investor International, with 127,000 small investors scrambling to buy shares in the personal finance website. The scramble paid off - trading began on Thursday, and the 150p shares immediately soared to 335p. But many financial advisers believe that when the bubble bursts, small investors will be left with hefty losses.

Some of Mr McLernon's first investments have gone up between five and 10 times. He bought internet investment group medi@invest at 8.5p and sold for 63p, having seen them hit 90p. He bought another media company, Birchin International, for 1.5p, they are now 8.5p and he still holds them. He bought Screen plc at 3.5p and they currently trade at 19.5p. Channel 4's Show Me The Money programme, which achieved fame after shares it highlighted soared, was the spur for Mr McLernon to begin share trading. "I planned a portfolio on paper and traced it for a month. I was making too much money, so I decided to put my money where my mouth was." He uses university computers to research stocks and follows the bulletin boards run by websites such as hemscott and iii. "I have started to use the chat rooms which have helped me to see when to sell."

And he admits: "I'm desperately losing interest in my degree subject ... but shares have given me a greater understanding of how companies work- useful in talking about jobs!"

fields.headline: The fund buyers
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: City experts scoffed when Framlington launched its "NetNet" fund last year. Surely you wouldn't want to put your savings into what was obviously a classic stock market bubble with obscene valuations? But small investors have had the last laugh - the fund has leapt by an amazing 188% in the past six months.
fields.body:
City experts scoffed when Framlington launched its "NetNet" fund last year. Surely you wouldn't want to put your savings into what was obviously a classic stock market bubble with obscene valuations? But small investors have had the last laugh - the fund has leapt by an amazing 188% in the past six months.

Mohammed Sheikh is one of the lucky investors who has put his cash into the fund. He should also know a bit about technology - he is a founding director of International Wireless Communications, which is working on the hottest buzzword in technology WAP, or Wireless Application Protocol. This will be the technology at the heart of the next generation of mobile phones.

But it leaves him little time to buy and sell shares directly, so he opted for Framlington NetNet, which has a spread of technology investments. "Obviously I believe in the technology story over the long term. But rather than invest directly myself, I expect a fund manager to distinguish between companies which have got a credible business and those that don't."

This week, though, one of the biggest investment advisers in the UK, Best Investment, issued a strong warning against buying net-based funds in the short-term. Jason Hollands, of Best Investment, says: "Most discount brokers are actively promoting technology funds because they are an easy story to sell. Investors who have seen last year's returns from these funds are clambering over each other to get in, often without fully appreciating the risks.

But try telling that to investors who hopped on the technology bus early. The two flagship technology funds in the UK are Aberdeen Technology - which has turned a £1,000 investment five years ago into £9,310, and Henderson Technology, which would have given you £8,197.

If you want a seriously racy fund, consider the Close Brothers Techmark fund, which tracks the Techmark 100 index of UK hi-tech shares. It only launched on November 3 and is already up 110%.

fields.headline: Online bank war heats up
fields.standfirst:
Patrick Collinson looks at the latest arrivals on the internet's financial scene

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Cheap internet-based mortgages moved a step closer this week, with both Abbey National and Halifax launching on-line banks to stem the flow of customers to rival start-ups.
fields.body:
Cheap internet-based mortgages moved a step closer this week, with both Abbey National and Halifax launching on-line banks to stem the flow of customers to rival start-ups.

Details of the mortgage products will not be released for several weeks - at this stage the banks are prepared only to unveil their strategy - but it is likely that UK homeowners could soon be enjoying mortgages priced on the same basis as they are in the US, at about 1% over base rate. That would give borrowers a typical interest rate of 7% compared with the current Halifax standard variable rate of 7.74%.

Abbey National is planning to spend £200m to recruit 1m internet customers for its newly created bank, named cahoot. It will be aimed at what its managing director, Tim Murley says are "a target audience of people who are comfortable with technology". By that he means homebuyers in their 20s, and definitely not the UK's most famous net virgin, 47 year old Tony Blair.

Abbey said it would also launch an upmarket bank, which would have a presence on the net but also in its branches, later in the year. The business, codenamed Prosper, will target people with more than £50,000 of net assets - a market of more than 4m.

An internet service for existing customers will be launched next month and will be accessible on digital television.

The separately-branded and marketed cahoot bank will keep the price of its products low by shaving its costs to a bare minimum. Cahoot - so called because cahoots tend to be formed between friends rather than enemies - will be a "virtual" bank, outsourcing nearly all its functions to third parties. It will have only 40-50 staff when it launches in April.

Nonetheless, it aims to offer the full range of services provided by traditional banks. "We are interested in being a full service provider, though we will not be offering all products on day one," says Mr Murley. To start with, cahoot will have an emphasis on credit cards and current accounts.

In a move that parallels the internet shopping zone set up by Prudential's Egg savings and credit card account, cahoot will establish links with Blackstart for videos, Boxman for CDs, Thomas Cook for travel and Dell for computers. This week Egg announced that it will give customers a 5% cash back for every purchase they make in its shopping zone for the remainder of February until March 6.

Within hours of unveiling cahoot yesterday, Abbey claimed the new website was receiving six hits per minute from people wanting to register before its opening in six weeks' time. Recent projections by Barclays that up to 10m people could sign up to an e-bank by the end of this year now look more plausible.

Halifax launched this week a site to rival Standard Life Bank, which has pulled the rug from under the traditional lenders with its telephone-based flexible mortgage, grabbing up to 15% of new mortgages sold last year. Halifax also announced details of a deal with BT Cellnet that will let customers access their accounts from internet-enabled mobile phones and personal organisers.

In the fierce turf war among banks on the internet, Barclays is determined not to be left behind. It already has 600,000 online banking customers, 100,000 of whom were recruited in January. In a survey this week it came top as the financial services provider most associated with the internet, leaving Abbey National trailing in ninth place. Barclays plans to unveil further e-initiatives in the spring.

fields.headline: Run a web firm
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Two years ago Karen Liebreich was a BBC assistant producer, working on the Timewatch series. A history graduate, she knew nothing about the internet and didn't care too much either. Now she's turning away internet venture capitalists and major corporate names keen to share in the success of her web launch, www.babydirectory.com.
fields.body:
Two years ago Karen Liebreich was a BBC assistant producer, working on the Timewatch series. A history graduate, she knew nothing about the internet and didn't care too much either. Now she's turning away internet venture capitalists and major corporate names keen to share in the success of her web launch, www.babydirectory.com.

It started in the proverbial spare bedroom of her home after the birth of her child meant that frequent work-related trips abroad were impossible. She began a publishing venture, the London Baby Directory, an A-Z of contacts for pregnant women and mothers with children under five. But she was spurred to go on the net by her brother, founder of another website, www.complete-skier.com.

Her initial investment was just over £10,000, largely design and IT support for setting up the site, and she's now getting around 40,000 hits a week on the site. However, she admits: "The books make money, the website doesn't - yet. It also means I work during the day, pick up the children and after I've put them to bed I start work again. But I can manage the business as well as be a hands-on parent and one day I hope to be a dot com millionaire. Why not?"

In another corner of the turf war among new websites is www.garden-genie.com, which launches this weekend and plans a £3m advertising spend. One of the founding directors, Tim Alderson, is part of the new wave of professionals quitting secure jobs to take a bet on the net. "We did a lot of research and identified the garden centre market because there was virtually no competition." Users of garden-genie.com can source their garden needs through the site.

Having a credible business plan is essential. "There's huge amounts of money going into start-ups, but the desks of the venture capital companies are groaning under the weight of proposals. You always hear about the successes, not the hundreds that fail." Fashions change almost overnight. "Before Christmas the venture capital was about business to consumer, now it's all about business to business ... It is a challenge, it is terrifying, but it's all to play for," says Mr Alderson.

www.fourleaf.com - online introduction and dealmaking service for internet ventures.

www.dcfor.com - online access to dotcom people, resources and knowledge.

www.estart.com - online resource centre for start-ups.

fields.headline: Invest in start-up
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Want to ride the net wave but not willing to take the risk of quitting your job? Then the answer may be to lend your investment cash and professional skills to a friend or colleague who you believe has a plan that will take off.
fields.body:
Want to ride the net wave but not willing to take the risk of quitting your job? Then the answer may be to lend your investment cash and professional skills to a friend or colleague who you believe has a plan that will take off.

Freelance travel journalist Sophie Campbell came up with an idea about selling weekend breaks over the net, but it was the business nous of her flatmate, Bridget Guerlin, which made the City sit up and take notice. Last June last year, between moving jobs from Schroder Unit Trusts, where she was the marketing director, to Matrix Investment Management, Mrs Guerlin wrote the company's business plan. She secured the backing of James Ogilvy, managing director of Foreign & Colonial, who agreed to become the start-up's chairman.

After that, raising the initial capital was relatively simple. "It was very, very easy. We thought it would be difficult, but we quickly raised £600,000 and even had to send cheques back." Other friends and colleagues have chipped in, most working two or three nights a week as non-executive directors. One is the editor of a travel magazine, another a lawyer at a major corporate, another an IT specialist at a bank. Currently it is due to go live in April or May, but its identity remains under wraps for now. A thorough business plan and a board with management expertise are essentials to raise financing. "Everyone's got ideas, but if they've got a business plan formulated and key management in place, it's far easier to secure funding. The crazy days of money pouring into little more than spare-bedroom set-ups are gone. Most of them are now dot bombs, not dot coms," says Eric Bain, managing director of Illuminator, one of the 'incubator' funds which finance start-ups.

Illuminator will cost out an idea and evaluate whether there's a gap in the market. It may then invest, but also demand a substantial equity stake in the business.

Links

Accountants - most have corporate finance teams which assist in finding finance from VCs and institutions.

Venture capital - the British Venture Capital Association has a list of firms. Contact: 0171-629-9949.

Incubators - UK Business Incubators will provide a list of firms. Call 0121-250-3538 or www.ukbi.co.uk

Angels - for the National Network of Business Angels Groups, contact LentA Ventures: 0171-236-3000.

Grants - The Princes Trust provides small start-up grants. Contact: 0171-707-4001

webTitle: Four ways to net a real fortune

fields.headline: Four ways to net a real fortune
fields.standfirst: More and more people are making unbelievable sums through internet businesses. But, as Patrick Collinson wonders, what does it take to get a slice of the action?
fields.trailText: Run a web firm
fields.body:
Run a web firm

Two years ago Karen Liebreich was a BBC assistant producer, working on the Timewatch series. A history graduate, she knew nothing about the internet and didn't care too much either. Now she's turning away internet venture capitalists and major corporate names keen to share in the success of her web launch, www.babydirectory.com.

It started in the proverbial spare bedroom of her home after the birth of her child meant that frequent work-related trips abroad were impossible. She began a publishing venture, the London Baby Directory, an A-Z of contacts for pregnant women and mothers with children under five. But she was spurred to go on the net by her brother, founder of another website, www.complete-skier.com.

Her initial investment was just over £10,000, largely design and IT support for setting up the site, and she's now getting around 40,000 hits a week on the site. However, she admits: "The books make money, the website doesn't - yet. It also means I work during the day, pick up the children and after I've put them to bed I start work again. But I can manage the business as well as be a hands-on parent and one day I hope to be a dot com millionaire. Why not?"

In another corner of the turf war among new websites is www.garden-genie.com, which launches this weekend and plans a £3m advertising spend. One of the founding directors, Tim Alderson, is part of the new wave of professionals quitting secure jobs to take a bet on the net. "We did a lot of research and identified the garden centre market because there was virtually no competition." Users of garden-genie.com can source their garden needs through the site.

Having a credible business plan is essential. "There's huge amounts of money going into start-ups, but the desks of the venture capital companies are groaning under the weight of proposals. You always hear about the successes, not the hundreds that fail." Fashions change almost overnight. "Before Christmas the venture capital was about business to consumer, now it's all about business to business ... It is a challenge, it is terrifying, but it's all to play for," says Mr Alderson.

Links

 www.firsttuesday.co.uk - meetings, discussion groups and resources for budding e-preneurs.

 www.fourleaf.com - online introduction and dealmaking service for internet ventures.

 www.dcfor.com - online access to dotcom people, resources and knowledge.

 www.estart.com - online resource centre for start-ups.

 www.business-incubator.com - technology support/design/consulting.

 DTI innovation advisory service: 01633-811161

Invest in start-up

Want to ride the net wave but not willing to take the risk of quitting your job? Then the answer may be to lend your investment cash and professional skills to a friend or colleague who you believe has a plan that will take off.

Freelance travel journalist Sophie Campbell came up with an idea about selling weekend breaks over the net, but it was the business nous of her flatmate, Bridget Guerlin, which made the City sit up and take notice. Last June last year, between moving jobs from Schroder Unit Trusts, where she was the marketing director, to Matrix Investment Management, Mrs Guerlin wrote the company's business plan. She secured the backing of James Ogilvy, managing director of Foreign & Colonial, who agreed to become the start-up's chairman.

After that, raising the initial capital was relatively simple. "It was very, very easy. We thought it would be difficult, but we quickly raised £600,000 and even had to send cheques back." Other friends and colleagues have chipped in, most working two or three nights a week as non-executive directors. One is the editor of a travel magazine, another a lawyer at a major corporate, another an IT specialist at a bank. Currently it is due to go live in April or May, but its identity remains under wraps for now. A thorough business plan and a board with management expertise are essentials to raise financing. "Everyone's got ideas, but if they've got a business plan formulated and key management in place, it's far easier to secure funding. The crazy days of money pouring into little more than spare-bedroom set-ups are gone. Most of them are now dot bombs, not dot coms," says Eric Bain, managing director of Illuminator, one of the 'incubator' funds which finance start-ups.

Illuminator will cost out an idea and evaluate whether there's a gap in the market. It may then invest, but also demand a substantial equity stake in the business.

Links

 Accountants - most have corporate finance teams which assist in finding finance from VCs and institutions.

 Venture capital - the British Venture Capital Association has a list of firms. Contact: 0171-629-9949.

 Incubators - UK Business Incubators will provide a list of firms. Call 0121-250-3538 or www.ukbi.co.uk

 Angels - for the National Network of Business Angels Groups, contact LentA Ventures: 0171-236-3000.

 Grants - The Princes Trust provides small start-up grants. Contact: 0171-707-4001

Share trading

Instead of frittering away his money on beer or CDs, one Loughborough University student turned £5,800 saved from student loans into £12,000 in just eight weeks after clambering on the net share-trading bandwagon.

Paul McLernon, a final year engineering student, says he has made enough money from buying and selling hi-tech stocks to more than pay off all his student debts and that his worry now is capital gains tax. He's part of the astonishing wave of small investors who are jamming cheap internet-based dealing services in the frenzy of technology share trading that took off in September last year.

This week it reached new peaks with the flotation of Interactive Investor International, with 127,000 small investors scrambling to buy shares in the personal finance website. The scramble paid off - trading began on Thursday, and the 150p shares immediately soared to 335p. But many financial advisers believe that when the bubble bursts, small investors will be left with hefty losses.

Some of Mr McLernon's first investments have gone up between five and 10 times. He bought internet investment group medi@invest at 8.5p and sold for 63p, having seen them hit 90p. He bought another media company, Birchin International, for 1.5p, they are now 8.5p and he still holds them. He bought Screen plc at 3.5p and they currently trade at 19.5p. Channel 4's Show Me The Money programme, which achieved fame after shares it highlighted soared, was the spur for Mr McLernon to begin share trading. "I planned a portfolio on paper and traced it for a month. I was making too much money, so I decided to put my money where my mouth was." He uses university computers to research stocks and follows the bulletin boards run by websites such as hemscott and iii. "I have started to use the chat rooms which have helped me to see when to sell."

And he admits: "I'm desperately losing interest in my degree subject ... but shares have given me a greater understanding of how companies work- useful in talking about jobs!"

Links

Personal finance website with share prices, bulletin boards and chat rooms:

 www.hemscott.co.uk

 www.iii.co.uk

 www.motleyfool.co.uk

Internet-based share dealers

 www.halifax.co.uk/sharedeal

 www.schwab-worldwide.com

 www.barclays-stockbrokers.co.uk

 www.natwest.co.uk/stockbrokers

 www.etrade.co.uk

Most popular hi-tech shares bought in last month through Charles Schwab:

1. Pacific Media

2. Medi@invest

3. Scoot.com

4. Birchin Intl

5. Arm Holdings

6. Evestment Co

7. Medisys

8. Telewest Coms

9. Baltimore Tech

10. Durlacher Corp

The fund buyers

City experts scoffed when Framlington launched its "NetNet" fund last year. Surely you wouldn't want to put your savings into what was obviously a classic stock market bubble with obscene valuations? But small investors have had the last laugh - the fund has leapt by an amazing 188% in the past six months.

Mohammed Sheikh is one of the lucky investors who has put his cash into the fund. He should also know a bit about technology - he is a founding director of International Wireless Communications, which is working on the hottest buzzword in technology WAP, or Wireless Application Protocol. This will be the technology at the heart of the next generation of mobile phones.

But it leaves him little time to buy and sell shares directly, so he opted for Framlington NetNet, which has a spread of technology investments. "Obviously I believe in the technology story over the long term. But rather than invest directly myself, I expect a fund manager to distinguish between companies which have got a credible business and those that don't."

This week, though, one of the biggest investment advisers in the UK, Best Investment, issued a strong warning against buying net-based funds in the short-term. Jason Hollands, of Best Investment, says: "Most discount brokers are actively promoting technology funds because they are an easy story to sell. Investors who have seen last year's returns from these funds are clambering over each other to get in, often without fully appreciating the risks.

But try telling that to investors who hopped on the technology bus early. The two flagship technology funds in the UK are Aberdeen Technology - which has turned a £1,000 investment five years ago into £9,310, and Henderson Technology, which would have given you £8,197.

If you want a seriously racy fund, consider the Close Brothers Techmark fund, which tracks the Techmark 100 index of UK hi-tech shares. It only launched on November 3 and is already up 110%.

Links

 www.micropal.com - information on fund performance and fund details

 www.find.co.uk - a comprehensive internet directory of financial services websites

 www.framlington-netnet.co.uk - site for the net net fund

 www.closefm.com - downloadable application forms for Techmark fund

 www.aberdeen-asset.com - information on Aberdeen funds

 www.henderson.com - information on Henderson funds

fields.headline: £17bn pours into Brown's war chest
fields.standfirst: Record public sector surplus paves way for modest tax cuts
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's pre-election war chest was replenished by a record £17.2bn public sector surplus in January, according to official figures published yesterday.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's pre-election war chest was replenished by a record £17.2bn public sector surplus in January, according to official figures published yesterday.

The windfall more than offset the £9.2bn deficit recorded in December and put the chancellor in an ideal position as he adds the finishing touches to next month's budget.

While significant tax cuts are ruled out by the danger of over-stimulating the economy, token measures can easily be afforded without jeopardising the health of the public finances or the expected generosity of the next spending round, economists say.

The office for national statistics said January's improvement in the public finances was mainly due to seasonal factors, with record income tax receipts, possibly boosted by bonuses and millennium overtime payments, and strong non-food sales lifting VAT returns.

The treasury pointed out that the closing date for self assessment - January 31 - fell on a Monday. Last year it was a Sunday, meaning many people settled tax bills on February 1.

The data might also have been flattered by a fallback in government spending to a more normal level after large interest payments on state debt in December and some millennium-related expenditure.

Even so, economists said Mr Brown would beat his pre-budget forecast for the public finances this year by a wide margin. "Barring complete disasters in the remaining two months of the fiscal year, the finances look likely to repeat last year's full-year surplus of around £7bn - £6bn better than Mr Brown predicted in his pre-budget report," said Jonathan Loynes at HSBC.

"Accordingly, the chancellor could afford in theory to give away a similar amount next year whilst sticking to his borrowing projections."

Neil Parker of the Royal Bank of Scotland said: "We feel it is almost inevitable that the full-year 1999-2000 PSNCR [public sector net cash requirement] will be better than the government's pre-budget report forecast. But we still expect the chancellor to be prudent with his purse strings."

With the economy growing strongly, significant tax cuts would almost certainly trigger further interest rate rises by the Bank of England to contain inflationary pressure.

But tax cuts of £2bn would not over-stimulate demand and would prevent the tax bur den rising over the rest of the parliament, according to last month's green budget, published by the Institute for Fiscal Studies.

The green budget said there would be room in this summer's comprehensive spending review to allocate an extra £3bn to departmental budgets in 2001-02, the last year of the current three-year spending programme, and increase current spending by 2.5% a year in the three years from 2002-03.

Spending on this scale would help shore up support among Labour's core voters.

A significant shift in Labour's presentation emerged last week when it was admitted for the first time since 1997 that Mr Brown's tax strategy has been redistributive in favour of the poor - the R-word he has shied away from to avoid frightening middle England' voters.

Labour MPs are showing signs of getting bolder - or more anxious about their re-election prospects - and party HQ is targeting disaffected heartland voters in what is officially called Operation Turnout.

webTitle: Pay more or lose out, policyholders told

fields.headline: Pay more or lose out, policyholders told
fields.standfirst: An insurance company has been forced to admit that its retirement scheme is poor value, reports Tony Levene
fields.trailText: Pension plan purchasers in one of Britain's oldest life companies have been given an ultimatum: increase your present payments or don't bother with any more premiums as you'll lose out.
fields.body:
Pension plan purchasers in one of Britain's oldest life companies have been given an ultimatum: increase your present payments or don't bother with any more premiums as you'll lose out.

The move has been forced by the forthcoming stakeholder pension plans which will cut a swath through the more expensive end of the pensions market.

Personal pension buyers with London Life - now part of the AMP Group along with Pearl, NPI and Henderson - have been sent letters saying they should increase contributions if "the policy is to provide them with good value".

Pensions experts are asking why other companies have not sent out similar letters. Many schemes look poor value compared with the new style pre-stakeholder plans entering the market.

London Life warns those who are unable - or unwilling - to increase their monthly or annual payments "that it might be better for you to stop paying regular contributions into your London Life pension plan altogether."

The letter has been sent to holders of old style personal pensions known as retirement annuity policies - many of which date back to before 1980. Some holders are now paying as little as £10 a month or £100 a year. London Life admits they "are unlikely to receive a worthwhile pension" and that "a significant proportion of each current contribution now goes to pay charges."

It says increasing contributions to £50 a month or £500 a year would provide "good value." But that is unlikely to be competitive with many pre-stakeholder plans such as those from Marks & Spencer and a number of independent financial advisers where costs only are around 0.65 to 0.75% a year.

London Life charges a typical £25 a month or £250 a year planholder an upfront 9% charge on top of the fund management fee - 1% for unit linked funds and around 0.7% for its with-profits scheme. On £50 per month or £500 a year, the upfront charge drops to 8%. It promises that those who stop will pay no more than annual charges while their paid-up policy continues to grow ahead of their retirement. Most of London Life's old style policies have guaranteed annuities which it intends to honour in full.

The pension provider says it has written to policyholders because watchdog the Financial Services Authority has ordered pension providers to ensure customers are not "at a material disadvantage" when stakeholder arrives.

London Life's Chris Essex says the letter only affects a minority of their customers: "The insurance industry has had a bad name for high charges. We're trying to be upfront and honest. Our charges will fall from March 1."

But he concedes the new upfront 5% on £50 a month or £500 a year will still be more expensive than stakeholder which has no initial charge. "No one has defined materially disadvantaged," he adds.

London Life is not a with-profits market leader. It does not send results to Money Management magazine for its annual pensions review. But based on its own figures for a £10,000 single contribution made by a man in 1980 then aged 45 who is now retiring, it would be at the low end of the league. This plan would have paid £111,817 last month. The most recent Money Management tables for the 20 years to July 1999 show the average payout of 20 companies was £164,120.

webTitle: Why fixed rates have not proved a snorter

fields.headline: Why fixed rates have not proved a snorter
fields.standfirst: In 1998, as the country was gripped by the tale of the Tamworth pigs, thousands opted for a sweet deal that has turned sour, says Rupert Jones
fields.trailText: Higher mortgage payments are on the way for millions, with Abbey National and Nationwide among the latest lenders to announce they will be upping their home loan rates by at least 0.25%.
fields.body:
Higher mortgage payments are on the way for millions, with Abbey National and Nationwide among the latest lenders to announce they will be upping their home loan rates by at least 0.25%.

The February 10 Bank of England base rate rise was the fourth in six months, and economists say there is more to come. However, if you think you've got it bad, spare a thought for the tens of thousands of homeowners who are seeing their monthly mortgage bills double at a stroke.

These people took out cheap two-year fixed-rate deals back in early 1998 - a time when severe storms were battering the south coast, Titanic star Kate Winslet was up for an Oscar and the second of the Tamworth Two runaway pigs was being recaptured- in some cases, the rate they paid was fixed at 4% or even less. But now the fixed rate period is coming to an end and they are suddenly being plonked on to their lender's standard variable mortgage rate - typically around 7.74%. In hard cash terms, that could mean a borrower with a £100,000 interest-only mortgage could see the amount they shell out rising by more than £300 a month. Over a year that's getting on for £4,000 extra.

Most of these deals carry early redemption penalties for up to five years, which means borrower are stuck on the variable rate until perhaps 2003. Unless they can persuade their lender to let them move on to another fixed or discounted rate, their only means of escape will be to pay the redemption penalty in some cases several thousand pounds.

What are the various options for homeowners in this position? To analyse what's gone wrong it is necessary to turn the clock back to the start of 1998. Back then, the base rate stood at 7.25% after having risen five times in 1997, while the typical standard variable mortgage rate was 8.7%. The view of many commentators was that mortgage rates would start falling as the UK prepared to join the euro and could go as low as 5% in 2000. So taking advantage of one of the many cheap fixed-rate deals seemed to make perfect sense.

However, things didn't turn out as the economists predicted. Interest rates did fall, but then they started rising, and the standard variable mortgage rate is now close to 8% and showing no signs of stopping there.

A borrower who took out a £100,000 loan fixed at 3.99% for two years and is currently paying £332.50 a month will see this shoot up to perhaps £645 a month when they move on to the standard variable rate. Some homeowners will be able to absorb this huge leap in costs, but for others it will put "an enormous strain" on the family's finances, says Simon Tyler at mortgage brokers Chase De Vere Mortgage Management.

If you think you fall into this latter category, the first thing to do is check exactly what the redemption penalties are. If you are not locked in you should be looking to move to another lender's better deal without delay.

If there are penalties, talk to your lender to see if there are any other products they will let you switch into. If that doesn't work, there are other options. One is to consider paying the redemption penalty so you can move to another lender's deal. You will need to work out whether you would be better-off staying or going once the costs are taken into account, says Simon Knight at mortgage brokers Independent Mortgage Collection.

Sometimes there will be little in it. Take someone with a £100,000 interest-only loan whose two-year fixed-rate period has come to an end this month and is locked into the lender's standard variable rate (currently 7.74%) until February 28 2002. There is an early redemption penalty of six months' interest at the prevailing variable rate.

If they stick with the deal until the end of the lock-in period they will pay a total of £15,480 in mortgage payments. But if they moved to a good-value two-year fixed rate such as one offered by Yorkshire Building Society - 5.89% with no penalties after the two years - their total outlay over the two years would be £11,779. But they will have to pay the redemption penalty, which here would be £3,870, and when this is added to the amount the Yorkshire would charge it gives a total of £15,649.

If the sums work in your favour but you can't afford to pay the penalty and you think you're not going to be able to afford the higher payments once you move on to the standard variable rate, you could still go down the remortgage road but add the redemption charge to your new mortgage. So if you need a loan of £50,000 and are stuck with a redemption penalty of £2,000, you borrow £52,000 from your new lender. If this is the only way you can remortgage it is worth considering.

The worst thing is to do nothing, says Ray Boulger at mortgage broker John Charcol. You could end up in arrears - and then you may have difficulty obtaining a mortgage in future.

webTitle: Race against time to find missing victims

fields.headline: Race against time to find missing victims
fields.standfirst: A million people caught in the mis-selling scandal could forfeit compensation if they don't claim soon.
fields.trailText: As many as 1m people mainly aged 25 to 45 could be missing out on their rightful share of a multi-billion pound compensation payout because they are unaware they are affected or they have not got round to responding to letters sent to them.
fields.body:
As many as 1m people mainly aged 25 to 45 could be missing out on their rightful share of a multi-billion pound compensation payout because they are unaware they are affected or they have not got round to responding to letters sent to them.

The hunt is on for these people, who may have been wrongly sold a personal pension and could be due compensation averaging £4,000.

But it's a race against time because March 31 is the deadline for people in this position to come forward and request a review of their case.

If you were encouraged to leave your occupational pension scheme and take out a personal pension, or you had access to an occupational scheme at the time you were sold a pension plan, and this happened between April 1988 and June 1994, you could be a victim of mis-selling.

Here we look at what you need to do if you think you may have been short-changed.

What is the background to all this?
Personal pensions mis-selling has been described as one of the worst financial scandals of the last century. Its "peak years" were the late 80s and early 90s, when commission-hungry insurance salesmen and financial advisers persuaded huge numbers of people to take out pensions that were unsuitable for their needs.

Many of these people would have been much better off in the occupational scheme because then they would have received a contribution to their pension from their employer.

A major investigation into the scandal was launched in late 1994 and is still continuing. Initially, companies were ordered to concentrate their efforts on compensating the 700,000 so-called "priority" cases - those older people who have already retired or are close to retirement. But now the focus has shifted to tracking down younger victims of the scandal.

The Financial Services Authority, the City watchdog, has estimated that potentially more than 2m people mainly in their twenties, thirties and early forties may have been affected and could be due a payout. But 13 months after it launched a campaign specifically targeting these younger investors, only around 1.1m people have come forward to request a review of their case.

It is thought that many of the people who have not yet put in a claim will have been written to by their pension company early last year, but may have binned the letter, thinking it was junk mail, or filed it away in a drawer where it is now lying forgotten. Some will have fallen through the net and won't have received anything, perhaps because they have moved and the company can't locate them.

To raise awareness of the issue, the FSA has taken out ads in the national and local press featuring the campaign slogan "R U Owed?"

How do I know if all this affects me, and what do I need to do?
If, between April 29 1988 and June 30 1994, you were sold a personal pension when you could have stayed in, or joined, your employer's pension scheme, you may well be affected. So could people who transferred money built up in an occupational scheme into a pers- onal plan between these dates.

Pension companies were told to contact everyone on their books who fits this description. If you have still got the information pack, dig it out, read it, and if you think you may have lost out, send back the form to request a review. If you've mislaid the pack, or didn't receive one, contact your pension company and they will send you one.

If, after having read the information sent to you, you're still not sure what to do, it is probably safest to ask for a review to be carried out.

Those who request a review will be sent a questionnaire to fill in. This will ask for things like details about your past and current employment and salary and the approximate dates when you joined and left your employer's scheme.

The company will then check your case to see whether you have lost out. If the review shows you were wrongly advised and have effectively been left out of pocket as a result, it must write and tell you, and take steps to put things right. Some people will get nothing - firms are only required to pay compensation where they broke the rules in force at the time and the individual "suffered a loss". However, companies are under great pressure to settle up - so far, they have paid out more than £3bn to about 400,000 people.

How will the compensation work?
The aim, where possible, is to put you in the position you would have been in if you had joined, or never left, your employer's pension scheme, says the FSA.

"If you are still working for the same employer, the [pension] firm will usually buy you back into your employer's pension scheme. If that's not possible, they will usually pay extra money into your personal pension to bring it up to an equivalent value."

The pension firm may also replace extra benefits (such as life assurance) if you lost them through not being in your employer's scheme. The only people who will receive their compensation in the form of hard cash are those who have already retired.

How much might you get?
The typical compensation figure has been put at around £4,000, but some people could be owed a great deal more than that, while others will get less.

How long will this take?
Ahh, there's the rub. Pension companies have been set a deadline some way in the future - June 30 2002 to be precise - by which time everyone should have received either an "offer of redress" (a letter setting out exactly how the company proposes to put things right), or a letter explaining that they are not due any compensation. But, the FSA stresses that companies must get on with the job quickly, so you may not have to wait that long.

Where can I find out more?

The FSA has a helpline - 0800-003-007. There is also a website: www.pensions.fsa.gov.uk

webTitle: How you can be a best seller

fields.headline: How you can be a best seller
fields.standfirst: Lucinda Perrin picked up the title of the 1999 young sales professional of the year at the National Sales Awards ceremony. Here, she spells out to Nick Pandya her ten tips for success
fields.trailText: Lucinda Perrin picked up the title of the 1999 young sales professional of the year at the National Sales Awards ceremony. Here, she spells out to Nick Pandya her ten tips for success
fields.body:
Tear your hair out all you Toms, Dicks, and Harrys: the winner of the 1999 young sales professional of the year award has gone to a woman, Lucinda Perrin, for her success with Pitney Bowes.

The company is the world's largest provider of mailing and messaging products for organisations and businesses of all sizes. It offers a full range of mailing equipment and related financial services and is actively developing new communications products and technologies.

Lucinda has always been one of the company's top performers and is the only woman to have been admmited to its crown club for staff who beat their annual targets three years running.

She was appointed senior account manager at Pitney Bowes Australia in February 1999, where she was responsible for the mailing and the paper handling divisions of Pitney Bowes for the city of Sydney.

Lucinda has recently developed new business opportunities with Hong Kong and City Bank. Throughout her career sales and marketing have been her forte. Before joining Pitney Bowes she spent two years at Champions, a company which invests in London restaurants, as a promotion and marketing assistant. She worked closely with company directors Martin Burridge, Daley Thompson and Sebastian Coe to set up a sports theme restaurant in London.

So, what's the secret of Lucinda's success?

Here are her 10 tips for successfully building a career in sales and marketing.

1. Attitude

Adopt a positive attitude and work at developing a good rapport with customers. Make sure that you always give the best of yourself every day at work, that you have a trustworthy personality and that you are confident about what you are selling and believe in the product.

2. Preparation

Prepare yourself before you meet customers. Get all the information you can to help build up an image of potential customers.

3. Hard work

Set your own goals. Don't think that your targets are too hard and set by someone who is out of touch. Think they're too easy. Go on, you can double them, serve your customers and earn your pay.

4. Questioning

Building good relationships with customers comes from targeting the right person and always asking about their opinions and feelings on the situation.

5. Listening

If questioning is important, listening to what the customers are telling you is also essential in order to sell the right package.

6. Spotting problems

Identify customers' problems and find out whether your product or service is offering the best solution to address their needs.

7. Developing ideas

Think outside the box. Too many people think: "I am selling this product to this customer today" rather than finding ways of making their products fit. For example, in Lucinda's business, she's not just selling a franking machine. She'll be thinking about who are the end-users; often they may be different from the buyer. How much mail they're sending are they folding it by hand? How many sites does the business have and are there more opportunities?

8. Follow-up calls

Don't limit yourself to a selective choice of solutions and recognise each customer's potential. Every follow-up call is an opportunity for you to offer a wider range of solutions relevant to their needs.

9. Learning

Every experience, either bad or good, has something to teach you. Don't be afraid to ask customers "why"? when you have lost the sales opportunity.

10. Persistence

It's all very well achieving points 1 to 9, but you will get knockbacks. You have to take the knocks. I learn from them and move on. Don't take rejections personally: they are saying no to the product, not saying no to you as a person. Today's "no, thanks" can become tomorrow's "yes, please". Persistence definitely pays.

webTitle: Help: Why won't he leave me alone?

fields.headline: Help: Why won't he leave me alone?
fields.trailText: Advice on dealing with an internal promotion
fields.body:
I've been promoted but am frustrated by a boss who rarely backs me up and often takes over from me.
Joe N, account manager, Plymouth

Internal promotions are tricky. There's a new job to do but you're often burdened with old expectations and relationships. Even if you have no problem adjusting your perceptions, getting others to do the same can be a challenge.

It's essential those above you in the hierarchy react to your new role appropriately. Their attitude sends out signals that others follow.

Your boss is undermining your position and you need to find out why. If you've taken over some of his tasks he may resent intrusion into his territory, or perhaps he feels he's giving you the benefit of his experience. Assume the latter and try to sort things out amicably.

Let him know you've appreciated his input, but make it clear that your settling in period is now completed, and you're ready to assume full responsibility. Ask for feedback on how you're doing, particularly when you feel he's interfered - perhaps there are sound reasons for his intervention.

Discuss any new project or issue you feel confident about, agree on demarcation of tasks and lines of authority. Ask to be judged by results rather than the processes used to achieve them. Point out you need to make your own mistakes to learn the job, and are prepared to be accountable for them.

Be aware that some of the problem could be staff playing you off against each other. Confusion and conflict have entertainment value and provide an excellent excuse for not getting work done.

webTitle: Put some punch behind your hunch

fields.headline: Put some punch behind your hunch
fields.standfirst:
Training
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Managing a successful organisation often takes more than a determination to succeed. Being able to identify opportunities and knowing when to act on them based on nothing more than a gut feeling can be the secret which gives upcoming executives and their businesses that winning edge.
fields.body:
Managing a successful organisation often takes more than a determination to succeed. Being able to identify opportunities and knowing when to act on them based on nothing more than a gut feeling can be the secret which gives upcoming executives and their businesses that winning edge.

Firms are waking up to the commercial value of gut feelings with major banking insurance and recruitment institutions sending key personnel for courses in developing their intuition.

Many industry sectors, which rely on reading people and situations and making high level decisions based on a hunch, are following the lead of transatlantic corporate cousins who working on turning the power of the unconscious mind into a potential business tool.

Now the new management training concept has been brought to Scotland delivered by Joan Charles who has more than 17 years' experience of counselling executives worldwide.

All of us use intuition to a greater or lesser degree, but it is not generally recognised as an ability which can be taught. However, Ms Charles's short course aims to add punch to your hunch to give you the edge in business situations.

Managers will learn how to combine intuitive and creative thought processes with more conventional techniques.

Ms Charles says that intuition can bring amazing results and can be easily learnt by all age groups and levels of management.

Students on her course will learn to benefit from the flow of creative ideas and sense what their best choices are. By fine tuning their intuition they will be able to take a different approach to problem solving while discovering their own strengths and weaknesses.

They also learn how to resolve workplace conflicts without too much blood being spilled on the carpet.

Despite its mystical connotations of telepathy and clairvoyance, several insurance and recruitment firms, banks, sales and marketing consultants are taking intuition seriously.

For details of courses in your area telephone: 01475-723-563
