Being able to identify opportunities and knowing when to act on them based on nothing more than a gut feeling can be the secret which gives upcoming executives and their businesses that winning edge. Firms are waking up to the commercial value of gut feelings with major banking insurance and recruitment institutions sending key personnel for courses in developing their intuition. Many industry sectors, which rely on reading people and situations and making high level decisions based on a hunch, are following the lead of transatlantic corporate cousins who working on turning the power of the unconscious mind into a potential business tool. Now the new management training concept has been brought to Scotland delivered by Joan Charles who has more than 17 years' experience of counselling executives worldwide. All of us use intuition to a greater or lesser degree, but it is not generally recognised as an ability which can be taught. However, Ms Charles's short course aims to add punch to your hunch to give you the edge in business situations. Managers will learn how to combine intuitive and creative thought processes with more conventional techniques. Ms Charles says that intuition can bring amazing results and can be easily learnt by all age groups and levels of management. Students on her course will learn to benefit from the flow of creative ideas and sense what their best choices are. By fine tuning their intuition they will be able to take a different approach to problem solving while discovering their own strengths and weaknesses. They also learn how to resolve workplace conflicts without too much blood being spilled on the carpet. Despite its mystical connotations of telepathy and clairvoyance, several insurance and recruitment firms, banks, sales and marketing consultants are taking intuition seriously. webTitle: Helping the disabled to join ranks of winners

fields.headline: Helping the disabled to join ranks of winners
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: A government-backed scheme to help people with learning disabilities take on a job is being field-tested in Leeds, Gateshead and Scotland. The Workplace Initiative in Natural Supports (WINS) project, funded by the government's New Deal for Disabled People Innovative Grants scheme, is a partnership between Charities Mencap in England and Enable in Scotland.
fields.body:
A government-backed scheme to help people with learning disabilities take on a job is being field-tested in Leeds, Gateshead and Scotland. The Workplace Initiative in Natural Supports (WINS) project, funded by the government's New Deal for Disabled People Innovative Grants scheme, is a partnership between Charities Mencap in England and Enable in Scotland.

The Wins project will link people with learning difficulties to employers and provide in-house training for existing staff who then act as workplace guides and supporters. The aim is to increase the opportunities for people with a learning disability to secure and sustain a paid job.

The pilot schemes will initially train 70 workplace guides before the scheme goes nationwide. Mencap and Enable, the charities involved, are not mental health charities. Learning disabilities, which afflict 1.2m people in the UK, are conditions which result from damage to the brain.

Hampshire-based Southern Tourist Board has launched a novel scheme to boost employment in the region through a "job rotation" initiative. The idea is to put unemployed people into tourism-based industries such as hotel and catering. The scheme works through a system of rotating training for those in and out of work.

Staff already employed in hotels and attractions are sent on specially designed courses, while their jobs are filled by local jobseekers with a Tourist Board's Diploma in Tourism and Hospitality. The project has enabled current employees to attend a training course without creating a staff shortage in their organisation.

Job-hunting nurses can now do so without traipsing around hospitals or recruitment agencies. A new website www.nurserve.co.uk flags hundreds of nursing jobs at home and abroad, complete with on-line application forms. The website also has useful information about training courses and other career development issues.

While average earnings are pegged at 5.5% across the whole economy, IT staff average salaries rose by 9.4%. The figure emerged from the findings of the Factual Salary Survey (FSS) produced by the largest group of independent IT recruitment outfit S Three.

Not surprisingly, pay for IT professionals with web-related skills is rising fastest at 6.07% over the last quarter, compared with average graduate salaries which are going up at 2.8%.

webTitle: Web flotation leaves investors high and dry

fields.headline: Web flotation leaves investors high and dry
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report

The anger of punters who had hoped to make a fortune when finance website iii went public
fields.trailText: Interactive Investor International, floated on the stockmarket this week for an astonishing £550m, was both the most successful public offering of an internet company so far - and an object lesson in how to upset small investors.
fields.body:
Interactive Investor International, floated on the stockmarket this week for an astonishing £550m, was both the most successful public offering of an internet company so far - and an object lesson in how to upset small investors.

While founder Sherry Coutu basked in a paper fortune of £80m, the 80,000-plus small investors who applied for shares in the personal finance website reacted furiously to what they saw as paltry share allocations. Because the issue was massively over-subscribed, applicants were allocated just 145 shares each, disappointing investors who had hoped to "stag" the issue with gains of £1,000-£2,000 on its first day of trading.

Instead, the early gains will add up to little more than £250-£300, based on a purchase price of 150p compared with the trading price at the end of the first day of 335p. Applicants who wanted £50,000 worth or more of iii shares were the most disappointed. They will have no shares issued to them at all, and will shortly receive their cheques back in the post.

Within minutes of the share allocation announcement, iii's website was bombarded with messages from irate applicants, who focused their anger on the decision to allocate 80% of the shares to big City institutional investors.

"iii have made a serious mistake... they have alienated the vast majority of their account holders," said e-mailer Peter Goddard.

"This sort of allocation makes no sense. I'm frankly disgusted," said David Hirst.

Many threatened to quit iii for rival personal finance sites run by hemscott and motley fool. "I for one will be using motley fool in future," added Robert Miles.

However, iii managing director Tom Carruthers (above) said that the 20% allocation was higher than in other recent net flotations.

Some users also backed iii: "You are all a bunch of money grabbers. You haven't won as much as you all thought you would... so what?? You got £280 for nothing. Wake up to the world of investments," said James Purnell.

Most of the 82,000 who have been allocated shares will not be able to trade until February 24. Initial trading is on a "conditional" basis: you promise to deliver the stock based on your promised allocation. In effect, this makes the first few days of trading the province of the institutional investors. Most brokers will not accept a dealing request from a small investor unless the share certificate has been issued.

fields.headline: Getting caught in the web
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The risk taker
fields.body:
The risk taker

It is hard to find a retailer with a more established reputation than John Lewis. Its public image seems light years away from the new crop of e-tailers, but Julia Cocking (33) has made the leap from one to the other in a single bound.

Until the end of August 1999 she was assistant lingerie buyer for the John Lewis group. Now she is in charge of selecting the lingerie that is sold on Easyshop

Ms Cocking is in no doubt as to the financial advantages of her move and says the package she was offered by Easyshop compared very favourably with those offered by more conventional firms such as Sainsbury's when she was looking for new employment opportunities. "The benefits package and the money were the same but they didn't have the share options and I really wanted to work for a small company," she says.

By the same token she knew she was being rewarded for taking a risk. "Being offered shares in the company there is a risk that the company might succeed or might not, and shares can go up and down, but if it goes well it could be a good sum of money," she says.

Aside from the shares, her financial situation did not improve, any more than it might have done by changing to any other job - her pay increased by about 20%. Her work is also much the same as it was at John Lewis, but without the net, Easyshop.com would not be able to offer its services on a national basis and that is where the real advantage lies, she says.

The evangelist

Matthew Hutchinson is 35 and an internet evangelist. That is not to say he preaches the word of the Lord over the web but that when he describes his job at musicunsigned a web service for record companies to pick up unsigned talent, he cannot resist using words like "absolutely awesome" and "fantastic".

Since leaving school he has had two jobs. His first was as a trader on the floor of the London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange (Liffe).

Life as a futures trader is highly paid, highly stressful and highly enjoyable - for those who can cope with it. He fell into it by accident after a friend invited him to watch the action on the trading floor. He was so taken with it that he put his plans to join the music industry on hold for 14 years. It was only when the introduction of screen-based trading threatened to put an end to the traditional open outcry trading style, where traders compete vocally for trades, that he decided to revive his old dream.

A conversation in a pub led him to the back garden of Aroon Maharajh, the brains behind musicunsigned, and the shed where it was born. "It was a normal shed but inside they'd wired it up to loads of computers. I loved it," he says. In a good year at Liffe, Mr Hutchinson could earn over £60,000; now he earns about a third of that and has no stake in the business. But he is still swept along by the excitement: "I haven't regretted a single day since I met these guys, it's changed everything: it's fantastic," he says.

The team player

Gillian Miller is 48 and has worked for Tesco for 12 years. She started out as a part-time supervisor on checkouts. Over the years she has moved up though the ranks as a training manager and then as a section manager.

Last August she joined the e-generation when she took on a job as home shopping manager for Tesco Online with responsibility for a 10-mile radius in Kent. Unlike other new participants in the wired economy, though, Ms Miller has not been plied with offers of share options or huge wages. In fact her employment terms are unchanged since her last job. She is a member of the employee share scheme, but so is every other staff member of Tesco who has been at the firm for two years or more. Aware of the internet revolution Ms Miller says "They offered me the chance to do Home Shopping and I said 'yes' because to me the way forward is on the internet."

But she does not see it as a risk or a reason to fatten her pay packet: "The financial thing didn't enter into my head," she says. On the contrary, the reason Ms Miller took the Home Shopping job was because she looked forward to the management challenge of looking after a new department which would stand or fall by her efforts.

So far she has not been disappointed: "I've got an excellent team; I mean they're really good. To me they're the best team we've got."

webTitle: How to... tell someone off without losing your cool

fields.headline: How to... tell someone off without losing your cool
fields.standfirst: There's no need for a public slanging match - keep it private
fields.trailText: There are only two ways to make telling someone off an easy experience. Either pick someone who is at least 20 years younger and a foot shorter than yourself, or delegate the responsibility for the telling off to someone else.
fields.body:
There are only two ways to make telling someone off an easy experience. Either pick someone who is at least 20 years younger and a foot shorter than yourself, or delegate the responsibility for the telling off to someone else.

Having to tick off a team member is one of the most difficult aspects of being a young manager Yet it is a situation that crops up all too often. "I've been putting off tackling one of my team, Patrick, for about a month," admits Martin Adams, associate director of a website design company.

"I've noticed two or three times that he's been playing a networked game when he should be working. Trouble is, some of the other people playing are doing it for research - but it's nothing to do with Patrick's job. I have to tell him to stop doing it, but I just don't know how to go about it."

According to Ros Taylor of Plus Consulting, it's important to have the right state of mind when you take someone to task. "First off, don't think of it as a 'telling off'," she says. "It's far more about moving a situation forward, overcoming a problem - and there are particular tactics that you can use.

"The best is what we call the DESC approach. Describe the situation, in detail, explaining what the problem is, and why. Make sure you have evidence to back this up. Then offer a solution - what you want them to do, and then the consequences: what will happen if they do - and don't do - as you ask."

All of which means tackling the situation in a calm, controlled way - which can be difficult if someone has been annoying. "Part of the reason I'm putting off talking to Patrick is because he makes me so cross," says Adams. "I know he'll tell me that he's done all his work, so why shouldn't he play a game. I'll just get angry and bluster and the situation will go from bad to worse."

In this sort of situation, it's very important to differentiate between being assertive and being aggressive. "Being aggressive inevitably has a negative effect," says Brian Clegg, author of Instant Motivation . "Being assertive is more about being calm and in control of the situation.

"One of the best techniques is the 'broken record'; you simply repeat your request whatever someone says. For example if you keep saying 'you must understand that being consistently late is not acceptable,' eventually the other person will simply run out of excuses and justifications. You can change your words slightly but you will still whittle away their resistance, and they will be left with no choice but to agree with you."

It's also important to realise that if someone is behaving in an unacceptable manner, it may be a manifestation of a problem or dissatisfaction they have with their job or role within the team.

"A member of my team, Vikki, started to take overly-long lunch hours and disappear off home early," says Sadie Williams, head of the marketing team of a large tour operator. "It was nothing outrageous, but definitely noticeable. At first I intended to tick her off for bad timekeeping, but I started to wonder why she was doing it - she'd always been a model employee before."

Rather than giving her a dressing down, Sadie explained her unhappiness with Vikki's performance and asked her to explain what was behind it. "To my amazement she said she was simply bored - I wasn't giving her enough responsibility and she didn't have enough work to do. Obviously she should have come and talked to me about it, but the fact was her slacking off was simply due to being under-motivated - which was quite easily resolved."

No one likes being called to account, but if you approach it in the right way it is possible to ask someone to change their behaviour without them seeing it as a humiliation.

"Begin with a compliment," says Ros Taylor, "and end with some reward. Don't just tear into their self-esteem - approach it from the 'you've always been a valued member of the team but...' kind of angle. And most importantly never, ever, haul someone over the coals in public. Do it in private."

If you don't remember anything else, remember this:

Employees aren't kids and they don't cause problems just to be naughty or to rebel. Generally there's a reason, a motivation for poor performance - as a manager, it is your responsibility to find out what that is and how to overcome it.

webTitle: Strategy for coming in from the cold

fields.headline: Strategy for coming in from the cold
fields.standfirst: Ian Wylie on how best to present your case for the job you're after
fields.trailText: You don't have to be in sales to use the technique of cold-calling. Next to face-to-face meetings, the telephone is the most effective method available to find a job. Every call you make is an opportunity to sell yourself to a prospective employer, to pursue a new job opening, or to obtain a referral.
fields.body:
Finding a suitable job has never been easier, whether your search takes you to the classified advertisement pages of the Guardian or to the bewildering new world of internet job listings and career web sites.

But landing your ideal job has never been harder. Competition for the plum posts increases all the time. Job-hunters therefore have a simple choice to make.

Do they play by the rules of sending in letters of applications and CVs or do they jump the queue by contacting the employer through more direct channels?

You don't have to be in sales to use the technique of cold-calling. Next to face-to-face meetings, the telephone is the most effective method available to find a job. Every call you make is an opportunity to sell yourself to a prospective employer, to pursue a new job opening, or to obtain a referral.

Your technique in the initial telephone call can have a huge impact on your chances to obtain what you want from the call.

Although cold-calling is an acceptable and occasionally effective way to land a new job, it can be one of the most daunting tasks in a job search. Cold-calling, or contacting people you've never met, puts the pressure on you to make a good - and quick - first impression.

The key to cold-calling is being prepared - for any thing. Because you're making an unannounced inquiry, you should expect almost anything in response from the target of your call, from flat rejection to open arms, as well as everything in between.

Remember, you may or may not have the opportunity to speak with someone in charge of recruitment, so you'll need to be ready to sell yourself, perhaps to several different people. You may be asked to call back, or you may find yourself in the middle of a full interview. In short, be ready to roll with the punches if you want to reap any rewards from the call.

To ensure you're not left speechless on the phone, take time to prepare a checklist of steps to go through when calling a potential employer. The checklist should include a verbal introduction and a brief summary of your skills and abilities.

Begin the phone call by introducing yourself, then explain why you are contacting them. Tell them three skills you possess that are pertinent to the type of job you are asking about, and remember that your aim is to distinguish yourself from

other applicants. Ask if you can, send or drop off a copy of your CV.

Finally, arrange a follow- up contact or phone call. Try to make at least half a dozen calls per day. Always be agreeable, gentle, and positive.

Smile when you speak - the listener will hear it. And always ask for suggestions, other contacts or openings which might be relevant.

Keep in mind that you will get better at cold-calling with practice. You may want to start by calling the bottom of your list and save your top choices for the end.

The most promising target for cold calls is your established personal network. Your own contacts are the best way to find out about a job opening before it's widely advertised. Your contacts can also clue you in to consulting opportunities or the most opportune time to approach a potential employer.

Cold-calling is not for the meek. Contacting a potential employer direct is a tedious and often unsatisfying process. It can take a toll on your self-confidence when the rejection is blatant or harsh. But don't let that discourage you. Cold-calling is an effective method if you are not under time pressure - you should plan to allow yourself at least six months to soften up your cold-calling contacts - and you feel you can sell yourself well over the phone.

If you don't deal well when put on the spot, cold-calling probably isn't the job searching technique for you.

Your technique in the initial telephone call can have a huge impact on your chances to obtain what you want from the call. Although cold-calling is an acceptable and occasionally effective way to land a new job, it can be one of the most daunting tasks in a job search. Cold-calling, or contacting people you've never met, puts the pressure on you to make a good - and quick - first impression. The key to cold-calling is being prepared - for any thing. Because you're making an unannounced inquiry, you should expect almost anything in response from the target of your call, from flat rejection to open arms, as well as everything in between. Remember, you may or may not have the opportunity to speak with someone in charge of recruitment, so you'll need to be ready to sell yourself, perhaps to several different people. You may be asked to call back, or you may find yourself in the middle of a full interview. In short, be ready to roll with the punches if you want to reap any rewards from the call. To ensure you're not left speechless on the phone, take time to prepare a checklist of steps to go through when calling a potential employer. The checklist should include a verbal introduction and a brief summary of your skills and abilities. Begin the phone call by introducing yourself, then explain why you are contacting them. Tell them three skills you possess that are pertinent to the type of job you are asking about, and remember that your aim is to distinguish yourself from other applicants. Ask if you can, send or drop off a copy of your CV. Finally, arrange a follow- up contact or phone call. Try to make at least half a dozen calls per day. Always be agreeable, gentle, and positive. Smile when you speak - the listener will hear it. And always ask for suggestions, other contacts or openings which might be relevant. Keep in mind that you will get better at cold-calling with practice. You may want to start by calling the bottom of your list and save your top choices for the end. The most promising target for cold calls is your established personal network. Your own contacts are the best way to find out about a job opening before it's widely advertised. Your contacts can also clue you in to consulting opportunities or the most opportune time to approach a potential employer. Cold-calling is not for the meek. Contacting a potential employer direct is a tedious and often unsatisfying process. It can take a toll on your self-confidence when the rejection is blatant or harsh. But don't let that discourage you. Cold-calling is an effective method if you are not under time pressure - you should plan to allow yourself at least six months to soften up your cold-calling contacts - and you feel you can sell yourself well over the phone. If you don't deal well when put on the spot, cold-calling probably isn't the job searching technique for you.
